description:
Pier 39! Just another one of those must see touristy locations of SF. So many touristy stores and quick service food locations. So there's plenty to choose from if you wanna grab a bite. Also, there's the Aquarium by the Bay up at the front of the pier.

It's really fun to people watch here. There's a wide variety of people that come here because of it's must see status. I didn't walk out with any shopping bags, but I sure did enjoy bite at the Boudin's on the pier because I picked up a coupon book with a coupon for a free soda pop with a purchase of clam chowder in a bread bowl. I was sold on that!

Anywho, there's a lot to see here. Even a store dedicated to left handed people. And there's the Smartwater stage at the far end with a carousel close by. The act I saw at the stage was Merry Mary. She was quite a hoot. She's an older lady with some classic circus type acts. When she pulled at the flames, I was terrified for her and us as guests. lol! It was a good show, but not good enough to keep me there for the entirety of the show. You even have the option to tip Merry Mary I think through Venmo or PayPal.

All the way at the end of the pier is a great photo location of the bay.
author: Antonio L.

description:
This area is a huge tourist trap with the cute sea lions first off roping you in. Then walking towards the actual area with more hidden shops and restaurants inside. Get ready for the instagram worthy pics because this little area will definitely give you just that! Full of different shops from souvenir trinkets to doggy shops. Just like other tourist areas, it's costly. The only thing free was the amazing ocean view from this area, which one can never really get sick of! 

*if you check in, you may receive a coupon book for free with cool deals and discounted prices. We ended up doing a mirror maze for $4 with our discount (took some pretty cool insta pics)
author: Amelia L.

description:
Always a good time when at Pier 39.

Whether you are a local or a tourist you are sure to find something new to see and do as well as eat.

It reminds me of the Las Vegas Strip, minus the casinos plus the water.  

It is inique and well worth the hassle of finding parking.

Expect to spend some extra time when in the area to enjoy all that this area has to offer.

You'll find yourself in the middle of all the action.

Similar to Union Square but a bit more relaxing.

Less skyrise buildings and more views and less business dressed people.

Make sure to wear comfortable clothes as well as shoes  as you will be walking quite a bit.

Lots to see and do here the chioce is yours.

Make sure to bring extra money as well as prices on everything around here is a bit high conpared to outside of the area.  Not many ATMs around either and most stores charge a credit or debit fee! Yikes... 

I always make it a point to drop by when in town to enjoy the picturesque views and get more of a vacation vibe even if its only for a day or two.
author: Arnel D.

description:
I was born in San Francisco (The Mission) but grew up in Los Angeles.  Our family used to come to Pier39 to play arcades and just have fun.  My
Auntie recorded herself singing as they had a sound booth before.  I love that they kept the  carousel!  The new Pier39 is still pretty cool.  To me S.F. is all about weather, if it's sunny the city is gorgeous which makes your visit amazing .  Although a lot of tourist come here and parking is $20+ a day it's still fun to visit. + the exploratorium moved next door to Pier39!  For tourist they now have currency  exchange booths.
author: Tala P.

description:
Seriously where do we find a pier in LA that's as much fun as Pier 39? No way not even Santa Monica pier! Since we stayed at a hotel so close to here so we walked here everyday to hang out and chill. 

There are so many restaurants and bars, we ate at the very popular Bubba Gump with amazing ocean and Alcatraz views. Most of the restaurants are great for seafood lovers, also food and drink stands, you can just find pretty much everything here. Even a cute little wine bar on the water, how romantic is that! Other than eat and drink, there are so many things to see like sea lion colony and its little museum, a little farmers market, mirror maze, aquarium, piano stairs, carousel, small performances on the center stage and tons of gift shops. There are just too many things to do around here and you will never get bored! 

I never really had enough time to hang around here the many times we were in town cause we had always stayed at the hotels in Union Square. So glad I took advantage of staying near Pier 39, and had loads of fun here with my family! Also the weather was so nice too, exactly like LA South Bay weather! A MUST stop when in San Francisco Bay Area!

Keep in mind that if you walk along the piers and get too tired, there are tricycle rides around, we took one from pier 33 to fisherman's wharf for $15, and we tipped him $5 cause he was from LA too!
author: Mimi L.

description:
This place is magic. One of my favorite stops on my San Francisco trip. It was literally a fairytale of by the ocean goodness. We walked the entire pier up and down and everything was bustling and beautiful. 

Seeing the Ocean changes me every time - it is an unknown feeling of literal peace whenever I am around it and I truly appreciate being able to walk through a festival type atmosphere on a random Wednesday! 

We ended up hanging out by the seals for over an hour. They are the most amazing and hilarious creatures I couldn't help myself. Reference the videos I have posted to Yelp and how happy I was the entire time. 

There was a magic show, jewlery shops, $4 jameson shots, sushi, and photobooths to take millions of pictures. I stayed as long as I possibly could and almost missed my flight because I just did not want to leave.
author: Josi H.

description:
Pier 39 It's a great place to visit if you are ever in the bay area. In fact I don't really know how you can visit the bay area and not go to Pier 39. It had been a very long day for my family and I but we were determined to go into the city and walk around and have dinner. 

It was late so unfortunately a lot of the shops were closed but I could still see the beautiful bay bridge and all of the surrounding area. I recommend going here in the early morning especially when the days are pretty. 

I had not been home In over 18 years and was extremely excited that my cousin went out of her way to ensure that I got to go to San Francisco. Since this visit is going to be one of many in the future I will just be sure that we visit during regular business hours. This is still a great place to see and lots of cool things to buy. I recommend that you bring your walking shoes as this is what you will be doing a lot of.
author: Lurine F.

description: Very touristy, but lots to do! There are so many restaurants to pick from, both chain and local. Stop by to get something to eat, have a dessert or just do some people watching and souvenir shopping! During the day there are plenty of street performers out and about...hear some music, watch people make art, etc. If you're looking to kill an hour or more, Pier 39 is worth a stop!!
author: Shelby H.

description:
If you're looking for a tourist destination this is it!! They have so many different food options, attractions, and gift shops! Bring comfortable shoes because the place is HUGE!!

We were also able to see a crap ton of sea lions!!
author: Princess Brittany N.

description:
I'm sure residents of San Francisco and the bay area loathe places like Pier 39.  As much as it's an overpriced tourist trap, it really is quite a beautiful location; right on the water, overlooking the water, with clear views of Alcatraz, and the Golden Gate Bridge. 

With plenty of outdoor seating options, both right on the street as well as inside the shopping/dining area, it's an easy way to spend a sunny afternoon in the city.  The stores offer expensive souvenirs of all kinds, there are a handful of restaurants, plenty of people watching and of course my most favorite part of Pier 39 which are stopping by to visit the seals!
author: Danielle W.

description:
If you had 1 hour to spend in San Francisco, I'd say spend 45 minutes at Pier 39, and the other 15 minutes going across the Golden Gate Bridge and returning on the other side. 

This place is probably the number 1 tourist spot for first time visitors and for a good reason; it embodies what San Francisco is all about, from the beautiful picturesque views to Alcatraz, to the different foods they offer that bring out the San Francisco culture, to so many shops that sell a great collection of shirts, key chains, posters etc, etc...

There are numerous bus stations that can take you around the city, or there are tons of chartered boat rides that will take you around the bay, and give you a history about Alcatraz. Sure there are tours to Alcatraz that leave from this pier, but if you're looking to buy tickets the day or, chances are slim to none that you're going to get lucky. 

The restaurants here are ok...I tried one a few years back when I was here at the pier but it wasn't good and they've closed since then; instead I'd venture off a bit to Fisherman's Wharf which is a 5 minute walk where there are better choices for fresh seafood. 

Whatever you do...don't park in the open lot that's next to the water that's in front of Fisherman's Wharf; none of their machines worked to prepay your ticket with a debit card, so you'll need to get over to CVS to use their ATM, then head back where it's another $5.00 cause it took you 10 minutes to do all of this. This lot is a scam at $15.00 an hour. Best place to park is across Pier 39 in the 5 floor garage.
author: Ivan H.

description: Beautiful harbor views surround you, but with parking at $12.00 per hour, we didn't have much time to look around. The women's restroom line had my wife backed up behind dozens, and we would be dining at Fog Harbor Fish House, which fortunately validated our first hour. We never even made it over to see the famous sea lion colony. We'll be back!
author: Ronald M.

description:
What a fun quick stop! We walked around the pier and eventually heard the sea lions from afar and decided to go check them out. They were all sun bathing and it was actually really entertaining to see them fighting for a spot and some of them chilling with no drama. It also smells pretty fishy in this area which you will get a huge whiff of because of the wind blowing in your face. 

Definitely check out this area when you get a chance!
author: Sarah A.

description:
**** Review 109 ****
This place was great! Lots to do, lots to see, and a whole lot to experience. Don't miss the sea lions, great for a few  laughs as they play fight. Plenty of stores to shop at, specially specialty stores. This place even has a few doggie stores, and a few restaurants. If your looking for a fun time, either with your family or on a date this place has it all. Don't miss out and definitely stop here!
author: Luis S.

description: Absolutely loved Pier 39. I made it a point to try as many food spots and see as many attractions as I could while there. The sea lions are a must, the aquarium was small but still pretty fun. Plenty to see and do at the pier, it's perfect for tourists and Fisherman's wharf is just a short walk away.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
Pier 39 is a San Francisco tourist location you feel obligated to visit during your stay. With over 100 restaurants, shops,and attractions, Pier 39 is a great place to spend the afternoon! The Pier also hosts special events and live entertainment. Additionally, the pier offers breathtaking views of the San Francisco Bay, Golden Gate Bridge, Bay Bridge, Alcatraz Island, and sun basking sea lions.

I was able to check out Pier 39 on my way to Pier 33 for Alcatraz Cruises. The shops had so many good deals, my favorite being $2.99 San Fransisco  baseball caps! With so much to do and experience, I wish I could have stayed longer. However, I was disappointed that there were limited vegan option. The only places that offered vegan fare were Dreyer's Ice-cream, which features two flavors of sorbet, and DoughHP, with one flavor of vegan chocolate cookie dough.
author: Stephanie L.

description: I love the pier even though it's always crazy busy. But I always try my best to enjoy my time. Mainly because I always make sure to get my crepes before I leave. If you haven't had the crepes here at Pier 39 then you must try it the next time you're in San Francisco.
author: Sammie L.

description:
What a lovely little spot that is tourist central in San Fran, CA. They have dozens of restaurants, shops, dessert stores, SF memorabilia stores bars, etc. 

Everywhere you walk there are beautiful views of the pier from all different spots, and there are endless photo opportunities. You can stop and see the seals and take tons of fun photos and movies. Due to the massive crowds, I suggest always making reservations at any of the restaurants in Pier 39 here since I saw tons of long wait lines on a busy Saturday night.
author: Emily D.

description:
Another must visit location in the Fisherman's Wharf area. Sea lions are the big draw here but there's also a bunch of restaurants available. Don't mess with the restaurants they're overpriced but the sea lions are a definite must see.

I've been here multiple times and the sea lions have always been there putting on their little show. Wheather its swimming, barking, wrestling, or just laying around sunbathing you could sit for an hour and not get tired of watching. Pretty cool how they sit on the docks based on age group. Senior citizens in the front then the adults and then the teenagers.

Doesn't cost anything to watch the sea lions play so make sure you roll through and check them out. There is a Bubba Gump Shrimp also right here which if you're going to eat somewhere you might as well go there.
author: James F.

description: The pier was great but there's just so many people. A lot of friendly staff! Very sweet and have a willingness so lend a helping hand  I would go back
author: Anisa S.

description:
The pier is like Santa Monica's pier but I'm extreme: such a tourist spot! Soooo many stores and restaurants and attractions and street entertainment.
Make sure you walk to the end where there's a beautiful view and one of the heart statues like you find them all over the city.
To sea the seals, go to the left and they are right there on the side, it's a must see! They are very entertaining. Someone warned me for the smell but I didn't notice it. It was also very windy, maybe that's why.
The other side of the pier there is the seaquarium. I avoid places like that as I'm supporting captures animals.
Issue is lack of bathrooms. I couldn't find one and restaurants only allow customers.
author: Apple S.

description:
This is hands-down the #1 touristy spot in the area. I visited SF with some friends and walked to Pier 39 from Embarcadero. Right off of the pier, you can spot a TON of seals camped out nearby which is pretty fun. We managed to witness a few seals arguing across the way. There's plenty of food and little unique shops. They had a saltwater taffy shop with a bunch of different kinds of taffy and candy. 

Considering we were on the pier, we decided to order some fish and chips as they were known for fish and chips which was DELICIOUS and filling. There was also a little circus stage with performing actors and entertainment which was fun and there was a mirror maze room ($5) that we decided to try out. It was my first time partaking in an activity of the sort so that was fun for the five of us who went inside.

They also have an aquarium on site as well that we did not have the time to visit.
author: Brittany E.

description:
Pier 39 is a wonderful tourist location that is crowded with people. We had trouble finding the entrance to the parking. One entrance said it was temporarily full and blocked but when we paid $20 to a private parking and walked over, there was another entrance! I was disappointed because we eventually dined at the dinner there and could have gotten a validation but why blocked one entrance?

When arriving to the entrance of Pier 39, in front of it was a little band, the music was pleasant. I love these kinds of music rather than modern rap, etc. 

There are many shops! You may just be broke after spending all those money buying merchandise and eating there.

Although this is tourist site, I don't see any usefulness of going here often after getting all those photos to post on social network. The restaurants are pricey and I don't spend my time going to the boat or something. If you haven't gone, then yes, please go. But I wouldn't come back for like the 4th or 5th time after walking all over the Pier.
author: Trinny T.

description:
This place was REALLLLLY touristy. Which is the exact opposite of the places I like to visit when out of town. But I must say it was surprisingly fun. We saw Alcatraz island from the pier, the seals, which was kinda cool and ate at a restaurant there. 

The seals come every year and sun bathe on the floating docks they have out, which is cool for the younger kids to see. There is an astonishing view of Alcatraz island from the other end of the pier which is cool for adults and older kids. Your typical shopping, boardwalk, restaurants, ice cream etc. very crowded. If you're not bothered by crowds, I'd say visit just to see the seals, if crowds aren't your thing, skip this and see seals at your local aquarium. 

Parking here was a good walking distance from the pier and also, very expensive. Had good souvenir shops though.
author: Krystine S.

description:
Pier 39 is very touristy. It's very, very touristy. But it is one of the most visited destinations in San Francisco. It has two levels of dining, shops, and attractions. It also offers an incredible view of the bay - if it isn't foggy, you can see the Golden Gate and Bay Bridges as well as Alcatraz Island! I managed to snap a couple of really good pictures of Alcatraz - but it was too foggy for the bridges while I was there. The walk along the pier is really nice and I highly recommend it if the day is nice.

Of course, the highlight, are the sea lions that sunbathe there every day. If you're not sure where it is, just follow the huge crowd that's perched on a corner of the pier. Plus the sounds will help guide you. They're super cute and don't really mind that their picture is being taken.

I found the souvenir selection to be pretty repetitive - and all the places mark their prices the same. There really isn't too much of a point in shopping around. I did, however, find the selection at Fisherman's Wharf to be nicer, with higher quality items.
author: Michelle T.

description:
This place is fun if you take it for what it is... a super touristy spot. Lot's of your typical corporations have taken over so there's nothing really all that unique about it. But like I said if you keep that in mind you could have fun. Typical surf shops, chain candy shops, ice cream brands, & restaurants like Bubba Gumps. 

The one thing I loved seeing was all of the sea lions out on the pier. They were so cute swimming around & chillin' out for everyone's viewing pleasure. If you're an animal lover like me you'll love that! & the pier is very beautiful in the evening with the bridges lit up in the distance. 

You can get some of the San Francisco yummies nearby on the Fisherman's Wharf at some of the side vendors but the actual Pier itself is full of corporate stuff. Actually most of the shops lined up on the Wharf are probably nothing you haven't seen before. 

Very instagram-y & a fun place to visit if you're not trying to be too adventurous but still want to have a good time.
author: Chelsea B.

description: We have visited this place n number of times. Very crowded. I love SFO golden gate view point. In general I love California a lot . I love nature fresh air , pure oxygen  . It's what some what very different.  For the past several years visited many places nearly half of world tour is covered .
author: Sri K.

description:
Although Pier 39 is a huge tourist destination it is my all time favorite place to visit. I love stopping by and watching the sea lions. No matter what my mood is at the time of visiting it always elevates after spending time watching all the loud shenanigans on the pier. 

Afterwards I poke around and purchase almost the same items every time that I visit. T-shirts, purses, magnets and more. This is the one and only place that brings the tourist out of me. It's all junk but it makes me happy so I recreate the same experience with each visit. 

My husband and I also spend time snacking on crepes, candies, breads and other food items. It's also a great place to get a cool drink and people watch. It's a happy place where you can slow down a lot and relax while enjoying the view of the Golden Gate Bridge or Alcatraz.
author: Laura G.

description:
Pier 39 is a recreation of the popular recreations of ocean boardwalks found on the East Coast of the United States. This is one of the most popular tourist attractions in San Francisco. It is located at the far northeastern part of the city overlooking all three bridges, Alcatraz, and many ships and boats. Paid garages are in the area, but the pier is well served by transit.

I have fond memories of visiting Pier 39 as a child. It appeals to the kid in all of us with bright colors and lots of fried and sweet foods. The overall concept is an east coast boardwalk over the Bay with many shops and snack food stalls.

This is a great place for souvenir shopping. They sell lots of San Francisco themed merchandise along with jewelry and some art mainly geared for the international tourist. The food ranges from bad to very good with several gems buried amongst the mainly average fare.

The real stars are the sea lions and the view. At some point, dozens of sea lions decided to make the pier home. Rather than fight it, the owners made it a prime attraction luring many people to view the lions. They can smell bad and are often just lying around, but the occasional fights and overall atmosphere is great. Plus you get a great view of the Golden Gate and Alcatraz.

If it's your first visit to San Francisco, I do recommend stopping by for a visit. There are FAR better places for shopping, eating, and sightseeing in the City, but a visit to Pier 39 seems like a good fit for most.
author: Kristian D.

description:
This is a great place to visit if you want a "touristy day". I recently came here with a friend who has lived in the Bay Area a few years. She had never been here and we decided to eat lunch on pier 39 after our half marathon. 

She kept saying she felt like she was in Disneyland. It has a touristy charm. There are a variety of cute shops from art stores, clothing stores, souvenir shops, arcade and bungee jumping, carousel for kids, and lots of good restaurants. 

At the very end of the pier is a lookout with binoculars where you can look at the Golden Gate or Alcatraz. 

On the left side of the pier are the famous sea lions. They're stinky but entertaining to see. 

They also have public restrooms available on the pier. 

There is almost always some type of entertainment at the entrance to the pier. On Sunday there was a school band there playing trumpets, flutes, clarinets and trombones. 

There are great seafood restaurants here and a huge parking garage that the restaurants will validate for one hour if you eat there.
author: Meghan P.

description:
This place is beautiful, lively, colorful and the list goes on.
It is apt for these situations:
-Date
-Just a stroll on the road when you can't decide one place to settle on
-Nice day out with the family
-A reunion with an old friend.
I mean it's apt for anything you can think of.
There are so many places to eat, buskers to watch, shops and nice bars.
It's lined with something for everyone.
Find a bench facing the waters and just sit there if you cannot think of anything else.
I know it is super crowded with tourists but it's not difficult to find a quiet spot or a good restaurant for a date.
author: Vaani S.

description:
If you're hanging around at San Francisco's Fisherman's Wharf, this popular tourist destination spot has it all! "Pier 39" brings visitors and residents to explore, shop, dine and play every 365 days a year! The atmosphere is very active and ongoing as I entered there. The concept is much like visiting to New Jersey's Boardwalk, yet in a traditional SF flare.

Inside at Pier 39, they have tons of restaurants to dine; mostly seafood related restaurants which I did visited "Fog Harbor Fish House" not too long ago. Their calm chowder tasted very good and devouring tasty to eat! There's also have tons of good shopping places to own from clothes, jewelry, accessories and plush dolls. Furthermore, they have tons of yearly entertainment around Pier 39 from carousel, visiting to the aquarium, dance and musicians spectators and of course, their Christmas tree lightning ceremony.

One of the most popular attractions at Pier 39 is the sea lions! Yes, many people are enjoying to watch the sea lions in action no matter how they lay on the board or simply having conversation. What a sight to see!

Parking at Pier 39 can be challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface metered street parking nor the parking garage if it's available. Alternatively, you can ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

In the end, Pier 39 is the finest and well maintained attraction site that I've ever visited right here in San Francisco! There are more things to discover at Pier 39, so I'm sure that I'll come back for more excitements to come in the future. A well visit for all ages! My rating: 4 solid stars.
author: William L.

description: If you're in the area or visiting SF for the first time, this is one of the locations that's a must to visit. There's many things to do like rides, places to eat and variety of stores from clothes to toys etc. We came in the morning around 10-11 and there's a fair amount of people at the time. It's usually tourist but I'm sure there are some residents that go there as well. There are a lot of views, one popular is the seals. You can see some sleeping, swimming or fighting each other. There's always people watching so you can either wait for a spot or if you're tall that works as well haha. There's parking but you have to pay. Restaurants can validate but for the first hour only. There's a lot of things to do there and I'm sure it'll be enjoyable for most people.
author: Mark D.

description: We went on a boat ride for my sisters birthday on a weekend. And They were so kind for letting us light a birthday candle for her cake on the boat. Good services, we were surprised of how loved & welcomed we felt. As we went around we saw the Golden Bridge & Alcatraz & the whole city behind us. We then went for some drinks at Ben & Jerry's, walked around to shop for souvenirs on Pier39 and ended up going in, in this crazy mirror maze. So scary but fun lots of laughs. Would recommend for families or group of friends!
author: Thamar G.

description:
We decided to come here in the early evening, which I imagine is likely it's busiest time. They have many staples of pier experiences like clam chowder and many gift shops. The gift shops pretty much all sell the same things - general San Francisco merchandise and T-Shirts.

The parking nearby can be a nightmare. We managed to eventually find parking and it costed $15. That seems to be a staple for San Francisco.
author: Jack D.

description: Great spot to see Alcatraz island. Great chowder bowls! Be sure to see the magic show--forgot the name of that guy but he's amazing. Be careful when you get near the seals...smell is putrid!
author: Kuulei S.

description:
Quick take: Grew up taking day trips to Fisherman's Wharf


I never get tired of Fisherman's Wharf. I am a SF native and I go to this area at least onxe a year. Just to hang out and be a tourist for a day.

Nothing like the hustle and bustle of people from around the globe. I never get sick of visiting FW. 

I take BART into SF. Get off at the Embarcadero station and walk around the FW area. Eat a bowl of chowder, visit the sea lions, and walk the piers. Great way to get your steps in for the day.
author: Nancy H.

description:
What to do when SoCal becomes SoBoring?  Been going off and on to Southern California that I think I wore out my curiosity of the place.  If you live in SoCal, what do they do for a break?

In Toronto, if you get bored and want a weekend of craziness, you head to Montreal.  If you want peace and quiet, you head north.  Well San Fran is 5 hours away and a change of pace and weather would be good right?  I'm packed up in the car already and my SoCal friend is available to make the trip.  Cool!  It's an expedition - like Miner'49'ers!

Arrived at San Francisco and what do all tourists do?  Gotta go to Pier 39.  Just a quick note SoCal is 100+ degrees, San Fran is 70 degrees and drops to 60.  Hmmm....got the wrong clothes with me.

For those who like to get souvenir clothing, Pier 39 does not have a shortage of them.  You name a SanFran/Golden State memorabilia and you will get it.  I opted not to overpay for a hoodie from china still with the smell of the sweat shop on it.

Food, fun, entertainment, shopping, and the scenery of the bay are all there on two floored wooden boardwalk that is Pier39.  If you are hungry as you walk through the place, they have their famous sourdough clam chowder everywhere.  It's basically a small town of it's own.  Just an FYI - if you intend to go to Chinatown sometime during your trip, you could pick up the souvenirs there.  They're all come off the same boat.

Since they started the e-bike and e-scooter share program.  The scooters are everywhere.  Neat little transportation device but I find it unregulated and dangerous.  Watch out for them.

Also, a nearby place to hangout is Fisherman's Wharf.  For those who come here on a whim, you are not getting onto Alcatraz.  That needs days of planning as tickets are limited and must be booked ahead.

Cheers!
author: Peter M.

description:
This is a place one could easily spend 3 or 4 hours just wondering around looking at the views, the restaurants, the shops, the carousel, the aquarium, and in general, just people watch.

It's where the tourists come, so if you're from someplace like New Jersey, please don't knock it for being "touristy".  

One point of interest is the dock area devoted to sea lions.  It seems the Pier 39 management calculated they would make more money from people gawking at the animals than trying to maintain boat rentals.  It is quite a sight, to be sure.

It's iconic, touristy, and certainly worth a visit.
author: Bert G.

description:
Well, we came here specially to see some seals but found only one (?!?!). Looks like that guy had his sick leave and stayed as home haha. To tell the truth we came here at 8 am so maybe that is the reason why we did not meet many seals. 

Area is nice, many cozy restaurants and shops. But don't come there very early as me !
author: Lara W.

description:
My father started bringing me here when I was 12 and I loved it. There were all kinds of interesting shops, there was good food and there were a ton of sea lions to watch! I was here all the time for people and sea lion watching. Over the past 25 years much of this has changed. The Pier is far too crowded now. Yesterday I could barely move around without running into someone. I think I said "I'm sorry" and "Excuse me" more times yesterday after bumping into people than I ever have in my life. The shops are less interesting and more generic, and, worst of all, there are too few sea lions. This place has lost a good deal of it's magic for me. I know that the average native of San Francisco will roll their eyes at this because they tend to look down on the touristy places anyway, but this place was special to me.

Tourists - Bring plenty of money and patience. Also, watch your bags and wallets.
author: Nick M.

description:
San Francisco is an unusual city.  The real heart of the city is in its neighborhoods:  the business people in the Financial District, the shopaholics at Union Square, the trendy atmosphere of Union Street, hipsters meet Latin America in The Mission, old money in Upper Pacific Heights.  But if the tourists want touristy stuff, they go to Jefferson Street and Pier 39.

In the mid-1970s, San Francisco took a dilapidated pier near Fisherman's Wharf and turned it into a tourist destination.  And it succeeded.

Most times I've gone to Pier 39, it's been loaded with people.  They're walking the length and enjoying the people-watching.  They're going into the stores and eating at the restaurants.  They're enjoying the views of the bay.  They're riding the merry-go-round.  It's not real San Francisco, but they're enjoying themselves.  Let the city snobs complain about it not really being what The City is all about;  they're the types who say that there's nothing good on the other side of the bay.

Still, I doubt that there are many locals here.  Partly because the stores are overpriced, and parking is awful.  As of this writing, the official parking garage charges $10/hour, which is comparable to the Financial District.  And the place feels so ticky-tacky.

Having written that, there are two things at Pier 39 where even locals put aside their snobbishness, or at least should:
* Aquarium of the Pacific.  I still haven't been here.  But it's supposed to be good, and is a fitting attraction for SF's waterfront that should be visited.
* The sea lions, who took over the boat docks in 1989 and haven't left.  I don't think there's any place like it in the world.  Active sea life on the shore of an urban city, easily accessible.  What was a nuisance quickly became, and remains, a point of pride in San Francisco.  The girl saw the sea lions for the first time today, and she was so excited about them.

Note that this part of North Beach has two-hour free parking on the streets, Bay Street and points south.  That may be all that City residents can stomach of Pier 39.  And it sure is easy on the wallet.  Also, I've been there at night too, and the crowds are gone.

If your relatives from out of the Bay Area come to visit, they're likely to want to go to Pier 39.  Okay, bring them.  It's not all that bad.
author: Ron L.

description:
I love the Pier just as much as I did when I was a little girl visiting for the first time! I'm pretty sure my kiddos are going to grow up to have the same fond memories of their first time too! 

Awesome sunsets, a lighthouse, views of Alcatraz in the distance, a gorgeous double decker carousel with rides for steal, shell shops, an arcade, classic sourdough bread, street performers including musicians, magicians and those spray paint artists (perhaps bring some cash for tipping?)....and SEA LIONS!! The best and most iconic part!! 

Sure it's touristy, there are chain restaurants like Bubba Gump and such, and there's definitely those cheesy shops with souvenirs I don't know who buys, but if you've never been to San Fran, you have to do it at least once! Me? I could sit and watch the sea lions for hours. 

I definitely wouldn't have dinner here but would without a doubt pick up a sourdough bread to go at least from Boudin. 

I would absolutely come back every time I'm here and would love to take a tour from here out to Alcatraz one day! 

It's one of those places you never know just what you'll see. 

A foggy chilly night stroll along the pier caps off a night in San Fran just lovely if you ask me. 

Street parking is rough. Self pay lots are your best next if you drive. They're pretty reasonable, especially for San Francisco prices.
author: Sari Marissa G.

description: Great place to check out and enjoy the shops. If you need a sovereign this would be the place to find it. There is also a dock that is loaded with sea lions.
author: Louis M.

description:
We always have to come here and see the sea lions. 
The rest of the place is tourist shops, but the sea lions are a treat.
author: Tommy F.

description:
This pier is a great place to walk around and sight see, with lots of amenities in walking distance.

There are a lot of great spots to take selfies at and a great spot to watch the sea lions. 

Just keep in mind, parking is pretty expensive..... It is $9/hr and you can only get validation for restaurants on that pier (cannot get validation at the Boudin Restaurant down the way...). So if you plan on staying for 3 hours, expect to pay $27 :(
author: Tiffany N.

description:
Pier 39 itself is pretty much what it has been, various shops and eating establishments. The views are nice, but do remember to have a light jacket even in summer as the breeze can get chilly.  

Pier 39 has private security which is reassuring. The problem is, Pier 39 is an oasis in a city that has become overrun with homeless and facing high crime.  The homeless and various garbage/waste are in your face, and you need to be on guard all the time.
author: Edward N.

description: Pier 39 is great. Every type of store and restaurant you could ever hold for with magnificent views and scenery all around you. Great to visit when walking around Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Nadia G.

description:
Pier 39 was definitely one of the highlights of my trip to San Francisco! I came here bright and early and the morning and it gave me plenty of time to see all the sights without too many tourists going around. It's a load of fun and there's tons of shops and various eateries.

I was pleasantly surprised to see the souvenir shops have pretty decent prices for souvenirs. It actually was cheaper than Chinatown! I walked away with some nice items to bring back home. The souvenir shops are fun! There's a store selling all Christmas ornaments, another one selling colorful socks and one dedicated to different magnets.

I also enjoyed the various eateries around here. When in San Francisco, one must get clam chowder (more about that in a later review) and there were several here that you could choose from in terms of clam chowder. 

One of my favorite things to see was the famous seals! Talk about an amazing sight. There were 200 seals that day. There's a small venue at the Pier that gives a good history of the seals and gives you real time info of how many seals there are that day.

Visiting Pier 39 was a lot of fun! I loved walking around and truly enjoyed visiting here.
author: Jenn G.

description:
San Francisco is a magnificent city to visit and there are so many places for families, for couples, with friends and even people going solo can enjoy!

One of my favorite areas to visit is Pier 39, a shopping center and very popular tourist attraction that was developed by Warren Simmons and opened in October 4, 1978.

One can find awesome restaurants, many shops, the Aquarium of the Bay, ride on a yacht, have a great view of sea lions and so much more!

Currently, Pier 39 features over a dozen full-service restaurants, 90+ shops and popular attractions and is home to a 5-actre waterfront park and a 300-berth marina.  You have gorgeous views of the San Francisco Bay and can see the Golden Gate Bridge, Bay Bridge and Alcatraz, as well as the sea lions hanging out.

There are so many things for couples, families or those who want to go solo and just admire part of what is awesome about the city of San Francisco.

I love visiting this place, it's a bit out of the way for me but each time I visit, I love trying to visit the many shops and delicious restaurants.

If you are going to San Francisco for the first time, Pier 39 should be on your bucket list!
author: Dennis A.

description:
Fun touristy spot that is a must see when you visit San Francisco.

I have to admit that I love being a tourist. I enjoy being surrounded by happy people on vacation. This is why Pier 39 is my jam. There are restaurants, shops, and interesting things to see and do. I love looking at the Sea Lions lying about. They are seriously my spirit animals. 

There are some fun out of the ordinary shops at Pier 39. Most notable to me was the puzzle shop (all the puzzles were made out of wood and looked like a ton of fun) and the water massage shop (you lay in a machine and get massaged by water). 

There was a magic act happening at the end of the pier when we were there. It is fun to see all the happenings. 

Even though you may not spend a lot of time at Pier 39 (especially if you aren't shopping or eating), I still think it is a fun place to visit!
author: Christina G.

description:
Pier 39 is definitely worth a visit when in San Francisco for the first time mainly because the end of the pier has a great view of Alcatraz and the Bay Bridge not to mention there are often a lot of sea lions hanging around. 

The stores and restaurants are mainly super touristy, which is fine but doesn't give you the taste of how amazing the stores and restaurants in the city can be.
author: Jaime H.

description:
Although Pier 39 is an absolute tourist trap, there is no way you can visit Fog City and not stop by....

There are plenty of shops and eateries for you to indulge in. For those who are more adventurous, there are a number of boating attractions to take part in or bike around and explore all that San Francisco has to offer (for a fee). The breathtaking scenic views of Angel Island, Alcatraz, The Golden Gate Bridge, and Bay Bridge will bring out the inner photographer in you. Explore what lies beneath the waters and view the 20,000 sea creatures that call The Bay home at the Aquarium Of The Bay. AND In my opinion, the best part of Pier 39 is getting an close up experience of California sea lions.
These sea lions have been present and enjoying SF waters since 1989 and the count continued to grow and grow. San Francisco has made sea lion conservation a top priority and strives to educate anyone who is interested in ways of maintaiing a sustainable environment for all sea life.

Fun for people all ages and very family- friendly.
author: Ter L.

description: Just had one of the best shopping experiences at Pier 39. Navigating the store was easy and the payment was fast and simple. Thanks for this wonderful experience; I will definitely love to shop here again.
author: Marilyn P.

description:
I love Pier 39! This is a must do every San Francisco visit, even if you just do it for the sea lions! I love seeing marine wildlife, and it's even more fun seeing them in their natural habitat rather than a stuffy zoo. 

The seals do draw such a crowd, but you will see why when you see (or hear them first). 

The shops are fun, there is a bit of everything for everyone - from candies to souvenirs and there are plenty of dining options, especially if you love seafood like me.
author: Mary P.

description: Wow, I didnt know what to expect after reading reviews about this "tourist trap." However, me being a tourist I enjoyed the pier. It was definitely lively and full of fun and cool stores to purchase clothes, stuff or food.  There were tons of family friendly activiites to do with the kiddos including the carousel and aquarium.  The pier was clean and reminded me of an organized carnival. This is definitely a cool place to walk around, eat or just sit and people watch.
author: Teresa S.

description:
Loved walking around Pier 39.

Beautiful water, flowers, fresh air, good eats all around, little shops, and the cutest sea lions ever! All in one spot, how can you not fall in love? There is also an aquarium here and a carousel. Yes, it's tourist central but I love it. It was close to our hotel and we loved walking here every night.
author: Kimberly J.

description:
It's as fun in the day, as it is at night. There's a tons of cool shops and restaurants with a tiny amusement park / carousel. There's even live performances / busker acts. If you go during the day, you must see the sea lions!

There's tons of tourists, any time, any day. It does have that very commercial feel, but a good place to pick up souvenirs.
author: Vincent H.

description: A pretty fun place to go. There's lote of activities to enjoy. We went as a group and had fun at 7D.
author: Freddy Z.

description:
Overly busy.
Dirty. 
Touristy. 
Lots of food choices. 
They have a carosel and an arcade.
Spent less than 20 mins here and moved on. 
Great people watching though..
Was a stop on our bus tour. 
Oh and sea lions...which were the best part...which is sad.
author: Pasquale R.

description: There are some five star components to the pier and some lesser ones. My kids loved that we saw a fight right in front of us while watching the seals. Decent free magic show as well but as with touristy places, the prices here are a bit high. We've been here over the years and it's about the same as it's been. - pretty consistent.
author: Ben T.

description:
One of the most popular places in the city; very touristy and crowded but always nice to be on the water! We were just here to go on a champagne sailing cruise and it was nice weather. 

We don't come here a lot because we stay away from the touristy parts of town but it was nice and refreshing to see a part of town you don't all the time! And the water and weather being perfect and sunny doesn't hurt anything either!
author: Bethany M.

description: Pretty cool place to visit. Check out the Sea Lions and the old lady doing magic. There are a lot of food choices, most of them are over-priced. But what you can expect in a tourist attraction.
author: Marty E.

description:
This place is such a tourist trap!  We were in the city celebrating a teenage birthday and following her lead on things to do.  Since we were around the corner she wanted to come here.  I think it was because of a magic show she watch and remember nostalgically 5 years ago.  However this one was far less memorable.  

There are a ton of shops selling over priced trinkets from China.  If you want something to eat, they have that too.  Open your wallet and pay at least 2x the norm.  

What did I learn today?  There is good people watching here.
author: Ryan C.

description: First of all, its a tourist area of California, so you know its going to be beautiful with lots to do. It did not disappoint. The shops were fabulous, the aquarium is one of the better ones around, and the sea lions are so fun to watch! They crawl all over each other, knock each other off the dock, and make lots of noise. The smell leaves a bit to be desired, but its still a fun experience. The street performers are incredibly entertaining. There is something for everyone. Definitely worth a stroll through!
author: Samantha S.

description:
Great place if the weather is cooperative. It is a tourist area of the city. Plenty of restaurants and a NFL store on the second level as well. The biggest draw is that it is right on the water with a spectacular view you can't go wrong. 
From Wipeout Café to San Francisco merchandise this place has it all.  This pier is superb. Go check it out, It is must see and checkout while you are in the bay area.
author: Scott H.

description:
Review for their baggage service in the 2nd floor California Welcome Center:

During the last day of my SF trip, we had an awkward gap between the check out at our Airbnb and our flight time.  I googled places to leave baggage in the area, and this place popped up. If you walk upstairs to the second floor and enter the California Welcome center, you can leave your baggage here while you do some exploring.  The cost is only $5 per bag for almost any size.  Over sized luggage is $10.  You can leave your baggage until early evening, which seemed reasonable.  The attendants  were nice and the whole process was smooth.  I was so thankful to not have to carry around my heavy bag.
author: Yvonne I.

description:
Lots to do. Lots to eat. Food was really good.
Shops were very reasonably priced. Clean. Able to catch the street car from here... and several boat tours. Watch the sea lions here as well.
author: Alyssa P.

description:
Being by the Pier is so breezy! 

I love the open air, public stroll and shops that are catchy to the eye and makes one go in to check it out.  

Entertaining and touristy place.  Being down by the Pier is quite pleasant and overlooked for me as a local.

Difficult to find parking, but wonderful outing!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Pier 39 is the pulse of San Francisco bay.

Yes, there are an incredible amount of tourists at Pier 39 yet that in itself creates the atmosphere. Everyone seems to be in awe of just being at the pier. For us, it was a chance to catch an evening wine tour cruise on the bay, browse through the shops afterwards to purchase souvenirs, and eat ourselves out of shape!

We enjoyed the huge selection of restaurants available to us and all the different places to find delicious desserts and candies. This is a very family friendly location and best enjoyed in the evening.

TIP: We took an Uber here because we did not want to deal with the overwhelming traffic. That is probably the only drawback; the traffic. 

Visit the pier on an EMPTY stomach so you can enjoy all the different types of eateries and desserts. Definitely book a wine cruise on the bay so you can truly capture all of San Francisco. 

Visit www,sanfranciscobayboatcruise.com for more information. The tour departs from Pier 39.

Enjoy your visit!
author: Vincent Artemio E.

description:
Reviewer # 1064

Where do I start? If you've never been, you're in for a treat. Let's start with parking... 
Parking is hard to find in this area. There is a parking garage across the street from the entrance and is $10/hr. You can download a parking app or go to a website that will help you find cheaper alternatives and even hold your place in advance such as parkme.com. 

Once you walk towards the peer you will see a lot of things-- Street performers are always fun to watch. My favorite are the artists that draw amazing things right in front of you. Not many people can do such talented things. Remember to always tip-- these people are artists, trying to do what they love. 

Another thing you will see are a lot of boats-- jet boats (shout our to Blue & Gold Fleet-- check out my photos of my speed boat ride) and small three level ships that take you all around the Bay. They go to Alcatraz, around/under both the Bay and Golden Gate Bridges and more. 

As you walk onto the peer, which extends out onto the Bay, you ill find tons of shops and entertainment such as an aquarium, theater, and a carousel.  Some awesome shops along they way will entice you to open that checkbook, a fruit stand will make your mouth water with fresh fruit on display, or you may want to get some fresh clam chowder in a sourdough bowl. 

Once you hit the end of the pier, you will see many seals and sea lions. They will make you laugh and smile. You will see the boats coming into the port and leaving... be sure to wave! 

I never have enough time to go through each and every store-- after all the meter is running at $10/hr to park! 


                                                        **Memory lane story**

When I was 18 (in 1999), my friends and I wanted to go see the pier for the first time. We had no car and was way, way too young to rent a car. We lived 45 minutes away in Fairfield, Ca. We decided to rent a Uhaul and drive it into the city and we did so. We parked the u-haul in the parking lot (it wasn't the same back then and that parking garage I told you about didn't exist) for what I want to say was just a few dollars per hour. Silly kids... Happy story.
author: Greg D.

description:
Pier 39's got it all; from food, entertainment, shopping, to the sights and never ending sounds! As the ocean breeze unfurls into the Pier, you breathe in what can only be that salty fresh "wind [blowing] beneath your wings." The aroma of mouthwatering fried food begins to take precedence of your olfaction as it soon targets your salivary glands. You're engulfed by what makes Pier 39 special; the flooding crowds of tourists perusing around the shops with the many whiffs of food and attractions from all directions.

As a self-made professional Pier 39 tourist myself, I've always found something new or charming from my visits here. There's a great selection of fresh seafood here and when in doubt on what to order, go with a clam chowder bread bowl.  From the vast selection of food and restaurants, Pier 39 also serves as an entertainment hub for marine life and entertainment. 

The sunbathing sea lions have become a recognizable stop for visitors as they go mad, barking and shoving rivals to claim dominance upon their favored dock. Along with sea lion noise, you'll also be able to listen to music from the iconic carousel, maybe a live performance on stage by street performers, hear arcade games going berserk, notes from the piano stairs and a whole lot of everything else!

There's great views throughout Pier 39. One popular sight is at the far end of the Pier, where you can see Alcatraz at a far distance. I personally like looking at boats jet into the Bay from the neighboring boat docks. The sights are truly entertaining as there's so much to see! Whether you're going for the sights or tastes, there's always something fun any regular or tourist can appreciate from Pier 39.
author: Andy L.

description:
This is a tourist attraction place. Came here couple times. I like the fact that its really nice to walk here on a nice day. There are good food at Pier 39 like Bubba Gump, food stands etc. Also at the end you get to see sea lions sitting around. Free tourist entertainment. There are street performers here. ITs really nice. 

Great place to walk and relax. Interestingly there is a carousel here. Great for kids.
author: Denise W.

description:
Is it touristy? Yeah.

Is it still pretty cool? Yeah. 

You've got lots of seafood restaurants (hit or miss), shops, a carousel, random attractions, a gorgeous view, SEA LIONS, great people watching. 

Nice place to spend an hour or two.
author: Maria E.

description:
I love touristy stuff. Its so fun to go to places that show off what is best about a city. I also hate touristy stuff. It gets SO crowded and people are so absorbed in their journey that they don't respect others. I was in the area today after having brunch in the city and decided to stop by since I had a wonderful parking spot (which is really saying something) that had no time restriction. Lets be real. If you live in SF or LA, traffic and parking dictate a lot about your plans. 

This pier has a lot of components. You can go shopping on the pier for goodies to take home. You can also eat on the pier and grab some Boudin or other food. You can sightsee all along the dock, especially the adorable seals. You can go on a ferry ride near the pier and see everything from the water. You can check out the local entertainment that performs on the street. The list goes on and on. 

I highly recommend coming here if you are visiting the area. If you do not like crowds, try to pick a less busy day. The winds are gustin so be sure you have a sweater if you're dressed in shorts. The parking is a pain in the butt in the area. There are lots but they are super expensive. If you go farther from the beach, there is street parking along the residential areas.
author: Ori N.

description: One of my all time favorite places to hang out. Catch some lunch with friends, watch the sea lions and get some shopping in all in the place. Lots to see and do. Family friendly or date appropriate. Just an awesome place to visit.
author: Jess G.

description: It's my first time visiting pier 39 a very tourist area in San Francisco. So many restaurants to choose from. I didn't know which one to pick from. I finally picked Crab House restaurant on the upper deck. The food was good and very pricey to me for such a small amount. That was very disappointing.  For all this total me $92.69.. will I ever visit again of course I will, the crab cakes was pretty amazing
author: Esther J.

description: Where all the tourists go when visiting SF. Lots to offer in terms of dining and shopping. Family friendly environment and lots of entertainment. Something to offer for everyone. The sea lions laying on the planks are fun to watch too. Pretty much busy everyday especially when the weather is nice.
author: Andrew P.

description:
A touristy area that's a must.  We are lucky that we live hear and we can go whenever we feel like it lol..

It's always nice to come here on a beautiful sunny day and peruse the shops, have a nice lunch and sit outside...

It is the City..so parking will be tough and expensive.
author: Veronica A.

description:
Date:7/10/2017.  Time: 2:30 PM.  65°.  Sunny

Pier 39 is 39 this year. They opened in 1978. I have been to this tourist attraction many times in the past. It's a fun place to visit if you don't mind the slow moving crowds and the wall-to-wall people in the shops, the eateries, the courtyards and the general outdoor. 

I always thought of Pier 39 as just being okay (3 stars) except for the NFL Shop and Boudin Sourdough (4 stars). A few years back there was a shop that sold holiday ornaments and Dept. 56 collectibles for the holiday season. They had some hard to find Dept. 56 items and it was my go-to place during the holiday. The shop was always festive and colorful. They have been gone for a while.  I was disappointed that they closed. Back then I also enjoyed having the clam chowder bowl on those cold days...ahh...comfort food, but those darn seagulls seemed to linger around in search of leftover sourdough bread or any food.

My visit was an enjoyable one, despite it being for less than 1/2 hour. I was amazed at their outdoor farmer's market - plump strawberries, bags of cherries, red and green apples, grapes, summer fruits (peaches, nectarines, plums). Fresh produce is always a welcome sight. I am glad they have this market available for the local people and tourists. It has restored my faith of Pier 39 and its attraction. Thus, I will return for more visits during the summer season - weekdays and/or weekends.
author: Carol C.

description:
How have I not written a review for Pier 39?  It's like the elephant on the living room sofa where San Francisco is concerned.   

As if we need another 2000 reviews making you aware of the fact that this is probably the #1 TOURIST destination in San Fran, I see that as great.   I live here and we go to Pier 39 quite often.   Our visit this last weekend was probably over the 500th time to visit Pier 39.   

The tourists from all over the world are exciting to mingle with and it gives you a great sense of pride in our city for having so many things to do in a beautiful fair weather setting which is unlike anything else in the world.  The range of shopping and food available does in fact attract the locals as well, even the ones that do not want to admit it on Yelp.  :)
author: Greg D.

description:
5 stars for the sea lions only. Otherwise it's like any other pier in a resort area, crowded and pricey. 

But, BUT, those sea lions are so funny to watch. Grab a cup of coffee and walk down to the end of the pier and be entertained by them!! 
Prefect spot to take a break and marvel in these stunning animals!
author: Anne W.

description:
Pier 39. Just as good today as it was when I was a kid. Only now I get to take my kids. Some things have changed, some things are the same but it's ALL just as fun as I remember. 
Super easy to find no matter where you're coming from. Just get on embarcadero and follow until you hit it. Lots of other cool stops along the way too (restaurants & Exploratorium & Embarcadero center). 
Parking was easy. I opted to just park in the garage. I'm sure I could have tried to find street parking because it was still early but $10 isn't too bad and we were right there with no hassle. 
Once we got there my daughter wanted to go check out the sea lions right away!  There they were, a SF staple. Swimming, diving, playing, pushing and yelping super loud. We walked over to the very end to see Alcatraz but it was too foggy to see. Oh well. 
Tons of fun restaurants and fancy ones too. There's a donut shop, a crepe shop, candy shop and faster types of food shops. There's also a number of fancy places which offer steak, clam chowder (of course) and wonderful sea food. 
I love the specialty shops there ever since I was a kid. Especially the store for left handlers. They had a cool knife store, fridge magnet store and tee shirt store. 
Overall loved the pier as I have for many years. Sure its aging but they keep it in phenomenal shape for its age. Not to be missed if you've never been or haven't been for a while.
author: Lawrence D.

description: What a nice change at Pier 39.  When to Pier 39 today and had a great time.  Fresh shops, clean and no one asking me for money.  Pier 39 has a lot of new shops, flowers are blooming and the smell of all the food, so many good things to taste and eat.
author: David E.

description:
Great place for photo ops and many dessert places and restaurants to visit! There are plenty of souvenir shops as well, and tons of people crowd this place. 

We saw a few arcades and photo booths mixed in with the different little shops. Every couple hours or so they offer a free show and there are a few benches to sit in in front of the little theater/stage. 

Some people don't know how to say excuse me, so be prepared to just be pushed. Oh and then you have the people that just abruptly stop walking right in front of you to have a full conversation with whoever they are with. Ugh.

The bathrooms were disgusting and they smelled so bad.. someone's not doing their job.

Three starts because the bathrooms were gross.
author: Christa M.

description: The kids loved it... I mean we are Bay Area raised so the pier is just frisco to us. But I want to say thank you to the gentleman who drew us. We loved our picture and we had such a good time and appreciate you being patient with us all. It's framed!!!
author: Coryann E.

description:
How to save money at Pier 39:

If your reading this then make sure you check in to Pier 39 and claim your fun pack and get it at the California visitors center located on the 2nd floor. The fun pack is a coupon book to most of the vendors of pier 39. It also has a free 1 hour parking coupon. If you eat at the full service restaurants get your parking ticket validated to get an extra free hour of parking. You have to park in the Pier 39 parking garage.

If your a local who lives near SF, join pier 39 local advantage. You have to be a local resident around SF to get these extra coupons. Many coupons are buy one get one free. They coupons will be emailed to you. You don't need to print them to use them just show the coupon on your phone.
author: Dorothy B.

description:
Tourists unite!  According to the tourist bus tour that I took to this über tourist site, Pier 39 is the second most visited site in San Francisco  (second to the Golden Gate Bridge, of course) and one of the top tourist sites in the nation.  You'll come to find a swarm of innocent tourists just like yourself who are wandering the pier in search of some goods to bring on home.  

The pier as well as some of the stores that are further down Fisherman's Wharf are actually some very neat shops.  There's a fantastic knife shop (yes, that sounds sadistic, but it's awesome in there), a Biscoff cookie butter store, as well a Freshwater pearl store, and my favorite - a whole store dedicated to ridiculous socks.  The conglomeration of stores here is just great - there's lots of good places to shop in San Francisco, and this is one of them.  Besides all the shopping, there's plenty of restaurants that might tickle your fancy!

You can spend a whole day here at Pier 39 and along the way of Fisherman's Wharf because of the shopping and dining but also because of awesome sights like the Aquarium of the Bay, the sea lions and not to mention, the Blue and Gold cruises.  All this and more is nestled into the Pier!  Pro tip: if you get the San Francisco pass you can get into some of the attractions at Pier 39 for free!  

I loved it here at Pier 39, even if it was super toursity.  Because of its nature, it does attract A LOT of kids and families, but there's plenty for couples like me and my fiance.  It's a beautiful place to spend a day, especially if the weather is cooperating which it did when it was there!
author: Lauren K.

description:
Such a nice place to bring vistors and family here visting from somewhere else. 
.
Def feels x mas and holiday ish during nov and decemeber. They have a big x mas tree which lights up and feels oh so holiday. 
.
There are lots of stores for you to visit, shop, look at, and food vendors for you to dine at to get a snack. 
.
Remember to walk all the way to the back, because you can see Alcatraz on the other side of the island. As well you can see the sea lions like a lot not just one or 2. 
.
Overall its a great place to stop, to just say you been to SF, also remember to charge your camera up and take lots of nice photos. Thanks for reading and have a happy holiday.
author: Alex T.

description:
You really need to come here if...
1. Your seafood addict
2. Your around San Francisco
There are Street performers, different kinds of foods, shops, lastly lots and lots of seafood! 
It's actually my second time coming to this area, but it's my parents first time. They loved it, it's Wholesome so everyone can come here, and trust me, unless you don't like living life, this is a place for you ;). You should definitely come here.:)
author: Helen L.

description:
In having grown up in the Bay Area my whole life I have been down to Pier 39 on numerous occasions. I very much appreciate the uniqueness of this San Francisco attraction as well as all that it offers. The food and the entertainment in the area have always been a draw for locals and out of towners. However, over the past decade, it has become more a hotspot for tourism. 

In being down here just yesterday I was surprised to see how crowded this place can be. There is so much foot traffic that it is still easy to get detached from a group. Definitely, keep your head up and be alert when in this area because it is easy to get lost if you are unfamiliar with the area. 

If you are planning to come down to Pier 39 and you can plan ahead try to do that. If you are looking to eat at a restaurant in the area and you can make reservations early do it or you will be waiting for quite some time. 

Great place to visit once every 5 years and that is all that I have to say about that.

#WaterFrontView
author: Robert F.

description:
Pro: Sometimes, there are sea lions.

Cons: There aren't always sea lions.

Neutral: lots of kitschy, touristy shops, and a giant Christmas tree to remind east coasters that it is, in fact, the holiday season.

Pier 39 was recommended to me by a friend from the Bay Area, specifically for the sea lions. It delivered in spades. Or in sea lions.

Other than that, unless you're looking for chain food and little knick knacks or souvenirs, there's not a ton to do here as an adult with a proclivity for biking around and day drinking. This place is probably a lot more fun if you have kids.

For real, though, awesome with the sea lions.
author: Vichet O.

description: I only visited this place on the recommendation of someone who insisted we go based on the reviews of the Chinese online community. The stimulation level of Pier 39 is an 11/10, which means you will be overstimulated after about 20 minutes, unless you find somewhere a little more chill to take a break from all the people, noise, and rambunctiousness. Definitely check out the seals. They are usually hanging out getting some sun. I saw a few seals wrestle, which entertained myself and the giant crowd taking pictures/video. Finding clean, functional restrooms is a problem at Pier 39. With the massive waves of people and constant tourist trap buzz, you will find it challenging to take fun, pleasing photos at Pier 39. Shops put on the performance of being unique all in their own way, but any well-traveled visitor will see through the novelty of these shops as mere ploys to empty your wallet. In short, Pier 39 is an okay place to visit once, but there are definitely much cleaner, pleasant locations to visit in the SF area.
author: Henry L.

description: This spot is touristy, but nice. We enjoyed walking through the shops and stopping at the fruit market. Everything was expensive here, so make sure to use the Ali Pay coupon for $5 off a purchase of $10 or more.
author: Kristina H.

description: High five to the tourist trap, some might hate it but its still a lot of fun. There are many food options that will please the pickiest tourist and great water views. If you want more old school authentic places to eat walk on over to the Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Franklin M.

description:
Good Old Pier 39. Great place to come and bring the kids.

There's a lot to offer from the Aquarium (which has an otter exhibit), plenty of restaurants covering any kind of food you could want, desserts, street vendors and even street performers. It's definitely a whirlwind of awesome surrounded by gorgeous views of the bay and what you can see of the city.

Pier 39 adds a bit of wonder to the already enchanting city of SF. You can catch a tour our of here or the other local piers as well as a ferry over to Sausalito. Which, I highly recommend. 
You're in walking distance to Fisherman's Wharf and to a number of other little gems in the area. If you're visiting the city for the first time, please come here. It's truly amazing and you will not find a place like this everywhere.
author: Zoe F.

description: Must must do... we even went in the rain. Its so mich fun to listen to the seals bark and play
author: Karole R.

description: Awesome experience getting to see the famous seals on the pier.  The whole area is a really fun tourist trap.  Interesting street performers and shops and restaurants.
author: Zen D.

description: This place always amuses me. I enjoy walking the pier, looking around at all the street performers and enjoy everything about this place.
author: Rayna B.

description: Saw handful of sea lions here. One can spend 30-40 mins near fishermans wharf to enjoy the nearby activities.
author: Shail P.

description:
Iconic spot in SF! Great during any season. 

This is SF's version of Santa Monica Pier minus the beach part. It has an array of restaurants and food choices. Also has a carousel, arcade, and cute stands to look at. You can spend a good 4-5 hours, just looking around. This place also has a part near the water where seals bask in the sun and many people enjoy looking at them. Make sure to put this on your SF list!
author: Jennifer G.

description: Awesome place to come with family for a day in the city. We usually take the ferry. There are so many great restaurants to choose from. Also if you happen to have friends or family from out of town this is the perfect place to take them for a good San Francisco's experience.
author: John H.

description: The Sea Lions at Pier 39 are so much fun to watch and a must see while in San Francisco! There are also many great restaurants and shops and it is fun to just walk through and check it all out, but worth it just for the Sea Lions alone.
author: Leo A.

description: Nice place ace, giant  seals so appeals... Hangout in SFC, known as SUCKA FREE CITY, crabs,, seafood and people watching all around, tourists abound. Come hangout with me,  don't doubt the SUCKA Free
author: Hp C.

description:
I Love Love Love this place! I have been twice and finally sat down to write this review. One time it was raining and we didn't care bc there were so many shops and it was kind of neat to see the fog over the ocean and the Sea Lions all over the place. The second time was a gorgeous day and we could see for miles. I was actually also an assistant in a magic show...that was a blast! 
Pier 39 is def the place you have to go if you are in town. Then a hop skip and a jump over to the SF Golden Gate bridge....also awesome! Honestly this should be on your bucket list. You will love it at any age.
author: Kari H.

description:
Came to the pier to do a bag of cruise tour and an Alcatraz tour . This is absolutely a touristy and must see spot if you are in the area . It's very lively , lots a good , entertainment . 
We were able to play a free game of basketball for a chance to be entered in a drawing for united airlines . It was a united airlines event . The line was long to shoot 3 balls in the basket but honestly worth it especially when you are trying to kill time between two cruises . 
We walked from pier 39 to pier 33 for our cruises . Only about a 10 minute walk. On our walk right outside of the aquarium we found some Oreo churros . You absolutely have to try these out . If you like Oreos , try them . 

There is plenty to do on the pier between cruises , games , food , bars , restaurants , shopping. Excellent spot to bring your family .

Check it out .
author: Binita S.

description:
This is one of the most touristy spots in San Francisco. Pier 39 is full of great places for tourists. Lots of restaurants. Aquarium of the  Bay. Boudin Bakery. Souvenirs shops. Views of barking seals. Views of the Bay Bridge, Alcatraz and the Golden Gate Bridge. 

There is a big beautiful carousel too. 

You can take a Ferry over to Alcatraz. Blue & Gold Ferry rides across the bay. 

There are endless things to do and see.
author: Robyn J.

description: The seals are a must see, not sure how we missed them last time but they were so loud this time around that we just followed the sound. Found tons of them laying around basking in the sun, I could have watched them all day. Some were swimming around, others pushing each other off, it was so funny to watch. We loved it! Don't miss the seals!!!
author: Mary M.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf and Pier 39 in particular are where the tourists gather in SF. If you're visiting the city, I *highly* recommend seeing other parts of SF to get the full and authentic experience.

Pier 39 is junky and touristy and kind of feels like an amusement park/state fair. It's practically it's own little neighborhood in SF. 

I stopped by to see the beloved sea lions on the west side of the pier and I loved it! They splash in and out of the water and make their signature sound. Walk around to the end of Pier 39 for nice panorama views of the bay, with Alcatraz front and center. This is the only reason I would come back to Pier 39. 

+Note there are public restrooms that are decently clean along Pier 39, which can come in handy when exploring the shoreline. 

TL;DR: come for the sea lions and bay views, but avoid the touristy shops and restaurants.
author: Katie U.

description:
Pretty interesting location, lots of shopping spots, plenty of tourist type stop in's, great people watching and the seals were a huge hit. 

You can see the Baybridge easily and  the Goldengate is a bit far away but you can still see it. 

They Have Street Theatre which was a juggler and he was very good. I recommend stopping in the wipe out bar and grill, food was yummy and they had a good selection of drinks. The fire pit and Adirondack chairs on the patio were a big hit

Parking is expensive and limited it's easier to ride public transportation in.
author: George W.

description: Pier 39 offers a variety of entertainment. The parking situation is not the best, it is expensive and difficult to find. There is a ton of traffic. Once you get past all that then there a lot of Touristy stuff to do!  Bring a jacket! it is very cold and windy!
author: Yessi H.

description:
Tourist's Paradise! Tons of shopping from touristy trinkets to chocolate to antiques and everything in between. There are also coffee shops, restaurants, bars, and even an arcade. We had fun wandering around the pier, in and out of shops, getting a caricature, watching a magic show, taking silly pictures in a photo booth, and Pokémon hunting. You can walk through to the back of the pier for a fantastic view of Alcatraz, sea lions, and a partial view of the Golden Gate Bridge.

Walk down The Embarcadero and you will find street performers, museums, higher end restaurants, and more shopping. Definitely a fun way to spend a day!
author: Brandi K.

description: I loved Pier 39! So much life, so much beauty, and so much fun! From shops, restaurants, street performers, stage shows, and of course the sea lions! Can't visit San Fran and not check pier 39 out.
author: Joiya A.

description:
If your in San Francisco area pier39 is a great area for some family fun. This is the 4th time I've been here when I've come to the area. It's a nice little walk by the water front. It has good vendors and some shops. If you walk to the end you will see the sea lions laying around on the docks sun bathing, this is a treat for the little ones. And this month jan 2018 they are celebrating the love for the animal and having Saturday with salty the sea lion on deck. They are raising awareness for the animals and funds to protect them. This area is a great view of the bay, and perfect to get pictures of Alcatraz. 

There is an arcade area for families. Games, rides, entertainment area. There is shops and some restaurants too. I does get crowded but it is a hot spot to check out and explore and see with the fam or even as a couple. I enjoyed coming for a quick adventure as I passed through San Fran
author: Jessica N.

description: One of my go to tourist places when I want to explore and walk around SF for some clam chowder. There are plenty small shops around the area and check out the street performing acts~
author: Yennie L.

description:
It's simply way too crowded here for me.  The only reason I'd brave the crowds was to shop at the now long-gone Department 56 store that sold those pricey ceramic Christmas village pieces.  Currently, the only cause for me to step foot inside would be to check out the sea lions that hang out on the floating piers at the west end.  Other than that, no thank you!  

The complex is loaded with quite a few restaurants, touristy shops, an aquarium, and the city's Hard Rock Cafe, which by the way, is conveniently located at the outskirts of the mall.  Street performers are scattered everywhere.  Parking?  Yikes, I'd never want to guess where you'd park, though I did see a few parking garages a short walk away.

OVERALL:
Check it out at least once, but I'm sure you'll find that dining at Fisherman's Wharf and shopping elsewhere are a lot more enjoyable.
author: Vince N.

description: i love this area!! saw sea elephants, ate clam chowder and took a lot of cute pictures
author: Soojeong H.

description: I have to say this place was really cool fun,family oriented,great food and just a really fun atmosphere there's also a lot of shopping stores if you looking for some really cool clothes,the Christmas in San Francisco is one of my favorite stores if your ever in the San Francisco area it's a must to come here.
author: Amazing P.

description: So much to do and see from harbor cruises to eagle watching to the aquarium to various shops and restaurants. Parking is a nightmare but the sea lions are great to view as well.
author: Steven W.

description: Me and my daughter drove here from about 2 1/2 hours south and it was totally worth the drive.  Theres so much to do on the Piers.
