We did the tourest-thing and spent most of our time at Pier 39.  There's a 30 min boat trip available below the Alcatraz store.  Its $15 per person and totally the perfect amount of time and we were able to get some awesome pictures from the boat.  We also watched a magic show that had us laughing and laughing. Another highlight for us was all the sites such as Alcatraz, the large boats that you can walk through, tons of gift shops (we love gift shops!), and the seals.  We also found great parking for $10 till 3pm next to IHOP by Pier 39... but you have to get there early. Worth a day trip for sure! We really enjoyed our time there.
author: Cindy G.

description: So much to do at Pier 39!! The restaurants, Ice cream parlors, shopping and activities made it a great day destination when in San Fran! The sea lions are hilarious to watch! There is also an amazing area to get some great photos with the Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz in the background!
author: Jessica C.

description:
Love the attractions.
Magic shows.
Food!
My favorite was the rocketboat. It's costly. But different.

There's no law enforcement around as much as other areas.

But  Smells like Seagle waste.
author: Sarah H.

description: Yes, this place is touristy but yes, it's a must see/do if you're in SF. On the weekends, there are tons of street performers and things going on. During the week, there are a lot of homeless there but only a couple asking for money. Good food on the pier. We went outside of Pier 39 to get the famous Lobster Roll and Clam Chowder.
author: Brittany R.

description:
This place is a must do for any tourist visiting San Francisco. Expect the crowds to move slow and it is usually packed. Park across the street at the Pier 39 Parking lot. Check in on yelp to unlock the free fun pack which includes a booklet of coupons to multiple Locations at the pier. 

You pick up the fun pack book at the California Welcome Center on the second floor. It also includes a coupon 2 free hours of parking at the Pier 39 garage! Save some money! 

They have a ton of little tourist shops here at Pier 39 as well as many very cool restaurants. It's a really fun place to visit. They also sell fresh fruit at this Pier with yummy strawberries. At the end of Pier 39 you get a nice view of Alcatraz and the bay. There are also cute seals to look at with plenty of seating.
author: Karen C.

description:
The two best things about Pier 39 are the Sea Lions and the beautiful views of the Bay. Beyond that it's basically an outdoor shopping mall looking to take as many dollars from tourists as it can. Unfortunately, it's just one of those super mainstream tourist traps that everyone just HAS to go to during a trip to San Francisco.

Come see the Sea Lions, look out at the Bay, people watch, and get your obligatory souvenir from Hard Rock, but don't eat or shop here.
author: Chad K.

description: Pier 39 is exactly what we expected: overcrowded and tourist heavy.  If you're interested in any of it - there's gift shops galore featuring colorful t-shirts, shot glasses and magnets, there's mediocre food (read: lots of chain restaurants), but overall not much else to see.  Except the sea lions!  I'm a total sucker for animals and I couldn't pass up viewing these lovely creatures lounging and soaking up the sun.  They don't do much, but its kinda cool to see so many of them hanging out together.
author: Alyssa R.

description:
Pier 39 is one of my favorite parts of San Fran! There is plenty to do for visitors of all ages and interests. 

Traveler Tip: There is often a brisk breeze that rolls through SF and if you aren't wearing the proper clothing, you will not enjoy your visit since you will be cold. Bring an extra windbreaker or warm jacket. 

I'm a fellow traveler so I appreciate when other people have given me tips/recommendations while in a new city. If this information is helpful, please let me know by hitting the like button. Even if this review helps only one traveler then it's worth it to know I'm contributing towards making someone's experience better, giving to the global community, and paying it forward. Safe Travels!
author: Neo N.

description:
Pier 39 is a fantastic location to see seals up close and undisturbed (the seals, not you), however, expect throngs of tourists oohing and awing just like yourself. 
The Pier itself is part of San Fransisco's vibrant waterfront scene and while touristy, it shouldn't be missed.
If you do the coastal drive, there will be several opportunities to see seals on beaches, swimming, etc, but this vantage point in a major city, is fairly unique.
author: Jim B.

description:
This is one of the more popular piers in the area. The crowd here was super dense. You can feel like you're in another world. There were so many shops here that you can most certainly price compare for the typical items you'd buy while being a tourist: postcards, magnets, shot glasses, t-shirts. 

At the end of the boardwalk with all its shops and booths, you'll end up by the water. Our friend found some seals or sea lions just chilling around barking up a noise storm on buoys. 

There was also a live magic/clown act/entertainment show near the end of the pier. There were chairs set up for people to sit and enjoy the show, but it was way too dang cold so our group just bolted into stores to look at tourist-sy crap.

I am bumping my rating up to 5 stars bc of the variety and # of stores and restaurants available.
author: Andrea M.

description: Favorite place in SF that I visited. The seals are so fun to watch. My friend and I caught a cat adventure boat ride and enjoyed the views. Super fun to stroll around and the shops are cute.
author: Casey W.

description: I've visited Pier 39 in SF several times over the years and have had an excellent experience each time. Most recently, I visited in May 2017.  The pier has plenty of awesome seafood restaurants and shops - we dined at Fog Harbor Fish House (I've visited twice and separately reviewed this place).  They also have great casual clam chowder stands, and the ice cream parlors are excellent.  The pier also affords a lovely view of the Golden Gate bridge, the bay generally, and Alcatraz Island.  Make sure to walk around the entire pier and say hello to the loud, boisterous sea lions. On a clear day, you can see pretty far into the city of SF and its slopey hillsides.  Also, make sure to take a boat tour of the bay bridge (it departs from the dock between Pier 39 and Pier 41). You haven't done SF right if you haven't visited Pier 39! It's fun for tourists and locals alike.
author: Pegah Y.

description: My first time visited San Francisco was to pier 39. I am impressed with the beach and the plenty of sea lions. Having chowder soup next to it was the best thing ever!
author: Gabriella Y.

description: Fisherman's Warf and Pier 39 is one of my favorite places in SF. From the specialty shops, excellent seafood restaurants, and scenic views of the Golden Gate bridge and Alcatraz; it's the perfect place to spend a beautiful day outdoors. Great people watching, perfect for a stroll along the water, just remember to dress in layers and bring a jacket as the weather can change quickly. But with so many shops around the pier, if you forget your coat, no worries you can always purchase your SF suvenior hoodie, LOL (I got one on my first visit). This place is great for families, nice for a daytime date or even to relax on a solo visit. With all the action surrounding you, you won't feel alone and you'll have plenty to entertain you.
author: Tatiana V.

description:
Great environment and plenty to see and eat. Every time we come to SF pier 39 is a must!!!!! 
Live music, great clam chowder, perfect views, and lots of shopping. We were lucky to be there today while they had their market going on and we taste new food/flavors DELISH
author: Eliza B.

description:
This is everything you imagine San Francisco to be. Wind blowing off the water, the Golden Gate Bridge to your right, Alcatraz (yes, the former federal prison) to your left. There are numerous restaurants, bars and ice cream parlors nearby. The sea gulls swoop overhead and the marina filled with sail boats is a sight to behold.
     But if there is one thing that will make you smile and have you taking more pictures and video than anything else it is the sea lions. They are loud, in motion, and a joy to behold. There are sitting/standing areas nearby so you can get a good point of view even if you're not in the front of the group. You can even keep watching them, via the Pier 39 website (pier39.com), after you leave. They can be found on the left side of Pier 39.


*Insider's Tip
-Be sure to take one of the boat tours. They will give you a close up of the Golden  Gate Bridge and Alcatraz plus a more landscape via of the city from the water. You will get the history of the area...and you get to go on a boat. It's a win-win every way you look at it.
author: Aaron S.

description: This is one of my favorite places to go although I hate crowds I love it here. The kids have fun I get a little drunk and my husband has to baby sit all of us. The kids love the magic act and all the excitement around. I hate trying to park but it's all worth the fun of being here
author: Lydia M.

description: It's just a quick trip to see the seals, if you haven't seen them up close,  you must come to pier 39. I did not know whales number one food choice are seals. Those poor babies! Other then that, I learned some new things and got to see so many of the beautiful mammals. I revised my review when I received a comment from Pier 39 customer service. Thank you for giving me the live feed for these beautiful Sea Lions! pier39.com
author: Nancy R.

description:
A ton of fun. This pier is awesome. I brought my family here last summer and the kids thought it was spectacular. Personally, I had mixed feelings about walking down the pier.

It was dangerously crowded and people were literally everywhere. It was hard to get on the rides and the lines were long (guess who had to wait in line for their family). 

The restaurants on the pier all looked pretty good too. We ended up trying this crepe restaurant and it was pretty good, however there is was absolutely no seating. We walked around trying to find seating for a while but we had no luck. We ended up having the stand and eat.
author: Owen H.

description:
We don't come here often, but when we do we don't take anything for granted.  Love Love visiting this place.

One of the well known area to visit when coming to San Francisco.  There's so much to do here and no matter what time of the year you come here, it's always going to be crowded. Any Tourist will enjoy coming here.

There's lots of places to eat, there's plenty of street shows to see, and and there's unlimited activities to do.  You can take a ferry to Alcatraz.  You can visit Ghirardelli's square.  You can visit Museums.  You can ride a bike or rent go carts and ride near the water.  There are many souvenirs shops.  The view is spectacular.  There are Sea Lions/ Seals along the side of the pier.  It's great for Photographers especially.

They also offer many tour guides here or you can just hop on the double decker bus, horse carriage, or cable cars to get around.
author: Grace L.

description: Pier 39 has a lot of little shops, restaurants, an aquarium, the infamous sea lions that lounge around near the end of the pier, an arcade and large carousel ride, and even some whale watch and Alcatraz tours. It's a great place for tourists when visiting and a definite must-do when visiting here. It's a tourist trap and like most we fell victim to the hype. Totally worth the visit though!
author: Ashley V.

description:
You'll find everything here, California wine tasting room by the water, a bar with local craft beer selection, California fruit mini market, restaurants and lots of name brand shops. It's a great place to go for people watching and relaxing, also we saw so many sea lions hanging out it was the best!! 

From here we walked to fisherman's wharf and there was a lot of entertaining street performers on the way. You can easily spend hours and hours here, we didn't have that kind of time but I'm glad we stopped.
author: Tony D.

description: I hadn't been back here for years, it is quite the equivalent to Navy Pier in Chicago with a lot of chain restaurants and tourist shops.  Close the Alcatraz boats which is where i walked from, it's a nice way to see the island and the bridges from a lively pier which is highly touristy but still a good site.  I tried out the best rated fish restaurant which wasn't too bad.  The seals are a hoot to watch and photograph, just don't swim with them (someone was bitten just after I was there).   They had a moderate sized Christmas tree for the season that seemed a little out of place in the sunny weather.  If you are hailing a drive company from there be sure not to take it from the pickup lane which is very congested with cabs and clueless drivers.
author: Brandon B.

description:
I've been here a few times - the first time being a kid in San Francisco for the first time, visiting the Bay Area with my family.  That's pretty much the demographic of who visits Pier 39, as it's a total tourist spot, with shops and restaurants on the waterfront.  There are a ton of places, advertising tickets for different site attractions, in addition to the several gift shops and eateries here.  I think the first time you visit, it's cool because you have no idea what to expect. 

The place is stacked with several different shops from name brand shops to little gift shops that sell SF key chains and water globes, and chain restaurants and a ton of seafood restaurants.  I think my favorite part of Pier 39 though is seeing the sea lions on the dock.  The locals are so used to it, but I still think it's cool how the sea lions always congregate around here, flopping on each other.  There's even a learning center at the Pier that even talks about the sea lions and local conservation efforts.  There's also plenty of hotels nearby, in case you're looking for lodging nearby and is walking distance to Ghiradelli Square, Fisherman's Wharf, Ferry Building, etc... If you haven't been before, it's worth taking a gander.  If anything - the SF waterfront really just reminds you of how beautiful the Bay Area is, which is reason enough to check out Pier 39.
author: Jacques I.

description: Reading about Pier 39 before coming to SF, I knew locals despised this place because it's a ginormous tourist trap, but as a tourist, you gotta see the sights! The sea lions lounge on the docks here (or shove each other off), there's numerous shops to explore and eateries to delight in. And of course everything in this area is way overpriced. We knew better than to eat here. Can't say there was ever a lull in people. We came here twice, once early morning, and once late in the afternoon and each time it was swarming with people. I can't comment on parking because we walked here from Chinatown, but all the garages we or surface lots we came across advertised at least $10/hr. Yikes.
author: Nikita H.

description: Lots of good restaurants and you can see these funny seal(there is this sign explaining about them but i forgot its exact name) guys(well maybe gals) pushing against each other! They are soooo funny haha it was a good experience. I would love to come and see these guys(again, maybe gals!) playing games :)
author: Kim P.

description:
My girlfriend and I recently spent a weekend in San Francisco; our hotel was very close to Pier 39 and we explored its shops, restaurants and attractions quite extensively. Though Pier 39 offers some evocative views of the ocean (including great photo opportunities of Alcatraz Island), I soon got the impression that it is merely a place that is famous for being famous.

Most of the gift shops sell an eclectic range of tourist-related tat - post cards, plastic souvenirs, shoddy keepsakes. Pier 39 is uncomfortably overcrowded by tourists; I didn't enjoy being there very much at all.
author: Jack W.

description:
It's been two years since I've been to Pier 39 it's been longer than that since I seen the tree lighting when we went last Friday we seen the big tree getting ready to decorate it. Was a lot of people out Pier 39 looks really nice with the lights all the little stores lots of restaurants you can pick what you want to eat down there the best thing is to take a cab don't park they change the parking don't go in the garage because apparently you'll get your car broken into take Uber or cab get off at Pier 39 when ur ready go bk home jump in a cab easy peasy no stress. Thanks for Reading my Review!
~Lizzie~
author: Lizzie G.

description: I had lunch here a couple of weeks ago. Food was OK, but I wouldn't go back. I had a cup of clam chowder which was too thick for my taste. From reviews it seems many people like it this way. I had the steak and crab. Steak was excellent, but the crab was tossed in mayo, with a mayo topping. I probably should have asked and not assumed that my crab would not be covered in so much mayo. Great views, service at the bar was just OK. A fee is added to your bill for the staff.  I don't mind paying, but I don't think it should be taxed plus added to the tip amount.
author: Crystal S.

description: My family of four had fun walking around pier 39. We spent some time watching the sea lions. There are so many shops and restaurants. We went early to beat the crowd.
author: Thao N.

description:
Everything, is so lively here.. a lot of things going on , so places to eat, so much entertainment, activities and so much more.. never, a doll moment here that's for sure.. 
 The thing that sucks, a lot of stores has closed. But hoping businesses will be there soon!!! 
 Recently, found out that the "rainforest cafe" is gone!!!!!! Why did it close!?!?! When they had so much business!! Ugh
author: LeAza D.

description: A very tourist place. This place was super crowded on the weekend and living in California, you want to do things that are not typically a place where the tourist go. We did come here and bought some souvenirs for the folks back home but left do to the crowds.
author: Noel I.

description:
Fun Shops and Sea Lions!!

A must see when in San Francisco, lovely area to wander around with sops and restaurants.
And the sea lions everywhere are great entertainment as well as the great views.
author: Rain B.

description:
It's fun to see Pier 39. Obviously a tourist location, make sure you walk to the end of the pier and see the sea lion colony and view of Alcatraz. 
There are many restaurants and lots of good Clam Chowder to choose from.
Unfortunately the pier has been overtaken with junk shops, but its still a fun place to bring out of town guest.
The kids will love this visit... lots for them and even a carousel.
author: Douglas F.

description: One of the best seafood places in this area of SF, not ridiculous prices compared to some restaurants nearby but a little pricey. Mo provided us with great, friendly service and some local recommendations.
author: Samuel F.

description: I loved this place! So many stores and restaurants! I'd definitely come back. Perfect tourist location. Even if you live here, I'd suggest going at least once. You can look at the sea lions, too. Plus lots of public restrooms, thank goodness.
author: Rachelle L.

description: Not bad but not great either.  Lots to do but very touristy.  We came here to take one of the bay cruises which was very nice.  Just plan for lots of people and ~$20-50 for parking.
author: Kristen G.

description: What can I say, I'm a tourist.... What do tourist do? They buy expensive junks made in China and take a plethora of pictures..... With that in mind, this place is extremely exciting! There are tons of shop and food destinations. I went to most of the shops and I can say that they all pretty much have the same exact thing. A lot of little trinkets and even more clothing. Even though the merchandise is pretty much the same, it was so much fun walking around and looking at everything regardless. Plus, it's good exercise after gorging your face in delicious food. Like I said, everything was pretty pricey, but what tourist hotspot isn't??? I enjoyed my time thoroughly and I will definitely be back.
author: Maile H.

description: Bought clam chowder along with calamari and chips at pier 39. Brought it back to eat at the hotel. Wish we knew there was public bathrooms on the pier than going to jack N the box, having to purchase smthg to get a token for the bathroom.
author: Maum K.

description: Our family loves to visit Pier 39 when we're in the bay area. It happened to be a beautiful and cool but sunny day so walking around outside was perfect. As usual there were tons of people milling about. The stores in this shopping center are also quite nice with lots of food choices and a variety of sellers. Most people like watching the sea lions, which is cool I guess but certainly not my thing. There are also great views of the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz and other bays.
author: F H.

description: The only reason to come here is to see the sea lions.  Make sure to walk to the end of the pier. Otherwise the entire pier is a complete tourist trap filled with mostly chain stores and restaurants and guys trying to sell you tours.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
We stayed nearby Pier 39 and came back here almost every single night. During the day, you can enjoy all the shopping in the mall. You can watch all the sea lions laying around sun bathing or fighting for females. During the evening, you can enjoy the sunset and night view of the entire area including Alcatraz. Prices are a bit steep but expected in the tourist area. 

I'll definitely come back here again.
author: April P.

description:
Personally, I like Pier 39 the best amongst all the piers. There is a little bit of everything for everybody.

Pros:
Kids carousel, even though expensive is a really fun thing. Live comedy/magic act behind the Carousel.
Sea Lions are always a pleasure. It is very rare to have natural wildlife relax without a care of their surroundings so close to human establishments.
Standard touristy items, pearls, restaurants etc. 

Cons:
Parking could be a hassle on weekends.
author: Krishna C.

description:
Nice views of the Bay and a fun place to walk around with your family. 

Food is overpriced but you can pack lunch and eat it while sitting on benches. 

My favorite part is the gigantic Pacman game in the arcade!!
author: Eric P.

description: So sad. This used to be a fun place to visit. Now it is a filthy tourist trap, crowded and junky. I would advise you to avoid it.
author: Mary Lee V.

description: Tourist trap must do.    Plenty of touristy shops and places to grab a bite to eat.    You can kick back and watch the world go by in one of the many restaurants or shop for souvenirs if that's your thing.     I enjoy the Beer 39 spot to grab a beer.   This is also the place to go to see the sea lions.   The pier offers great views of Alcatraz and then bay.
author: Courtney T.

description:
On my first visit to SFO,  I did all things touristy (as one should when you are indeed a tourist).  This included Fisherman's Wharf/Pier 39. 

I was enchanted by the sea lions.  They were so cute,  and very entertaining.  So,  this trip,  I decided to go back.  They did not disappoint.  This review is strictly based on the sea lions. 

With that being said,  I don't know if I would go back to Fisherman's Wharf/Pier 39.  It is extremely touristy,  crowded,  over priced,  with a lot of chain restaurants. 

If you go,  enter the main entrance.  Make your way towards the marina,  and walk around until you see the docks.  Go past Dock G,  towards Dock F.  You should see a crowd of people,  and hear the sea lions.
author: Karen P.

description: We are visiting San Francisco and definitely needed a great seafood experience. Our server, Benjamin, was phenomenal. We was very helpful when we needed help choosing between all the delicious menu options. Unfortunately, Benjamin had very difficult tables on both sides of us. Even though he had to run extra for his demanding clients, he was exceptionally attentive and aware of our needs. Thank you Benjamin for such a great experience and thank you Pier Market for the fresh seafood. Our daughter says Benjamin was "lit".  Highest compliments all around!!
author: Heidi H.

description:
Big crowds. Lots of touristy shops full of tee shirts. Restaurants, coffee and candy. It's two levels of tourist trap with views of Alcatraz and sea lions. 
If you like crowds and over priced souviners you are gonna be wowed by this place. If you don't love a big crowd, waiting for a seat at a restaurant, or paying way too much for anything, don't bother.
author: Jen W.

description:
FOOD choices are busy anywhere you go and pricey but you're paying to eat on prime real estate with a view of the SF bay. Fancy places and less fancy places where you can grab a beer. Carnival type food too like churros, ice cream Ben and Jerry, hot dogs can be bought at kiosk stands. Chocolates and candies too. Bottled water is expensive at these stands so bring your own if you can. 

SHOPPING tourist dream with little souvenir and sports shops. Small boutique type stores with jewelry and candles. 

KIDS can have fun at the carousel and stage at the end of the pier. Also out back have fun gawking at the seals laid out on wood floaters. Beware in the summer months seals migrate south to Mexico so you'll only see a few during this time of year. 

At Christmas there's a big tree near the sidewalk nicely decorated. Street performers and artists entertain the sidewalk all the time. 

BATHROOMS are ok, kinda gross old camping feel. No paper towels just those Dyson blow the skin off your hands dryers. They have some downstairs and some upstairs. I try to go upstairs with the assumption it's less busy. 

PARKING in the city is always hard. You can park outside in the lot or in a structure across the street. Or park along sidewalks and feed a meter then walk to Pier 39 and count up. 

OVERALL I am a fan of Pier 39. They allow dogs to walk around and even have grass areas designated for them although the poop bag dispensers are always empty of course since free plastic bags are rare now. There's stuff to see and enjoy the bay for a day. Definitely bundle up as it gets cold and windy no matter how hot the rest of the city might be.
author: Michelle M.

description:
I thoroughly enjoyed my experience here! The lights lit up the night and guided me onto a pier full of shops and delicious treats! There were several street performers and families all around to participate and enjoy the entertainment. In addition, there are countless places to eat and a a beautiful view of the Bay Bridge in lights! 

I would recommend anyone traveling to San Fransisco to experience a night out at the pier!
author: Jeanee V.

description: Always a good place to come to when visiting SF. Expect parking and food to be expensive. There's is also always a crowd so watch your surrounding.
author: Khiet E.

description:
This is a fake pier built as an amusement park forty years ago and it is tourist sheep-shearing station. It has nothing to do with the industry of the waterfront, with fishing or for that matter, San Francisco. I grew up nearby.

The food is mostly industrial frozen, the real money is made on the outrageous parking charges in the dangerous garage across the street or the corporate owned vendors of Chinese plastic clothing, and if you are interested seeing and meeting the low-lifes of the Bay Area--the kind of women that paint eyebrows on their face with Sharpies and have huge butts, or guys with lots of sports clothing and gang tattoos, plus lots of other bewildered and victimized tourists, Pier 39 is for you. 

If you are from the Midwest and it's the first thing you see of the city, you will probably be impressed, and write perhaps a great review, but please know that more authentic, cheaper experiences, plus far better food, is available further west toward Taylor Street. 

That said, the views of the bay, the proximity to the sea lions and the tourist boat rides are worth while. Just don't spend any money at the pier itself. You can buy far better food down at the real Fisherman's Wharf at the foot of Taylor Street, then take it to Pier 39 and enjoy the scenery.
author: Chris D.

description: This is one of my fave places to visit in San Fran. There is so much going on all in one great spot. Everything is within walking distance from here. I'm sad last time I didn't realize everything was all here but glad the second time I found EVERYTHING. Just a short walk from where we parked, we made it to Pier 39 and found the cute sea lions barking away on the side of the pier. There is also the Heart of San Francisco o display at the end of the pier. We also saw an entertainer performing, there are multiple shops and restaurants as well as little snack shops. Just a great mix of variety. Something for everyone for sure. All my kids have enjoyed this pier. It is definitely on my list for every visit. I'm sure there are other things I'm forgetting to mention but I definitely have the great memories. We will be back soon! PS-next trip I must remember to bring a lock for the fence.
author: Pam M.

description: Very busy part of San Fran. No shortage of good food options, entertainment, and wild life. Come with an empty stomach and a stuffed wallet. You'll be happy you had both.
author: Chris G.

description:
The busiest if all the piers along the waterfront. You won't miss it because you will see the blue flags bearing it's name waving from afar. 

The only pier with a second floor which can be accessed either via escalator or going on foot through the red wooden stairway. I chose the latter. The second floor gives you a better view of the area. The tourist information center is also located here. By checking in yelp, you will get a free fun pack with the map of the area, schedule of events, and coupons for different establishments. 

While visiting, there was a van promoting the upcoming Tarzan movie. We saw people lining up for #tarzanexperience so we did the same. We found out that you will be allowed to get inside the van which was decorated in forest theme. A camera is inside which will take 4 sets of pictures that you can either text or email to yourself for free. It was kinda cool. 

There's also a mini amusement park at the back of the pier where a carousel and other rides are. Going a bit further, you will see sea lions by the dock.
author: Cris I.

description:
Tons of things to do here! You got the restaurants, you got the stores, you got the cruises, you name it, they most likely have it. Very cool area and very touristy in this area. Be prepared to walk a distance if you have to park your car and if you don't want to pay the high price points of parking. 

On a clear day you can see Alcatraz island clearly and it's very pretty
author: Magz K.

description:
It's the pier-  tourist spot and yes it gets cold .
I alway go here even being a local for so long now ... it s like doing a staycation.
author: Victor D.

description: Parking is super expensive. Recommend getting on public transit. You can spend whole day here on a sunny day. Restaurants here caters to different tastes and classes. You can get a good close view of seals. Carnival style entertainment for any little ones in your group. Food is affordable. Street paintings, dance and music. Few ferry rides start here.
author: Yugi M.

description:
I've been coming to Pier 39 since I was very young! Such a fun place! 

It is beautifully located on the bayside of SF. There are many "piers", but this one is the best and most fun. 

There are a lot of shops, restaurants and entertainment located here. Some are more touristy than others. However, it is fun for locals and tourists. 

One of my favorite things about Pier 39 is seeing the seals... so many seals! They are fun to watch.

One of my MOST favorites is the Bush Man.. haha. He has been scaring people since I was young... decades! He hides in a bush and jumps out to scare people. When I was younger we would watch from the distance and it was hilarious. He has his own Yelp page, so check it out haha.
author: Summer C.

description: Amazing pier with lots of food/ attractions/ stores/ gift shops/ overall shopping area to offer  I love how it's so close to the bay and the boats are viewable on the deck :)) at night lights come out and the winter decorations really start to kick in
author: Joanne D.

description: This is probably the most tourist heavy area of San Francisco. Most of the shops here at Pier 39 are small little souvenir type stuff and many of the stores are nationwide chains you'd find in other similar tourist centers in popular cities. Come here once to say you were at Pier 39, but there are better and more interesting areas of San Francisco to explore.
author: Karen W.

description:
Wow ah wow!  Can one believe is or been twenty eight years that our famous Sea Lion Friends been coming to the Pier 39!  They at Pier 39 now having twenty eighth anniversary to celebrate!  There been docent talks, one can take guided tours!  Sea Lions are great!  They in the pinneped family, that be seals, walruses, sea lions!  Wow, is now twenty eight years our famous Sea Lion Friends been coming to here at the Pier 39! They always quite so entertaining!  They very loud, they use one another as pillows!  Many times they fight as say since they use one another as pillows, they just need find space for themselves when on the pier!  I have seen some sea lion pups, but mostly just the Adults are on the Pier 39!

Yay Pier 39!  Yay for our Sea Lion Friends that enjoy visiting!  May they all continue to visit here at Pier 39 for many more of years to come!
author: Karyn C.

description: Stopped in several stores and shopped around and had a wonderful time down at the Pier 39 area. Highly suggest everyone to stop and see all the sites.
author: Gail H.

description:
Parking: There is a parking lot across the street and I have never had a problem finding a spot. I think it may be pricey but everywhere in the city, you will have to pay for parking so you should expect that anyway.

Food: I love Bubba Gump's. It's a classic and you can never go wrong. I have been there countless times and all the main dishes are delicious! I also really enjoy Aunt Fanny's Hot Pretzels for a quick snack. Fog Harbor's is also very good - there may be a wait but it's worth it!! If you have a sweet tooth, there are candy and chocolate stores that have a variety of sugary treats :D

Sights: Aquarium of the Bay is fun, especially for the kiddies. There's also a sea lion center that is pretty cool. I still have not tried the 3D experience but I will soon - there's always a Groupon/Living Social deal for that! There are sailing or bike tours that you can rent/buy - if it's a nice day, definitely take advantage of that. 

This is also where the huge heart (where tons of people take instagram pictures) is. Lolz.
author: Brittany R.

description: I was on a business trip to San Francisco and I wanted to get in the essentials. Pier 39 has been on every "San Francisco to experience" list so I knew I had to go check it out. This place is very touristy and the shops and activities there very much cater to them. It gets very crowded, even on a Tuesday evening when I was there. That said, there are lots to eat and experience there. I saw some interesting specialty shops there and of course there is an endless supply of eats available. There are a number of seafood places (appropriately themed with the Pier) as well as other food options. There is a carousel toward the end of the pier as well as the seals that inhabit the side of the pier which is an attraction on its own. At the end of the pier offers some great views of Alcatraz. I would definitely recommend this place to everyone, at least for a stroll through like I did. If I had more time, I may have stopped in more of the shops as they did have some unique ones and maybe even sample more of the food there. I wouldn't plan on spending a day there, well maybe if you add in the aquarium and the entire wharf area. But for the pier itself I would think a 1 hours stroll, add an hour for activities and maybe another hour if you plan to eat there. FYI I ended up taking an Uber there, but I was told that the cable car goes there. I tried to return using the cable cars (Market Street Car) but the stop was very crowded and it is hard to get on at that stop, especially if you have bags, strollers or other bulky items with you.
author: Jason P.

description: Pier 39 is a hot spot for tourist. Great place to eat fresh seafood and to shop for souvenirs. There's also entertainment and performances randomly throughout the day. It is also within walking distance to the Aquarium of the Bay and Alcatraz Cruises. I remember coming here a couple of times when I was a kid and man did everything looked twice as big and crowded. But everything seems big and crowded when you are little. This hot spot is still crowded and full of people that are enjoying their time. It's fun both day and night. I ended up taking my boy friend since it was his first time visitng here. He was in awe of the beautiful landmark of Pier 39. Overall, great spot to visit for your first time in San Francisco!
author: Natasha N.

description: Great ending to a trip to San Fran. Highly recommended any visitors to stop by and enjoy the sights!
author: Eviana D.

description:
Come in to the visitor center on the second floor to get your fun pack before you buy or do anything here. There's coupons, specials, and freebies.

Pier 39 is full of shops, little tiny food places, restaurants, and much more. You can see the sea lions, in all their fat glory. 

Very very very touristy, but there's a reason for it. Go get samples, enjoy life, and wander around. It's fun.
author: Victoria M.

description:
Hey you!  Are you looking at Yelp to see if you should visit Pier 39? Why are you even on here? You already know if you're visiting SF for the first time that this is the MUST on every Bay area Bucketlist.

YES- its filled with tourists on any given day. YES- most stores are probably over priced. YES- its a cliche tourist spot. But it IS a Bay Area Landmark and destination known around the world.

Sitting right next to the Fisherman's Wharf and Ghirardelli square. There would be no excuses for anyone NOT to stop by Pier 39. 

I always come here when i visit with new friends because its great for photos. I consider this a great place to shop if you're looking for SF type souvenirs its a one stop shop for all things SF, chocolate and random gift things. 

From the pier you also get a great view of Alacatraz and the Sea lions.

If youre thinking about going here. Just go. You get: Fishermans Wharf, Ghirardelli Square, Pier39 and even a cable car ride all in one. Best to spend one whole day here!
author: Michelle M.

description:
Pier 39 is a very cool San Francisco attraction. As you approach you will undoubtedly pass a number of sidewalk performers and artists.   If you walk down the right side you can view all the boats in the yacht club harbor.  If you walk down the left side you can see a bunch of sea lions sunning themselves of floating docks and a ton of interesting sea lion facts posted on the wall.  This nature show is one of the few things to do without paying an admission.
  
Walk down the center of Pier 39 and you are where it all happens.  Tourists and locals are all converging on the live entertainment at the end of the pier.   You can visit some of the coolest shops and eateries around.  The Wipeout Bar & Grill is not to be missed.  Many shops sell souvenirs, clothing, jewelry, ornaments, artwork, wine, snacks.  On the upper Level is more shops, restaurants and a place dedicated to sea lions.

Go on a nice evening with someone you love, plan to spend a few hours of dining and shopping, take some pictures of Alcatraz Island, The Golden Gate Bridge and a selfie of the two of you kissing in front of the giant Heart.
author: Rich C.

description:
You want it? You got it!

This should be a stop on your northern California vacation!

Although touristy and a bit overwhelming at times, you must stop. Seriously, take the guests that you might have to this weird wonderland to pick up their shirts and sweatshirts emblazoned with all things NorCal! Plus, you can watch people do strange things that they only do on vacation!

Walk down to visit the sea lions, but be sure to plug your nose. Also, make sure to take a picture of the Golden Gate bridge, Alcatraz, and the Bubba Gump Shrimp Company!!

We love San Francisco!!
author: Jason B.

description:
Pier 39 is great! I moved to the Bay Area earlier this year and this is one of the first places a friend brought me. I come back regularly to grab a bite to eat pretty often. It's a very high traffic spot, but both tourists and locals will fit right in. When my family comes to visit my house from the east coast, they like to visit the heart of downtown SF and this Pier. So if you're looking for a nice spot to get food, or to bring company from out of town, or even you yourself are from out of town, I highly recommend it.

Also the Sea Lions area is pretty cool. I've never seen Sea Lions gathered in one place like here, and supposedly they've been gathering there for many years! Nice!
author: Kevin R.

description: Neat place for first time visits to San Francisco. It is jammed packed with stores that if you bought something from there will almost always never be worn or used once you get back home. More then likely you will donate it or put it up for sale on an app. Unless you have a horrible hoarding problem and in which case, welcome home! Lol just kidding. This place is like pigeon forge or that other hoaky place in Montana. If you have kids they may get a kick out of this place and they have a large gang of seals over on the left side of the pier. Go see it, just to say you have been to the fisherman's wharf.
author: Moses H.

description: This pier couldn't be more cool! So many cool restaurants and shops. Loved hanging out there while we were in town. The seals are as axing as you could imagine. Such a good atmosphere. Would have loved to spend more time there.
author: Bill J.

description:
It was my first time in San Francisco, so I had to check out Pier 39.   Yes, it is super touristy, but I was a first time tourist.  Masses and masses of people on a Friday afternoon.   

The highlight for me by far was the sea lions.   I could have stayed and watched them all day.    The masses of people were also sea lion watching.  The view was much better from the upstairs deck.  

We ate at Pier 39 and shopped for some souvenirs as well.   

I'm glad I visited and would again.
author: Karen S.

description:
It's an awesome place to people watch, window shop, eat and just hang out.
The weather was fine. It was an amazingly summer-like winter day when I went. Blue skies, not a cloud in the sky. 
There's Ben and Jerry's - My weakness, tonnes of restaurants (clam chowder in the infamous sourdough), coffees shops, ice creams amd chocolate shops.
Lots of interesting shops to wander in, souvenirs and random stuff too. And of course, the allegedly world famous sea lions were all sun bathing.
There's a great view of the golden bridge from the pier and also the alcatraz (didn't seem far to swim for those prison escapees!)
There are other touristy stuff like boat riding too. The queue was pretty long. 
For those who drive, there's a huge car park next to it. The walk from downtown was about 30-40 minutes and it was very pleasant.
author: Jenn H.

description:
Pier 39 is a great an excellent place to visit when touring around San Francisco. On the pier you will find plenty of restaurants of all kinds and price ranges. Lots of souvenir shops with the $10 t-shirts and pretty much anything you can think of with a SF logo on it. 

You can find a good place to eat no doubt, especially the famous clam chowder sourdough bowls. Plenty of chocolate from Ghirardelli and sports gear from the local teams. 

The views are great too. Walk to the end and see Alcatarz island. Turn to the left and you see the Golden Gate Bridge, to the right you can see the Bay Bridge. Overall a very nice view of the bay on a clear day.  

Parking is a whopping $27. I was not a fan of that :( - that puts this place right under the category of tourist trap. And plenty of tourist you will see. But hey when in Rome...

A short walk down the street you will find more seafood places to eat, and evern further the Ghiradelli chocolate company. An easy walk if you are up for it. 

I usually always make my way to Peir 39 when I visit the city.
author: John E.

description:
Ok, Pier 39 is super-touristy, but it's still a fun place to check out! Lined with so many shops and restaurants, just walking through the storefronts is an experience on its own. Sure, most stuff here are overpriced but hey, it is free to eye them! No matter what you do though, don't forget to check out the sea lion at the pier end that is filled with their barking. If you do not intend to eat here, you should be able to see the entirely within an hour. Definitely worth a quick visit if you are in the San Francisco area!

---
PARKING: Pier 39 parking can be expensive and problematic. The most convenient parking is the garage, but without restaurant validation, the hourly rate can get ridiculous. For a quick visit, your best bet on cheap parking is a block away on North Point Street - Check your options first there too, because one block difference on North Point can be a $2 hourly rate difference as well! Rates are also especially cheaper before 11 AM.
author: Jay Y.

description:
Who doesn't like this place. Being that I live in Hayward, it's okay to blend in with the crowd and play tourist on the weekend :) There are actually some great places here to eat and a nice video game arcade that the kids can enjoy with their parents. 

Tourist trap for sure but will leave you in a refreshed feeling that you got out of the house and enjoyed the scenery and the crowd here.
author: Jason C.

description: There's quite a few restaurants to choose from, and there are some great views. Right before you get to pier 39 there are a few performers entertaining the crowd that ask for tips. I saw a painter that did really good work and had pumped up music playing. Once at pier 39 you will also find arcade games and small rides. Unfortunately the days I went the rides were closed due to rain, but that is to keep people safe. There were also tons of little shops for shopping for souvenirs. Tons to do for sure and can easily spend a few hours here walking around and enjoying the views.
author: Brenda R.

description: We loved the sealions.They were so cute, it was fun watching them. All the shops there were cool to check out. We will definitely go back when we have more time.
author: Amy J.

description: 4 stars because the Sea Lions are 5 stars, and all the other parts of Pier 39 would be a 2 star tourist trap-don't recommend. But the Sea Lions make up for everything else, and I'd recommend this place just for that reasons.  One of my favorite things in San Francisco that's a must do for an out of towner, and though I rarely go on my frequent Bay Area business trips, I will once in a long while and it never gets old watching them bark at each other, jump out of the water and climb all over the other sleeping sea lions who in turn bark at them, etc.  Sometimes there's a lot of them, sometimes there aren't....either way, it's worth the quick stop especially if you're an animal lover.
author: Ryan B.

description: As far as Piers go...this is #39 in SF. That being said, it is pretty popular and packed with tourist. If you love crowds, tourists that don't know what there doing, over priced things and seeing the sea doggos then this is the place to be...if not...well then you don't love sea doggos.
author: Andrew M.

description: Whenever I come to San Francisco, pier 39 is a my go to if I want to relax, eat, and shop a bit. Got to do some wine tasting and also to see walruses. Gets crowded all the time, but this what makes it lively. I recommend coming early in the morning to get the chance to explore everhthing on the pier without having to deal with alot of people. All the family friends enjoying their time visiting the piers. Great place for tourist attraction. Lots of entertainment and plenty of things to do. Of course being by the pier alot of places would be over priced, especially with resturants.
author: Ryan N.

description:
Review #100! Or One Hunnit if you're talking slag and wanna sound like a "G" Man this review is a long overdue one. But now is better than later. Let's get to talking about Pier 39 a little bit shall we....

Pier 39 is right off the Embarcadero, it's not the last of the piers which starts at the Port of San Francisco and goes on down. But out of the piers, "39" is like the main attraction and the excitement grows as you inch closer and closer on your journey down the piers. Pier 39 is a hotspot for tourists and even your adverage Californian alike. It's been very rare I've found myself here and it's not had a crowd of people partaking in the many little fun things you can do here.

It's full of many little nice shops where you can purchase souvenirs and trinkets to take back to your homestate "if you're from out of town or country" and they have a nice food selection for those foodies out there. Be it a famous Chowder Bowl from Boudin, or some select dish from the Hard Rock Cafe. Or kicking it with Mr Gump eating some of Bubbas famous "Shrimp" at Bubba Gumps. This place has got it all.

The place has something for everyone. The arcade here is pretty cool, parents can give their kids some tokens and let them have at it while they visit either the sports bar or tiki bar attached. Almost like having a Dave and Busters on a smaller scale close to you. Plus for parents you aren't far from your children.

In closing, Pier 39 is an experience. And to be honest doesn't end just there. Somewhere the whole family can enjoy. Be it you're a local or out of towner. Stop by, stay close to one another and have a great time here and Yelp your experience!
author: Tre S.

description:
This is a standard tourist attraction that we take all of our out-of-town guests to - even though we've been here countless times, it somehow never gets old for me! (Can't say the same about my husband, though, lol)

I'm glad the sea lions still come around - it's definitely one of the best things at the Pier! The entertainment stage usually hosts interesting acts, and there are lots of restaurants to choose from. The only thing I haven't been to is the Aquarium...perhaps next time??
author: Cathy W.

description:
It's a tourist trap full of mediocre places to eat and drink. The best thing about this place is the Sea Lion park :-)) it's quite a big complex with lots of choices around the pier. 

It's busy and tons of people here during the day. As a tourist you will probably end up here and, end up eating or drinking here :-) 

There is a money exchange here that is a total rip off but if you are desperate for cash you can exchange here.
author: Sam S.

description:
WARNING: TOURISTS / FAMILIES 

Do NOT park at Pier 39 parking garage. 6 cars was broken into this lot and securities did not do anything but watch our cars been broken into. The security is obviously part of this scene if they're letting this happen to their own customers. 

Think before you want to park here!
author: Angelica A.

description:
As far as tourist attractions go, this one has a few redeeming qualities, but it is crowded and expensive. 

Came here to meet up with a friend from Omaha, which was a highlight.

The views are great, particularly at sunset. 

We stopped at several places I'll review separately, but here are the highlights:

7D Experience - 4 Stars
Chocolate Heaven - 4 Stars
Fog Harbor Restaurant - 3 Stars
Wines of California - 3 Stars
Musee Mecanique (Pier 45) - 5 Stars
author: Scott N.

description: Pier 39 is so much fun. Great food, shopping, and sightseeing. It is one of the livelier areas of SF. Great for family fun.
author: Shenna J.

description: I went to Alcatraz, and decided to walk down to Pier 39 on my way back to pick up a couple of souvenirs to bring back home. Honestly, I didn't make it that far. It was a swarm of people, tour buses, and after a few minutes of fighting the crowds, I left. The whole pier area was very cool, and I'd like to come back sometime when it isn't as busy.
author: Adam S.

description: A major staple in San Francisco! How do you not love this place? It's one of my go-to places for food and just to hang with family every once in a while. It does get packed because it is a tourist spot so I try to avoid going here during prime time which is the weekend. There are some new shops that are opening and I can't wait to check them out. You must check each shop out since it's unique. The foods here are amazing. I love Fog Harbor, Trish's donuts, and Boudin. The candy shops are sweet spots to check out. A staple to check out here are the infamous seals. They are loud. I highly recommend people to check this place out and be prepared to spend. I almost spend some sort of money everytime I am here. I will be back soon. I was just here during the holiday's before the tree lighting and it was beautiful. I love the decorations. It definitely brings the holiday spirits. Parking is tough, if you find street parking be prepared to walk, otherwise you will have to park at the parking garage across and pay. You can get the ticket validated at the stores in pier 39.
author: Danika P.

description:
Definitely a tourist trap but do you blame the beautiful scenery yes some stores will be pricey as well as food but it's worth the experience dined at bubba gump excellent , next day dined at wipe out . . There's so much to see I love everything, if you come visit pier 39 for the experience, take lots of pictures and try new things it's been the best vacation I finally can check it off my bucket list been here since 8/9/17-hopefully til Sunday .

(tipsters) very windy
 wear jacket, sweats, beanie gloves lol
 park away from pier causes it's very expensive if you park at the garage $10/hr
author: Nina S.

description:
Even just to see sea lions deserves a visit but there are definitely more to see:

- Alcatraz cruises and sunset cruises depart here
- There is a Hard Rock Cafe
- A carousel
- Live music bands or performers to watch
- Maaaaany food options ( 3 star places mostly) 
- Gift shops
- Lefty's store for left handed folks :)
- Chocolate & Fudge stores! 
- Public restrooms :)))
- A shark aquarium 
- Boudin Bakery (but it is a small one, check the one 2-3 blocks from here)
- A sock store :) But they do not carry 100% cotton pairs.(Just in case you have a picky brother like mine.)
- Hot Licks! Crazy hot sauce store.

Long story short, very centrally located pier, walking distance to Coit Tower, Explotorium, 20-30 bike ride to Golden Gate,etc.
author: Ceren A.

description:
Oh man, I haven't been here in forever since it's just so touristy, crowded, and seemingly overrated. To me, Pier 39 seemed like a one and done kind of place, in that once you go once you're good to go. 

However, I took my parents here for their first time over Thanksgiving weekend, and it was actually quite nice. Don't get me wrong - it is definitely very touristy and crowded - especially during the holidays. That being said, it is enjoyable and pleasant to walk around if you don't have to drive and park. It'll definitely get you in the holiday spirit with the holiday music and huge Christmas tree. Plus, I didn't realize how many specialty stores there are (e.g., cap store, sock store, magnet store, lefty store, etc.)!

Also, for all your Pokemon trainers out there this spot is LIT with Poke stops, lures galore, and tons of Pokemon!
author: Phoebe C.

description:
One of the best things to do at Pier 39 besides visiting the aquarium is to go on a boat tour ride with Captain Ryan (beforeyoudieguy on Instagram).

He is nice and knowledgeable and make you safe. Have fun!
author: Tony N.

description: 5 - Been here several times over the decade. This is my family's go-to location in SF and I can't be more happy about it. Many say this place is a tourist trap; I agree, except only some parts are a tourist trap. The food here? $$$. The drinks here? $$$. The souvenirs here? $. The view here? $$$$$$. There are sea lions super close by the outer parts of the pier. Come here! It's everything SF in one place. You won't be disappointed.
author: Shirley N.

description: There's always so many things going on at Pier 39. Street arts, magic shows, and a lot more. It was such a popular spot for pokemon go players as well. I love coming here just for a walk when I have time. Love it.
author: Rosalie H.

description: Very crowded on Saturday. Fun things for kids to do with street vendors and arcades. Bathroom wait times are long.
author: Jennifer R.

description: This Landmark destination of San Francisco has almost no limits. Restaurants to tours to music it's got a little bit of everything. You can go check out the sea lions, or go on different ferries to visit different things, even speed boat trips
author: Matt B.

description:
Busy place but worth the stop. 

Pier 39 has just about everything for a tourist.  There are a ton of dining choices, shops and a brilliant view.  There is also a double decker carousel about half way down.  

When you walk to the west side of the pier, there sits a sea lion haven of docks.  While we were there only about 3 of the floating docks had sea lions covering them.  But it's still a sight to see.  They are more than happy to pose for a picture! 

At the end of the pier lies a perfect view of Alcatraz Island. On a sunny day it really is gorgeous.  

Tourist trap? Yes.  Would I go again? Absolutely.
author: Bethany E.

description:
Must visit when in the City!

Nice place to visit no matter where you're from on the globe. I'm only two hours away from San Francisco but I always enjoy coming here. Never gets old. It's usually always crowded but there are times when Pier 39 really gets super crowded like during Game 2 of the NBA Finals on June 7th when we decided to visit. It was a home game (Warriors vs Cavs) and San Francisco must have been filled with Cavaliers fans the day before the home game. Super crowded! There are lots of entertainment and food spots as well as souvenir shops. Many street performers too. Believe it or not, there are world-famous San Francisco Street Performers that perform here live and they can be found entertaining the crowd at the Bay End of Pier 39.

Been here a few times just to break away from the summer heat in the Valley. Watched the sea lions, dined a few times at the Pier Market Seafood Restaurant and if you do decide to have lunch (or dinner) here you must try their award-winning clam chowder! They do have indoor and outdoor seating (http://www.yelp.com/biz/pier-market-seafood-restaurant-san-francisco?hrid=8hw9Qx8IQ2P8I0U79Uy9yA&page_src=shared_via_messages_or_emails).  We've tried the 7D Experience and killed a few zombies by laser guns (http://www.yelp.com/biz/7d-experience-san-francisco?hrid=C_nEm17RfEwKoBL_uKasbg&page_src=shared_via_messages_or_emails) in their DarkRide attraction. Lots of gift shops from a magnet store to speciality gift shops such as the Alcatraz Gift Shop and Bubba Gump Shrimp Co. Gift Shop... because life is like a box of chocolates in this Forrest Gump-themed gift store :)

Before heading out there to San Francisco check out the Pier 39 website and print your coupon of Savings Fun Pack to redeem at the California Welcome Center. They are open from 9:00a to 7:00p everyday (except for major Holidays, I'm assuming). It's FREE and has discounts to many of the shops, restaurants and attractions at Pier 39, and two hours of free parking in the Pier 39 Parking Garage. 

I still have yet to visit the Aquarium of the Bay. I wonder if it is as big as Monterey Bay Aquarium. Just a few minutes walk to Pier 45 you can also tour a part of history, the USS Pampanito (http://www.yelp.com/biz/uss-pampanito-san-francisco?hrid=5mgYE5jC5lbpupOylkg8Vw&page_src=shared_via_messages_or_emails). Anyway, make Pier 39 a must on your list of your things to do in San Francisco. It is a tourist hot spot so bring enough money to accommodate dining and activities you plan to do for the day. There are ATM machines provided here as well. We enjoy playing tourists here sometimes. San Francisco Pier 39 is just a place like no other :)

Review #0302
author: May A.

description: Enjoyed the vibes here, definitely is the parallel to Pike place market in Seattle! There's more bustling people and even street musicians that fit the mood well so I enjoyed that.  Food at every corner! Eat away
author: Sandra N.

description:
Pier 39, probably the most famous area in the bay area!!!

This place has so many things to do and it is always busy!!!! So bring a lot of patience for big crowds!!! Parking is probably the worst part which can run you about $25 in the parking garage! 

Anyways you will probably spend a couple hours here so plan for it accordingly!

There are crepes, souvenir shops, fun house mirrors, restaurants, ice cream shops, magnet shops, sea lions, shows, 7d attractions, live music, seagulls stealing food!

If you want to see the best spots I'd suggest getting a clam chowder, see the sea lions, merry go round, watch a free show, 7D attraction, fun house mirror maze, and maybe if you want....the aquarium!

It is right near the water leading up to the ocean so it does get really chilly! Bring a jacket!!!

Even after you are finished with the pier just end west on embarcadero with more restaurants and more stores! This is a tourist trap so things that usually costs about 2 dollars will cost 5 or 6 dollars so be careful here and know there are food just like 5 mins away!
author: Jason H.

description:
Touristy and parking is a nightmare.

However, this is one of the premier landmarks that everyone should go when visiting San Francisco.  Always being a light jacket or hoodies if you want to walk around after dusk.

All sorts of shops and restaurants and an awesome two deck merry go round.  You can see Alcatraz across the water along with the Golden Gate.  Very pretty place but it'll definitely put a dent in your wallet.
author: Ben H.

description:
When my boyfriend takes me to San Francisco, I love the chance to come to this area to shop and eat.  There are quite a few unique stores here including ones that focus on Ireland, Fantasy, Kites, being left-handed. Rock n' Roll (the Hard Rock Cafe), and much more.  Among the stores are touristy shops as well.  Sure the prices at these shops can generally be pricey and can be tourist traps at times, but there are a few deals you can find.  

There is a variety of restaurants but the majority are pricey.  My favorite restaurants are the Hard Rock Cafe and the Wipe Out.  But these are popular restaurants and on the weekends, you may need to wait a while before you can get seated to eat.

Along the back of the main building, you can watch the lazy sea lions lounge and make burping noises.  It is always a popular thing for tourists to see when they come here.  I enjoy seeing it too but have to admit, they remind me of a group of overly drunk people that are hanged over.  LOL!!!

There is a huge visitor's center with lots of free brochures regarding towns in Northern California mostly but also of other parts of the state.  There are staff there that are always willing to help answer your questions.

There is a newsletter that you can subscribe to through email that sends you monthly notices regarding events.  In the summertime, there are great deals and discounts available for the local parking garage, restaurants and shops.  

Pros:
-has an e-newsletter that sends monthly emails regarding events
-lots of unique shops and restaurants
-great place to watch sea lions
-lots of events through out the year
-conveniently located on the edge of Fisherman's Wharf
-has a huge and helpful visitor's center
-the aquarium at the pier is a fun, educational experience
-fun to come here during Christmas time with they have elaborate decorations 

Cons:
-much merchandise at the stores and the food at restuarant are generally expensive
-souvenir stores can be tourist traps

If you want to find out more about the specific places I like to go at this pier, check out my reviews on:
-the visitor's center
-Hard Rock Cafe
-Wipe Out
-Forbes Island
-the SF Bay Aquarium
author: Irene S.

description:
It's like Times Square in NYC:  you have to see it if you're first time there but all of the people and consumerist schlock will drive you out of your mind within an hour or so....

So here's a tip no one tells you:  for $5, you can walk upstairs to the Visitors Office and leave your bags until they close at 6:30pm!!! That way, you're not hauling all of your crap up and down the Embaradero, onto the trolleys and Alcatraz/harbor tour boats all day long.  (If you're wondering what crap you might have if you've only brought your wallet, you will soon be laden down with a giant paper bag full of Boudin breads shaped like trolleys and teddy bears, ghiradelli chocolate gifts, take out frozen clam chowders, Peets coffee gifts, etc).  Very inconvenient while touring.
author: Dawn V.

description: A must stop by if you are in SF doing the tourists thing.  Summer time forget it... no parking, crowds of people, and very overwhelming.  Great food places and  CRAB CRAB CRAB.  Everywhere you turn there is another restaurant with CRAB.  We went a few weeks ago (summertime) and the wait at 3 different restaurants was over an hour and a half.  We ended up at Fisherman's Wharf.  Fun for everyone in the family.  If your in town, don't let my review stop you from stopping in.  Just trying to prepare you.
author: Ashley W.

description:
Pier 39 has been my happy place since I was a kid. I remember coming here as a child to see the sea lions. A visit to SF is not complete without coming to Pier 39.   It is a popular tourist shopping center and attraction built on a San Francisco pier with shops, restaurants, a video arcade, street performances, the Aquarium of the Bay, virtual 3D rides, and views of California sea lions hauled out on docks on Pier 39's marina. The marina is home to the floating Forbes Island restaurant. Love the two-story carousel is one of the pier's more popular features. I am a left handed so the famous store Lefty's is a Left-handed haven for original kitchen tools, basic school supplies, musical instruments & more.  I get my favorite sweet treats like mini cinnamon sugar donuts at Trish's Mini Donuts, yummy flavors at the Fudge House, Banana Nutella Crepe at The Crepe Café, taffy at Candy Baron.  Some of the best seafood places  I have eaten at are at Pier 39 like Pier Market and the Crab House.  Fun group dining spots like Bubba Gump and Hard Rock Café. 

A popular spot to take pictures is at the end of the pier with a good view of Alcatraz Island, the Golden Gate Bridge and the Bay Bridge. It is a fun place to visit for your and old alike.  This place is definitely a must see in SF.  Even as a local I love coming here! 5 stars!
author: Maria M.

description:
I love being a tourist even if it means fighting crowds.

Pier 39 is a must tourist spot in SF. I mean, it's FREE to walk around, see the shops (mostly eateries), take a selfie with the Alcatraz and the Golden Gate in the background, hear the seals make funny noises...

There's lots of places where you can get clam chowder, and just sweets in general

Many parking lots validate with restaurant purchase.

Enjoy!
author: Silvia G.

description: Day trip to SF?  Unless you like huge crowds of tourists and the kind of street performers they attract, the only reason to go to Fisherman's Wharf would be for the view of Alcatraz, the food options, the iconic sign for a photo-up an, my favorite: Pier 39, home to the silly sea lions, who I can watch for half an hour without get bored, even though they don't do much.  They sleep, they bark, wiggle their whiskers, and scratch themselves.  Basically they're my dad.
author: Glen N.

description: Pier 39 is one of the greatest tourist destinations in the great city of San Francisco. It is a lovely place to visit on a sunny off day (Monday-Thursday). The weekends can be a bit much at Pier39 as there are a ton of people, limited parking in the garage, and wait times at restaurants and activities. I have stopped at a few restaurants, the 4D experience, the aquarium, and the donut shop-- all linked to/connected to Pier39. I think it's a place you tour to say you did it; however, SF has so much to offer you probably won't make the trip to Pier39 more than once.
author: Allison J.

description:
Sure it's a tourist trap but there is nothing wrong with being a tourist and there is some fun stuff here.  Lots of wine bars, restaurants, shops, etc. It's also the point of departure for ferries to Alcatraz and the North Bay.

 I first visited first back in 2004 when I was just visiting the Bay Area to see a friend; now that I live here I seldom venture to this area but I went to meet some out of town friends back in July and I continue to regard this area with a certain affection.  Some great views and a nice place to take friends from out of town since they will always want to see this.

It does tend to get crowded and it's not the place to go to get a sense of "real San Francisco"...but that does not mean it's a bad place or should be avoided.  Just be sure that it's not the only stop on your itinerary when you visit...wander south into North Beach/Chinatown AND/OR West towards Fort Mason, Crissy Field, the Palace of Fine Arts, and the Presidio...these areas feel much more uniquely San Francisco to me.
author: Alan S.

description:
BEAUTIFUL !!!!!!!!!!!
SPLENDID!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! 

They have tours coming out from this pier. To take pictures at this place is wonderful. In the morning is good to go because there is not a lot of people in between 8-10am but after that BOY does it get crowded. They have a lot of deals on souvenirs.
author: Jannie M.

description: I must say, out of all the Piers I've been to, San Francisco can claim this! Pier 39 is the real deal! Just as what you would like to imagine a pier port, boardwalk type of place to be ... this is it.  Quaint, the size is just right.  The shop selections just perfect.  even the, quality of shops and cafes and restaurants. yes, i would say it's really meant more for the tourists.. But even the locals can truly enjoy this haven. The prices in the smaller kiosks are more outrageous than the prices in a regular restaurant.  which is pretty funny.  But that's a tip you guys need to know.  Here's an example.. a Nathans hotdog cost $3.95/ dog, a Dreyers one scoop cone is $5.95 make it a waffle cone its $6.95... That's the ballpark price.  you go to a regular restaurant,  an entree is between $15-$25... which is basically a price for a regular fare everywhere you go.  so there.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
Review for 6/17/16

I highly recommend visiting Pier 39 at least once if you ever visit San Francisco.  It is very easy to spend a good amount of time here.  There are tons of dining options, from sit-down restaurants, like Bubba Gump's, to hot dog stands and small crêpe shops.  

One of the things I really enjoyed is the number of tourist-y shops with super inexpensive souvenirs, with deals like $2.99 hats and 3 for $10 t-shirts.  They also have a ton of specialty souvenir shops, including a hat store, a sock store, and a magnet store.

There are also really great views of Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz from the pier.  Don't forget to stop by and see the iconic Pier 39 sea lions!

There are definitely lots of sights to see and things to do here, so be sure to plan enough time here!
author: Marissa J.

description: The Fisherman's Wharf along with Pier 39 was the first place my husband and I visited when we arrived in San Francisco. It was a nice experience and lots to see with good food It's shops, restaurants, souvenir shops, tour places and etc. While here we visited he Aquarium of the Bay. That was a nice experience. The Aquarium isn't too big but big enough. It was definitely a nice experience and I will enjoy telling people that I have visited this area. We will come back while here to take one of the Bay cruises to learn a little more about The Bay. Overall, it's a nice attraction and a good place to visit if a tourist in San Francisco.
author: Tiffany D.

description: This place is freakin awesome. Totally a must see for any visitor of San Francisco. It is vibrant, live and filled with things to do. There are tons of shops. Tons of very good restaurants. And tons of walking to do. Lots of activities. You can rent a bike and cruise around also. You can enjoy the view. The famous Alcatraz is only few minutes away from there so you can check that also. It's a great area to spend time on and get to explore one of the busiest and highly attracted area in the city of San Francisco.
author: Hisham B.

description: It's a tourist area so prices are high, but the quality is great. If this is your first time in SF, then you have to stop here, have some lunch, and buy some souvenirs.
author: Jessica H.

description: This place is super beautiful and great for pictures. There's a lot of art and music and it's a lively place to be with lots of restaurants and things to do like boat rides and such. We enjoyed our time but it was a bit dirty and obviously expensive. Also, some of the workers could sprucin up on their costumer service skills.
author: Ana M.

description: A great tourist spot indeed. Great views of Alcatraz and is just peaceful, really. Besides the fact that this place was flooded by tourists, it didn't bother me as much as the crowd in Times Square on a Friday/Saturday night. It was nice walking around and seeing a different view from what I am used to, so I sucked that all in.
author: Ina M.

description: I always enjoy Pier 39. Whether it is daytime or evening, so many yummy aromas of food and sounds of joy. There are fun novelty shops. I enjoyed conversations with two friendly shopkeepers on my last visit. The lights at night are fun and festive. I visited during Fleet Week and a great guest band was performing. The place looks clean and family friendly to me. I did pick up my check in offer- a coupon book at the visitor center.
author: Julie S.

description: If your a tourist this place is a must. If you hate crowds of people, avoid at all costs. You'll find a few good food places, places to buy some decent souvenirs and then random skin care and art places. If you come go to the end to the carousel and around to look at the sea lions. You won't regret that.
author: Jen H.

description: Was at this lovely location last Friday to see the start of the Blue Angels.  I have been going here for years, showing my out of town family a "touristy" location.  But the best part about it this time was the entertaining sea lions.  I brought my son with me as he had never been to Pier 39 and he could not laugh more at the sea lions. He was completely entertained. Pier 39 is always busy, so be prepared for about 30 min to find parking.  Great for all ages and the street performers are awesome.
author: Mercedes M.

description:
I'm a Bay Area local and I'm always having fun here. Especially on days when I want to play tourist. The only downside is the traffic on Embarcadero and finding parking and not to mention the crowds during the summer and when the sun is out. 

But nonetheless it's a fun place to go and walk around. Expect to spend a whole day in the area to explore both Fisherman's wharf and Pier 39. And expect to walk a lot. (I see a few girls in heels and man I do laugh at them)
author: Rochelle M.

description:
One of the most beautiful areas in the bay area! We have a lot of friends in SF and stay in the Fisherman's Wharf area each year. There's tons of things to do at Pier 39, with a wide variety of food vendors, restaurants, and tours. I'd highly recommend the GoPass if you're going to be out here for a few days, as it offers a flat rate and allows you to go on as many different tours as time permits. We did the Alcatraz boat tour, the cruise around the Golden Gate, and many others with the GoPass. The area is packed with people, so you may be walking through some crowds, especially when street performers are out. As you walk past the docks of sea lions, you'll find yourself walking among a myriad of different chain restaurants, stores, coffee shops and the Pier 39 aquarium. Make sure to grab some seafood before your departure!

Best,
Charlie
author: Charlie K.

description:
--Atmosphere & Parking---
When in San Francisco, this locale is not to be missed. I'd probably describe the pier and surrounding locale as the Venice Beach of the North (for California residents) except it's not a beach. 

Where else are you going to get street performers, vendors, photo opportunities, numerous shops and cafe's, restaurants abound, and with options for various activities all over the place? It's definitely a unique area and super touristy and very busy with locals around as well. When in the Bay Area it's definitely an area to see. There's truly a lot to do, even if it's just watching the sea lions roam around or glancing over at Alcatraz miles away. 

Attractions include the Aquarium of the Bay, a lazer/arcade game attraction, caricatures, an arcade, carousel, a mirror maze, musicians, and more. 

Pier 39 is just one of the many piers in the area with lots to do. 

Parking is a mess in ways (but that's San Francisco in general as well) and expensive depending on how far you're willing to park but there are lots around the neighborhood that have cheaper prices than others or even free parking in the neighborhoods. You'll have to take a look around. Parking at the garage nearby (Pier 39 Parking Garage) will be costly if you don't get validation at a participating full service restaurant. I believe you can get parking validated for 1 hour if you leave before 5pm, and if you leave after 5 or 6pm with the validation you'll get 2 hours. I think the hourly rate is $8-9 dollars. 

It can get cold especially in the evenings, so I'd have a light jacket/sweater around in case.

----Something worth checking out----

Check out these two sites for plenty of info regarding the piers in general and their respective attractions and more, and this specific one. 

http://www.inside-guide-to-san-francisco-tourism.com/san-francisco-piers.html

http://www.pier39.com/home/attractions/#
author: Aryo S.

description:
Went to Pier 39 to check out what is here. There were so many shops and food eateries. There was also an arcade for kids. 

We actually got to catch a show right in the middle of Pier 39. The guy who performed his act was funny. His name is Bob. He was the center of attention during the show. He juggled knives and hacky sacks. He also balanced himself on a tricycle which was three small wheels stacked up with a bicycle seat on top. He had help from a guy in the audience. He also balanced himself over some cylinders stacked high. Great show! Loved that part of Pier 39.
