The shops consisted more of jewelry stores, toy stores, etc. The stores seemed a little over priced since it is a place where a lot of tourists go to including myself. I really had a great time here. I wanted to try a restaurant here but my husband didn't want to spend a fortune. Great place to walk around.
author: Maritess C.

description:
On a nice sunny day, this is one of my favorite areas to visit in SF.  The views of the boats, Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz can't be beat and the people watching is fun too.

There are great restaurants, fun little shops and a lot of street entertainment on the walk to or from Fisherman's Wharf.

It's a great spot for all ages and interests.
author: Lucky S.

description:
Last time I was in San Fran, I walked down here mostly just to see the water, feel the breeze and walk by Francis Ford Coppla's old office where he wrote the screen play for the Godfather! 
The Pier is absolutely beautiful, no doubt, but it's also crazy with tourist in every direction.. 
There are street performers and people dressed up in costume! I took a picture of some Star Wars dudes taking a break and smoking a cig, and Chewy yelled at me and told me to get out of here! What a Wookie! 

There is a great view of the city from here as well as Golden Gate, and Alcatraz, but if your not into big crowds and you might want to skip this little nugget of San Fran.
author: Patrick T.

description:
It's a "must go" for tourists, but a "no way Jose" for locals.  I go every 3-5 years because I forget how touristy it can be.  Maybe now with a written Yelp review, I will be reminded to prevent a reoccurrence.

Parking is a mess, expect to pay over $20 for 2-4 hours, more for longer.

The only thing worthy that I don't tire of, you ask?  Sea Lions.   They lay around on floating wooden platforms on the leftside near the end of the pier.  They yawn, sleep, stretch, hug, and make this most adorable barking sound.
author: Randy B.

description: Great for SFO tourists or any locals that want to bring their significant other on a date. It has small dainty stores, seafood restaurants, and a few carnival activities. If you come in the early morning, you avoid the crowd. The pier gives a beautiful view of the sea. You can also see over 40+ Sea Lions basking in the sun during the day time. I thought they were so cute !!! I also went to check out the mirror maze they had going on which is right above piano steps (every step u make created sound). Parking is harder to find in the area, but if you come bright and early and go towards the residential areas, you will find one with some luck needed. There isn't a lot to do, but I would definitely recommend this place as something tourists should visit. I had a short, but wonderful experience.
author: Shirley G.

description:
I have been coming here for as long as I can remember. This place is ALWAYS busy thanks to the locals who come here on the weekends and to the tourists who come here from places around the world. It is a great pier with so many things to do and see, places to eat, places to shop at, activities and so many great photo spots. The place isn't super huge but it also isn't large. You are able to see Alcatraz from the pier over looking the water, you can see sea lions when it is their season and many boats parked them for SF tours. 

There is a mixture of high end stores and restaurants to eat here and there is something that everyone can enjoy. There is also a carousel here, movie viewing ride, aquarium, and many other things. There is a parking garage across the street from the pier which is convenient but it can get expensive if you are there for more than 2 hours (some places will validate your parking for you if you ask).
author: Anne R.

description: I went to see sea lions here. They looked so relaxed and cozy! I could sit there & watched them whole day long. Love this place!
author: Jinny T.

description:
This is a solid spot for a date and cool for young folks. Having noted that, truth be told, we (My Bride and I) expected a bit more.  While it is not always fair to compare cities and tourist areas...well, we did. Seaport Village in San Diego...Umie in Kobe, Japan...Sanur shopping area in Bali...there are a number of PORT AREA SHOPPING TOURIST AREAS that put Pier 39 to shame. However if you are NOT looking for what it is not and appreciate it for what it IS...well, for what it is...not bad.
Simply one man's opinion, but PIER 39 is not all that great.
With that said...I would say that if you are a tourist and visiting San Francisco you should check out PIER 39.
author: Caliph A.

description: So may restaurants and shops it's awesome. The views are great also. From various points, you'll be able to see the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz island and downtown. The area that houses the seals is also great.
author: Juan M.

description:
I enjoyed checking out Pier 39, but it absolutely screams tourist trap. It was amazing to see the sea lions (my favorite part of the excursion!), and there was a street performer putting on a good show inside the shopping area. Lots of the shops sell souvenirs, so be ready to buy something, see it two doors down for $1 less, and then have a small sense of disappointment. 

Tons of candy/sweets, restaurants, and activities for kids as well.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
You cannot come to SF without stopping at Pier 39!

What an attraction to see and so much to do! It's nice to come here during the evening which I have found it to be less crowded and much prettier to see.

Great food and great things to see all in one place! Let's not forget Ghirardelli Chocolate at the end of the Pier! :) Its such a great place to visit if your in need of a quick getaway or if your on a date or even as a tourist in your own city! haha :)

The sea lions, just like other yelpers stated is a popular attraction and amazing to see! They have all types of food that you can think of right at the tip of your fingers. My favorite is Fisherman's Grotto and Boudin Sourdough as well as Capurro! Yummy! 

Shopping can be done here as well and they even have Bus tours that have tour guides to show you around of the beautiful pier and gives you a better idea of the history and how the Pier became such a big attraction!

Boat tours are beautiful and at night you can see if beautiful view of the San Francisco Bay Bridge! It reminds me of how lucky I am to live in a beautiful city like SF!

This is a MUST SEE attraction when you come to SF!
author: Porsche C.

description:
Lovely sea lions, must see !
Small shopping stores and dining places
Cute carousel and nice view
One of my favourite in SF
author: Sergin Z.

description:
We went there to visit Alcatraz. Easily accessible. Signage not so good.
If you drive, look for parking on one of the side streets. Inexpensive at $3 per hour.
author: David M.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf, basically Pier 39 is where the tourists are at, a.k.a ME! Yes, I love touristy locations (except for the fact that everything is overpriced and crowded with people all the time). I came when there were two cruises, so definitely not one of my favourite times, but there was live music that day, the sun was shining beautifully, all the shops were open for business!

There were a few souvenir shops, special stores such as a "lefty store", a store that sells wooden and cork objects, a store that sells baths salts, etc, a few restaurants such as Buba Gump, a pretty famous restaurant world-wide. At Fisherman's Wharf, there's also a location that sells a ton of friend seafood products along with a lobster claw meat sandwich, etc. 

Shoutouts to the beautiful double decked carousel. You honestly brighten up all my photos and make them glamorous! Also, sea lions in their semi-natural habitat, pretty awesome. I'm saying semi-natural because clearly the wooden boards are built for them to use. 

YAY Pier 39. Not a place for me to buy stuff, but definitely a pretty place to look at!
author: Kristy N.

description: Great place get really packed on weekends and holidays. Otherwise I still see this as a tourist place. Even though I am a local I come down here to dine and walk around. Great family day around the pier.
author: Meishi M.

description: As the locals call it tourist trap. Me personally I think it's a great place to people watch. This is on my quarterly rotation of places to stop in sf. After living hear a few years now I still do touristy things. But unlike most folks i get here early so I can actually enjoy the Pier. Parking is crazy expensive so be prepared to pay.oh and if you come on the weekend in the afternoon you will have a hell of a time trying to find a spot. But once you get pass the madness take sometime to walk around and enjoy the views of sf. If you park in the garage across the street take the bridge over. They have lots of places to take great photos. You will know these spots by the signage throughout. Then Mosey on down to the Pier. They have so many fun things to do. You can catch a boat around the bay. Get cross the bay and get arrested at Alcatraz . Or if boats aren't your thing you can just check out those loud ass sea lions chilling by the Pier. FYI You don't have to spend a lot when on the Pier. Check the local sites there are lots of deals to be had.
author: Tony B.

description:
There is so much to see and do while visiting San Francisco: Alcatraz, the Golden Gate Bridge, Lombard Street, The Presidio, the California Academy of Sciences, Ike's Place, Za Pizza (to name just a few.)  And while Pier 39 is generally included as one of the must-see tourist attractions in the area, I've never really bought in.  Maybe it's because I've been to San Francisco so many times, maybe it's because I've lived in California for so long that visiting another pier just doesn't promote much excitement, or maybe it's because--besides getting a few, cool shots of the basking-in-the-sun sea lions--the dining choices are less than spectacular.  I mean, the Hard Rock Cafe and the Bubba Gump Shrimp Co., for example, aren't that difficult to find.  They're plentiful.

Certainly, that's not stopping anyone though.  The Pier's always busy, and I don't suppose that will change anytime soon.  But after about an hour of walking around, finally deciding upon an overpriced menu, and consequently inching our way through respective lines, we'd had enough.

There were some hot spots, however: Trish's Mini Donuts, the Crab House, and Wipeout.  Tourists definitely took notice.  So, overall, Pier 39 harbors three stars, an A-OK.  This review isn't meant to deter, by the way.  If you haven't been, drop by.  But for those who've strolled across the boardwalk before, maybe you'll agree: the Pier's replay value is a bit low.
author: Craig F.

description:
It's a bit quirky but still a lot of fun to visit. I had a much better time here then Fisherman's Wharf. Leave your diet at the door because the food and the aroma is pure sugary goodness from ice cream to crepes. There are some other kitchy shops but I bypass those. And although it's pretty stinky, going to see the sea lions floating on the wooden planks is so fun. I was truly shocked at how big they got!

I'm guessing rain or shine it's busy here because on our rainy day it was packed. We parked at Ghirardelli Square and walked to it since that area was a little quieter. Definitely do not miss this place if it's your first time in SF! Even if it is cheesy, I can't imagine the city without it.
author: Christine S.

description: Pier 39 is a must visit, tourist spot. Come here for the food, live performances, spray painters, and take  pictures and selfies from all angles, (downstairs--view of ocean/ships, and upstairs--buildings and clouds) and then leave elsewhere. No need to linger here for too long.
author: Linda S.

description:
For locals or tourists, it's a fun place to spend some time.  Groupon's make some of the entertainment and dinning a little more affordable.  
Across from Pier 39 or walking distance away, you'll find some old time staple tourist attractions and some new ones, too.  Ripley's, the Wax Museum, and my new favorite, The San Francisco Dungeon.  But that's not Pier 39.
P39 has The 7D Experience!  OMG that attraction is so much fun!  The house of mirrors is a good 5 minutes of laughs.  When we go to a coffee shop we just get straight coffee (less expensive) and load up on the condiments offered to sweeten or creamy it up.  The food is expensive, but again, Groupon's can make it easier on the wallet. 
The aquarium is fun.  And there's live entertainment too.
I wouldn't say it's a Must Do, but if you're looking for something to do, it's a fun place.  We've found parking in the garage across the street to be expensive, but you can get validation at a couple of places.
author: Reba Jane S.

description: Since we only live in the valley we've been here many of times.. always super crowded given it's a big tourist attraction, but it's a nice place to walk around and enjoy great food and maybe take one of the many tour rides or boat rides. There's a lot to do, but it can be super expensive though! I wouldn't recommend going to the aquarium though, personally I don't think it's worth the money it's super small and crowded too.. Monterey is were you wanna go for an aquarium! All in all it's a great place to visit atleast once.
author: Sophia G.

description:
One of the slightly (just slightly) better tourist traps that I've visited so this date.

Pros: Tons of souvenir shops, a carousel, and ... the sea lions (located at the end of the dock)! The sea lions were the best part about the Pier 39 ... you can climb up to the 2nd floor to get a better view of these lively creatures! You can also get a good view of the Alcatraz and the Golden Gate Bridge.

Cons: Nothing interesting to see other than the sea lions and taking pictures.

Transportation: The best way to get here is exiting the Embarcadero BART Station and taking the F-line (F-Market & Wharves historic streetcar, $2.25 per ticket with 90 minutes of free transfer for all Muni Metro and bus lines).

It is what it is - made for tourists just like myself.
author: Luke L.

description:
i know that this is a tourist trap but i love it over here 
there is allot to do no matter what you are doing 
there is so much to see and hear and see and taste 
omg the mini donuts in a bucket  yummmm
author: David O.

description: Pier 39 is super touristy, but it's worth it to see the sea lions. There are also street performances, some overpriced shops and restaurants, the Aquarium, and an arcade. It's one of those places you go to once, while you're a tourist - and then you'll never come back.
author: Judy S.

description: Crowded place for tourist, and it's so cold in the winter time. But there's still so many people outside.
author: Maruko X.

description: We were already in the Embarcadero walking around so walked through Pier 39 because we were being tourists.  There is the typical pier fare with carnival games, souvenirs, and restaurants.  We went to the 7D Experience because we had a free ticket.  We rode the bus here so we didn't pay the $20 per 2-4 hours but I can't imagine that paying for parking is ever pleasant in San Francisco.  The sea lions were out in full force, sunning themselves.  Go for the sea lions, everything else is really not worth seeing.
author: Trina D.

description:
Since my youngest was more aware of everything happening and surrounding at 1 years old and super active we decided to explore SF more. I was an absolute tourist on my last visit to SF with the babies, cousin and BFFs as my visit prior we were just foodies and shopaholics. LOL.  This place was suggested by my cousin which was awesome! My kids loved it! Pier 39 is where the sea lions sun bathe and we can all watch tons of them while on the pier. On the 2nd floor there was also a sea lion educational center. Kudos for learning and answering the children's curiosity about the cute sea animal everyone is crowding to see. 
  The pier also have many eateries and stores. One of my favorite discoveries was Global Candles where they make and carve the candles right in front of you! There's also a Merry go round, a scenic boat tour and a mirrored maze! We were there much longer than we should but absolutely enjoyed it as there was so many things to look at and eat.
  There was a Yelp check in offer but when I went to customer service they knew nothing about it. Luckily I had my AAA card and was still able to get a coupon book for the stores and eateries on and around the pier (^_^) If you're a local this probably won't be much fun but if you haven't visited yet drop by!
author: Marilyn C.

description:
Pier 39 is an absolute must visit, take pictures, bring the family.  If you are in the area, then you need to make this a "To-Do".  It's wonderful to walk around and for the picture taker like me.

It provides a variety of shops, scenic shots, people watching opps, and a view to remember!
author: Manny S.

description: Commercial and touristy, but fun and a mandatory spot when you visit San Francisco. The candy store downstairs is amazing!
author: Bianca S.

description:
Boudin, Ghirardelli, and street performers galore.  My brother who was scared by the bush guy swore the tall robotic guy in sequins was Lady Gaga!  This place is excitement, high-energy, and a sugar rush in one.  It's a delightful combination of food, ocean air, and all the flavors that makes San Francisco amazing in one.

I don't want to drone on and on about the greatness of Pier 39 after writing about Fisherman's Wharf.  Like I had said in my Fisherman's Wharf review, Pier 39 is a great place and definitely a staple of San Francisco.  Who cares if it's a tourist spot?  There's still much to do, tons of sights to soak in, and more importantly:  lots of yummies to eat!
author: Joyce W.

description:
The sea lions are one of San Francisco's greatest tourist attractions. Yes this is a tourist trap, but there's a reason why. This colony of sea lions is an amazing sight to behold.

Pier 39 is a huge area and part of a large outdoor shopping center. The stores are typical touristy spots and the street performers, avoid them at all costs. 

Head straight to the pier to see these cute little guys. Bring your kids, bring your family, it's worth the trip.
author: Kevin F.

description: Everything is overpriced. $5 a person to ride the merry go round and kids need to be accompanied by an adult. So it's a little annoying but it is San Francisco so everything is expensive. The sea lions are so cool, though! You have to go just to see that! Especially on a clear day with the Golden Gate Bridge in the background!
author: Samantha M.

description: Do you want to dip your feet in the bay? Do you want some fresh clam chowder? Do you need to buy a sweater because it looked like a nice day and the sun is but you are freezing your butt off.. Welcome to sf! Well your in luck cuz pier 39 always has something to offer and new attractions and stores. Yes its overpriced but you know what your stepping in to so its not a surprise. Come to the Pier and workout or just hang out.
author: Krystal S.

description:
YELP 365 CHALLENGE 2014-(278/365) "Great Spot For Tourists and Locals"

I'm totally a fan. Yes, its touristy but there's tons to see and do here! 
Heck, we even played tourist even when I was a Bay Area resident for 9 years!

You have tons of food options here, whether you want to dine in , or snack on...not the best, but they're there in case you need some nourishment!

The best sourdough IN THE WORLD is found here...No one comes even close to Boudin!

Great people watching, and sightseeing here for sure. The Sea Lions, Alcatraz, Bay Bridge and Golden Gate make for some beautiful photos.

Go to Ghiradelli and get CHOCOLATE WASTED!

There's boat rides and tours to Alcatraz if you decide to go that route

Ride a Cable car if you haven't already

Sip on an Irish Coffee at The Buena Vista

One place I don't really care for is that whole Fisherman's Wharf Section. Overpriced seafood, and THE place where I had the worst meal of my life, Alioto's 8...Yuck!

Some of the street performers are very entertaining too!

Go! Play tourist! Screw what the haters think!  ALOHA!!!

Shaka Meter:  \uuu/  \uuu/  \uuu/  \uuu/  4
author: Nelson Q.

description:
This landmark could have got my top score so like clearly Pier 39 is one of the best moments I will always remember because during my freshman year of high school our band took a trip to Pier 39 for a local State Performance! How cool is that? Honestly, when we got there it was totally COOL! I liked every part of it from the animals, tourism and even Fisherman's Wharf was totally neat.

My recommended advice for you is to dress warm if you are going to Alcatraz. Fortunately for the band director, he made a reservation for us to arrive which was really neat. Also, picture how strange this was... in the midst of performing, it was triple digit hot! Since I was in charge of taking photos, I have to say it is worth coming back to a GREAT place with awesome features!
author: Bryan N.

description:
Super fun area to just wander through... checking out all the souvenir shops, restaurants/dining options, and, of course, the sea lions! It seems like a necessary stop whenever you're in San Francisco, really.

Sure, it may be a bit of a tourist trap... but just GO. Be a tourist. I'm usually one to avoid tourist traps like the plague, but Pier 39? C'mon, it's fun! If you enjoy seafood, take some time to hunt down a delicious food stand for some fresh seafood or clam chowder in a sourdough bread bowl. Otherwise, enjoy some shopping, riding the carousel, or just wallow in the fresh air. Besides, the views of the bay are just too good to miss. 

Overall? 10/10, would love to visit again - and I'll be sure to the next time I'm in SF. :)
author: Erica R.

description: So great!!!! Perfect for family or going on a date, the restaurants and gift shops are so cute and the aquarium is really cute!!! I had a great time and I made it a fun day with friends I def recommend it
author: Ryan T.

description:
One of my favorite tourist traps in SF. Sea lions, great restaurants with beautiful views, street performers and so much more. A very fun place for the whole family. Parking costs a bit but if you go to one of the restaurants they give you some free hours. Many tours start from here. Probably best to research a bit and plan since there is so much. Less of a chance to miss something you really like. Although regimented and pre-planned is not my style, I still recommend you do it for a place like this. Maybe you don't want to get there and start researching restaurants on your limited vacation time here - its understandable... Stuff like that can be done at home ahead of time.

When it comes to something like this I usually recommend you hit up the hotel concierge on recommendations. They are professionally trained for just this sort of thing - you are paying for their expertise as part of the high cost of your hotel, so give them consideration.

Me as a local (east bay) I just tell my friends from other countries to simply go here. Let a degree of impulsiveness guide you. Walk past a restaurant and go to the one that lures you in by what you see and smell. I don't have a regimented list of what to do here I just put it on the must see list. Just as I do going by bicycle across the Golden Gate and photo opportunities of Lombard St and the six Painted Ladies at Alamo Square - I simply tell them to go. Let things naturally fall into place.

Put on some sun screen, make sure your phone is fully charged. Take a windbreaker in case you decide last minute to take a sailboat ride... Enjoy!
author: Stefan T.

description:
Spent a great deal of my teenage years down the streets of pier 39. Probably one of the most to go tourist attractions spots after the Golden Gate Bridge but simply a spot that's pretty much a given to visit.

The pier 39 itself is is a bunch of souvenir shops, restaurants and an arcade. There are places to sight watch such as the view of the Alcatraz Islands and unique spot to see seals/ Sea lions. As a SF residence... the souvenir shops are pretty much unimportant to me but i do appreciate the small local restaurants and food areas. 

Personally would recommend the seafood here and following activities...
- The Crab booths lined up in a row: Fresh crab and chowder. ( usually would not get Boudin's because it's located everywhere)
- Spray can painters that put on a show with their stunning art (Located at various times on the street)
- Street Stunt Performers.... Again varies time when they come out
- Christmas time... which is coming up, pier 39 christmas tree and Decorations
- Gherridehlli square factory for ice cream within walking distance
- Dinner by the water at various restaurants available ( My most recent was fisherman's grotto)

Downside....

- Crowded and full of people.....
- expensive everything... be prepared to be bankrupt especially if you're a tourist 
- Dirty and smelly because of the fish markets/ booths
- Limited parking of course....
- Same stuff, different day if you're a SF resident. 

Place was made especially for tourists but as a SF resident... i do appreciate its existence!
author: Auden W.

description:
Great fun place for families, couples, or an individual, there are all kinds of attractions and things to do. If you are going on the weekend it can get busy even during the winter time so prepare for lots of people. It is not as busy during the week except during high travel time (Christmas, summer, etc.) Pier 39 is an extension of Fishermans Wharf which is just a short walk away.

It is a large area with a little something for everyone. They have street performers mostly on the weekends, many places to eat, a carousel, shops, and some spots to take wonderful pictures of the bay, Alcatraz, and sail boats. There is a visitor center and if you check in on Yelp you get a free coupon book for the Pier 39 and it includes discounts on parking, food, attractions, and shops. 

Follow the signs for the sea lions, they are around year round. There is also a sea lion center where you can find out some interesting facts about this interesting animal. There are some food spots where they do not have seating, you can take just a short walk to the benches by the water and enjoy the view while you eat (it is also cheaper). One of the things that I love about Pier 39 is you don't have to spend much money to enjoy yourself, there are several free things that you can do making it a budget friendly attraction.

The Embarcadero is a nice stretch to walk down, start out at the Ferry Building and walk your way down to Pier 39 then Fishermans Wharf it is a great way to spend a day in San Francisco on a budget and you have nice views of the Bay, sail boats, and you see a little of the outskirts of the city.
author: Lacy C.

description:
Pier 39 is great! It is a pretty well known tourists destination in San Fransisco that is almost always crowded. We liked to come here a lot when our dog was a puppy because the crowds were perfect for socializing here and most of the restaurants have pet friendly patios! 

Without our fur child, we have spent entire days at pier 39! There is so much to do! Food, drinks, arcades and shops galore! I am absolutely in LOVE with the bath salt stand! I get a new bag of bath salt every time because it is the freshest, made from the one and only San Francisco bay!

Bring a sweater! If you're coming from Sacramento and its 110 degrees outside and you think you'll be okay, trust me- its always cold on pier 39! 

Ice Cream on pier 39 is also a must! There's something about being cold ^ and eating ice-cream that is incredible. 

Parking around here costs an arm and a leg but thats to be expected. 

I love making the trip to pier 39, it's once of my favorite spots in SF!
author: Nicole B.

description: The pier is so much fun! There are sea lions, markets, restaurants and little shops. It is a tourist trap and it seems like its more expensive because of that. But, just don't buy anything, go eye-shopping and watch the sea lions.
author: Katherine Y.

description: Pier 39 is a really nice place to visit if you go down to the Embarcadero. There are a lot of things in a small area so you don't have to walk a long way. In addition to the Sea Lions, there are shops and restaurants. There is a Hard Rock Cafe as well as a wonderful Mrs. Fields Cookie Store. It is a very easy and safe place to get around.
author: Richard F.

description: Pier 39 and Fisherman's Wharf in general is one of those tourist places you should see at least once. The sea lions on the floating decks is always fun though.  They are big and loud sometimes and that particular area can get sort of crowded as well.  There's always people here all year round as it's one of the city's top attractions for tourists where they can see the sea lions, possibly take a boat cruise and see Alcatraz as well.
author: Ingrid A.

description: We had a great time visiting here. Lots of food places to eat in, shops and sweets shop. The view of the water makes it so nice. It can get pretty busy, but it's a tourist spot so that's expected. There are stores on the second level too, so make sure you don't miss it. I would say it's kid-friendly.
author: Hannah V.

description: Worth watching. Nice place to spend time. Surrounded with shopping places,restaurants. Along with this they have too many activities like ferries​,boat which can take you for ride. Good place to enjoy the evening and feel the nature.
author: Asp K.

description:
Sometimes you have to let yourself go and be a tourist. Even if you're not a tourist, but definitely if you really ARE a tourist.

You watch a freak show.

You buy some postcards.

You go to an arcade.

You watch some stinky seals. 

You watch the boats sail by.

That's just something you have to do here.
author: Fawn G.

description:
I love being a tourist in my own hometown. You get to see the touristy spots that you otherwise... would not! Heck, I even got to watched Sea Lions basking under the sun with their belly up! 

I feel so humbled that this area gets so packed with tourist. It is great for the city's revenue, and especially for all the neighboring businesses. I do suggest you pay a visit to Boudin Sourdough located inside Pier 39 boardwalk because their service is fantastic, and there's something about the fog that makes their bread, that much more memorable!

There are so many things to see here, from shopping to the Wax Museums to eating fresh cooked crabs, it's hard to imagine what the city would be like without you Pier 39!  You are fantastic!!

Parking can be a challenge, but there are several parking garages nearby, or even better, leave your car behind and explore Pier 39 by walking, hiring the cool bike riders that will take you around the area, or rent a small electric vehicle for two, and even rent a bike for a day! 

If your are planning on staying in the city for a weekend visit, I suggest buying the "CITY PASS," ( http://www.citypass.com/san-francisco) -- this will save you tons of money and will give you huge discounts on almost all of the sites! How cool is that?

Until then, Cheers! ~ :p
author: Edwin R.

description:
Had an absolute blast. So much to do from the aquarium to all the fun shops! Yes, it's a total tourist attraction and prices are pretty steep but it's still a good time. I checked in on Yelp and got a free fun pack coupon book from the welcome center (The welcome center is located upstairs near the front). The coupon book has deals for every place on Pier 39 from free gifts to discounts on food and shopping. 

Oh and the ever so entertaining seals at the end of the pier are great entertainment. Might end up staring and oogling over them for hours.
author: Mo M.

description:
Great place for tourists, they just put up a 60 ft Christmas Tree along with ornaments in front of Pier 39 entrance. Plenty of great places to eat, specialty shops, stores, aquarium next door and great places to take pictures on the other end of Pier 39.
Sea lions also hang out on the platforms and you could hear them bark before you actually see them.
Parking at Pier 39 could be validated at selected Pier 39 restaurants and shops.
author: Dirk D.

description: This is one of the piers at Fisherman's Wharf and it's pretty fun! It has lots of restaurants and shops as well as amazing views of the Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz. The real draw here is seeing the sea lions along the west side of the pier; they're beautiful creatures and it's pretty amazing to get to see them. I'd suggest coming here early in the morning to beat the crowds!
author: Kevin B.

description:
I think this was the best part on the fisherman's wharf! 

A nice boardwalk area by the water, where you can try lots of different things to eat (if you are foodie like me you will enjoying trying different things), take some rides, see some cool street performers and sea lions!

Also be prepared to flow with a lot of other awesome tourists and met many friendly locals and few not so friendly; also seat on the side to people watch. Get a bag of Trish's Mini Donuts to get some energy and be on a sugar rush. Also be sure to watch for Zoltar Fortune Teller Machine! it awesome! Do partake in the shops, some of them are quite nice!

Overall very enjoyable place!
author: Bilal S.

description:
MOST IMPORTANT: if you are driving or have kids and will end up inedibly spending money on random things then you REALLY need to "check in" on your Yelp app and pick up the "FUNPACK" that they offer for Yelp check in's for free! They gave us a coupon book full of things like "free 2 hour parking" and tons of "buy one get one" offers for the restaurants and food stands on the marina/pier. All right so since that is out of the way ... here goes!

Yeah yeah it is a touristy place but aren't we all tourists who need a little bit of a touristy place to go from time to time? hehe ~  I guess if you travel a lot and expect the worst prices and know that there will be "tourist traps" here and there then you are pretty much set to explore Pier 39. So what is so touristy about the place? They don't really have any authentic places to eat that have the SF flavor. The prices are inflated since they know we are all tourists desperate to buy random things to bring home to friends and family. There are way too many people walking around and way too many people standing around watching street performers. 

Ok, I'll cut to the chase ... just walk around, look at the cool little boats in the marina, and go see the silly sea lions basking in the sun! Take some photos and get some fresh air. If you get hungry just walk your way to the Ferry Building because that is where the good food is at! (the walk can be far so if you are in a time crunch or simply tired then take an Uber or a pedicab - either one costs around $7-$10 ; pedicab being more expensive)  Another spot for grub that I personally ended up hitting twice in the week I was in the area was Waterbar.  They have $1.05 oysters for happy hour until 5:30PM daily!! 

...... sorry for going off on a different subject there but Waterbar HH was that good*
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Really overrated, there's just some quick bites and a lot of trinket shops but overall it's not that exciting. There's way too many people to enjoy the place
author: Katie H.

description: First off, Fisherman's Wharf is totally a touristy spot so if you don't like crowds, then this might not be the place for you. However, I kind of liked the energy and movement of this place so the crowds really didn't bother me. The shops were pretty interesting and you have a number of restaurants from which to choose. The highlight was catching a glimpse of the sea lions sunbathing at the far end of the pier. It was rather amusing hearing the barking and swimming. If you come to Fisherman's Wharf, definitely check out the seals since it's something you won't see often. The views from this general area are pretty cool so this will be a fun spot to visit.
author: Christine B.

description:
Not much left to say that hasn't been said many time in the hundreds of reviews. I think sometimes we don't always take the places we review at face value. I can honestly say this place, is part amusement park, part circus but it also has some history so instead of stating all the things I love about this place I've decided to post some historic facts so if you've never been you will know what to expect and respect and if you've been here many times and don't know the significant impact of this place you can say "wow"


History of PIER 39

August, 1977 - PIER 39 breaks ground. Authentic 1910 wood from Piers 34 and 3 are used to erect the new structure.

October 4, 1978 - PIER 39 opens on schedule to fanfare in San Francisco. Originally, PIER 39 had 23 restaurants, 50 stores, a diving pool and street performers.

August, 1981 - Moor + South acquires property, forming the PIER 39 Limited Partnership.

May, 1983 - Diving pool at Bay End of The PIER replaced with Venetian Carousel from inside Palace of Fun Arts.

January, 1989 - PIER 39 is named the third most-visited attraction in the country by USA Today.

January, 1990 - California sea lions begin arriving in droves on PIER 39′s K Dock, creating a local and international sensation. To date, the population has grown as high as 1,701.

April, 1996 - Underwater World (now Aquarium of the Bay) opens to the public.

July, 1998 - PIER 39 "Best Place to People Watch (San Francisco)" and "Best Video Games Arcade" as voted by the San Francisco Chronicle's Readers' Choice competition.

February, 1999 - Forbes Island, the world's only man-made, floating island restaurant, opens in PIER 39′s West Marina.

July, 1999 - PIER 39 "Best Place to People Watch (San Francisco)" as voted by the San Francisco Chronicle's Readers' Choice competition.

May, 2002 - Riptide Arcade family entertainment center opens with more than 100 video games, virtual reality units, novelty and prize redemption games.

August, 2002 - Hard Rock Cafe opens.

October, 2003 - PIER 39 celebrates its 25th anniversary on San Francisco's historic waterfront.

April, 2005 - Theatre 39 begins featuring live theatrical performances.

May, 2007 - Fog Harbor Fish House opens.

December, 2008 - Arrival of the new, two-story San Francisco Carousel hand-crafted in Italy with renderings of its home city.

May, 2009 - Blue and Gold Fleet officially debuts RocketBoat, the all new thrill ride on San Francisco Bay. RocketBoat is open seasonally (May through October).

July, 2009 - Riptide Arcade is remodeled into Players Sports Grill & Arcade.

October, 2009 - Magowan's Infinite Mirror Maze opens.

November, 2009 - 1,701 Sea Lions haul out on PIER 39's K-Dock. Six new floats are added to accommodate the sudden influx of these marine mammals.

January, 2010 - Aquarium of the Bay obtains non-profit status after it is acquired by The Bay Institute.

September, 2010 - Hana Zen Japanese Grill & Sushi Bar opens.

May, 2011 - A newly remodeled Swiss Louis Italian & Seafood Restaurant opens with a new menu.

August, 2011 - The Spice & Tea Exchange debuts at PIER 39.

October, 2011 - Beer 39, featuring beer tasting and beer-related gifts, opens on Level 2 of PIER 39.

October, 2011 - Aquarium of the Bay opens The Bay Theater which features a full line-up of daily film programs featuring award-winning documentaries, animated shorts and beyond, on ocean-lover favorite topics including sharks, whales, surfing, marine life conservation and San Francisco Bay ecology.

August, 2012 - Wine Tasting on the Bay joins the PIER 39 Marina.

October, 2012 - Mangos Taqueria & Cantina, Club Tattoo, 7D Experience and SOLVE IT: Think Out of the Box all open their doors at PIER 39.

October, 2013 - PIER 39 celebrates its 35th anniversary on San Francisco's historic waterfront.
author: Dave O.

description: As others have said, touristy and a must do when visiting San Francisco, lots of shops to browse, plenty of restaurants to try out. Watching the sea lions is pretty cool. The aquarium is a must do also.
author: Mikey C.

description:
Great tourist spot for everyone that comes to SF. Usually it's crowded but the time that I went it wasn't crowded at all for the first week of March. Which made it easier for us to find parking and walk the pier freely.

Pier 39 has a lot of shopping plazas and restaurants. You get to see Alcatraz at the end of the pier and walking around to the left side of the pier you can hear the sea lions yawn and see them stretch and lay on top of on another. Honestly, there's really nothing to do at Pier 39, it's just fun to watch sea lions once you encounter them. Tip: You can see Alcatraz a lot better from Hyde Pier.
author: Sophia V.

description: I used to love this place but now.....meeh!  Big crowds, touristy, and worse of all .... everything overpriced   $12/hr for parking, just as an example (without validation).  INSANE!!!.   If you don't mind the drive, I recommend heading west to Santa Cruz boardwalk or even to Monterey Cannery Row.
author: Angel Sam V.

description:
Such an amazing place to visit. In my belief, i truly feel this is the best tourist spot in San Francisco, coming from a local San Francisco native. The stores, the food (although there is barely any place with a $ sign...if you are okay with that lol), the people, the views just everything about the Pier is beautiful. On cold days however, you better bundle UP. However, when it is a nice sunny day in SF, the Pier is pure with heat for sure!!! 
Parking is crazy expensive. I do not quite have a tip on that. As far as trasportation, i would just leave your car whereever, catch a F bus down to Pier 39 and walk throughout the day. It is worth it anyways.
author: Stacey M.

description:
Pier 39 and Fisherman's Wharf in general is one of those tourist places you should see at least once but don't necessarily have to return to.  It's been around forever and it has it's charm being that they have all sorts of stores and restaurants geared more towards the tourist but in a city as diverse in food as San Francisco there isn't that much here that is a must do.  

Seafood restaurants I get but the chain type places like Bubba Gump and Hard Rock Cafe that you can get just about everywhere.  Do yourself a favor and try something more unique to San Fran like Boudin or something along those lines.

There are a handful of souvenir stores here but I've seen better deals in Chinatown if you're looking for that sort of thing.  One of the unique stores here are the memorabilia store that has many autographed items regarding sports, entertainment etc.  While there are other sports stores and such pretty much this is a tourist place so you will find things related to tourists.  

The sea lions on the floating decks is always fun though.  They are big and loud sometimes and that particular area can get sort of crowded as well.  There's always people here all year round as it's one of the city's top attractions for tourists where they can see the sea lions, possibly take a boat cruise and see Alcatraz as well.
author: Lambert P.

description:
Great sight seeing attraction and good food too. Lots of fun things to see, eat and do around here.  Fun ride on the old worldwide collection of buses. From Union Square to Embarcadero for only $1.25, what a deal in SF.

Had some lunch and took in some sights in the area. Great restaurants, gift stores, entertainers/street performers, sea lions hanging and Ghirardelli square nearby.
author: Russ C.

description: Crowded, overpriced restaurants and too much of everything. You have to visit this place at least once, but avoid coming during the weekend. Also, if you dare to drive, keep in mind that parking here is crazy expensive.
author: Roxana C.

description: A must do in San Fran! Trish mini donuts are a hit. The sea lions are so fun to watch and put on quite the show!
author: Chelsea M.

description: It's Pier 39. Come here to see the seals and buy I heart SF Shirts for your family who visited from out of town.
author: Roen R.

description: Great place for tourists. Really jam-packed filled with people so make sure to keep the kids close!  If you haven't been before you need to check this tourist attraction off your list.  Lots to do and lots to eat along the Pier!
author: J T.

description: This is a great place to visit with multiple things to do. Super touristy and parking is pretty tricky but if you don't mind a little walk you can park back in the neighborhood a bit and it's cheaper. We usually start with a visit to the seals at the end of the pier. There is a carousel in the middle that is a must for the kids. There are many restaurants and shops. The crepe place is delicious as is the Ben and Jerrys ice cream shop. There are a few fancy seafood restaurants. This is also where you depart for a lot of the boats for the Bay tours, rocket boat etc. I recommend a walk from pier 39 back towards the wharf which will take ten minutes. You will pass Rainforest cafe, madame toussads wax museum, Ripleys believe it or not and some other fun shops on your way to delicious food.
author: Francine B.

description:
I did a quick Word Map for Pier 39 Yelp reviews and these are the terms that stood out. It's no surprise that these are the reasons tourists (never locals) visit Pier 39.

 - Pier
 - Tourists
 - Sea Lions
 - Alcatraz
 - San Francisco
 - Bay
 - Touristy
 - Golden Gate
 - Views
 - Shops
 - Crowded
 - Carousel
 - Restaurants
 - Trap
 - Photo
 - People
 - Food
 - See
 - Aquarium
 - Maze
 - Time
 - Check-in

Now, let's summarize. All tourists visiting San Francisco must make time for a visit to Pier 39 to see the Sea Lions, Alcatraz, the Bay, and the Golden Gate Bridge. Other attractions include a Carousel, Magowan's Infinite Mirror Maze, and a small Aquarium. There's also plenty of restaurants, touristy shops, and food stores to satisfy the crowded mass of people. Check-in on the Yelp app for coupons from the Visitor Center.

You're on vacation in San Francisco. A visit to Pier 39 won't be the best or most amazing thing you experience in the city, but it is a-ok ... and obligatory.
author: Michael S.

description: A touristy spot for sure, located at the end of the Fisherman's Wharf Area. How do I know? Well, there are places filled to the brim with SF branded souvenirs and a Bubba Gump Shrimp. Enough said. Still, we went the day after Thanksgiving and I remember the place fondly enough from my time there as a kid. There's a big tree in the front, it's festive, and even window shopping will kill an hour or two.
author: Desmond F.

description: This place is an absolute gem and a must do for anyone in the area! Has many little shops you can wander into for seafood, dessert, or souvenirs.  I also saw people stopping by to see some shows, the ones on the day I went had a magician which seemed really fun.  They have a carousel and a jumper.  The Pier is extremely kid friendly which is always a plus for families.  There is something for everyone.  The best part is at the end when you get hit by the beautiful views of the sea! Adore this place and highly recommend to anyone interested in a versatile and truly friendly area.
author: Jamie M.

description:
Just like the Fisherman's Wharf district it's located in, Pier 39 is a big tourist attraction in San Francisco.  The pier is home to shops, restaurants, a small aquarium, amusement park-like rides, street performances, and more.  It's kind of like an outdoor carnival and is somewhat reminiscent of the Santa Monica Pier, but on a more touristy and smaller scale.  It's not the cleanest place, but one reason is because it's packed with so many people and there are seagull droppings everywhere.

The only big reason I recommend coming to Pier 39 is to see the sea lions.  That's what makes this place unique.  The sea lions are a lot of fun to watch.  They are located on the northwestern edge of the pier.  There's seating and a couple different vantage points to take in views of the animals.  There are hundreds of them and they can be loud.  If you visit, be prepared for the smell.  It doesn't smell good.  Very fishy, perhaps with some sea lion excrement mixed in too.

For an example of what the sea lions at Pier 39 are like, check out this short clip I posted to Instagram: http://instagram.com/p/iZ6M02wBhy/.  You probably won't be there long unless you *really* like watching sea lions.  It's best to visit the pier in the morning because the sun will be behind you as you face the sea lions.  Also, there are much less tourists in the morning.

Another reason to visit Pier 39 is for its excellent views of San Francisco Bay.  From west to east, you can see the Golden Gate Bridge, Angel Island, Alcatraz Island, Treasure Island, and the Bay Bridge.  Therefore, this is a good place to knock out all of these popular vistas from one spot.  Note there are much better spots to take pictures of some of these landmarks individually -- for example, Golden Gate Bridge Pavilion or Marin Headlands for the Golden Gate Bridge and the Embarcadero waterfront for the Bay Bridge.  I personally prefer those spots over Pier 39 as you're much closer to the bridges, which makes for better pictures.
author: Daniel B.

description: Too crowded tourist place. Rest rooms were plenty, still had to wait and the smell were still terrible. Very expensive parking. Thank God for the yelp tips to go to welcome center when you open yelp app and check in so we can get 1 free (not 2) hour of parking. We were there just a bit over an hour, but were not expected to pay. So I'm really happy, lol
author: Royeni T.

description: Love love love Pier 39!  Yes its a touristy place but its in the most beautiful city in the world. The energy is amazing. I love sitting there drinking a Biscoff hot chocolate enjoying the lively chatter and views. So many amazing restaurants and dessert places to choose from.
author: Pratibha G.

description: I was only in town for a couple days on business and did not have much of a chance to do any sightseeing. I decided to come down here and walk around and check out some of the shops. There's a cool carousel for the kids and a few other things to do but primarily just shopping and restaurants
author: Travis C.

description: We had so much fun here last night. Tons of stores, food, gand activities. Great place to bring your friends out of town. Fairly priced parking is just accross the street.
author: Bud S.

description:
LOVE the shops! LOVE Waltz warf! So delicious! The fish and chips are AMAZING!

I love walking into all the shops it is so fun! Going up stairs! I've never been on another pier that has 2 stories! It is great fun! Souvenirs! !!
author: Jennifer H.

description: Every city has their version of a tourist trap, welcome to SF . Regardless it is a go to destination if your visiting to take in the crowds and piers and sea front restaurants. Plus you get great views of the bridges and Alcatraz island.....Parking is a complete RIP OFF, so if your driving....round the local streets and you'll find a spot. This place is happening on the weekends so arriving early is more beneficial to you.
author: N And N K.

description:
This is absolutely a tourist trap but the shops on the pier are actually pretty cute. It gets extremely crowded, so don't go if you're claustrophobic. 

There are really delicious looking strawberries somewhere in the middle of the pier. They were ONE DOLLAR EACH. EACH BERRY. NOT KIDDING. They were good but we were probably pretty stupid for purchasing 6 strawberries for $6. We were just so hungry and hot we couldn't resist!
author: Holly N.

description: Love pier 39. Every Time I come to the city I always try to come here, there's lot of little shops that o look at Every Time, I've been here enough time to know what to buy and what to stay away from, most of the tourist stuff they sell all around SF, i mainly look for stuff for my kids. The food here is a hit and miss, sometimes good sometimes bad, but I still love the place and will continue to come here when I'm in the city.
author: Dennis T.

description:
Actually had a great time here.   Plenty to see, cool shopping. Fun with kids.    

Can walk to all sorts of cool places down here.   

Scored a metered spot on the street on our first visit, checked the place out, and came back the next day and paid to park in the garage.  Well worth the time spent here.


Update on Pier 39......


Received a message from someone over there.

That is exactly how it should work.   Pier 39 was awesome, and although I have left, they still care.    I am not sure if can increase their stars, but I will try.    Otherwise, Thank You.       I may never be back, but I will be sure to tell others.
author: Ken R.

description: Always a treat to visit! Love coming here for lunch with the family and simply to be touristy and buying things I don't really need. The air is so brisk near the water and the seals are the cutest things! Watching them bask in the sun has to be one of my highlights. We ate at a restaurant with a nice view of the seals and boats. Had my clam chowder bowl with a side of oysters. Perfect on such a cold day. After eating we grabbed some hot chocolate and went shopping again. I grabbed a few key chains, chocolates and these cool shirts that changed color with temperature. They had a cute collection of star wars themed merchandise so had to get them. They even have cruises available as well at the pier. Didn't have time this time around though but maybe next time.
author: Diana M.

description:
This looks to have been built with the intent to build a tourist trap and rake in as much money as possible. Its in the Fisherman's Wharf, tourist central. Its on a pear sticking out into the water. Filled with overpriced tourist shops and restaurants (many chain restaurants).

All the shops face inward and while there is a walkway facing out (most restaurants have windows out) most people walk around where there is no views. I come in here every once and a while, but mostly I skip it. 

When I come in here I realize that there isn't mach in here for me. The views are better close by. I do like the piers between Pier 39 closer to the main Fishermans Wharf. They often have lots of sea lions.
author: Mark B.

description: This place is the most awesome place in all of SF. I loved it so much. you can find any kind of entertainment you are looking for. Go there with lots of money, you will thank me later ;)
author: Menna Y.

description:
When a lost tourist in Union Square asked me where Pier 39 was, I asked "Why?". Not because I was trying to be obnoxious since for some reason, I never need to try to be. No, my gut response was why would anybody subject themselves to a crowded seaside corridor of such crass commercialism. It's inevitable that any major city have one if it's next to a major body of water. Chicago has Navy Pier. New York has South Street Seaport. I've been to both, and I have to admit with a heavy heart that Pier 39 is the worst when it comes to uncontrolled crowds and thoroughly useless shops. But it would be too easy to slap one star on it and be done with it.

I remember when it first opened back in 1978 and how it was going to bring a lot of revenue to the city. It has, but the downside is how there is anything of little redeeming social value on that pier. Nope. Even the Aquarium of the Bay is a snore since it feels like an underwater walkway to a real aquarium, but then comes the startling realization that the walkway IS the aquarium. The food should be completely bypassed here as my two recent experiences can attest - the Eagle Cafe (review: http://bit.ly/159peOO) and the Sea Lion Cafe (review: http://bit.ly/117MJH0). I had a lovely time at Swiss Louis with an army of friends...in 1984 (!)

Only two aspects save this mad cacophony from a one-star rating are: (1) the territorial gamesmanship at the Sea Lion Marina (photo: http://bit.ly/12Z7D7O)...and I don't mean the tourists jostling for the best iPad camera angle (review: ); and (2) the views of Alcatraz and environs at the end of the pier (photo: http://bit.ly/18wCEZO). So you could walk along the far less crowded outer boardwalks of the pier (photo: http://bit.ly/1aBLVNr) and leave the merchandise to the tourists in the central area. All you miss are the sideshow and the carousel (photo: http://bit.ly/16SGfKV). Regardless, do yourself a favor and skip it. Spend more time at the Ferry Building if you need the bay views.
author: Ed U.

description: Very touristy area all year round. Parking is expensive, but it is worth walking around here. You can feel the wonderful Bay area breeze and get to see sea lions. There are many gifts shops, boat tours, restaurants around here. Ooh and street performances are pretty cool. Public restrooms available as well. A must visit if you are in the area!
author: Se C.

description:
It's the No. 1 tourist destination (trap) in SF.  But let me be brutally honest about Pier 39.  It's still fun no matter if you're a tourist or a local.  And on days with nice weather, it's just a nice spot to just to hang out and walk around.

Much to see here.  You've got the Hard Rock, a Carousel, Sea Lions, Bubba Gump's, Players (formally Riptide Arcade), and stores that range from crazy hats, one that caters to left-handed folks, and one with magnets of every kind.

I'm not too keen on the dining establishments here though.  They really seem to just be thrown in.  Although most of them have great views of the bay, the food is  mediocre and way overpriced.  Just stop by here for Trish's Mini Donuts.  Thank me later on that.

As a local, if you can get past the tourists and the insane food prices, this spot is still a gem on the waterfront.
author: Rodney H.

description:
In the city is where we fell in love!!! Especially here at one of our favorite places to get lost in. Whenever you want to have a good time and also exercise, you have to  go to The Pier. It's a long stretch of so many things to do. 

Of course there are the famous spots such as Fisherman's wharf or the exploratorium but there are also hidden Mom and Pop novelty stores.

Great place to take the family on the weekend. So much to do and so much to see. There are even the famous sea lions that are beautiful to take pictures of however they kind of have an unforgettable smell.

Or you can check out the delicious Bubba Shrimp restaurant! The list is endless.

You just have to check it out with your loved ones.

Happy exploring!!!

Toodles~
author: Mae M.

description: I love this place, it's filled with tourists, but if you want that vacay feeling, you should definitely come here. I love the atmosphere!
author: Be H.

description:
VERY Touristy and crowded, but I believe everyone should experience the walk down the pier at least once! There are plenty of affordable restaurants, free attractions, and family-friendly quirky stores (Lefty's anyone?)! My favorite sight is always walking all the way down to the end to get a great view of Alcatraz and the famously photogenic and musical seals. 

The performers on stage are always entertaining as well, and my favorite places to stop by are the big chocolate shop, the Hard Rock Cafe, and Boudin.

The most frustrating parts of Pier 39 are the pricey merchandise, dingy restrooms, complicated parking, and narrowly crowded walkways. 

Traveling to and from here is generally difficult due to the traffic, yet if you have a small party I definitely recommend taking one of the rickshaws with the friendly cyclists who can take you along the Embarcadero for a very cheap price! We were a group of three trying to get to the Ferry Building, and it only costs us $25, and they were very open to conversation!

Everyone knows Pier 39, so go check it out for yourself! :)
author: Kyrie S.

description: Come see the sea lions as they sun bathe. It gets crowded. (And I feel like there were less sea lions this time around vs. when I was younger, but who knows.) It's more fun when you see them singing or jump in/out of the water, but ...most of the time they're just there. HA!
author: Karen L.

description: Pier 39 is still the tourist trap that its always been but, there are still some artisan shops, not as many as pre recession era, but enough to make it memorable. Unfortunately most of the shops are now filled with overpriced Chinese made junk. I grabbed a bowl of clam chowder n a beer, which was good, but $18.75 good? I don't think so. There are now more homeless people than seagulls in the area and I'm not sure which is more intrusive. I used to love coming here but this will be my last trip. Almost $30 bucks to park for 3 hours. Big Tech companies and their billionaire owners have really messed SF up for its long time residents and tourists. Clean this place up and make it great again! Unless you're blackmailed into it, avoid the piers and hit some off the beaten path places instead. Try the Prime Rib House and hit the Mission district for lunch.
author: Rob R.

description:
Every tourist and local end up at Pier 39 sooner or later.
Although it does get crowded, it's a pier worth visiting.  Shopping, food and amusement condensed on a picturesque waterfront location.

Some of my favorites are the double decker carousel towards the end, watching the sea lions bask in the sun overlooking Forbes Island, Taffy, The Lefty Store, The San Francisco Sock Market and Aquarium on the Bay.  

Worth a visit if you've never been or if you want to stop by for your favorites.  
Often the sunnier it is the more crowded it will be.
author: Kristi G.

description: Grab a bowl of Chowder. I recommend the cream-based. Watch some magic shows, music and more. Grab a trinket or to-do at the shops and enjoy the views. It's definitely a touristy spot, but extremely fun if you embrace it.
author: Parker S.

description:
The Trap is Set.

For Tourists that is......

Ok ok, perhaps not truly a tourist trap, but its certainly a popular Tourist Destination in San Francisco for sure.

Pier 39 has the right mix of businesses, shops, eateries, and tourist-related attractions/activities that make this a popular destination for tourists/visitors.

WHERE:  Located along Fisherman's Wharf.  You'll know you've reached your destination when you see the flagpoles and signs for "Pier 39".

HERE:  Food/eateries, rides, and souvenir shops await visitors as they enter the main walkway of Pier 39.  You'll find the usual shops selling almost everything from t-shirts, jackets, hats, sweaters, cups, etc., adorned with "San Francisco" or "SF" prominently displayed.  There are even specialty shops selling magnets (of which I bought 3 for $11.99).  Regarding the food vendors, I was almost tempted to buy some cotton candy truth be told.

THERE:  Pier 39 is comprised of 2 levels, with restaurants I believe comprising portions of the 2nd level.  Bathrooms are slightly tricky to locate to be quite honest, despite the signs pointing you in the "right direction."  

EVERYWHERE:  When you finally reach the end of the walk way, you will come to "the end" (so to speak) facing the bay.  Visitors can take in the scenic views of the bay, the Golden Gate Bridge (to the left), as well as Alcatraz in the distance.  

Bottom Line:  Tourists and/or first-time visitors to San Francisco will surely delight in the shops, foods, and scenery of Pier 39.
author: Michael C.

description: Awesome, but overly busy, and it's annoying as hell all the people walking around with their phones out doing that damn Pokemon GO crap!
author: Parker B.

description: We stayed very close at the Holiday Inn Express .. anyway I liked walking down to the Pier to just watch the sealions .. they are super cute. I don't have a sense of smell but my hubby informed they they really stink ..  :)  so he was ready to go after just a few moments. But I was really enjoying it so he toughed it out  .. what a guy.
author: Rhonda W.

description:
Pier 39 is great for the kids... For about 20 minutes. To make the most of it, find out when the presentations are scheduled and sit on the platforms and enjoy the free show.

The kids loved the sea lions and I did too, but they do a lot of barking and not much else. The only thing that made it worthwhile was the information and the history associated with the sea lions.

Don't get me wrong, it's definitely worth the stop! As it turns out, it's just a stop on your way to a nice boat tour of the bay, or Alcatraz, or just before a seafood lunch.

If you paid for parking just to see this, you'll feel like you overspent. Make sure you have more planned.
author: Brian F.

description:
Tourist trap alert!

One stop was enough 15 years ago, but my in-laws were insistent that they must visit Pier 39 despite it being one of the biggest tourist traps in America.  Since I try to be a good daughter-in-law I bit my tongue and grinned and beared the tacky monstrosity of trinket shops and tacky restaurants.  (I did put my foot down on eating here!)

This place is a zoo as it is flocked with hundreds of tourists.  Stop by a kiosk and buy your obligatory coffee or clam chowder.  Sample some chocolates or purchase a San Francisco t-shirt or snow globe.  Watch the street performers and chuckle at their lame acts.  Just don't waste your money at Bubba Gump Shrimp.

The highlight of Pier 39 for me was the adorable sea lions.
author: Michelle M.

description: So out back is a good vantage point to see Alcatraz, plus this is where all the California Sea Loins come to lay on the docks. Otherwise is a bunch of super tourist trap souvenir shops.
author: Christian W.

description:
Wow this place is awesome. ..you have everything to be entertained & a little bit of everything for everyone...if you walk all the way to the back you  can admire sea lions.. ..so many it was awesome...
I stopped at the crepe place..very yummy..missed out on the funnel cakes tho...
I love all the stores that sell sweaters & souvenirs. ...
author: Ana G.

description: Pier 39 is very touristy, but we had to check out the Seals.  It was very crowded, which is to be expected. The LO loved seeing the seals frolic and sunbathe.  Afterwards she took a ride on the 2 level carousel.
author: Rochelle R.

description: You have to visit Pier 39 when you are in SF ! You HAVE to. A real must have. Everyone on the world know this place and it wouldn't let you down. It's a really amazing spot with so many things to do. So many restaurants and souvenir shops. And last but not least, the sea lions. Very special to see.
author: Dennis K.

description:
Pier 39 is my most favorite place to visit in San Fransisco. It is always active with some or the other event going on. I've been to this place quite many times and have always found it to be amazing! We went here yesterday and there was a guy playing Saxophone and that created a fun ambience.

This place has a lot to offer. There are many boat rides which go along the Golden Gate Bridge and the Alcatraz jail and gives a brief history about these places. There are always different events going on. There are many street performers who continuously keep performing to entertain people. There are many stores where you can shop and many eateries like Waffle cone shop, WipeOut Bar & Grill and many more. They generally celebrate all the major events of the year like 4th of July, Veteran's day and many more.

We always go to Pier 39 whenever we are in San Fransisco as it always has something new to offer!! :) :)
author: Harshada K.

description: No...just no. So very overpriced. So very much of the same over and over again. One exception: Shell Cellar. Crab House is good - but expensive so just be aware of that. Other than those places, you'll not see me step foot here again for another 20 years. Let's see if it changes LOL
author: Laurie H.

description: I love this place I wish marina Del Rey had this much to offer and nothing is expensive.
author: Tamara C.

description:
Yelp's 365 Review Challenge 2014 #355 - #365

Welcome to Pier 39! You are in the middle of the tourist action filled with souvenir shops, street performers, San Francisco tour companies, and last but last but not least is the fresh seafood.

Let's not forget Boudin's and Ghirardelli Square who are important in bring the San Franciscan flair to Pier 39. I mainly like coming here to breath the fresh air and admire the shops and action. 

The food is another thing with it's abundance of fresh seafood all over the pier. Walking around you can just smell the fresh clam chowder, shrimp and crabs being cooked on the small cafes and restaurants. If you have a family or friend who wants to check out San Francisco than Pier 38 is he perfect area for that. Don't forget to have a taste of Ghirardelli chocolate or ice cream!
author: Paul B.

description:
The only reason I headed out to Pier 39 was the sea lions. I went over early, before they technically opened (a few stores were open, it was around 9:30am on a Sunday). There were some people around but I strolled through the store area (the same kind of stuff you find in places like Daytona or Gatlinburg).

There weren't a ton of sea lions out (basically one platform full) but they were fiesty and making a lot of noise. There were even a couple that were clearly in areas where they weren't allowed (see the video of a man shooing one away). 

Not a bad place to stop by for a quick view of the sea lions and to take some pictures but outside that, not a whole lot worth checking out.
author: Kristina K.

description: I do not even care how touristy this spot is -- and if you skip it solely because of that, you are seriously missing out. The sea lions are WAY TOO AWESOME. We must have stood and watched them for a good 30 minutes. They're these completely bizarre animals, and seeing them up close is just... surreal. They're goofy and weird and they play with each other and bask in the sun and bark and it's hilarious and totally worth the touristy aspect of the whole place. Don't miss 'em!
author: Justine J.

description:
Lots of tourist stores and restaurants built on a long pier off Fisherman's Wharf.  Fun to just walk around the outdoor split level shopping center.  A fun tourist trap.  

But don't forget to walk on the west edge of the pier to take a look at the sea lions lounging on what used to be docks for small boats until the sea lions took over.  

Very safe to walk around at night with all of the tourists.
author: Doctor G.

description: A complete tourist trap.  In such a pretty city, I was quite shocked to see such a place.  It's literally a heard of tourists roaming around cheesy souvenir shops, cruddy restaurants and crowding around to take pictures of the only reason I bother coming here, the California sea lions.  I would like to recommend skipping it, unfortunately, it's where the Aquarium of the Bay is as well as where you pick up your San Francisco City Pass.
author: Anthony G.

description: Whenever I'm coming to Fisherman's Wharf I'm always looking for Pier 39 because that's where the excitement is. It's always where the parking garage where I set my car. Fisherman's Wharf is VERY touristy so if you're not into that, probably not the best place for you. However if you're looking for that friendly tourist trap, this is it. Flashing lights, people dressed up and sometimes hiding behind a bush to get your blood flowing, you'll find it all here. Even if you're going to Ghirardelli's, I advise parking at Pier 39 because parking is sparse elsewhere unless you're going at a time where there are no tourists which is only a few days out of the year.
author: Eric C.

description: A tourist attraction to go. The view of the ocean while sea lions are chilling on the dock and Alcatraz island from the distance. You can reserve a tour to check out the prison. I went and see aquarium of the bay. A lot of different sea creatures to look at. The pier gets pretty chilly, so bring a jacket! Street performers add entertainment to glance upon. Variety of foods to choose from. Of course there's going to be seafoods.
author: Anonymous U.

description:
Walking along Pier 39 one evening, I started to remember how great my adolescence was. Back then it was just simple times, with minimal responsibilities. Not much to do about anything. Just living the Wonder Years of your life. Man, sometimes I wish I could go back. Then, all of a sudden, I see this machine - a Zoltar Fortune Teller Machine!

BIG
Considered by many as one of the best films of 1988, Tom Hanks was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role, for his portrayal of the older Josh Baskin. Being, a fantasy comedy, young Josh makes a wish "to be big" and is then aged to adulthood overnight. In the movie, that wish was made on a Zoltar Fortune Teller Machine.

What a trip. Made me think twice about something like that happening. If I only knew then what I knew now - life would be magical. It's like getting the answers to your trials and tribulations, with at least a hint to help you. Think about the possibilities.

If you've never seen the film, I highly recommend it. What I also highly recommend is do the touristy stuff on your next visit to San Francisco and walk along Pier 39 to enjoy the environment. Grab a bowl of clam chowder and a bag of Trish's Mini Donuts, partake in the shops, and bask in the atmosphere. Created in 1977, Pier 39 just celebrated its 35th Anniversary as San Francisco's historic waterfront. All the details you need are here. (http://www.pier39.com)

One more thing. Don't blame me if some guy jumps out of the bushes and scares the living crap out of you. Blame it on the Silver Robot Man. It goes with the territory. 

YOUR WISH HAS BEEN GRANTED
ZOLTAR
author: Chris C.

description:
Tourist trap. 

Oh my gosh, I don't think I've ever seen so many people. People we running into each other and taking selfies with selfie sticks. 

I did enjoy waking to the end of the pier and seeing a great view of Alcatraz. We also lucked out and saw sea lions sunning themselves on the docks.
author: Rachel R.

description:
I went on the Tulipmania tour on Sun 2/17/13 at 10am.  Walked from Embarcadero Bart takes about 20 minutes along the Embarcadero.

The group was about 45 people so they split it into 2 groups.  We got Denise & she talked about the different tulips: most from Holland, some from Washington State.  They usually do reds & yellows up in front.  Some tulips are early, then there's mid season, & late.  Each tulip flower typically lasts about 2 weeks.

They mix other plants in the arrangements too: primrose, lettuce, parsley, narcissus, hyacinth.

After the tour we got some snacks at the Wine Shop: cut up croissants, palmier, madelines, coffee, soda, or bottled water.  I got madelines & bottle water.
author: Ann L.

description: San Francisco's best place to walk around with lots of shops and great food! I come here every time I come to the city to get a good meal or just a work out my legs or even get some great clam chowder! I love coming down here before a ball game and going to bubba gumps but hey there are lots of shops to go get a souvenir or even some good food I would definitely come here if you are new to San Francisco and definitely come back if you come back to visit!
author: Addison M.

description:
As others have said, this is such a tourist trap!  However, one that even locals succumb to.  Overall it has improved over the past decade.

First of all - do your research and save some money!  Go to their website and check out what they have to offer. My two biggest tips is if you are a bay area resident, you can get a coupon to redeem 2 hours of free parking in their lot (usually $8/hour, so it helps).  Also, get the Pier 39 app for your smart phone.  There is a simple game on it for older kids, but what I wanted was the PhotoBooth photo frames with cute Pier 39 and San Francisco frames.  Just a word of caution: it's a little tricky to use AND the photos did not save onto my phone (iPhone 5), so we got the app for my husband's phone (iPhone4S) and it worked.  We're not sure, but perhaps the app was designed for the older phone? So test it out at home before heading out.

We also arrived at the parking lot at 10am since stores open at that time.  It was so much better than when we left at 1pm after lunch because it was less crowded, and it was easier to take photos of our son and let him roam more freely.

We were also lucky that Tulipmania just started, so we enjoyed all the beautiful tulips and other spring flowers that they had on display.  The sea lions were also out to sunbathe, so my son enjoyed that until the cold wind started to bother him.  If you are a fan of flowers, go check it out before it ends.

My son really enjoyed the carousel ($3 per person or $5 for two people), which we did first to avoid lines.  Then he found a little red car to ride in front of one store and the rest of the time he just enjoyed roaming.  IT would be great if there was a toy store here next time!  Overall a great trip and I can't wait to go back.
author: Tracy L.

description: After a long time i vist sfo with my family.i can't forget about peor 39 .we went there and enjoy a lot best place for tourists
author: M C.

description:
Considering this is a tourist attraction and after living in SF for 7 years and I don't consider myself a tourist anymore I am not really a fan of this place...

It's always crowded no matter what time of year of what day of the week, and expectedly everything is extremely generic and overpriced. But, now that I have a daughter I am going to be forced more and more to get out of my own comfort zone to take her to places like this to make her happy.

We made the smart plan of not buying anything or not eating anything down here during our visit and I think that was a smart choice. We just walked around and the baby loved seeing all the people and the colorful lights. It was great seeing her so happy!

A plus about Pier 39 is that it is very well maintained. The bathrooms are clean and you never see trash laying around anywhere. I totally appreciate and respect that aspect. 

Overall, Pier 39 is a very aesthetically pleasing sight in San Francisco, so if you're in the mood to take on the crowds come on down!
author: Andy S.

description:
Super crowded. Hella expensive parking. Stores are mediocre and staffs are rude. Good for first time tourists only.
Will never come back
author: Zoe Q.

description:
Never again.  Went here in 1995 on our honeymoon and it was awesome.  Returned March of 2016 and it is now a mall with talentless "street performers" aka beggers and trash. 
Go tour the Presidio instead.
author: Eric E.

description:
Yes this is such a big tourist hole (Who hasn't heard of Fisherman's Wharf?) but still a MUST for you come here at least once if you are visiting San Fran. I like stopping by here every so often when I do come to SF because it's something to do and get a chance to see the ocean, take in the seafood and chowder air, take photos (you know you want to take a photo with the Fisherman Wharf's sign in the background) that I'll upload onto my computer later and look at a few years down the road, take a look at the seals that lay on the pier and laugh at them and tell my husband how cute I think they are or how they remind me of our dogs or someone we both know (lol), to walk around and stretch the legs and just be a tourist.
