I really like going to Musée Mécanique whenever I do come to Piet 39 to check out the old school arcade games (ranging from $0.25- $0.50). I also like to just stare at the bread basket contraption circling all around the Boudin Bakery too. 

Yes parking can be a bit expensive, but if you are lucky, maybe you can score the free 3 hour parking that is near Pier 39. If not, then drive around a bit further and find cheaper parking and just walk over. 

If after you have visited Pier 39 and taken in all the sights and collected some pretty pictures on your camera, and you still didn't enjoy it, then at least that is once thing you can cross off your list and move on. But you should at least try it once and stroll around and take in the fresh air. (Yes there are crowds here because you aren't the only one who knows about Pier 39, but it's not so unbearable that you can't get around)
author: Vic C.

description:
DON'T GO TO THE RESTROOMS. You simply must avoid them. They are really dirty all the time. I don't even see any cleaning crew around. They smell really bad. Upon entering, a foul stench fills your nostrils and burns them beyond recognition. It is as if Satan himself were tasked with designing a restroom so repulsive that even his captives would rather go in the corner in the fiery depths of hell. The standard of toilet tissue is also truly appalling, double ply in this day and age is simply a must. If I wanted to use single ply I would move to a third world country. I have heard people complaining about the sea lions but they are an absolute walk in the park compared to the halitotic odor emitting from these death traps. 

Otherwise lovely place.
author: Carlos T.

description: It's fun, a lot of people. A lot of attractions, restaurants and you can see sea lions. But food and coffee are bad, I wouldn't recommend to have snacks where. Toilet in second floor not so busy.
author: Elita L.

description: Must Go! I love this type of atmosphere, lots of people, lots of shops, nice atmosphere, and water!! The view is great when u get to bottom of pier and there are so many cool shops to browse in. My advice save your souvenir shopping for this place, not FW!!!! I saw the difference and regret buying my stuff from FW and not here!!! Way better prices and stuff!
author: Justine S.

description: This is clearly a must when you are in San Fran! You cannot miss the sea lions and cool little shops. I was disappointed because the beer bar was closed for a private event, but it is defiantly worth a stop!
author: Heather M.

description: Pier 39 is a very nice place to hang out and take pictures of the sea lions. The place has a lot of shops and restaurants. And there is a small stage, they do have small shows there. Once you done with pier 39 just keep going to fisherman's wharf.
author: Hani G.

description: Great deals for knock off shit. The food is awesome. The parking sux and there are WAY too many people all the time. Have fun
author: L K.

description:
If it's your first time visiting SF, you'll want to stop by Pier 39 just to check it off your list. There's quite a few fun things to do in the area - there's an aquarium, carousel, shops, restaurants, and of course the famous sea lions! Kids and adults alike will enjoy meandering around the pier. It doesn't hurt that the best crepes I've eaten are found in a tiny crepe house here, either! 

Most of the restaurants are chains, so if that's not your style don't eat here. There's some interesting shops that I haven't seen anywhere else, so take the time to explore and see what all there is to see. The pier isn't too big, and can easily been seen in a few hours. Along with the crepe restaurant, I'd recommend checking out the Left Handed store for fun, let handed gifts for your favorite lefty, and the bath salt stand where you can package your own salts for fun gifts.
author: Melinda R.

description: It's very well maintained, with very nice buildings, wooden walkways, bridges, and sea views. However, it is a tourist trap, but one I would recommend anyway. Just try not to spend too much money here. The sea lions are pretty great to see. There are also great views of Alcatraz in the bay. There is easy transportation to Pier 39 using the streetcars. We came after Christmas and they had a huge Christmas tree that was decorated, and it looked great at the entrance to the pier. There is a huge variety of restaurants, dessert places, specialty food, seafood, and souvenir shops. You could visit San Francisco without visiting here, but if you have time, you should come see the sights. We visited 3 times.
author: Chloe G.

description:
This is a must-see spot for tourists and locals, alike!

I've been visiting Pier 39 ever since I was a baby, and most recently started visiting from time to time again now that I'm a young adult. The pier has changed a lot from what I remember...I believe it's been over 10 years since I first visited the famous pier.

It seems less seagull-y than I remember and MUCH CLEANER now. There are also more restaurants here and more things to do like window shop, stroll with the family or friends, and the best part is the validated parking in the DESIGNATED parking structure (don't make the mistake of parking in the wrong structure)! 

There's fancy dining (Fog Harbor upstairs), chill but delicious clam chowders downstairs, and chain-dining like Hard Rock. There's the famous SF Lefty store for left-handers and overpriced boutiques as you walk farther down the boardwalk area. It's a great place for young kids, but it's so annoying and packed during summer and peak tourist times.

P.S. I only checked in here because there's a discount deal via Yelp for restaurants (NO SHAME!)
author: Jodi H.

description: Stopped by to see the Seals on Pier 39 always an interesting site.  You get a view of Alcatraz as well so it is fun to see.
author: Dona S.

description:
I'm pretty convinced that nothing signifies our cultural and social decline more than the proliferation of "selfies."

When historians look back at our downfall one day, they won't make long lists of contributing factors like they did for the Roman Empire. They'll just all take selfies and create memes with the words "the end can be traced back to this" written across them.

If Pier 39 could add one more attraction, it should be a sign with the rule "No Selfies." 

I will fully acknowledge that about 2% of the population takes amazingly good selfies, and they're the ones whose pics I double tap on Instagram. It should go without saying, but NONE of them are guys!  A guy taking a selfie is as despicable as Justin Bieber singing a song. You know those cars that won't let you turn the ignition on if they know you're under the influence of alcohol? Well, phones should be installed with a device that automatically shuts the camera down when it detects a male is trying to take a selfie.

If we're friends (or yeeps), there's no need to take my condemnation as personal. For I hate the sin, not the sinner.

There are tons of traits that tourists exhibit (which are in abundance at Pier 39) that we can poke fun at, but I'll leave that to others and zero in on selfies, since it's a relatively new epidemic.

Studies show that some of the world's best photographers are Asian tourists and people wearing fanny packs.  There are plenty of both at Pier 39. Yet, some people just can't resist stopping to take selfies in the middle of crowded areas where others are trying to walk by. Like really, it was so important they just had to impede the flow of foot traffic all for a pic with shoddy quality that they'll probably want to retake multiple times.

There's nothing wrong with wanting to have pictures of yourself or with others at touristy spots. I even dare say it's a positive thing.  So, next time you want this, find an Asian tourist or fanny packer and ask them to take the pic for you then step aside from the crowd for it. It will be of a much higher quality and may even capture a memory that you can keep for a life time!

Conclusion: Pier 39 has some attractive elements, but much like taking a selfie, the only point I see (in spending time there) is being able to say you did it.

Im my humble opinion, there are better places to visit and take pics at in SF. Search under the "local flavor" category and you may stumble across a few finds that provide a more authentic sense of the city.  The only problem is, no one else may be at those places, so you'll be forced with the decision to experience the moment as is and remember it, or, take a dreaded selfie that will be met with my strongest denunciation.
author: Brandon C.

description: It's always a place I come visit with my family when I'm in town.. It can get super packed at times but it's worth it.. There's tons of place to eat and shop. And all the seafood you can eat it that's your thing lol! Nice views of the bay, the golden gate bride and Alcatraz. They also do boat tours so you can get a look at everything up close.
author: James T.

description:
The Bain of my existence - when I first moved to SF from Philly I worked on Pier 39. It's definitely a place for Tourists, and what we call Bridge and Tunnel. I've become a bridge and tunnel guy but won't admit it to anyone since I lived there for 20 yrs. 

Bad Parking
The parking lot makes more money than the ENTIRE Pier combined!! The spaces leave no room for opening the door without nicking the car next to you. 

Chronic Pain
The wood planks can ruin your knees, ankles, back etc. That's on the 2nd floor. I ruined my left knee for the rest of my life by working there. 

Good Enough
PROS - it's a must see for your visiting friends, the shows, the trinket shops, the crab and other seafood, beautiful vistas. 

****MUST DO ONCE IN YOUR LIFETIME****
The absolute best thing about Pier 39 are the Seals and Sea Lions that swim in and have their own decks to lounge on the left side of the pier. Go towards Neptunes palace - have a meal - ask for Paul D to wait on you (he's excellent and will take care of you) and then go to the left facing the golden gate bridge and just sit there and take in nature for free. I've never seen so many seals and sea lions - they play, push each other off of the decks - it's amazing to watch and experience. 

A lot of the restaurants serve good food at fairly - not too out of hand - prices. Better here than down the street at Alioto's and the rest of them that are double normal prices. Neptune's is one of the better spots in my opinion. Also good wine and beer by the glass.
author: Rew C.

description:
This venue is part of the local tourist trap called the Embarcadero, but my review is of the really stinky sea lions lounging outside, as opposed to the building itself.

Yes, there are a pile of sea lions here.  They must have the easiest lives on the planet, as all they do is lie there, stink, and get photographed.  With that said, you just have to take a look, and whip out your camera like every other tourist there.

This part of the pier also gives your best view of Alcatraz, though you'll probably want to bring your telephoto lens.
author: Edward L.

description: It was a cute little place full of shops and excitement. Lots of street performers and different places to eat. I loved seeing the sea lions flopped all over the docks relaxing!!! My only complaint was the amount of people. Once the day got going you could barely move! People shoving to get through the crowds. I would avoid the weekend because we had better luck during the week. Also a lot of the tourist stuff is overpriced on the pier and much cheaper down the street. Great view at the end of the pier to Alcatraz, it was a must see!!!
author: Morgan W.

description:
Capital T for Tourist Trap!  

But every once in a while it's fun to be a tourist in your native town especially since I hadn't visited in over ten years. Try not to actually buy anything here. Your wallet will be seriously hurt. Sea lions are fun to look at. The views of the bay and Alcatraz are purty. Recommend the Aquarium for the kids, smallish but has some very nice exhibits. If you are a resident of the Bay Area, you can get a discount. 

Going on a lightly rainy day worked really well. The crowds were manageable.
author: Nora S.

description: This place defines tourist trap, other than seeing the sea lions, which you can do without entering the pier, there is absolutely no reason to visit here.
author: J. B.

description: If it's your first time to SF, this is a to-go place. Because this statement is true, it's always crowded, the restaurants are expensive and not that great, and it's pretty dirty. There are a lot of little shops to walk around and there is clam chowder! You get a nice view of the water too I guess, although the water is pretty dirty. The parking around here is also expensive since it's a tourist area. If you come here, take BART or Caltrain and walk; it'll probably save you lots of time looking for parking. Coming here also gets repetitive; the scene is basically the same, and the restaurants/shops aren't overly interesting. Worth a visit if it's your first time to SF though!
author: Andrea W.

description: I have always enjoyed Pier 39 and I probably always will but the independent street performers are getting out of hand. They literally clog up the sidewalks and walkways so it takes effort to get around them and all the onlookers. I believe in freedom of expression and trying to earn a buck but they are getting out of hand. The pier is always kept squeaky clean and all the shops and restaurants are great. Good place to bring your family and take in the sights
author: Rob C.

description:
I have been here several times and i love it. There are alot of shops along the pier and also varieties of food choice. The down side is....Too many seagulls  and pigeons  try to get some food along the food stands and restaurants. They dont even bother getting close to you just to get food and that scares me. 

Walking around the pier is nice. I got to shop around and check souvenirs. On the back of the shops there are area for sea lions to chill and you get to watch them. It was an interesting experience checking those sea lions crawls ups to down. I think this is definitely a good place for family and friends just to relax and discover the port of SF.
author: Yushan W.

description:
I have got to agree with fellow Yelper, Rodney H.!
It is a tourist trap but it is fun even if you're a local. 

I've been living in the Bay for about 10 months & just this last weekend was my first time at down in this ever-so-famous area. I know! I am slacking in getting to know my city better. lol.

There is so much to see down here. A ton of food choices, shopping centers, perfect for people to load up on the souvenirs ;)

There is a lot of foot traffic as well as car traffic down here but what can you expect as one of the tourist destinations in SF. Even if it was crowded, it didn't seem congested. A plus :)

If you ever visit SF or if you're just a local, you'll have fun just strolling & enjoying the sunshine :) It won't disappoint, SF is amazing.
author: Camille C.

description:
As all of the previous reviews have stated, Pier 39 is most definitely a tourist destination.  There are cute, kitschy shops and restaurants, most of which are pretty expensive.  Parking is also expensive, but you can save on it if you check-in with Yelp and pick up your free fun pack.  It's fun to browse the pier, but it isn't somewhere I can imagine spending an entire day. 

The Aquarium might be a nice way to spend some time if you have kids, but it's not very big.  My favorite part of Pier 39 is sea lions.  There are also great views of Alcatraz and the Golden Gate Bridge.  The street performers are always fun to watch.  

If crowds don't scare you, this is a good place to come with visitors.
author: Kim L.

description:
Well yes, it's a tourist attraction. There's not much I can say that has already been said, but when it's not too crowded, it can be a real peaceful spot. I love the food, but it can get overpriced, better to pick up souvenirs for friends and family instead. I'd consider this spot to be pretty default, it's not so much a hidden gem if everyone's flying in and coming directly here. :P

Sea lion watching can be pretty entertaining, they fight and wrestle each other for the perfect nap spot. My husband and I have been here a couple times, but have yet to check out the aquarium, we always find something else to do instead. Sorry folks, I just moved to SF and still consider myself a tourist, there's so many things I still need to tackle in the 7x7 city. I feel like the city itself is a tourist attraction and it's not like this is the best of them all haha, but I don't mind taking visitors here.
author: Jenny M.

description:
My favorite was the seal lion park!
It was so much fun to watch them on the rafts and making sounds.
Lots of places to eat & shop - each one more expensive than the other.
author: Carrie W.

description:
Fun area worth checking out for anyone who has never been before.
But, now that I've been, I really have no desire to go back. While it was very cool to see the water, the seals and Alcatraz, the pier really had nothing else to offer. A lot of the stores were cool, but they were also overpriced or sold things that would have been difficult to take back home with me (I live in Nevada)
It also took forever to drive back to our hotel once the normal traffic of tourists and locals started. What was a fifteen minute drive there took almost an hour to get back.
author: Katelyn R.

description:
Why do I love this place so much? There's so much within walking distance.

We arrived early and found a great parking spot, right by that chowder place (yeah there may be more than 100 there), you know where the seagulls are fearless and get fed by all the tourists.

We returned a few hours later to find our car completely shielded in Sea Gull goo, poop,droppings, muck...we just laughed. Avis rental wasn't as amused.

I passed 8 bread bowl chowder places to get a "to-go" In-n-Out Burger.

We spent $9 for a cup of coffee with whiskey in it, before 10am.

We watched corpulent, surly sea lions lay in a mound bigger than east coast mountains, while other's crawl over each other for a half hour.

We let street vendors haggle with us...without ever saying a word. I saved $20 just by blinking.

Not one Steamed Crab vendor laughed when I said, "I'll trade you a blind crab for one that doesn't bite."

Watching tourists board the "$15 to Tour Alcatraz" boats. Boats that illegal immigrants from Cuba would say, "Naw, I'd rather take an inner tube or that 2x4 to float to America on."
author: Rick H.

description: Always stop by here when I'm in town. The one thing I despise is the wind. Lots of memories here with family and friends.
author: Marcus D.

description: Such a fun place to walk around and explore!! We spent a couple hours there and enjoyed walking around and exploring the shops they had!! Definitely a great place to visit! Lots of fun!
author: Amanda G.

description: Loved pier 39-my husband and I did our own pub crawl started out at hardrock, they did a beautiful job on this restaurant and the bartender was pleasant.  Next we walked up to eagle cafe, bartender made husband a powerful couple of drinks. He was happy LOL..off to our next stop was fog harbor..we couldn't even get to the bar, smelled yummy though..place was mobbed.  So off to the crabhouse..very crowded as well. We did get a seat at the bar, had some garlic bread, it was  cold when it arrived.  The bartender was very sweet.  Swiss Louis had spectacular views!!!! Bartenders were great.  We then stopped at chart house,  gorgeous restaurant and bar. We ended up eating in the bar area. At first they said we couldn't have a seat in the restaurant area due to guests they were expecting. Meanwhile the tables were empty.  We realized that the bar tables were available and moved  there.  They made me a crab mac n cheese ..it was excellent . I special ordered this and was completely impressed with my meal.  The waitress was very accommodating.  We then sadly left the pier....perfect place to visit.  After our sunset cruise we stopped at Bodins and had oysters...the young man serving us was terrific, polite and very friendly.  This place smells fantastic, bread baking aromas fill the air!! Bread is delicious. Make sure you see the seals on the dock! Anchor steam beer is amazing..
author: Patti A.

description: Tons of tiny shops it is a great place to go shopping for tiny and placeless things. It is a little bit cowed so a wouldn't recommend bring children. But a very nice area
author: Braxton L.

description:
***************************** 1,062 *******************************

   I got to love this tourist trap. What not to love? Lots of Dungeness crab stands, lots of seafood restaurants,  Bouldin, Ghirardelli Chocolate, the bay, the view of Alcatraz, and the breath taking view of San Francisco Bay.... I often jog by here on nice day on the Embarcadero and always ends up here watching tourists passing by.
author: Manda Bear B.

description:
I absolutely love Pier 39! It really is a whole day event to be here: Food, Games, Shops, Boat Tours, Sea Lion watching, street performances, and more shops!

I went here again this past Saturday and oh my gosh it is packed like a tank of sardines. I think that's the only thing that bothers me about this place is the amount of people that go here too!

Definitely stop by here when you're in town. Parking may be expensive but you can get parking validation from certain restaurants! It is indeed one of those San Francisco gems that tourists from all over come to see. 

You may feel like a tourist when you come here, but who cares? My favorite things here include: 7D Experience (shooting game), the sweet shops, the carousel, eating clam chowder, and watching the sea lions!!!
author: Julie N.

description:
Absolutely the best touristy destination in SF!   
Pier 39 is known for its kitschy shops, casual dining, family fun, and last but not least... Hundreds of sea lions sunbathing on K-dock. These pinnipeds migrated here after the Loma Prieta earthquake hit San Francisco in October 1989. 
They've remain here ever since...

Recommendations:
-Bring a jacket. Temperature falls rapidly after the sun sets.
-Bring water ($5 bottle water here)
-Use public transportation; driving / parking is cray-cray here!!!!  
Or maybe it's just me :-/  
I'm a huge fan of Uber transportation service though :)
author: Snow W.

description:
I visited here when the cruise ship stopped at the city for the day. This was a very nice tourist area. The best part of it, in my opinion, were the SEALIONS!! It was fun seeing them lie around, and play in the water at times.

A lot of the shops here were very expensive, but regardless of that, this area's worth visiting to look around!
author: Alexander H.

description:
If your a fan of crowds of people and over priced touristy type stores you'll love this place.

Traffic is a nightmare. Trying to find somewhere to park is headache inducing.

If you happen to get there really early in the morning before everything opens it's sort of nice.
author: Mark B.

description:
Warning: this is a review purely made from a tourist:

Pier 39 is such a fun place to spend half the day. Yes, it is commercial, and it does remind me a little bit of the Santa Monica Pier, but if it's your first time visiting SF, I would definitely take some time out and come here.

There are some fun activities for people and families to do - you can get on a boat and take a tour of Alcatraz or around the bridge and come back. You can eat delicious clam chowder and tour the Ghirardelli Chocolate Factory. There's also some great (albeit, touristy expensive) restaurants in the area. 

If you're a photographer, you can also snap some pretty awesome photos here as well.
author: Lalida S.

description:
The Best Spot to spend a beautiful day...

Hangout with friend?? Go to Pier 39

Never Miss to take pictures with the crowd and Sea Lions
author: Priya S.

description:
There is something for everyone.
Don't miss out on the view at the very back. You most likely will get to see some sort of live performance.
Shop. Eat. Have fun!
author: Marla M.

description: Overly saturated by tourists, like myself, but I'm sure ya'll know that already. Be prepared to cash out for parking and anything else on that pier, this is no bargain trip by any means.
author: Mr. Rawsteen ..

description:
I LOVE This Tourist Trap. I technically am a tourist so why would I not love it? you can trap me in here all your want! I have been here so many times that I can not count it all, but I love coming back here, it's beautiful, full of people (but not too crowded since it's a large area), great food and cheap souvenirs.

Food: plenty of great food, you can't go wrong but anything here! fresh oysters, cold crab (or hot) clam chowder in a sour dough bread bowl, and especially that fruit stall near the front, very delicious fruits and the BEST Strawberries I've ever had!! every single strawberry is beautiful, stem on, large, bright red, moist and juicy! I would come back here JUST for the strawberries! the strawberries are 9.99/lb and that's around 7-8 strawberries.

there are plenty of souvenir shops, and the price is of course higher than Chinatown (which has the exact same stuff) but it's still relatively cheap compared to other tourist traps I've been to.
author: Bebe B.

description:
After visiting the Ferry Building, my boyfriend and I took the trolley to Pier 39. It hosts a bunch of shops and restaurants, along with a great view of the Bay, including Alcatraz and the sunbathing seals!

Pier 39 has a very seaport like vibe, along with super touristy shops and eateries. In addition, there are many fun activities for kids to do. While cool and all, we weren't really interested in the touristy stuff, so we quickly went about our way. The sunbathing seals, however, were freaking awesome. Some were just lounging and some were playing around... it was a cute sight to see.
author: Felicia L.

description: While most of this place was just as you might expect a busy, touristy area to be - I forgave it all of that as soon as I heard the sea lions (the reason that I came to the pier). Walking around, I heard them before I saw them. They were surprisingly loud! They are always barking, growling and even roaring. Perhaps this is why they are named sea lions? I had never seen sea lions up close, much less in the wild, before, and I just loved sitting on one of the benches in front of their area and watching them. They are pretty interesting creatures to watch - both cute and beautiful, awkward looking on land but then so graceful and elegant in the water, and never seeming to stay still. If you are in San Francisco, seeing these animals is a definite must! It was certainly a highlight of my trip.
author: Jordan T.

description: I had wonderful time with family make sure to wear warm clothes and sign up for their offer mostly they send you coupons with 50% off
author: Raj J.

description: I still love coming to Pier 39 and walking around. I have fond memories of coming here when I was younger. We used to walk around browsing stores and I'd always get some clam chowder in a bread bowl. Now that I'm older, I like coming here to have a drink and enjoy the scenery. It's fun going to Wipeout to enjoy a beer and the fireplace out front. Or drop by the Wines of California Wine Bar for a glass of wine. And if you want to satisfy your thirst and the inner kid in you, go by Players, grab a drink and play some games! I know it can get super touristy, but on a nice day, hanging out at Pier 39 can be a treat!
author: Elena N.

description:
If your idea of fun is walking around a huge gift shop, then this is your place. Beyond that, Pier 39 is a commercial fueled tourist trap. everything is overpriced, hokey in concept, and forgettable once you buy it. The only redeeming quality is how busy and exciting the crowds usually are. This is a great place for people watching. There are also a few cool things scattered around, like a 5 dollar maze and a staircase that plays musical notes. 

This is the second most overrated part of San Francisco, behind the Trolley rides. The Fisherman's Wharf is worth checking out, but don't spend more than 30 minutes at Pier 39. And what ever you do, don't eat at any restaurants at the Wharf. There are so many good restaurants outside the Wharf (like the Hollywood Cafe)
author: Gill S.

description:
Huge Tourist Trap - However, The Sea Lions Are Worth Visiting in the Early Morning to Avoid the Crowds. 

My mother and I visited Pier 39 briefly on the morning of July 31st, after strolling along the waterfront at Fisherman's Wharf. We walked to the area after riding the Powell-Hyde cable car and hopping off at Lombard Street. 

Pier 39 is a huge tourist trap. It consisted of a boardwalk-style pier lined with expensive souvenir shops and chain restaurants catering to tourists by selling overpriced goods. However, there was a large carousel in the centre of the pier that I enjoyed taking photos of, which was very colourful and beautifully detailed. Pier 39 was basically a large outdoor mall. 

When we arrived to the pier in the early morning (around 8 AM), there was nobody around and we were the only people there (because the stores/restaurants had yet to open), which was lovely and the atmosphere was quiet and relaxed. However, I can only imagine how busy and crowded this area would be starting in late morning and into the afternoon and evening. As someone who hates crowds and overly touristy areas, Pier 39 is definitely a place that I would avoid at all costs during these times. 

My mother and I only stopped at Pier 39 because we happened to be in the area. Originally, we did not plan on coming here and definitely would not have gone out of our way to include this in our itinerary. 

After strolling around Pier 39 and taking photos of the interesting carousel, we wandered over to the area of the pier where the sea lions were. For me, this is the only part of Pier 39 that made my visit worth it. There were also great views of the Bay and Alcatraz Island that were worth checking out.  

There were a bunch of large wooden platforms floating in a section of the Bay with tonnes of sea lions laying on them and piled on top of each other. We watched them for a little while, as they moved around, jumped on and off the platforms into the water and played with each other. It was quite fascinating and I really enjoyed watching them! 

You might like Pier 39 if shopping for overpriced touristy souvenirs, eating at expensive and inauthentic restaurants and battling through crowds of people are things you enjoy. But in my opinion, the only worth seeing at Pier 39 are the sea lions. If you do choose to visit here, I recommend getting there as early in the morning as possible, in order to beat the crowds. 

Despite the fact that I enjoyed strolling around the pier in the morning and enjoyed watching the sea lions, I would not return to Pier 39 for a second visit. In my opinion, there are so many more interesting things to see and do and authentic neighbourhoods with character and history to explore in San Francisco. Do yourself a favour and don't waste too much of your time here!
author: Brittany T.

description: There is around 20-30 shops of food, clothes, and souvenirs.  They have a bunch of things going on here.  It is kind of a tourist trap.  I recommend using Uber to get around.  Out of the 5 we used only 1 guy was kind of a jerk.  The Alcatraz tour needs to be booked 2-3 months in advance.  Circling the island is no problem but if you want to actually go on the island it is booked like crazy.  The food is good and its a little pricey but all worth the experience in my opinion.
author: Peter G.

description:
The nightlife, the sights, the views, the adventures as well as the ambience here definitely makes this place well worth of 5 stars. If possible, I'd give it 6 stars!

A historical landmark here in the beautiful city of SF. There are amazing views of the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz Island, as well as their beautiful skyline. There are also sea lions lunging around the pier near the bottom, where you can always hear their barking which is pleasant to hear honestly. 

The only perk here is the parking, which can be kind of a toughie, considering there are so many tourists walking around here. It is very chilly here so bring a coat and a scarf!! There is a carousel for the children as well as many shops to choose from to shop or window shop at! There are sports memorabilia stores, candy stores, souvenir shops and a fine array of restaurants to choose from to eat. The Aquarium is also here if you enjoy learning about the wonderful sea life. 

All in all, very wonderful place with an exciting vibe along with a vibrant ambience. A must to check out if you are planning a trip to the Bay Area!
author: Julian A.

description:
There is one reason I can really recommend Pier 39. Sea Lions. The honking, smelly but hilarious aquatic mammals are available by the bucketload here. I don't know why they came, but they seem to love canoodling on the floating platforms just... sealioning about and being adorable. 

This was the main reason me and my colleague Cressida ventured down to Pier 39 on a beautiful sunny Friday morning in San Francisco. Despite me getting us completely lost (totally unable to read maps properly), we eventually found this twee tourist hotspot along the waterfront. 

The pier itself is lovely with gorgeous wooden decking, a mix of shops and great decor (and photo opportunities) at every turn. They also have free public toilets and plenty of seating areas so you can stop and take a breath after a good walk around. The food selection here seemed to be very varied with delicious smelling waffle cones, fantastic looking seafood spots and all sorts of cafes and restaurants spread along the length and breadth of the pier. 

The shops and restaurants here did seem expensive, but you don't have to spend anything if you don't want to. As we were here on a Friday morning, it was lovely and quiet; but I can imagine it being very busy with tourists over a weekend. 

Whether you're up for a bit of retail therapy (I can recommend "Hot Licks", the hot sauce emporium) or just a wander, I can recommend a wander down Pier 39 to enjoy the sealions and the amazing views of the boats and the bay.
author: Vicky O.

description:
Seals!
Lol I always think of seals when I rem Pier 39, the seals lay around on the boat slips and it's neat to see them swim about. Other than that there is also a great view of Alcatraz for those who want to see it but don't want to actually take a tour. Lots of eating places on the piers. Had to pay $10 to park but deff worth it.
author: Autumn S.

description: Mongo like Pier 39. Mongo see boats. Mongo drink beer. Mongo eat hot dog. Mongo drink beer. Mongo see sea lions. Mongo drink beer. Mongo shop in many, many, many, many stores. Mongo drink beer. Mongo watch merry-go-round go round and round and round and round and round. Mongo get dizzy.
author: Mongo I.

description:
I wouldn't come here unless I am a tourist and know no better or more interesting place to go. I only went there today for the 'Tulipmania" to shoot photos of the beautiful tulips they set up in buckets all over Pier 39. Oh, also the sea lions were cute to watch. I saw some Yelpers call them "seals" in their reviews. On the sign there it says sea lions though. What is the difference between the two?

There are many seafood restaurants here, but I did not try any as I am sure they are way more expensive and not necessarily good.
author: Claire W.

description: Visiting from Miami, Florida we had to stop and spend the day at the Pier. It took us a good 45 minutes to find reasonable parking. Since we were not from the area we couldn't find a spot that seemed worth paying more than $40 for. It seemed as though paying to park was going to be a hassle. Especially if you planned to park directly across from the Pier? Forget it. Ridiculous prices. We were able to find a parking garage about two blocks away where we ended up paying $23 for the entire day. Definitely worth it. The Pier itself does have the touristy vibe but it's fun to experiencing especially since you're visiting from another state. We saw the sea lions, had clam chowder in a bread bowl, bought some souvenirs from the myriad amount of shops on property and eventually ended the day with a cruise tour of the Golden Gate Bridge. Great experience for everyone! If you're visiting and playing Tourist then the pier is worth your time.
author: Alicia S.

description:
How can Pier 39 not get 5 big stars! This is a San Francisco staple/must-see/can't go wrong. It's definitely a spot you would take any tourist or visitor - it's one of my favorite attractions in SF (cheesy as it sounds).

On a good day, it's actually great to do the walk from Embarcadero to Pier 39 and you can then easily explore that area. It's about a 20-30 min walk but at a leisurely pace where you'd stop to take pics and such. It goes by fast and of course the view is amazing. There are actually a ton of cool spots along the way to get a drink or appetizer. I'd recommend doing that too if it's in the plans.

Once you get to the Pier there are a few things you can do. There are a ton of eating places so you can do drinks, eat, get dessert or junk food and be touristy and walk around the general area. THere are usually people doing little side acts and tricks - that always attracts a good amount of people! 

The MUST-SEE is the dock where all the seas like and congregate. It's a cute thing to show people visiting - they're always really excited about it! You can get great views too of the water, Alcatraz and what not. If you keep walking down further you run into all the cutesy pier shops, your tourist staples and such. Once you get to Fisherman's Wharf you have to try some seafood - too good not to try!  Almost anything you can imagine so hopefully you can at least sample or share with your group.

If you keep walking down and end up at the end of the street near Ghiradelli Square there's a great photo opp, as well as that Square which is adorable and you can get your chocolate fix on. It's worth doing the whole walk and being a tourist about it!

Always crowded on good weather days and holidays! So keep an eye out.
author: Priya S.

description: A tourist trap filled with kitschy stores and eateries that mostly offer little in the way of an authentic West Bay experience - but a necessary trap at that. If Pier 39 sucks in all the tourists, then hopefully there'll be more room at the truly good restaurants and shops that Bay Area locals frequent. And Pier 39 is also where may sightseeing boats and booze cruises dock, so yes, it's a necessary evil even for us locals.
author: Vincent L.

description:
As one of our stops during our cross country trip we made it to San Francisco and made it a point to go to Pier 39. When we arrived we had some trouble finding parking but once we finally found a spot we walked over to the pier and enjoyed the experience.

Some of our favorite spots were the trolley store, the different dining options, as well as the different entertainers on the pier. In the end the weather was nice, the pier was a blast, and we enjoyed eating at Pier Market Seafood. This was a blast and we hope we can travel back in the future.
author: Dan R.

description: My favorite place to take my kids for the tree lighting event. My adorable kids look seeing the Disney characters preform on stage. At the end, my kids got the chance to meet mickey and the rest of the gang. This is the closest that they are ever going to get to dianeyland.
author: Tamara S.

description:
Pier 39 is a tourist destination, especially for families with kids. There are shops and restaurants located here as well as the Aquarium of the Bay. We didn't walk the whole length of the pier, so I didn't see the two-story carousel. Entertainment includes street performers and California sea lions. There were a lot of sea lions hanging out on the docks. Alcatraz and the Golden Gate Bridge can be seen from the pier. Trish's Mini Donuts is a must if you are here!

Free Fun Pack at the California Welcome Center, which includes a coupon for two hours of free parking in the Pier 39 Parking Garage. Too bad I didn't know about this until after the fact. Parking cost us $8 per hour. Pricy!
author: Helen H.

description:
Pier 39 is great! But..... Don't waste your time at CRAB HOUSE. Came with family. Reserved a spot next to the window for a nice view under the name of "Maria" for 5 people & was told the wait was an hour. Not really complaining since its at the pier on a weekend night. Walking around wasn't a big deal. But as we came back after an hour, supposedly the "manager" says our name was not in the list... It was already bad enough that we were starving and had an hour wait, but to tell us that we weren't added on was complete and utter bullshit when they specifically confirmed everything with us. To add on they said there were no more windows seatings. Great. 

First impressions are everything. And if none of that nonsense happened I wouldn't have to complain. It set a bad mood so the food was mediocre. Maybe if everything went how it was suppose to My family would have had a better experience. Oh well.
author: Sadia B.

description: Lots to eat, see the sea lions, the ferry to alcatraz is nearby, enjoy the bay. Some of the things are pricey there since it is a tourist place. But very enjoyable especially since the weather was nice
author: Jesse V.

description:
Came here once again just to revisit this place... Pier 39 would always be my most favorite place to chill and have fun since my middle school & high school days!!! Pier 39 has changed alot thru out the years!!! Despite not seeing bumper cars which, I miss the most and not that many video arcade games to play with... My favorite video games back in the days... I have to say would be Pac -Man & Pole Position there were alot more other arcade video games that I like but can't name em all... 

Pier 39 for me would be the place that... I would always love to revisit on my days off... Not only do I like playing the arcade games... I also love the shopping areas,fast food and ice cream joints... Pier 39 also has lots and lots of fancy restaurants out of all the fancy restaurants that Pier 39 has... My most favorite restaurant that, I really like would be no other than The Hard Rock Cafe!!! Reason why its because I love to collect the Hard Rock Cafe memorabila and also love the hamburgers that they have at this Hard Rock Cafe of San Francisco!!!
author: William B.

description:
Pier 39 is a must-see for everyone visiting San Francisco. Because, c'mon, SEA LIONS. What is cooler than seeing all these sea lions sunbathing and/or fighting?! They're loud but cute ;)

Pier 39 is pretty easy to get to by public transporation, or they have their own garage if you're driving there. If you dine at one of the restaurants in Pier 39 you can get one hour validation for lunch or two hours for dinner. Not only are there are a lot of restaurants and stores here, but the Aquarium of the Bay is here as well. Pretty cool.
author: Esther K.

description: Having never been to San Fran, Pier the 39 was super cool!  Filled with many cute shops and restaurants, there is something for everyone. Sadly every time we went to see the seals they weren't there. Can't wait to come back!
author: Ashley N.

description:
Big tourist shopping mall. Lots of restaurants and shops. I don't care for touristy stuff but since I was on vacation and a tourist, I have to give it 5 stars for what it is... A tourist Crap Trap... lol.. 

We were sad that we didn't get to see the sea lions :(
author: C L.

description: Big, big fan of this iconic tourist spot. It's alive, full of energy, and such a cool representation of The City by the Bay!  Tourists AND locals alike enjoy this locale!
author: Gene D.

description: Pier 39  was a fun day trip while I was in San Francisco. As you could imagine,  it is very touristy, but everyone I met was nice, and the area overall was family friendly.  Fun place to grab a few gifts and a bite if you are into people watching.
author: Adrian A.

description:
Sorry SF tourists, but this is a lousy tourist trap.  We were there last night for a friend's birthday dinner, the restaurants and bars were insanely over priced and not fresh food.  I think one of the crab salads was rancid, stomach is starting to turn.  

Also had our car busted into, windows smashed, paint scraped up, everything inside stolen.  Not a Porche, it was a Prius.  And in a paid parking lot.  So to add insult to injury, we're out $40 parking fee plus another $500 deductable and the loss of all our personal items and all the time and hassle to repair.  

The only plus is that SF has such an expedited way of making poilce reports.  311 special hotline.  They don't even have to come out, just email you a file for your insurance company.  Great job SFPD.  Don't even have to go protect and serve, now that you have your hotline setup.  

If you want to go visit someplace nice, go to Carmel, Santa Barbara, Santa Monica,  Orange County, San Diego, Seattle, Vegas, New York, Miami...  San Francisco, and Pier 39 in particular, are just ruins of what was once maybe a nice city 50 years ago.
author: Chris M.

description: We miss this place! so much energy and shopping not to mention the great food it has to offer. We try to go every year for my birthday and then catch a Giants game down the street from here. Where ever you visit from bring a jacket! it does get cold once the sun goes down and though it's a tourist attraction it not bad at all and the street vendors make it a souvenir hotspot.
author: David P.

description: Fun pier to check out if you feel like being touristy. Wish they actually had some gluten free and dairy free dining options. I feel like they had so much dining, but nothing for my friend and I. Both of us have celiac disease and I have a dairy allergy so just kinda stunk that we had to leave earlier since their were really no food options for us.
author: Diana W.

description: Tourist Trap. Over priced everything. Views you can find anywhere. Not a big fan of tourist traps. Better things to see in San Fran.
author: Linds H.

description: Have not been here in years (last time I was, Yelp was not around)!  IT was such a neat place to stop and visit. So much to see and do! The shops, the seals, the restaurants, the view while walking around.  Pier 39 is a must stop when in San Francisco.  You won't regret it! We walked here from our hotel at least 4 different times on our stay and just couldn't get enough!
author: Jason T.

description: Holy smokes! Went during the 4th of July weekend and it was like walking around at Disneyland during summer. BUT... Super Cute pier. Loved walking around, checking out the shops and totally would have gotten an ice cream cone but the line was rediculously long. Apparently there are usually tons of sea lions hanging out but there were only 2 when i went. Still cool to see and worth checking if any are out there.
author: Heather M.

description: What a combo! Learning new NLP techniques at tourist haven Pier 39. Can you spot air swimmer Succophin, the Dolphin made of succulent & flowers in front of the "Only in San Francisco" store. Catch him before he grows into a bush. :)
author: Erin R.

description: Great place to hang out lots of shops in especially like nfl shop plenty of merchandise. Parking is expensive but worth it. Went to Bubba Gumps nice view of the bay also gave us an hour free for parking.
author: Mark O.

description:
The best thing about Pier 39- correction- the only good thing about Pier 39 are the sea lions. Grab your camera, enjoy their noisy banter and watch the younger sea lions crawling all over the grumpy older ones. Watch them dance with each other in the water. It's a beautiful thing. If this doesn't bring a smile to your face, you're evil.

The mall itself is ueber- touristy and overpriced as you can well imagine.
author: Ute L.

description: So touristy. Chain restaurants and shops and gobs of people. Even the sea lions attraction was sad, maybe 10 sea lions sleeping on a dock. Anytime I see Bubba Gumps Shrimp Co that's a red flag to avoid the area.
author: Shawn H.

description: If you're a visitor and you haven't explored San Francisco, pier 39 is a must go. From upscale restaurants to fine seafood eateries, the pier has it all. Lots of tourist shopping and cool street shows as well. Go to treasure island or Alcatraz for a fun tour. If you're a city person, many clubs and bars are nearby...
author: Jordan B.

description:
Along the loading dock (Embarcadero) are various piers, not that anyone is doing load or unloading or really much to do with shipping and cargo.

Pier 39 is all about unadulterated indulgence.

Be prepared to engage, inhale, exhale, and enjoy!

You can eat, drink, be merry--play, learn--there was something for everyone, I'm sure.  There was an aquarium of sorts.  No, I'm not talking about a fish tank with Henry floating upside down.  They seemed to have all sorts of sea creatures within the building, although I didn't enter.  $21.95 seemed a bit dear.  If only I was older or younger, the price would have been $12.95.  Parents, here is your chance to give your parents time with your kids for a creative learning experience that moves by itself.

Having recently eaten, I didn't see anything I really wanted.  It seemed at times like various boardwalks I'd walked in New Jersey, but without the familiar brands.  No Nathans hot dogs or Kohr Bros. frozen custard, but they had hot dogs and ice cream, to be sure.

I didn't indulge but it was quite amazing to see so much of everything and all those people.  What would have been better was to put the whole contraption nearer to the center of the loading dock, to make the rich people drive further to enjoy themselves away from the common folk.
author: Nobuyuki S.

description: Go see the sea lions! They are almost hidden. Don't walk down the part of Pier 39 that is all tourist shops and restaurants. If going west pass it up and go down the next Pier. Here are the sea lions laid on a series of floating docks. Some are just sun tanning, others are squealing and frolicking about so it's a fun things to briefly go and see.
author: Ben S.

description:
Welcome to Tourist Central.

I noticed that at the time of this writing, Pier 39 has 333 reviews.  That's half of 666--perfect; because Pier 39 is half beastly, in a way.

NOTA BENE--whether you're a local or a visitor, be sure to come here with either a full wallet or substantial money in your bank account, because this place is calculated to extract money from you in a variety of different ways, whether its from overpriced food, tons of useless trinkets and toiletries, or parking fees (which you can lower by spending more money at a restaurant and getting a validation).  It's essentially a big, outside, alternative, ocean front mall.

Now, don't let my cynicism discourage  you--this place is a lot of fun, and there's lots of things for every member of your family to enjoy.  Your date will love coming here with you.  It just takes $$$, and more than a little bit.  My daughter loves the bath salt store, and the food ranges from decent to yum (some of the places here serve PRIMO clam chowder).  One thing that I did notice is the seemingly high rate of turnover from a number of the shops here.  I tried to do a Yelp check-in on a number of the places here on my iPhone and found that a lot of them don't exist on Yelp (and there's often another business at that location now).

If you haven't been here yet and are thinking about it, I say go for it.  Find as many coupons and deals as you can and enjoy yourself.  The old advertising slogan I used to hear on television was "Pier 39 is a Wonderful Time!"  They're telling the truth--just be prepared. . .
author: Matthew D.

description:
Why 3 stars? Because it's total tourist takeover... but they do have seals.

   ---   ---   ---

This is exactly the kind of place I don't like to go when I'm visiting a city. The place that seems like it should be cool, but it just isn't. The last time I was in San Francisco, my girlfriend wanted to go... and I told her about 100 times that it's just tourism gone wild. She didn't care, and raved about the pier.

I'm just not wowed by expensive souvenirs and big signs. I like walking around the eclectic San Francisco neighborhoods and popping into to 500 square feet delis or bars. That's the real city, not the places that have the "I left my heart in San Francisco... AT PIER 39" shirts.

That being said, we stumbled upon the seals... and I have to admit that it was pretty damn awesome. I could have watched them fight with each other all day. And the views of the water/Alcatraz in the background aint the shabbiest either.

That being said, I'll probably call it a wrap on my appearances at Pier 39.
author: Brett N.

description: Pier 39 was jumping. We were there on a Sunday before Columbus Day and happened to be the last day of fleet week. Fleet week featured the blue angels which was a nice unexpected treat but the crowds were ridiculous. We went back and enjoyed the pier on Monday Columbus Day and it was much better. Casual stroll lots to see. Plenty shopping and places to eat. Mini donuts stand is a must. Donuts melt in your mouth and served warm
author: Dona W.

description: Lots of cute and quirky little shops!! It was awesome seeing Alcatraz island but don't get too close to the ledge when you're on the deck viewing the scenery as the waves will come up and splash you! The sea lions are also a fun sight to see :)
author: Melissa C.

description: Since I was a little girl visiting the SF Warf was like taking a kid to the candy store. Always fun and amazing people from around the world. If you're lucky enough you may see a bit of a show in the bay as well.
author: Nancy C.

description: Easily my favorite place to visit in S.F. There are many great things to do at pier 39. This is where you catch the ferry to Alcatrez or there is another ferry that cruises around the bay including the Golden Gate. There are many great resteraunts and shops in the area. I think my favorite part was seeing the dozens of sea lions!
author: Christopher F.

description:
So you've never been to SF and you wanna be a tourist. Where do you go? Pier 39, of course.  There are cool little shops and tourist attractions (especially that tourist trap Bubba Gump) if you want to loaf around the city by the Bay. 

So you've been to SF many a time and you want to hang with the locals. Where do you go? Not Pier 39. To be fair, there are restaurants that look pretty cool. Other than that, I'd recommend just walking around the city of SF. I think you'd get more culture, better food, and a better "SF Experience".
author: Temenah C.

description:
***Pier 39 is incredibly touristy and unbelievably busy (even on a cold day); it is not really for me (reminds me of the Santa Monica pier), but there is a lot to do; you can find touristy stuff here like San Francisco magnets and Biscoff cookies***

I think there are a few paid parking structures in this area.
author: Anthony N.

description:
You really never appreciate things until you don't have access to it as much anymore.  I was born and raised...lived in SF my entire life...until recently I moved out to Elk Grove for a job.  Yes, it's only 2 hours away...but still, way too far to my liking.

I come back to SF every day that I have off.  My stops always include pier 39.  Why?  It's beautiful...it's what SF is about. And besides, I love standing out at the end of pier 39 while staring out into the ocean feeling the breeze on my face.  The smell of salt water is invigorating.  Freakin love it and miss it. 

While living here, I used to take walks out to the pier from J-town.  After a Giants game, I walked the long way towards the pier and then back home.  I always stop and watch the spray painting planet peeps as if I've never seen their work before.  There is always a grown man or a son banging on his drum.  You can't forget the bush man just a few blocks down.  

Oh yeah, and grab some donuts at trish's. 

Love it!
author: Jen W.

description: The best part of Pier 39 is the Ben and Jerry's ice cream shop and the sea lions! The sea lions gave us a good laugh, by barking at each other and lazily laying themselves out to dry. There are plenty of places to shop inside the Pier 39 outdoor mall, and even more places to eat. This is a good place to catch a bus, taxi or trolley/cable car. The views are gorgeous and you can see Alcatraz from this area. You can also hop on a cruise and go fishing or sight seeing.
author: Margaret P.

description:
Complete tourist trap but you've gotta visit it In order to see the seals.

Where can you go and find a left handed store right next to a knock off Disney toiletries establishment?  Only at pier 39.
author: Kelleigh M.

description: I always enjoy myself when I come to the Pier. Never a dull moment. And they is always a something to do. Me and my honey come for Vday and I didn't know why we pick all days because it was pack. That's the only reason I gave a 4 starz. Beside that Entertainment was Perfect and Food was Amazing.
author: Carletta L.

description: This is a great tourist area that has so many little shops and restaurants. Great fresh seafood and amazing views of so many things like the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, and the Bay Bridge, as well as the Sea Lions and the marina. This is a major tourist attraction, but another one of those places you have to go if you are going to visit San Francisco. If you are on a budget, maybe eat somewhere else.
author: Tina S.

description:
Possibly my favorite tourist trap on the West coast. I have fond memories of coming here with family over the years - trips with my grandma as a kid and romps through the city with cousins as an adult, Pier 39 has always had my back.

Most of the food is overpriced for what it is, and most of the stores are souvenir-oriented, but it's still not bad for a peruse and hosts other cool outings like gawking at sea lions, looking at Alcatraz, and passing through the aquarium.

Maybe not a full day's activities unless you're specifically coming to the city for a week's vacation, but a fun place to go from time to time if you're semi-local. If you're a clam chowder in bread bowl kind of person (everyone not lactose intolerant or allergic to shellfish should be) then this is the sort of place you do that too.
author: Riki N.

description: It's very hectic because of all the tourists. However, it definitely has a lot of places to check out and tons of food to eat. If you wanna have some fun with friends and family and just relax, come to the Pier! Plus there are a ton of Pokestops and water Pokemon if that helps.
author: Erica S.

description: Cool pier with lots of different stores and restaurants. There is something that will satisfy everyone there. It looked to be one of the better piers in the area. You could also see sea lions sunbathing from the docks.
author: Ryan H.

description:
Located at Fisherman's Wharf, Pier 39 is quite the tourist destination.

The main draws are the beautiful views of the water (look for Alcatraz in the distance!) and the sea lions.  The sea lions love to come out and sun themselves right by the pier and it is a pretty fun sight.  There is plenty of education material posted about the sea lions as well, which makes the experience more interesting.

Overall, I don't see the huge appeal, but I enjoyed my time here watching the sea lions play in the sun.
author: Sonya L.

description: This is about the biggest tourist area I think you can find.  But if you are in town it is worth walking through, it will provide some entertainment.  I could sit and watch the sea lions fight for hours alone.
author: Mike B.

description: Don't buy online, no help no refunds.
author: Jesus O.

description:
There's no better place to get a hefty dose of annoying tourism, terrible food, street performers, views of Alcatraz, and wonderfully awkward sea lions. 

It does hold its useful parts, though. It's a great place to rent a bike to ride across the Golden Gate Bridge, buy ferry tickets to Alcatraz, etc. Not exactly things that are my cup of tea, but they are there for your perusal. 

Pro Tip: If you're looking to grab a cab or Uber, head out to Embarcadero and have them pick you up in the pull off where the cable car rails are. It'll be better than fighting traffic while you're getting into your cab.
author: Benjamin G.

description: A little better than average. Probably another of those things that you can do to enjoy a day outside and people watch.  Plenty of stores, some better than the usual trinket fare, but also some decent food place and s carousel to amuse the kids.  They have a magician there sometimes as well.  It's a nice stop for the day.
author: Nick S.

description:
I walked a long the pier on a Saturday and it was soo crowded.. but I guess that's normal. LIke any pier really, you have a ton of local jewelry vendors, souvenir shops, seafood stands, etc plus the crazy amount of seagulls and pigeons. The seagulls are huge here..... Not a fan of birds scavenging for food on the tables. 

The rating could be my fault since I was already too full to try seafood here, but I didn't even go into any of the shops because it looked quite boring. Upside there was a huge christmas tree and they have a bunch of "photo spot" signs of great places to take a picture.
author: Candace L.

description: This is always one of the highlights to my visit to San Francisco. The energy and vibrance around the pier is outstanding. To save money on parking, many of the restaurants will validate your parking ticket and give you $9 off a $45 parking fee. The many shops and street performers will keep it interesting for at least 4-6 hours. There are many dining options across the entire spectrum of restaurants. One of the highlights of my visit was watching the sea lions near the end of Fisherman's Wharf. Although, a bit smelly, their social interactions with each other will keep you entertained. So don't miss out on this experience.
author: Jim T.

description: Worth to come and see the sea lions. Lots of food around the area. Definitely an area to check out if you're visiting.
author: Michelle V.

description: Fun atmosphere,  lots of little shops and places to explore. Seal lions are fun to watch.  Restrooms a disaster.
author: Irene S.

description: This place is unbelievable. The appetizers (Honey BBQ Shrimp) were amazing. The sauce on the shrimp needs to be bottled and sold. The fish (Aha Tuna) was super fresh and tasty. I highly recommend this restaurant...!!!
author: Mark G.

description:
Very touristy place, but nonetheless very fun to visit. Many things to do & see. Carousel is pretty fun and so is the 3D rides. The seals are annoying and stinky. Ahhh Chocolate Heaven :)

And yes, parking can be pretty difficult. Also, read the sign at the parking garage closely cause it's tricky! Very tricky. You can find free parking if you have the patience to drive around & around to find it.
author: Amy C.

description: Bring layers of clothing.. The sea air gets chilly any time of year.  If you forget to bring sumn warm, There's tons of shopping and warm clam chowder everywhere! Great seafood dining, DON'T feed the seagulls.. They will jack you up.  Lot's of touristy things to do including tours of Alcatraz and the city. Doughnut bites and hot chocolates galore! I think it's a cute place to go on a date or just for fun. The 7D video games are amazing and the carousel is totally instagramable. I feel like it's a San Francisco treat for any age. It's touristy but not cheesy.
author: Mandie A.

description: My SF guilty pleasure, this place is as touristy as you can get but it had quirky shops, beautiful views and a nice friendly atmosphere! We spend a few hours here before our take off to alcatraz and it served it's purpose!
author: Cornelis T.

description: You could easily spend a whole day here and get away with spending very little money. A very nice and relaxing day with a bit of fun for everyone in the family.
author: Tyler C.

description:
Tourist heaven.
Get souvenirs, eat at Bubba's,
Good views of Alcatraz and if you're into organized tours, good place to sign up for one.
It was nice to walk along the waterfront, but was quickly put off by the abundance of tourists and panhandlers. Quite a feeling to have, when you yourself are a tourist.
There was a cool shop that sold lots of chocolate covered things. Tried hard to find a good seafood place, but everything either seemed highly commercial or highly generic. There's also an aquarium over here.

Not much parking in the immediate area, but if you're willing to park a few blocks away, you should easily be able to find a street spot.
author: Carol B.

description: Great place to visit when your in town. Check out the seals and get something to eat.
author: David R.

description: If you are from out of town or new to the area, you have to come check out the Pier. Lot's of restaurants and shops to visit here. Great views of the bay, Alcatraz, Golden Gate Bridge, and sea lions. Although once you have been here a couple time the novelty definitely wears off and it becomes a place you avoid at all cost till you have out of town guest.
author: Kenny B.

description:
The carousel is CLOSED for repairs to the wheelchair ramp, and yet the web site says it's open. This misinformation resulted in a child's total meltdown!!!!!!! Try explaining that to a 2 year old who loves carousels and traveled quite a ways to get there...

Otherwise, great. Once she stopped screaming, we enjoyed the bubble machine, the puppet shop, and the aquarium.
author: jenn H.

description:
Pier 39 is a-ok to visit if you have never been there.  It is fill with all kinds of tourist type shops...places to leave your money!  :)   They have some
great restaurants.. including Bubba Gumps and my favorite, Pier Market.
They also have crepe shops, jewelry shops, chocolate, ice cream and
candy shops.  Sports shops...well, you get the idea.  Just about every
other shop sells the $9.99 fleece SF jackets!

I go to Pier 39 to see the sea lions and to go to specific shops or
restaurants.  Other than that I don't spend a lot of time on the Pier...
too touristy!...haha I'm surprised that's even a word! ;)

It is worth the trip to see the sea lions.  They are a riot to watch..
fighting, arguing and playing with each other... sleeping on top of
each other.. playing king-of-the-hill and pushing each other off of the
platform.  The kiddies will love watching them!  Here is a link to the
live sea lion's webcam:
http://www.pier39.com/Information/webcamnew.htm
author: Dale N.

description: Had an awesome time yesterday with my bff and mini me... Highlight was the entertainer putting a tennis racket over his whole body! So insane and he was hilarious!!
author: Natasha R.

description: It's all down here.  Food is reasonable and good.  Musicians and kid stuff all around.   You must pick up fun pack.  $20 off parking.   So $40 total for all day or only $30 of you eat at pier 39. Plus 20% off food here.  Supper helpful and friendly
author: Steve A.

description:
SEALIONS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!


Ok so this review is really for the little area right next to Pier 39 which smells of seawater and the ripening of flesh in the sun. I don't care if the surrounding area is a total tourist trap. I'm here for one thing! I have only two memories of San Fran from when I was a child and sea lions was one of them.

There were only 3 that I saw (in July they apparently are having babies elsewhere) which was a little disappointing but they made up for it with their adorableness. One of them even barked and swam laps back and forth in front  of us! The other two couldn't get off their fat tails... and this is why their genes won't be passed to the next generation.

Yes, I'm an animal lover freak and I love seals. OOOH SOMETHING SHINY!!!
author: Leslie D.

description:
I have traveled to many places and have seen many tourist traps, but Pier 39 has got to be the most OVERRATED tourist trap I have ever been to. 

There are so many amazing places/things to see/do in San Francisco and I will never be able to comprehend why Pier 39 is at the top of every tourists' San Francisco to-do list, but if it keeps the tourists on this side of the city, I am all for it (just kidding... kind of). 

For starters, Pier 39 is like a cross between a shopping mall and a county fair. There is nothing unique about most of the restaurants, stores and attractions in Pier 39 (I said "most" not "all") because you can find almost all of them in any other tourist trap/Middle American suburb throughout the country. 

Other than clam chowder bread bowls and views of the Bay, there is nothing about Pier 39 that will give visitors the San Francisco experience. 

Overall, Pier 39 is only worth visiting if you have some time to kill, and I would only recommend it for seeing the sea lions and the beautiful views of Alcatraz and the Marin Headlands. 

Tourists, save yourselves some time and money by visiting neighborhoods that are unique to San Francisco; not some carnival-by-the-Bay tourist trap.

On a side note about the sea lions: They are NOT as abundant during the summer because most of them go down to Southern California. Winter time is the prime time to see the sea lions in great numbers.
author: Mark B.

description:
A must when in San Francisco. I love the views of the sailboats and Alcatraz. I enjoy looking at all the sailboats on the nearby docks. You can catch sunset sails from here and experience being on the water with good views of the city. Near here they book ferry tours, and Alcatraz boat tours. There are street performers that had so much talent they should be performing live at Red Rocks. Yes it's touristy and the shops are touristy but I didn't even bother with those. Hard Rock Cafe is here and I bought a t shirt for a gift. Nearby is the best clam chowder- try samples from each vendor! Yum! 
Dont' miss the sea lions- I could spend hours here and I did- in fact I came here twice on my 3 night trip- just to watch them again. They push each other off the docks and they say " ark, ark, ark, " so loud you can't miss them.
author: Bonnie C.

description: ALL WAYS GREAT TIME KIDS LOVE IT .. lots to see and do and food is good... only thing is They need more and cleaner bathrooms ......
author: Kid R.

description:
One of the places to stop by if you're a tourist and you've never been to San Francisco.  I grew up in the bay so I would always visit this place when my relatives from the Philippines would come visit us. I love this place, I love being by the ocean. It isn't as cool as the beach but it's nice walking on the pier. 

There are a lot of restaurants and attractions to visit so you'll have a lot to choose from.   I always enjoy trying out a new place just to try out their clam chowder. Yes, I know.. I always bring up clam chowder. I also love ice cream. Try three twins ice cream when you have the chance! They have the best cinnamon ice cream I have ever tried!
author: Jared F.

description: Best to visit on a weekday. NOT A WEEKEND! Lots of souvenir shops. They all carry the same things for the same price! Some cool speciality shops. Great food and amazing views! A must see if San Francisco! Use Uber to get downtown. Parking is way $$$!
author: From C.

description:
I grew up in the Bay Area and spent most of my childhood in San Francisco. When I found out that this city is the most popular tourist destination in America, beating out both New York City and Los Angeles, I was SURPRISED.

"What the fuck is so special about San Francisco?"

We have no amusement parks, no flashy Hollywood, or the ideal "sunny California" beach-y image.

It's fucking San Francisco and you're going to freeze your ass off even in the summer.

But this is one of those cases when you don't know how great something is until you lose it. It wasn't until I left San Francisco that I realised how awesome this city really is. My boyfriend has never been, so yesterday I took him to do all the tourist-y bits and internally I thought "oh god here we go to these tourist traps...".

I haven't been to Pier 39 since I was a little girl, and immediately I was blown away by the cute "village like" atmosphere of the place. You have all sorts of people walking around - tourists, locals, people who paint themselves gold, street performers, the works. It seems that as tourist-y as it is, Pier 39 epitomises the vibrant atmosphere San Francisco uniquely possesses that makes it a "big city" that is different from the stale and shallow. Sure, we don't have much entertainment or even good weather, but we have something that I can't quite put my finger on... a certain je ne sais quoi as Tyra Banks would say.

Wander around the strange and unique shops ranging from a left-handed emporium to a shop created for magnet collectors. Eat at a restaurant with a great view of the bay and Alcatraz. Meet strange yet friendly people.

Welcome to San Francisco where everyone is friendly, strange, and a little bit fucking mental.
author: Clarissa Y.

description: Loved it and loved the Sea Lions.  A nice place to stroll around and look at the stores. There was a outdoor museum as well but we did not go in
author: Laurie I.

description:
Love this place.  There's a lot of shops and food places if you walk along the pier.  Not to mention, the view is amazing if the fog is not too heavy.  It does get windy but this is the city so dress warm.  

I love the street performers.  My friends and I actually stuck around to watch these guys break dance right on the street and they were amazing.   Food especially seafood is awesone.  Don't forget the musical stairs which is cool even for grownups.   If you're into whale watching they have lots of tours.  

Or if you just want to walk around the view is stunning especially during sunset.
author: Julieanne R.

description: I love Pier 39. I've been coming here for years. It's a great environment, with a lot of fun stores to shop in.
author: Kenny T.

description:
I have been here numerous times and no visit to San Francisco is complete without a visit to Pier 39! Yes, it is a touristy place, but it has lots to offer. The end of the pier provides breathtaking views of the bay and Alcatraz. Nearby, sea lions bask in the sun or play in the water. On the pier there are numerous restaurants including seafood, pizza, a Boudin  Bakery and a Hard Rock Cafe. 

Shopping is a main reason for visiting Pier 39. One of my favorite stores is Na Hoku, which is a Hawaiian based jewelry store with very nice pieces. I also like the college sports gear store. Pier 39 is one of the best locations for San Francisco tourist items ranging from shirts to magnets and everything in between. One of the best items to shop for is fleece jackets, especially if you forget to pack a jacket (like I have a few times). It can get cold in San Francisco even in August!
author: Susan M.

description: Pier 39 was my favorite part of Fisherman's Wharf. The atmosphere was always lively. There are a lot of good restaurants, shops, and tourist attractions. Also, visitors can see sea lions up close. I was able to take some amazing pictures of the bay from Pier 39. Cool place for tourist to check out.
author: Dominic B.

description: Def one of the most awesome spots to visit in San Francisco. You get to see the seals, Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz all from this spot. I had such an awesome time here and got to snap some cool pictures/video. Def a touristy area, it's a good idea to get here as early as possible to avoid the crowd. I went first thing in the morning and there was only 2 or 3 other groups of people there. It was perfect and I had a bunch of fun. Enjoy!
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Tacky tourist crap = 2 stars, sea lions = 5 stars. 

There's not much to say about this place that hasn't been said. It's silly, it's trashy, it's full of the sort of restaurants that children are drawn to and uninspired adults fearful of real, non-chain restaurants flock to. There are a couple of unique shops, but mostly it's just silly.

The sea lions, however, are delightful and fabulous.
author: Laura Kate S.

description:
People bitch that this place is full of tourist. Obviously.
Its iconic. Why would tourist not go here? Having been said, i love this place. The shops are cute, the views are gorgeous, the sea lions are adorable, they offer activities here, its a really sweet way to spend your day. 
Biscoff lattes there are hands down the best thing ive ever tasted.
author: Ella A.

description:
I'm new to the bay area and I absolutely love it here! There are so many things to do and see. You can get a good view of Alcatraz and also some sun bathing sea lions. Just be careful if you're walking around with food in your hands, the sea gulls will swoop in and steal your goodies LOL.
It does get very crowded since it is a tourist spot but its definitely worth it. There are so many restaurants and shops in the area with so many adorable souvenirs. BEAUTIFUL!!
author: Maggie J.

description:
Environment: Really nice! I don't know why this place has so little stars. At night time when the lights come on it could easily be a date spot. Maybe  the christmas lights that were up first week of January made it seem so nice.

Stores: Primarily a lot of restaurants upstairs and gift shops downstairs! The sock store is pretty awesome.

Occasion: Group of us driving back from Tahoe to LA decided to get dinner here as it was one of our friends birthday's. We walked around looking at gift shops...good times.

Overall: I have been in San Fran 3 times now and I think I've always ended up here. The slight sea breeze is refreshing after walking around town or being on market shopping all day! Tourist-y spot but still love it.
author: Ryosuke K.

description: This placed is super packed but there is so much to see. Plenty of stores for souvenirs, shoes, clothes, jewelry and can I say food. They have seafood, Mexican food, burgers and American. For the sweet tooth lovers they have donuts, chocolates and funnel cakes. Then you have the beautiful scenery of the beach. I've been here a couple of times and it never boards me. A must place to visit when your in San Fran!! Parking sometimes it can get crazy but it's worth it. Don't forget to get your validation at a pier 39 store or you will end up paying $30 for parking.
author: Aimee A.

description: We arrived with a stroller and the staff could not be more unwilling to help. It was a busy day and they all behaved like they didn't want to be bothered. It was 5 of us and we got different dishes, The food was ok, the seafood was better than the stake which was very bland. Overall overpriced experience.
author: Mahban G.

description: Pier 39 is fun! I have gone there many times before and had stopped going. Mostly because it felt run down and dirty. I was pleasantly surprised this time around.
