Everything looked wonderful, the flowers and plants were tidy and pretty. I didn't see garbage laying around and things just felt clean. The stores are your typical tourist stores but they are fun. My favorite part is at the very end of the pier where you can see Alcatraz and watch the ships sail by. We watched the fog come in and surround the Golden Gate. It was a great afternoon and I look forward to going back again soon.
author: LeeAnne B.

description:
Ok love San Fran but this is total tourist trap,
Not worth your time - you have to board for Alcatraz here which is cool, but that's about it...
author: Rebecca O.

description:
A tourist trap full of mediocre places to eat and drink is how one Yelper described Pier 39 and I have to agree 100%.

Funny I've never written a review about Pier 39 when half my family is from SF.  As a kid I loved Pier 39, but I was just a kid.  I know why I loved it......Pizza from Sal's, which went out of business many years ago and I enjoyed the street performers.....particularly Bush Man who passed away recently. RIP Bush Man.  I remember standing across the street as a kid with my family and just watching Bush Man scare the shit out of people  Lmao  Awesome as a kid and as an adult.  He had a simple gig that drew crowds and made people laugh.  The street performers who are out there now are really lacking IMO, but if you're a tourist you will love it.  

One thing that irks me is how the street performers ask for money.  It's begging and it's a turn off.  Some of them have gotten really bad with the begging.  It's like I need money, give me some money, $1 dollar bills are okay....but $5 dollar bills are better...I need to pay my rent....I need the money to come out here and entertain you.....Pier 30 doesn't pay me to do this.  You will hear this or something similar to this and you might hear it multiple times during a show.  I laugh when people just walk away Lol  Focus more on performing and putting on an awesome show.  I think people will tip more.

On to the restaurants.  There's a lot of restaurants, but are they good?  Meh.  Hard Rock Cafe....oooooh.   Bubba Gumpp shrimp....AHHHHHH.  Lol  Um...no.

I can't review all of the restaurants and everything else at Pier 39....it would take too much time....so I'll wrap it up here.

If you're a tourist please take my somewhat negative review with a grain of salt.  You should definitely experience Pier 39.  There's something for everyone.  I absolutely recommend taking one of the Bay cruises too.  I still like to do it every Blue moon.  If you're a couple I recommend one of the later cruises at night (romantic) Lol  You can see all of the city lights and skyline and just being on the water.....it's awesome.  Bring a jacket!

Also, I know people wanna look cute, but to all the women who wear high heels to Pier 39.....you look like a fool  Lol  I can tell your feet hurt and you will pay for it later  haha  Flip flops are a no no too.  If you're smart you'll throw on a pair of sneakers or running shoes.  You definitely want to be as comfortable as possible to enjoy the experience.  Bring a coat no matter the time of year or even the time of day that you are visiting.  Another yelper said to bring a wind breaker.  Yeah...it can get windy, but a wind breaker is like wearing a t-shirt to me  Lol  You might be okay with only a windbreaker during early to mid afternoon in the spring or summer, but that's about it.  Bring a coat  Lol  or you will freeze your butt off.
author: Cee B.

description:
A tourist trap with stupid gifts, overpriced food, and ...

and ...

and ...

and beautiful, sweet sea lions, playing around and being adorable.

You win this round Pier 39.

135/365
author: Christopher M.

description:
Well, this is a must-see for any tourist when they come to SF, but seriously...what is there to do here? 

Watch out for the guys who pop out of the bushes to scare people!

Pay those silver or gold painted dudes to dance for you! But warning, they may not dance, even after you pay! I witnessed them taking a "break" right after someone gave them money, ha!

Walk around the pier and stare at the boats.

Stare at Alcatraz from afar?

Admire the ocean, animals, etc.

Indulge in a few of the nearby carts with giant pretzels, soda, etc.

Hmmm...doesn't seem that exciting, when you compare this place to Santa Monica Pier, with all of its happening food and rides. But....it's not bad! Like I said, it's still a must-see!
author: Nancy T.

description:
Great place to go walking.  Have enjoyed it several times.  You cant beat the $16 souvenir SF fleece jackets at the gift shop.

There's also food & street performers if your into that sort of thing.
author: Vance M.

description: Not really a fan but the area doesn't suck completely. This was one of my least favorite spots. if you have 100s of dollars to burn on touristy stuff, this is the place. If you love being trampled by massive crowds (i.e. like other tourists), this is the place. Tons of mediocre food options at a much higher rate than other places in the city.
author: Susan H.

description:
Eh I wasn't overly excited about the pier.

There was a very yummy clam chowder place called chowders. They also have a lefty store, which was pretty cool but my boyfriend did not find anything too cool or useful for himself in there. There wasn't much exciting food, or drink, or activity going on to capture our tourist eye, so we ate, walked around for a little and left.
author: Nataliya A.

description:
Family Vacation Part IX:

Title: A dumping ground for old refrigerators become a magical place or Beware of Sea lions.

There were actually a lot of numbered piers. I guess to describe pier 39 it is similar to walking into the entrance of Disney Land. A lot of people, food places, and a ride or two. A very cool place. Found one of the best places to eat seafood on this pier. (will get to that in a future roman numeral.)

There is a place that serve donuts. Find this place and get a bucket. Trust me you will be glad I mentioned it, unless you hate donuts... which I would say... what is wrong with you!!!

It has a movie theatre style game where you shoot stuff. It was cool. 

A lot of restaurants and shops. Really too many to name. 

It is a kid brain overload this place. When we showed up there was some guy blowing giant bubbles. Balloons everywhere. Some other guy with a mechanical plane attached to a string I think. Music and people all over. You will get tired of saying no every time your child ask can I have that or can you buy me that!

There are a lot of places to buy shirts, and I guess hats with ears are in style right now. (with it being so windy here the ears are helpful to keep warm). 

I am told there are a lot of Sea lions here. By the time we made our way to Pier 39 it was dark so we didn't see them. 

Big ups for Warren Simmons for having a vision and creating this place. I wouldn't have sold it though. He would be making a killing on the rent alone.
author: Patrick M.

description:
Tourist Trap?  Well, it does not have to be.  If we are there on weekends, then it gets really crowded.  Fortunately, we only visit on weekends if we are showing family and friends San Francisco.  Monday through Thursday, we have had much better luck.  We try to get there early before the crowds build.

It's fun to walk around, window shop, people watch, sea lion watch, and enjoy the views of the bay.

The one activity we never fail to do when we visit Pier 39 is to walk over to where the sea lions are.  Don't ask me why, but we just do.

If you're a tourist, then visiting Pier 39 is a must.
author: PatrickJ T.

description:
One star for the stinky sea lions, because they're basically the mascot of the shoreline here.

If you're from away, then you'll probably feel some kind of weird force drawing you here, because It's Just What People Do.  But honestly, it's not worth the hassle.  It's a bunch of overpriced restaurants with crappy service, crowds of slow-moving slack-jawed people gawping around at nothing, women with strollers the size of Hummers, souvenir shops hawking anything they can possibly paint "I heart SF" on, and pigeon poop.

There are a squillion better things to do in SF if you're from out of town....I wouldn't waste your time here!
author: Heather K.

description: You know what - it might be popular to talk smack about this tourist trap but I say you need to visit. They have something for everyone and even do free shows some days which are fun. There is a mini farmer's market at the end of the Pier and what great views of Alcatraz, the Bay Bridge and the bay. Go see the sea lions who are ridiculously cute. There are several great places to eat, some really unique shops which are not even horribly priced....and there is always the carousel.  I also love walking through here at night...
author: Mikhail H.

description:
Pier 39 is to San Francisco as Navy Pier is to Chicago.  Gross.  Typically, these are the places I would avoid like the plague.  But Pier 39 is home to the CUTEST SEA LIONS EVER!  You have to go see them.  I did.. twice!  I braved the throngs of super annoying tourists and cheap, kitschy facades and shops to see those sea lions and it was worth it!

Nothing else here is worth doing unless you have kids, which makes you boring.  This place is loud, annoying and over-priced.  There's better, cheaper food everywhere else in the city and you'll get a real San Francisco experience anywhere else.  No one who lives in the city actually hangs out here, so avoid Pier 39 at all costs.

Unless you're going to see those cute sea lions.  WORTH IT!!!!!
author: Jenna S.

description:
Pier 39 was definitely one of my favorite spots during my recent San Fran trip!  
The shopping is great.  Some stores I recall were the sock store, left handed people store, Irish stuff, chocolate heaven, etc.  The restaurants are great too, Fog Harbor being my favorite.  On top of all of this, Pier 39 offers some fantastic views of the city & bay, and of course the arodable sea lions.  So cute!
Pier 39 is certainly touristy, but it is very well done and a great place to start a San Francisco visit.
author: Mallory D.

description:
I'm sorry, landmark or not, Fisherman's Wharf is disgusting. Everyone who comes to San Francisco thinks they have to come here. I tell them it's disgusting but bring them anyway and when we leave, they inevitably say "you're right, gross!" 

A) The food is decent but why not go to the Ferry Building for fresh oysters, clam chowder and seafood and eat like a human?
B) It's stinky, filthy and dirty. The seagulls love it. Why? Because it's gross.
C) You can't even see what a historical landmark it is because it's been engulfed by cheesy tourist shops selling high-priced crap. It's an eyesore.

A few okay things: There's a beautiful tile mural in the ladies bathroom. The arcade is kind of fun and you can tour a Navy sub for a small fortune. If you want to see Sea Lions, drive down to Cambria and see them in nature. They really stink. Walk, don't run.
author: Angelique L.

description:
Tourist Trap from he11. Parking is a total scam, and if youre lucky to not get your windows smashed out and all your contents of your vehicle stolen, then consider yourself lucky. But mark my words, every time you return to this cesspool, you just increased the good odds considerably that it will happen. And dont bother calling the police, they do not care, they will just transfer you to a number that hangs up on you. This is after you get placed on hold for around half an hour or so. The number is for your phone report, that they will try to encourage you to make on line. these are city employees BTW, not law enforcement personnel in any way. Then there is the actual city....The shops and food places are run down and filled with over priced junk, which includes the food at all the strip eating places. The whole area is infested with scum looking for their next fix, and anyway to get it. the touristy areas of this filthy city make you want to shower continuously for a week just to get all the scum off. the streets and sidewalks are congested with bodies, most living clueless tourists, some not moving-possibly sleeping, others look like walking zombies, even others looked so strung out youre not sure what they might do next. What the hel happened to this place. The tourists seemed to think all the scum bags are part of the SF culture?   They take pictures of the punks as their partners are lifting their wallets and grabbing purses and shopping bags and running off etc.
they must sell this place HARD in other countries, cuz its the sludge at the bottom of the Bay Area barrel. Youre better off going to a better maintained and policed area where the people of the city and the police force care about their community as a whole, and this is NOT that place.
Don't be another of the HUNDREDS, close to THOUSANDS of victims monthly here, or fall in line with the brainwashed sheep and don't say you weren't warned.
author: The S.

description: You could spend all day here and never get bored, or spend every day here and never get sick of the view! It's one of my favorite places to hang out. If you're in SF, you must go!
author: Christy B.

description:
This place in two words: Absolutely overwhelming (in a great way, if you ask me!)

Pier 39 is a fantastic tourist spot, with plenty of shopping, eating, people watching, and sea lion oohing and aahing. I love sea lions, so this was a great opportunity to see them at their finest: in piles of blubber and lazily fighting/soaking up the sun. I also really enjoy people watching, so I did a lot of that too. The piano stairs were great--it was fun to watch people as they realized that they were making the music. Some were really into it and tried to play songs, which ended up just making me nervous I'd see someone fall and get hurt. 

We got overpriced corn dogs and a bottle of water, but that's just something that comes with vacation. Splurges on normal things in an abnormal setting, right? 

I certainly couldn't spend a whole day here, because as much as I love people watching, I can't handle crowds for that long. i'd definitely make this a stop on another trip and recommend it to anyone trying to see some good SF touristy things.
author: Kaitlin D.

description:
Oh I don't come here for the stores.  This stretch of SF's waterfront is tourist central and as such is filled with that sadly familiar assortment of t-shirt shops,  those electronic stores that somehow always end up in these places and a Hard Rock Cafe because of course there would be a Hard Rock Cafe.  

No, I don't come for the chain restaurants... 

I come for the pinnipeds!
author: Kevin T.

description:
If you only have a few days in San Francisco - do not go to Pier 39.  It is a trashy tourist trap at best.  There are so many things to see that are not this crowded or commercial - things that are free or at least nearly so and much more interesting.

And - whatever you do - don't give money to the weird homeless looking man with the tree branches who tries to startle passersby - it's just encouraging him.

Here's an alternative one day tour: walk along the water front to the Cable Car turn-around, visit the Maritime Museum (is it reopened yet?), walk along the pier and watch the swimmers in Aquatic Park, walk through Ft Mason and check out the awesome friends of the library bookstore, have lunch at Greens-to-Go and take it with you as you stroll through Chrissy Field to Ft Point, then go up the path and walk over the Golden Gate Bridge, check out the old fort on one side and then head back - catch a bus - maybe the 38, get off at 34th Avenue and walk back toward the Bay to the Legion of Honor.  Enjoy some gorgeous statues and art, eat some delicious french fries and watch sunset over the Bay before heading back out the park for a nice dinner with belly dancing at El Mansour.
author: Jenn C.

description:
It has sea lions!  How could you possibly give a pier with sea lions less than 5 stars?!  I mean, exactly how many piers are there in the world that feature sea lions and ice cream?!  Sea lions can warm the blackest of hearts!  

You will notice there are no baby sea lions.  The mothers do not want their babies around the adult male sea lions, so they hang out at Yerba Buena island.  Sadly, the only way to go see the babies is via boat.  Boo.  The sea lions of Pier 39 had their 24th anniversary on the weekend of January 18th, and they had a small little celebration going on for them that weekend.

The restaurants are nothing really spectacular, but SEA LIONS!  I just stood there for probably 30+ minutes watching them.  Some of them stretch out their neck to sunbathe.  Some try to encroach on territory they know is not "available" to them.  Some pose like they want Jack Dawson to draw them like one of his French girls.  Some fight to defend their honor (!!!) and prime real estate.  Some just want to nap.  Some just act like they meant to go swimming when they are pushed off.  Some just complain to each other about "personal bubbles" and disturbed naps.  Some try to nurse their bloody battle wounds with the rays of sun.  Plus, there's usually one who just decides he's too old for all of that nonsense and just goes off on one pier all by himself.

Pro tip: if you're trying to find pier 39, do not look between pier 38 & pier 40.  They put the oddly numbered piers on the left/west side (If you're facing the water) of Embarcadero, and the evenly numbered piers are on the right/east side.
author: Larena H.

description: This is a nice place to look out into the bay and to people watch. There are little stores and shops that line the pier. It's very touristy, however, so expect crowds and above average prices. However, it's definitely worth checking out if you haven't been to San Francisco before.
author: Ally M.

description: Went Sailing around the bay in between the two bridges a bit cold at first but for the most it became really warm and the view wa spectacular! The captain and first mate Caleb were hilarious and very helpful!
author: Melissa T.

description: Good place. A lot of shops and cafe. Little bit expensive but very cool. Highly recommended
author: Liubov D.

description:
Parking.Is.Cray.

Other than that, this place is a hoot.  They have SO much to do and see!

It can get pretty pricy if you choose to add on (carousel, boat rides, and the like) but just walking around and enjoying everything Pier 39 has to offer is free!!

But it's family-friendly and gorgeous.  You can't beat the scenery and the ambiance!  I love it there!  It's well-maintained and clean!
author: Michelle F.

description:
As far as tourist trap goes, this place is pretty fun.  You can do a day trip here without spending too much.  The prices on food and attraction is fair, they won't rape you that hard (like other tourist traps).  A little sore bum, but not a bleeder.

Parking is bad, but that is true for the entire SF area.  Free parking can be had if you park a few blocks up and walk down.  Locals proud themselves on not paying for parking.

I go there to people watch.  Like a zoo.  Cheap interactive fun, I guess.
author: Jason L.

description:
Holy tourist trap.  No, thank you.

Do you want to see some crappy trinket stores selling what could only be described as eye sores?  Do you want to pay entirely too much for something to eat?  Do you want to fight strollers and tourists in order to walk anywhere?  Well, you've found your place!

What a nightmare.  Do yourself a favor and visit a park instead, and then use this awesome website called Yelp to find a restaurant that is recommended by the locals.  Don't waste your time or money.
author: Nicole W.

description: Yes, it's a touristy place but Pier 39 is a fun place to go to when you're visiting San Francisco. My boyfriend and I avoided the crowds by going on a weekday. It was Christmastime, so the area was decorated with festive, holiday decor. In the morning, we watched the sea lions barking and putting on a show for all to see. We later went on board a boat from the pier to cruise around the Bay and see the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, and SF's waterfront up close. Upon returning to the pier, we walked around the area and browsed through the various shops and eateries. We found the cool musical stairs and saw that there are other fun attractions such as a mirror maze and the Aquarium of the Bay.
author: Joanne A.

description: This is my favorite place in San Fransisco. I love coming here !!!!!!
author: April B.

description: Tourist central galore, but I still kindof love it.  Maybe cause its so reminiscent of fond memories, but there is certainly a big fairground/carnival feel to this place.  Buy some souvenoirs, have some fried goodies, or dine at some of the places like Boudin's, all very much catered for tourists.  Don't expect to find a foodie gem here, but you can see spectacular views of the GGB, Alcatraz and the bay area and here the sea lions out back.  There's a little bit of everything here for everyone to look at/shop/eat.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
You like to shop at the mall.

I like to shop in The Haight.

You like to eat at restaurants like Applebee's.

I like to eat at restaurants like Aicha.

You like t-shirts that say, "I went to Pier 39, San Francisco."

I like t-shirts of defunct baseball teams that no one has ever heard of.

You like views from Pier 39.*

I like the views from Twin Peaks.

You sometimes order things that are As Seen on TV because you fall for it.

I order too much from Amazon, but I also order Modern Farmer magazine to learn about modern farming and sustainable culture.

You wear a fanny pack.

I wear a belt.

You are a tourist.

I was a tourist. I just didn't act like one.

You loved Pier 39.

I hated Pier 39.
___________
* Actually, the views are one of the only redeeming qualities of Pier 39. From the top of the parking garage at Pier 39 you can get some surprising and interesting shots. The views of Alcatraz, on a clear day, are also nice if you can avoid the masses of people walking through your shot.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
FIRST OFF:
We all know this place is a touristy attraction hotspot, so lets just cut to the chase. 
My girlfriend suggested we should come here, which means, we better go there ASAP. Questioning her is not an option. I am not whipped. Lets get that straight. 
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------THE IMPRESSION: 
There was a sea of people walking in and out, lots of street performers, many expensive, overpriced seafood, and small attractions for all ages. 
It was really crowded on the day we went, and hot but then again, San Francisco weather what do you expect. 
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------WHAT TO DO:

Vitality: if you got yourself 20 minutes to spare, and $60 bucks to burn cause your girlfriend is expensive, then come here. This place gives you the best water massage of your life. My girlfriend pass the hell out while enjoying the massage, The water pressure can be changed and the movement of the massaged can be paused at any time so you can make it focus on any specific spot that is sore. 

Chocolate Covered Apples: Go find them, they are so good, all i know is that they are next to the tattoo shop at the end of the Pier. It is around $6 bucks but it is really worth it!

Watch the Ocean: Have fun, enjoy the wind and the hot sun burning on your back. The view is just okay but relaxing. Go watch the sea lions! 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------TIP:

Don't just walk to the Pier, ask one of the guys that are on the bicycle to give you a ride there! It is so much more fun to watch the view and watch those slowpokes fade behind you as they walk. The cost is only around $20 bucks. They also can give you a tour for $80 bucks. They will take you anywhere you want! 

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
WELL HOW MUCH DID IT COST:

Bring money, I spent around $110 that day; to the pier and back, the massage, the extra food that she wanted.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
CONLUSION:

It was worth it, but my wallet disagrees. 

=]
author: Jason Ping T.

description:
Honestly does this place deserve 5 stars? Probably not. 

So why the 5 stars you may be wondering. I love sea lions and I could see so many of them playing around. I could watch them for hours. This automatically makes Pier 39 a 5 star place in my eyes. 

Pier 39 reminded me of a carnival though. It just had this carnival vibe to it without it being a carnival. I get it - that probably only makes sense to me. Also this stuff had a Biscoff shop which I LOVE so of course I had to stop there and stock up on the cookie spread and cookies (can't find in Hawaii)! This way I don't have to be sad when I don't fly Delta since I'll have my own Biscoff cookies! Oh yeeeahhh!

Lots of shops - make sure to check out the hot sauce shop (can't remember the name right now) on the second floor. Awesome service and you can taste test some of them. 

Definitely a tourist trap - which was A-ok since this was a stop on our Cali road trip! 

Heart sea lions. Just saying.
author: Jessica S.

description:
I love pier 39!

I used to always come here as a child with my family. I still always go there now you get some clam chowder. 
Everything is just so much fun there's so many things to do there so many good restaurants to go to and everything just feel so alive. 
It's a little scary at night on the weekends because a lot of people were drunk but isn't that everything there feels really nice to just walk and relax and you see all the doors that go to visit San Francisco
author: Yasuko R.

description: If you have ever been to San Francisco and wanted to just go some where to spend some money on some fun stuff then this is somewhere you should go. Although it is always packed, there is always somewhere to go look at or even watch. Every time i go to the pier they have performers. That always attracts people plus they have many types of games to play! Its a good place to bring kids I would say. Try it out sometime guys!
author: Jesse M.

description:
SQUEEE! SEA LIONS! SQUEE LIONS!

Ok, I've got that out of my system.

(SQUEEEEEEE)

Ahem.

So yes, the sea lions. They are myriad. They are vocal. They are totes adorbz.

Aside from that, too, Pier 39's a proper worthy destination. We were lucky enough to catch it on a glorious day - I guess the wood on the boardwalk maybe gets slippy in the rain but for us it was 100% joy and sunbeams. It's a bright, colourful, and slightly mysterious network of boardwalks and mezzanines that trip from seaside delight to seaside delight. Arcade here, gift shop there, fun things everywhere you look. A shop devoted entirely to hot sauces. A sea lion education centre featuring a genuine sea lion skeleton, and pelts you can stroke enviously.

I've no doubt that the primary goal of Pier 39 is to entrap giddy daytrippers like me, but it does it so marvellously that it's hard not to cast cynicism aside, open one's arms and give oneself over entirely and willingly to the experience. If we'd had longer, I could have stayed all day. I particularly enjoyed the Celtic goods gift shop named Treasure Ireland. That kind of thing is so brazenly good-natured you could tar and feather it and it'd still grin back at you and offer you a bowl of Lucky Charms.

Are you getting that I liked this place? I liked this place. Did I mention the sea lions?
author: Cressida F.

description:
One of the must go places in San Francisco is most defiantly Pier 39.  Now, the pier itself is nothing more the shops and a very touristy fountain of kids and adults with fanny packs on holiday, but there are some good aspects to the area.  Some of the shops are really interesting to browse through.  But, the best part of Pier 39 is all the way at the end of of the pier and to the left where there are sea lions all year around that relax in the marina.  You can get some good pictures of the animals and the water.  This is also a good place for pictures of Alcatraz Island.  SO enjoy your visit to Pier 39...

And as always... Have Fun!!!
author: Christian H.

description: Lots of great shops and places to eat. The seal lions are fun to watch as well. We got to watch a fun street performer do his thing at the stage by the carousel which helped pass the time while we waited for a table for dinner. We had a nice evening walking around and window shopping.
author: Andrew Z.

description:
My experiences at Pier 39 have been great. From the trove of sea lions that wail throughout the day, to its Christmas spectacular with a centerpiece tree at the entrance during the holidays, it's certainly not a place to miss when you're in town!

I'll admit to being a tourist every once in a while. I mean, what's the purpose of even going there if not for some random adventure and getting kicks out of people-watching or going from store to store to see what fun and crazy items they have in stock. I wouldn't go there for any other reasons, I'll tell you that much.

As far as attractions that I haven't mentioned, you have a crazy hall of mirrors, a two-tiered carousel, balcony photo ops, restaurants, great views of the bay, and even an aquarium. This place is worth a first visit, and if you're like me who just loves to be around anything fun, even a second visit won't hurt either!
author: Calvin John B.

description: I went here in Sept, 2009.  Yes, it's a touristy place.  There are lots of fun, souvenir-type shops in a fun atmosphere.  The shopping area isn't big, but it's fun to see, especially for the first time.  I may not necessarily want to come here every time I visit SF.
author: Rolena I.

description: This would be my hangout spot if I lived here. Tons of restaurants, gift shops, and a great view!  I don't know what the parking situation is as we got dropped off by a taxi.
author: Michelle H.

description: Great place to hang and have a drink or have lunch.  Yes, it is the mecca of tourism in San Fran but does it pretend to be anything different?  People watching is great and just a good place to waste some time.
author: David D.

description:
Pier 39 and the piers in general can be a lot of fun if you take it will a grain of salt.

Yes, it's touristy, yes people will try to sell you cheap knock offs and rip you off, and yes, you will be charged an arm and a leg for food that anywhere else would be called divey.

But, I personally really enjoy wandering around by the bay. I love the sealions and watching the art performers work and the arcade.

I simply deal with everything else. Especially the tourists.
author: Meg T.

description: Pier 39 is great for first time tourists. So many cute little gift shops and many good food places to choose from. It tends to get super crowded at noon but that's the fun of it.
author: Irina B.

description:
Tourist trap that sells nothing but junk.  Parking in the area is way overpriced.  

If you're into tourist traps and shopping, you might like this place.  But, if you want a genuine San Francisco experience, check out Golden Gate Park, the Presidio, or the Marin Headlands.
author: Martin A.

description:
I love coming here and sure, it's a tourist trap. But any city is subject to a giant tourist trap but at least you've got sea lions here. So sure, there's a sea of people and a stretch of stores offering chocolates, wine, and canned clam chowder in the mix of the very many seafood places. Oh and SO MANY souvenir places. I digress.

I like it. It's certainly amusing at best but the best part is just looking at the Bay and enjoying this part of SF for what it is.
author: Shauna S.

description: Not sure when I've been anywhere more touristy. It was crazzzzyyyyy! If you don't like crowds, don't come here. This is a great area for people watching, however. There will be something to see everywhere you look! Some of the shops are pretty interesting. I can't say if be interested in ever coming back to Pier 39 but it was an experience for the books! I had a good time overall, you can spend a few good hours here without even noticing. I recommend it if you have have that fanny pack, visor, sunscreen, Sketcher's Shape-Up sort of bone in your body.
author: Marissa W.

description:
Enjoyed myself at the Pier, has a lot of shopping & eateries to chose from. The edge of the Pier is really wonderful, on a clear day you can see Alcatraz & The Golden Gate Bridge.

I will know where to stop by the next time I am in town.
author: Sal M.

description: Lots of cute stores and places to eat but mainly an overpriced tourist trap. The Chocolate place had truffles for $3.50 each, Cup & Cakes cupcakes were $3.50 too, but they weren't the large cupcakes, they were the normal size you bake at home. The sock store charged $10-$12 for a pair of socks. After paying $18 for parking, who can afford to eat at the overpriced restaurants. I almost splurged on a banana Nutella crepe till I saw it cost $8. Left with an empty tummy.  I'm sure they make tons of money, but I wonder if with lowered prices they would have more purchases and possibly make more...?  There were several things I would have bought if they were more reasonable.
author: Debie K.

description: For people watching, and seeing SF bay at one of its most popular tourist attractions, how can you not give this place 5 stars?  The parking is crazy expensive, but you can't really do anything about that since it is Pier 39.  I will never tire of this place and the seals, the picturesque views of the Bay and Alcatraz, and most of all-- people watching!!
author: Lorie N.

description:
My first visit to San Francisco in 2010 included a stop at Pier 39 as I was catching the ferry to Alcatraz.

I was not impressed with Pier 39 as it was exactly like every other Tourist Trap in every major city in the rest of the country. 

- Crappy Overpriced Restaurants
- Crappy little trinket shops full of crap you and your family members do NOT need

Now that I am a local, I feel dread when a visiting guest requests that I take them to Pier 39. 

1 Star is for the Sea Lions; although the smell is WOW!
author: Melissa H.

description:
Great tourist stop in San Fran, especially if you've never been to the area. I was here a few weeks ago, and it's one of the first places we went. 
There's lots to do nearby and it's convenient to the BART and the midi, not to mention other nearby stuff like the water fountains/park up Embarcadero. 

There's a lot to do in the area, both as activities (boat rides, the carousel, the aquarium), food (Planet Hollywood, Hana Sushi, Bubba Gump, to name a few), and shopping (chocolate, cosmetics, some touristy objects/clothes), but it does get super crowded. I enjoyed walking around and taking in a little of all of it, and the tons of people added to my people-watching enjoyment.

Sadly, there didn't seem to be any sea lions visible when I tried to find them on my visit. :(
author: Stefany V.

description: Fun place to spend time with your family and make new friends with loads of places to eat.
author: Nicholas K.

description: This is the standard place you take your out-of-town guests. Some okay restaurants and shops, but overly touristy and the "magic show" in the back--the "magician" taunts the audience if they don't give over $5...very uncomfortable and rude..ruins what could be a pleasant atmosphere.
author: ABayAreaLady R.

description:
Alright, so San Franciscans hate this place because it's a tourist trap and yes, it does have some of the worst offenses of an obnoxious tourist destination: horrible chains like Bubba Gump flaunting oldlandish architecture, the smell of every type of food in the world being fried is pervasive, parking is ridiculous, it's crowded, there are crappy T-shirt stores pimping out the city's beauty on tacky beer cozies and comemorative spoons, there's also pickpockets, a teensy bit of crime and a very present police force.

Despite all that I love it -- well, mostly because I know how to get around all of the obstacles above very quickly and access my own little best-of Pier 39 experience that never fails to delight.

And besides, I bet most of them don't know that a lot of the woodwork caricatures that make Pier 39 seem so over-the-top are actually handcrafted antiques from SF's original playground: The Sutro Baths and Land's End. So get off me!

Here's how you do Pier 39 right son: 

Late afternoon: park ridiculously far away, usually in a lot to the far South or street parking if you have absolutely nothing in your car (otherwise, meth-head zombies will break in and make love in your child's booster seat).  

I walk quickly up past stunning views of Alcatraz into  a horde mass of street performers: metallic painted men posing for photos, young guys spray paining celestial hiphop moonpaper (or whatever you call that) and street musicians until the smell of spray paint and sweat forces me north (or a scam artist approaches telling me he bets he can tell me where I "got dem shoes"). 

I stop quickly at the Boudin factory to see what crazy sourdough statue is on display today: usually a crocodile or a scorpion made out of 20-100 fused loaves of bread. 

Then I stop at Crab Station #2 for my shared bowl of Clam Chowder- don't know if it's the best or if it's milkpowder and silk worm uterus' but I like it and think it's respectable for what it is. Chat it up with the folks hanging at the cart. 

I go nextdoor to Sabella & La Torre for a plate of oysters. Last time, they had some newbie kid shucking the oysters and when we asked for horseradish he poured tartar sauce all over our oysters. His boss made it right though and their horseradish is so strong, I love it. 

I usually take these around the corner to the boat slips and walk out onto a dock and eat them with 10-20 seagulls watching me with completely seduced anticipation. 

You know you're in the right place if you pass the Musee Mechanique which I think is free and seems totally awesome and why the hell haven't I ever been there?

The oysters are great and by now the sun should be setting, walk along the water north and spot the Wildman of Pier 39 who hides behind two palm frawns, and then at the precise moment, jumps out and shoots Oooga Booga at unsuspecting tourists, much to the delight of you and 50 other jerks with their iPhones out capturing the moment for prosperity.

The Golden Gate bridge is beautiful at dusk from the 'beachlet' north of Pier 39, the Buena Vista is just up the road for a great Irish Coffee and Ghiradelli is fun to stop in and get the free caramel sample at the door  and watch people blow their mortgage on ridiculous platters of ice cream. 

It may be touristy but it's totally worth a do, and worth doing right!
author: Ryan S.

description: Good place to take our first time visitors to SF. Food and parking is pricey, but that's what this tourist trap is for. Sea lions are what they want to see. Also they wanted Blue & Gold boat trip, Aquarium, and dungeness crabs. Not cheap but you can make a day of it and not have to travel to multiple places to see/do many things here in one shot.
author: Clifford W.

description:
Huge tourist trap.  I mean it's cool to look at all the stores and see what you can waste your money on but yeah.  It's alright.  I mainly came here for the sea lions.  They mostly come in the winter so I only got to see one.  I'm fine though.  It was still cute.

This place is super crowded.  It's best to park somewhere far and then grab a taxi because I don't know how you'll be able to weave around here, find parking, or actually move your damn car.  

They have a bunch of restaurants here but it's not really SanFran kinda things.  They're the kinda restaurants you have back home.  Nothing special.  Got off the pier a lil and go to the vendors.  At least it's authentic and straight up from the locals.
author: Jackie N.

description: I had a blast on Pier 39 , just being a tourist and vacationing my face off .  It was here that we discovered the Crab House.   There were plenty of cabbies park on the main drag and a lot buskers here to keep things interesting.  Pier 39 is all about fun and commerce.  There are great views of the Bay and plenty of green space around too.
author: Lucretiz C.

description:
What a fun little area to explore. The only problem with it is that it can get very crowded. Stop by and grab some coffee or snacks from the various shops. There are also gift shops around where you can grab nifty souvenirs. Don't miss the dock where all the sea lions are. It's fun to just stand there and watch their interactions with each other... it can be easy to lose track of time just doing that! 

It's fun to come around christmas time because there's a large Christmas tree around. Definitely a place to check out.
author: Janet L.

description: This is probably one of the to go place for tourists. It is located along the shorelines which was a perfect walk on my first day at sf. I recently brought a friend for the same walk and she loved it as well. The walk along the shorelines is nice since it is always sunny. The pier has a lot of souvenir stores, nothing special but it's nice. One thing that surprised me was the showcase of sea lions they got there.
author: Andy A.

description:
My guilty little secret....I love acting like a tourist in my own backyard. I get a real kick out of the street performers and people watching. My favorite was the the "Bushman" R.I.P. he was a real hoot. There is another "Bushman" around, sure to give some a gentle scare. I won't say more about his perferred location. That would take the fun away. 

My favorite thing to do is jump and flip on the "Frequent Flyer". Weeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee!!!! It's located right next to the Farmer's Market. Find your way to the Carousel, and you're sure to find it.

All in all, there are MANY things to do. Something for everyone. Enjoy!
author: Purple L.

description:
A must stop for any tourists to our great city! Plan to be here for a few hours in between your visit to the sights! 

My personal suggestion would be to drive down Lombard street (the windy part), go straight up to Coit Tower, and then on your way down, stop by Pier 39 for a quick jaunt. You won't regret it! Nice views of Alcatraz and the Golden Gate Bridge!
author: Charles K.

description: This review reflects our time on the pier and in the warf in general.  There are tons of people, first off.  Most of them are tourists.  With that being said, you will get asked for money about 15 times an hour.  If you get a bread bowl from anywhere, keep the leftovers and tear it up to feed to the seagulls.  The view is out of this world and the street performers are actually pretty good for the most part.  As you can imagine, the food down here is unbelievable so choose wisely.  The shops are fun, even though it has a bit of a "vegas feel".  Again, lots of people so be prepared.  Overall, this place is nice, but clearly a trap for most tourists.  I wouldn't book anything online.  I would get to the pier early in your trip and see what you want to do, then move forward.
author: Brian H.

description:
It has been a number of years since I've visited Pier 39 and even more years since my friends and I would run around the pier at night being silly, young kids. We use to drive down from Napa every weekend (or at least every other weekend) to hang out, experiment with smoking, and try to act old enough to get a beer.

Fast forward some years later and the pier still looks the same. Maybe a lot more crowded with tourist and some new stores, but looks AND smells the same to me. Truffles from Chocolate Heaven is a must!

Just a note, if you are looking for tickets to Alcatraz you have to go down to pier 33. However, I recommend you buy your tickets in advance, they were sold out for the whole week!
author: Julia C.

description: Love coming here since you have movies, aquarium,  Alcatraz views, activities,  rentals, and a lot more to do.
author: Erik P.

description:
Just a few quick tips. 

- For free 2 hour parking after 6pm, just go to the welcome center on the 2nd floor. Check in through Yelp and Redeem the coupon book. Inside the book, on the first page there's a coupon for validation. Rip it off and give it to them and they'll give you a validated ticket! 
- Parking is $8/hour or any fraction thereof! 
- The best time to come to the Pier is at 4pm. Stay until 6pm, and your parking is free! :D
- Bring a jacket! a thick jacket!
- Clap for the guy that does the shows near the back. He gets sad when the audience doesn't participate.
author: Chris C.

description:
I love going to Pier 39. I've been coming here since I was a little kid. Today was just a quick trip with no plan. 

While the PIer 39 parking is convient, next time I'm going to pursue somewhere else to park. $38 for a few hours is rediculous!
author: Julie H.

description: Great sites to see and food to eat!  Check out the sea lions, bridge and Alcatraz while enjoying a great meal.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Pier 39 is a tourist trap. There aren't really any restaurants here that represent the area. If you're looking to try some authentic food, try Fisherman's Warf. It's steps away from Pier 39, a little less expensive, and a lot less gimmicky. 

I really don't even think there's anything worth seeing here beside the sea lions. They're the only reason Pier 39 gets any stars. The sea lions are super cute and sit on these little floating platforms on the water and bark. They're not always there though. They do their own fishing at certain times of the day. 

If you don't have kids, save some time and money for other things in SF. There are so many other things to do: The Ferry Building, Alcatraz, Union Square, Chinatown, Little Italy (North Beach), Golden Gate Park, the Golden Gate Bridge, Coit Tower, the list goes on and on...
author: Hilary C.

description:
Good Place to walk around. Parking is expensive, but it is what it is. 
We went an hour boating, walked around.
author: Dylan R.

description: Highly overrated tourist trap and a gigantic time suck, but we were on vacation and had time to kill so Pier 39 fit the bill!  You must go into this area ready to fight crowds and browse a bunch of niche type stores.  The puzzle store was fun to mess around trying to solve all the wooden games and the boardwalk area was great for people watching.  Would I go back?  Probably not.  But are you a tourist in SF and have time to kill?  Then yes go!
author: Kevin T.

description:
Oy!

Except for the sea lions, I try to avoid Pier 39 at all costs. For my taste, this place is just too crowded, too touristy, and not all that interesting. All it took was a single short visit when I first moved here in the 1980s and I had checked that box and moved on.

Yet time and time again, this is one of the place that my out-of-town guests want to come (followed by more time at Fisherman's Wharf). But I am a good host, so Pier 39 (including the Aquarium and food) it is. However if I'm lucky, I'll get them on a boat to Alcatraz and then persuade them to walk the other way along the Embarcadero and try out the Ferry Building and maybe even a Giant's game.

I too was a starry-eyed Midwest teen that visited San Francisco (with flowers in my hair). Yet I was lucky that my parents focused on Chinatown, North Beach, the Cable Car ride down Hyde, and a walk that mysteriously avoided this area. I guess Mom and Dad felt the same way.
author: Eric B.

description:
Okay, it's a total tourist trap, but I loved it. Of course, I had to see the sea lions, and I must've caught them on a good, upwind day because they didn't smell at all. Once I took my obligatory sea lion pictures, we explored the rest of the Pier 39 shops. We didn't have a lot of time, but we did stop at the Hard Rock so I could buy a shirt, and we had a quick lunch at Boudin, where I had what was quite possibly the world's best grilled cheese sandwich.

Parking in the garage is expensive, but if you have AAA, go to the Visitor Center on the second floor and you get two hours of free parking! Saved us $16, which was awesome. We didn't even know about it until my friend's mom told us that morning.
author: Cherine A.

description: I'm not exactly sure why, but I love this place. I'm a tourist and this is one big trap, but I just love sitting around and enjoying the views. You have alcatraz island, the sea lions, the performers, the wooden structure, and the crowds. You can drain a lot of money quickly but you can also buy a tea or coffee and just enjoy yourself. My kids loves the carousel which isn't all that expensive and giving the performers a few dollars here and there is worth what you get. And then there's the awesome aquarium nearby. If I'm in the city with my family, I'll happily bring them here every time. If I'm alone, I'll probably come down on a nice day with a book, grab a nice tea, and sit somewhere and read a book. Just avoid the tat and restaurants and you'll have fun too.
author: Derek F.

description:
Man, I hate tourist traps. Living for 10 years in the Bay Area, and now living in Vegas, working on the Strip, I see the same junk at every tourist trap with little variation.

What you will find on Pier 39 
Shops selling :
- Only magnets
- Random, non-Californian sports memorabilia.
- Popcorn
- 3 wolf moon tshirts.
- Stuff about cats, fairies or tshirts that say you'll exchange your husband for a bottle of wine.
- Tons of junk with Marilyn Monroe or Elvis Preseley
- Snarky signs that say "Democrat parking only, all others will be incinerated." 
- Clam chowder that doesn't hold a candle to the stuff in Monterrey Bay.

Other things you'll find at Pier 39:
-Empty floaty boards where stinky seals used to be.
-People who can't read maps.
-Panhandlers who dress up in spraypaint or try to beat box for a nickle.
-People who think that running shoes and a fanny pack are appropriate to wear anywhere.
-Overpriced, sub-par food.
- Decent bathrooms (!)

Avoid this place at all costs - it's not that interesting and is a huge waste of time. If you are insistent on going, WALK or take Muni. Do not pay the ridiculous parking fees. I've walked all over that city, 3 miles here or there never killed anybody, it's a very walkable place!
author: Rachel S.

description:
This is a must if you are visiting San Fran.  Wear comfortable shoes and dress casually or resort like.  This place has always been busy packed with people.  My favorite are the numerous sea lions that hang out around the pier.

There are plenty of restaurants, shops, and services offered here.
author: Linda Y.

description:
I think the Pier has been remodeled since my last visit three years ago.  It seems cleaner and more spiffy than I remember on the last visit.  Because it's in walking distance from our apartment, it's fun to play tourist and check out all the little shops.  Sort of a cross between Disneyland and a shopping mall.  The architecture takes me back to when I was a kid and Santa's Village was in operation down near Santa Cruz.  Just a kid's wonderland.

The tulips bloom in the spring which makes it nice.
author: Delaine Z.

description: The only pier I'm fond of having lived in OC is the Huntington Beach Pier. This one completely blows it out the waters (see what I did there?). Yes, it's a tourist attraction and probably not many locals clamor here, but it's beautiful and scenic at night. There was a local saxophone player that evening and he got everyone pretty into his music. Plenty of shops to blow money away needlessly and a few nice restaurants and eateries as well.
author: Quoc N.

description: This update is only in regards to the Pier 39 Christmas decorations. They have the tree up which can be seen from several blocks away as you approach the Pier and is such a pretty sight. The tree is a great Christmas photo op and the Pier has pretty evergreen garlands and wreaths throughout. Even if you're a Pier hater, stop by during the holidays for the lights and decorations. The festive holiday atmosphere is fun to take part in!
author: Jennifer N.

description:
What a tourist trap, just my kind of place. Plenty of options to eat at: Bubba Gump Shrimp Co. Restaurant, Chowders, Crêpe Cafe, The Crab House at PIER 39, Forbes Island Restaurant, Hana Zen Japanese Grill & Sushi 
Bar, Hard Rock Cafe, Luigi's Pizzeria, Neptune's Seafood Restaurant and the list goes on and on.

I enjoyed looking over the bay and seeing the Rock, Alcatraz.The kids loved the boats and the sea lions. The entire family enjoyed the Mrs. Fields Cookies, yum! 

My wife's favorite part was the sports store because she purchased all her Giants World Series memorabilia. What can I say, she is a northern Cali girl.
author: Alberto E.

description:
So much fun! Even after all of the times that I have been to San Francisco! The selection of shops and sea lions is top-notch.  

PS. Go looking for the piano key staircase!
author: Raza H.

description: This is best tourest spot to come to when you visit San Francisco. The wide food selection like Boudins or Bubba Shrimp co. The beautiful view of the bay and watching sea lions rest n play.
author: Alexander K.

description:
This is very fun place for me like an entertainment park with free entrance with ocean view! 
A lot of things going on, stores, gift shops, little farmer's market, restaurants, an aquarium...and open until later than many of other touristy places. It was great to visit here for my last night in San Francisco.
The gift shops are well stocked with variety but they are more for personal memory items.

Lively atmosphere and everyone is happy as long as the weather is good.
I was looking for a souvenir to my company that maybe like box of chocolate or baked snacks that multiple people can share, but it was not easy to find here.
author: Blue G.

description:
Being a tourist... this place gets 5 stars for awesome views.

When I was a resident of San Francisco, I still love Pier 39 and its views.

I can't think of a better way to spend the afternoon or evening walking around marveling at the seals, the pigeons and seagulls, the overpriced foods albeit yummy nonetheless, and the crowds.

If you want ice cream - you got it.  They have Ben & Jerry's and Dreyer's!

You want clam chowder in a cup or breadbowl?  It's EVERYWHERE.

You want a good lobster/crab roll?  It's EVERYWHERE.  

If you want a cup of coffee?  You got it!

Fried calamari and other seafood fried delectables?  You got it!  

My favorite spot is Chocolate Heaven.. can't say enough good things about this place and I don't care if it's unhealthy, fattening, or overpriced.. it's a must go to store when you're at Pier 39.  

There's a little kiddie area and a small area like a Famer's Market.. 

I don't park nearby.. I park away from Pier 39 and no hassle!!!
author: Tram N.

description:
Generally a cool place to stroll around. There's plenty of shops and stuff to check out, plus great areas to get pictures of the skyline. There's also docks where seals hang out, and who doesn't like seals?

Seriously, a pretty nice area. Also some of the best crab you'll ever eat in your life, and plenty of restaurants that serve it.
author: Alek Z.

description:
Yeah yeah.. It's a touristy spot but as an SF native, I have no shame in saying that this is still one of my top 3 kick-it locations in SF.

There is so much to do here. I have been hanging out here since I was in middle school, and as my preferences in entertainment have changed, this place has never let me down.

Two of my favorite spots:

-The Musée Mécanique (Near the iconic Fisherman's Warf Sign) 
  *They have $3 Old fashioned Black-and-White pictures

- The spy museum.
author: Liz H.

description: A must when you are in San Francisco. The only thing you have to order is a clam chowder in a bread bowl. You might have to stand while eating it, but it is worth it.
author: Zaheem B.

description:
As far as tourist traps go this is the Boss!
It is a great place to take your unsuspecting guests once, after that your kinda over it unless you do it from a Segway where you can see what they have to offer and then boogie to some other areas of the city to see.
author: Drew F.

description:
The food is bad and the stuff is expensive. This is a true tourist trap during the day and a rat trap at night. 

All the restaurants here are overpriced and not worth what one is paying for at all. The shops sell the lowest quality material, one is better off getting it at the shops off of Grant. 

At night the bushes come alive with sound, with all the rats wakes up and starts becoming active.
author: M C.

description: Pier 39 is definitely a must see in SF! The seals and the boardwalk are a gorgeous sight in the city!
author: Jena D.

description:
Touristy attraction alert!! Perfect, as hello?! That's why I was here!

Restaurants, trinket/souvenir shops, and many attractions...
carousel, sea lions, various street performers, aquarium, and numerous boat outings. Plus the view is GORGEOUS!

A fun place to check out for an hour or two unless you go on a boating outing or visit the aquarium then possibly spend more time in the area.

Perfect for those with children however
a little too cheesy of a place for my liking in general.
author: Kinga H.

description: The only thing worth seeing here if you're a local are the sea lions, past 11 p.m.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Yes this is a tourist trap, but it's just one of those places you have to visit when you're in SF. Even as a local, I've been here 3 times to show visiting friends around, and I've had fun showing them around. Despite how crowded it gets, it's actually kinda nice strolling around looking at all the interesting shops, some of which are really unique. They had a shop just for socks, a shop for left-handed people and all sorts of silly shops to pop into. There's also quite a few restaurants you can dine in and get a good view of the Bay, but everything is a bit overpriced (as with any tourist trap). I usually get the famous Clam Chowder Bowl from Boudin's Bakery, but I can never finish the whole thing, just because it's so large!

Parking can be kind of a pain as the closest/biggest lot is really expensive. If you're lucky, you MIGHT be able to find some street parking, but for convenience sake, I've always just parked in the structure. Your parking ticket comes with some coupons and a list of restaurants you can dine in to validate your parking, I usually just pay without validation.

As a local, I wouldn't come here unless I was showing someone around. But on a nice day you can actually walk passed some street performers, more food vendors and souvenir shops on your way to Ghirardelli Square.
author: Amanda L.

description:
If you're heading to San Fran at any point in the near or distant future, be sure to make your way to Pier 39. It's a typical tourist attraction, i.e. you can tell that the majority of people there are tourists and not native San Franciscans, (Is that correct?) 

Still, though, on views alone, it's a must.

In the distance, across the bay, you've got Alcatraz Island, which sits ominously in a field of blue roving waters and evokes what I can only describe as a creeping dread. Now, I know that sounds awful, but it really isn't. Let's face it: that kind of fear and/or disgust is one of our more primitive and evocative emotions, and it makes for a totally cool experience.

You also get... seals! Yeah, that's right. Seals. Sitting on a grouping of floating embankments, hundreds of seals sunbathe and make for an interesting sight. It's not something you get to see just anywhere.

There are, of course, a number of eateries and shops to coax those greenbacks from out your pockets, but this can be expected.

And, lastly, if you're looking to take a tour of the city, your best bet is to head here first and jump on one of those two-story, open-air buses. Because San Fran is fairly small, two hours on one of these will afford you the opportunity to see everything from the Golden Gate Bridge to Little Italy to Chinatown to the Haight Ashbury to George Lucas' film studio to --- most importantly! --- the Tanner household from "Full House."

Once again, be sure that this is a TOURIST ATTRACTION and in no way fully tells the story that San Fran has to tell, but that makes it no less attractive a place to visit, so do yourself the following favor: check-in to your hotel room, grab a cab, head to pier 39, do the touristy thing, and then go find your next adventure on the streets and among the locals.
author: William O.

description:
Well, it beats Santa Monica pier back home =p The shops are more interesting and you get to see REAL sea lions rather than the ones munching on their double doubles on the bench.

but it's essentially the same deal. Overpriced shopping and the worst parking in history. 

Did I mention it was the WORST parking in history? You can only validate your parking in select restaurants. 

Y'all some hustlers!
author: Ivy M.

description:
I really do not know what to say about this place.  It is one of the busiest places in San Francisco that I know of, everybody has to see Pier 39, but honestly does everybody in the city need to see it at one time.

It is clean and well maintained, but honestly the amount of people that visit here I am surprised there is still room to walk on the Pier.  

If you have never been here, yes this is a must see spot, but if you have been here once or twice, then there is nothing much here for you to see, as most of the same shops are here for as long as I remember, which might be good or bed, but that is the truth.

Well, it is a place if you need to bring somebody here, you might want to try and get there here in the morning hours, or late afternoon just before dinner, those times I would think are the slowest.  If you have been here already, then you might want to try a different place in the city to visit.
author: Michael N.

description: As a SF native many better places a tourist should go to see the city and spend their vacation dollar.
author: Laurence V.

description: Fun tourist attraction! I like to bring friends that aren't from the area here to get clam chowder - Chowders is a good casual restaurant here to get chowder in a bread bowl. The sea lions along the left side of the pier are fun to watch. Some of them will show off for you! Park across the street in the parking structure. If you check in on Yelp or have AAA you get a free fun pack from the info center on the second floor which includes two hour validated parking. This way you don't have to eat at a sit down restaurant just to get your parking validated. Lots of other coupons in the book too, but I would say the parking one is the best! Make sure you bring your parking ticket with you because they will stamp it to show you got the validation ticket. Also need to write down your AAA # on a clipboard in the info center so have that ready.
author: Jenn D.

description:
When traveling I like to travel the unbeaten paths, look for local favorites and spend time there. However, since it was along my group's path while seeing SF, we decided to stop at Pier 39, see the docks, and walk through the area.

Pier 39 is essentially a tourist trap. Overpriced restaurants, "I HEART SF" memorabilia, massive crowds, and other overpriced shops and kiosks. While the Embarcadero is definitely worth the time and walk, I would walk past Pier 39.
author: Thomas P.

description:
If you don't live here, this is a must place to go to. It's the part of San Francisco that's touristy. 

Sea lions, where they go? Did they really flee from us? Did they really get chips installed? Who knows?!

SALT WATER TAFFY!!!! Ned Flander's (it's not really his store) Left Handed Store!!!!
author: Kylie L.

description:
Touristy, but a must see.

Go for the sea lions.  Stay for the shops/restaurants.  The pier is packed, wall to wall strollers!!  Bring a good camera for a direct view of Alcatraz Island and the Golden Gate Bridge, the pier is a great photo op spot.
author: Shannon H.

description: Great live music on July 4th! Went to aquarium, mirror maze, pier market restaurant, 7D experience, rode carousel and topped it off with a churro and funnel cake. Fun times but spent a TON of $ in a matter of minutes:). Things didn't get started until after 10 am but by the time we left the area around 3pm it was crazy busy! So sad the sea lions had already migrated:(!!! My daughter enjoyed seeing all the birds around by the waterfront. Fun day!!
author: Christie D.

description: Food was average! Service was crap! Plenty of other places in the area to enjoy fresh seafood!
author: Jimmy G.

description:
To steal a quote from Brett N, "This is exactly the kind of place I don't like to go when I'm visiting a city. The place that seems like it should be cool, but it just isn't."

That is an accurate description for this tourist trap, which is kind of a trek just to see the seals (which are actually kind of cool).  Lot of chain shops, overpriced souvenirs, and a store just for left-handed people, which is funny from a novelty perspective but doesn't deliver (according to my brother who is a lefty).

If you are forced to be here for an extended period, Chowder's is actually decent, and Dreyer's has some extremely unhealthy but taste-bud-satisfying shakes.

Bottom Line:  If you're looking for a more SF-vibe with restaurants and souvenirs, head about 1 mile south along the Embarcadero to the Ferry Building, which has a neat Farmer's Market on Saturday's (and some great chowder!)
author: Kevin S.

description: I really like this place.  It's very nice for a weekend.  It is very touristy but besides that it's cool. Nice view.
author: Javier B.

description:
Iconic Pier 39
So much to do, see, and enjoy!
We walked down the pier, enjoying the shops...okay yes, all overpriced, but still fun.
The views are fantastic and the entertainment value of the sea lions alone is worth the trip.

The Blue and Gold Fleet is just off to the left of the pier and my guest and I enjoyed an hour tour around the bay out to the golden gate and around Alcatraz island.   Great company, views, and fun!

Parking prices are exorbitant!!!  $8 an hour!  
Go hungry and eat at one of their selected validating restaurants for a 2 hour validation!  It's like deducting $16 from the excursion cost.

Love, love, love SF Bay...

Go with with someone special!  It makes all the difference between a good time and an amazing experience.
author: Michelle J.

description: Played tourist here with family and surprisingly was impressed. Really clean with some neat shops. Spendy but good food options. Also fun seeing all sort of folks around the globe visit. We spend the $45 at the parking garage, a splurge but worth the convenience.
author: Deborah L.

description:
TOURIST TRAP.  So not worth the money. The only thing cool to check out here are the seal lions. 

Oh and don't EAT here. My advice is to go to the many authentic, great restaurants that SF has to offer!
author: Sarah C.

description: Can't leave SF without coming here. Lost of shops restaurants! Great getaway place to hangout with friends and family. You'll never get bored here with so many unique locations.
author: May F.

description: Historical landmark and tourist attraction here in San Francisco. Although it maybe a bit crowded, I enjoy this place as well and I come here on my own sometimes. One of the great places here in San Francisco for taking photos!
author: Bennett W.

description:
This is a tourist spot, but a good one. The best thing to see here are the fat little sea lions who have a permanent home floating on rafts just off the pier, they are hysterical to watch.

If you want to grab a bite to eat, take a bike tour, or hop on a boat to Alcatraz this is the place to be. 

There are always street performers about... however lacking some of them are, they still add to the energy...  

It is a great place to walk and enjoy the view and the crowds and have a fresh crab dinner..
author: Corey Tess T.

description:
So many things to see and is a must if you're a first time visitor.

From what the tour guide mentioned, Pier 39 is the 2nd most frequently visited attraction in CA. The first being Disneyland.

You can have lunch here, visit the local sea lions or hitch a ride to Alcatraz. 

Lots of shops align the pier and a great place to hit up at night. There are so many interesting performers and artists that take the streets, and you can't help but watch!

Oh and the [homeless] guy that hides behind the bushes to scare people is still there after all these years...
author: Maria C.

description:
Total tourist trap!!  Not that I don't like this, most people that visit here are out of state or from a different country, prime example of being from a different country:
I had a job here at a booth/kiosk for a time share company, the main requirement for qualifying someone is that they have to be a US citizen. Well, I actually got one person to tour, and she bought. The tourists love this place. I'm a local boy.
author: Peter J.

description: Loved the whole atmosphere!  Great place for family of all ages! Shops are fantastic! Don't leave without riding on thier carousel!
author: Terry G.

description: Update: pier 39 actually reads the reviews so that's a bonus they get another star from me. They actually care about the reviews and personally let you know how much they appreciate the review. Great hospitality yall keep it up!
author: Lakeshia J.

description: We feel like toourist everytime we come here. I come here for the salt water taffy. We always park in the Pier39 parking garage, it's $8 an hour but if you eat somewhere on the pier you can get it validated. Also, the taffy store...they validate too. We park on the 3rd floor away from all the crazy drivers fighting for parking. Plus on the 3rd floor has the entrance for the bridge from the garage to the pier.
author: An N.

description: Everytime I come to Pier 39 you rush over to where the sea lions are... you can just stand there watching them for hours just because they are so adorable and entertaining to watch!
author: Vanessa S.

description:
First of all, this is a tourist trap.  It is very crowded, loaded with souvenir shops and with many overpriced restaurants.   This however is a clean, well planned and controlled San Francisco tourist attraction.  There is a stage for free performances at various times of the day and of course the sea lions are always out.  Pier 39 has viewing areas for the sea lions and has an area at the end of the pier to see the Bay, Alcatraz and the two bridges.  
If you are visiting San Francisco as a tourist, this is a must see and feel experience.  Get an ice cream or a treat and just stroll though the variety of shops and sights.  
Pier 39 is crowded and touristy but a must visit attraction
author: Al E.

description: Pier 39 has just about everything for a tourist.  There are a ton of dining choices, shops and a brilliant view.  There is also a double decker carousel about half way down.
author: Gavin M.

description:
Super Touristy...indeed...but  something you have to see. I don't know anywhere else in San Fran to see the sea lions.  

Parking is fairly easy if you have a car.  There's a parking garage across the main road...I don't recall the price, but it's simple.  Additionally, you can also walk over to Fisherman's Wharf.
author: Cobra K.

description: It was great place to check out many events there and the food. We rode Blue and Gold Fleet boat ride. It was amazing even it was so cold and windy. It's definitely worth a boat ride and enjoy the day there. We went there twice.
author: Regina D.

description:
I'm a Native San Franciscan and I never get tired of playing the touristy role. On a beautiful San Francisco summer day, you can find me near the water. Take me out to the Pier to mix amongst the street performers and tourists from all over the world. I'm people watching and entertained by watching others take in the beautiful city views.

Pier 39 has changed a bit since I was a kid. I loved the bumper cars, which are long gone and the arcade has been replaced by the Hard Rock Café. Players Sports Bar has the machines from the old arcade and skee ball, sometimes it's fun to act like a kid playing games for tickets. Novelty shops and the smell of ice cream and waffle cones. Ride the classic merry go round and watch the Sea Lions, there is so much going on and it is truly a fun place for kids of all ages. 

Don't let the whole Pier Novelty throw you off, there are some nice restaurants here such as Fog Harbor, Crab House and Eagle Café. Excellent Bay View too! For a girl who loves fresh seafood as much as I do, the Pier is a great place to do my crab hunting.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
Definitely a place to stop by when you are visiting San Francisco.  There are dozens of places to eat and shop.  One the edge of the pier you have amazing views of the Bay as well as Alcatraz.  Come here close to sunset and watch the fog consume the Golden Gate bridge and Alcatraz.  There is also the infamous sea lion area where hundreds of sealions are barking, snoozing, and playing in the water.

There are some pretty random stores on this peer, including "Lefty's" which is a shop dedicated to items made for our southpaw friends (i.e.: left handed people).  So if you have a friend or family member who is left handed, check that place out and get them something they desperately need (ex: scissors, can opener, etc). 

Close to the end of the pier there is a gorgeous double decker carisol and a stage where frequent magic shows are performed.  This place is very family friendly.  Mind the crowds, but that's to be expected around here.  Another fun thing to do is explore the house of mirrors maze.  I went there in 2009 and in 2013 it was still there and still quite the popular attraction. The only bathrooms on the Pier are located towards the back on the second floor.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
I get that people come here to see the seals. But even they're MEH. I'm not a seal-hater, but it kinda makes you think... well, those seals should be sitting on rocks instead of this god-forsaken tourist trap. 

YES ITS A TOURIST TRAP. My sister rolls her eyes every time a new person comes to San Francisco and asks to go to the pier. 

1) PARKING. Chances are that if you came from LA you FOOLISHLY DROVE to San Francisco and didn't know that SF, like normal metropolitan cities, has a functioning public transit. but anyways, parking in the closest structure is $8.00 an hour!!! That's two gallons of gas!!! All to see ... 

2) OVER PRICED STORES AND USELESS GIFT SHOPS. There's a left-handed shop, one of those "farm-fresh pearls", a novelty sock store, and the mandatory San Francisco apparel store. Basically you could transport all of these shops to another place in the world and you wouldn't know the difference, nothing uniquely San Francisco about the shops at about Pier 39. And seriously, $10.00 for a pair of socks? WHY?! 

3) Same ol' street performers. The guy covered in silver paint who pretends to be a statue, someone playing steel drums, another playing some kind of weird instrument. You're not fooling anyone when you buy their professionally done CD and say "Oh I heard this really cool person playing on the street". They're not true street performers, they got permits and are hired by the city to make you think you're a hippie. Not to say its bad, but don't fool yourself in to thinking you've discovered hidden talent. 

3) The only thing worth going to is probably Boudin's... but two other places you could go to that would allow you to have that sourdough bread bowl without trekking over to pier 39. and this Boudin's doesn't validate!

For TOURISTY San Francisco, better to spend your time at the Golden Gate bridge, Fisherman's Wharf (at least there are more interesting shops and somewhat fresh seafood) , Twin Peaks, and Union Square. meh and I guess Chinatown. They all fulfill your touristy desires while allowing you to spend your time doing more interesting and wallet-friendly things. Please go and explore all the other awesome places in San Francisco! Instead of blowing an easy $100 at Pier 39, why not get yourself a swanky dinner at one of SF's high end restaurants. Pretentious and bougie, but at least you could brag!
author: Crystal M.

description: Although we went during the week, all the rides were shut down, not a lot of people there on the pier, it was still a nice experience to.   I'm not sure if I want to go back though, because I didn't like the drive from Moffit.
author: Jay J.

description: The sea lions are definitely the highlight! Other than that, it's a cheesy tourist trap - overdone restaurants and souvenir shops. However, the little ones do seem to love it. Don't drive down, or you'll be overcharged for parking.
author: C. D.

description: Best to go there during the weekday to avoid the crowds. Need to have better directions for elevators.  The star attraction, sea lions were few but still smelly. But then some of the tourists smelled worse! Phew!  They need to have a free shuttle going there from the embarcadero Bart station, because walking there will take some time. Driving there is even worse because of traffic around the area.
author: Ron D.

description:
I thought I already wrote a review about this, but I guess not.
The Pier 39 is VERY TOURISTY. Almost like everything else in San Francisco. I really liked it though. It had all the tourist shops we needed to get people their gifts. I also advise you get the Fun Pack because it has a lot of great deals for shopping. 

I agree with Jennifer when she says you have to at least come here once.
author: Shanel S.

description:
Pier 39 is a carnival of tourist attractions ranging from bungee trampolines to magic shows and 500 different ways to part you with your money, none of which you need. If it's your first time in SF, you should probably go just to check it off of your list of sights to see.  It's about 95% tourist trap, with merry-go-rounds, magic shows, and bungee trampolines, but the other 5% is worth a visit.  You can snag a nice view of Alcatraz from Pier 39, and also see a whole flock (group? gaggle?) of sea lions do their thing near the back, all of which you'll want to tell your friends about once you get home.

Other than that, there isn't a ton of depth of attractions here.  It won't leave you wowed, but seeing the pier and sea lions are free, so you may as well enjoy the walk here on a sunny summer day.  Just be sure to go elsewhere for your souvenir shopping.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
I merged this with my Fisherman's Wharf review but the same holds for this place.

I think Pier 39 is a tourist trap worth visiting and being "trapped in". There are many worse places to be. 

You won't starve here. Average seafood galore.
You won't easily get bored of the sights.
You also have plenty to do here.
There's random entertainment.

On a clear day, you can see the Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz clearly.
There are sealions stinking up the place.
author: Nick L.

description: This was a nice place to visit once, but I would not go out of my way to go back again. I took my family (wife and three kids) as they have never been, but the crowd on a weekday morning was insane.
