It was shoulder to shoulder and there was really only a bunch of restaurants with a few trinket shops in between. Most of it was the same crap we've already seen at every other stop along our Highway 1 travels from the south. If you've never been I would recommend going at least once, but don't get to excited, in the end it's just another tourist trap.
author: Chris R.

description:
I love going here to see the Sea Lions  :O)
Yes, I know, they're super stinky but it so much fun watching them.  They are so cute!!!!  I couls spend a whole hour just watching them move, cuddle against each other, play, get in and out of the water...
Also, from that same spot you can see Alcatraz and walk a to Fisherman's Wharf.

Definitely a must see, and great photo spot.
author: Greshka P.

description:
ORK, ORK, ORK!  

That is Freddy the sea lion and welcome to Pier 39.  There's no actual Freddy, I just made that up.  He's probably a she anyway...well...we are in San Francisco.  Again welcome!  

Besides the kiddy magic show in the back, the sea lions are probably the only other thing that is free at Pier 39.  These wonderfully lazy creatures seem to dazzle the eyes of tourists who come far and beyond.  Walking amongst the crowd of visitors, only one question racked my mind.  What is so interesting about these sea lions to stare at them for even more than a minute?  Understandably for a kid, the allure of something spontaneous happening like a fart or "animal wrestling" (mating) would sound exciting.  Yet the crowd was full of adults too.    

As a native San Franciscan, I just don't get it because I'm from here.  If you saw what I saw with their glowing engaged eyes, you'd swear it was a unicorn out there.  Understandably, California sea lions are native to you guessed it, California.  As since has now worked into becoming a symbol of the pier.         

Venturing into Pier 39, "you can literally spend half the day there*".  I put an asterisk next to that first sentence because of the tourist factor.  If you have relatives, friends, or just playing guide to folks out of town, you can easily burn through a good four to five hours with all the shops and restaurants they have.  Bun's favorite is the Candy Baron; that's located in the back near the arcades in the back.  As expected, Candy Baron sells all different kinds of candy.  The aquarium which I haven't been too is at the front.  My remarks on that are nonexistent as I'll probably not ever go though I heard it's great for tourists.        

A view of Alcatraz is the backdrop in the rear where you can sit and relax.  For me this is the best part, watching the water, feeling the wind, enjoying the view while dodging possible seagull dooky bombs from above.  I sincerely felt bad for the kid with the poop tainted overpriced cotton candy.  Minus the latter, this is the best part about Pier 39, the view from the back.  

So if you're a tourist, come on over and visit Pier 39.  This place is for you.  I mean it; the city of San Francisco literally developed this place to welcome the tourists.  Freddy, the sea lion, will be waiting.
author: Arnold T.

description: I have lived in the bay area my entire life but only visited the pier a handful of times. As a child, I remember it being boring! Recently, my family and I made trip to see the aquarium and wandered around the pier a bit afterwards. There is an abundance of restaurants and little shops which make for a nice day out. It was great to be able to show my son the sea lions which he enjoyed mimicking. We passed a big carousel and a free magic show which looked fun. I'm sure we could've more time and money on Pier 39 but were being conscious of the extravagant parking fees which cut our visit shorter than it could've been. We had a great day out at Pier 39 and I'm sure will be back for another day trip in the future!
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Who goes to San Francisco and doesn't visit Pier 39!?

There is the Aquarium of the Bay,  Fisherman's Wharf, all those sea lions sunbathing. :)

You even go here to go to Alcatraz.
author: Emily S.

description:
Warning: Pier 39 is a tourist spot and probably the busiest place in Fisherman's Wharf. If you are not a fan of crowds and noise, then this is not the place for you (I'm not sure where there isn't a crowd in San Francisco).

Things to consider: (1)Try to visit Pier 39 during a weekday. It is the least busiest. (2) Like everywhere else in San Francisco, if you plan to drive, you will end up paying for parking.(2a) On the plus side, the parking garage is right across the street. If you do not want to cross the street, there is a bridge (PHOTO-OP: great view of Pier 39) that connects to the second floor of the pier. 

Again, this is a tourist spot. Pier 39 really caters to the tourist crowd. There are "photo-op" signs posted throughout the pier. 

There is tons to see- souvenir and art shops, different types of restaurants and smaller eateries. The shops that caught my attention were:  (1)The Seasons store: This store has decorations for all seasons; especially Christmas!!!! (2)The Left-Handed store. (3) The various souvenir shops.

The highlights of the Pier was the fantastic view of the bay, the sea lions and of course the world famous- Golden Gate Bridge. It is a perfect area for photographers and the like.
author: Queen Claire B.

description:
This is my favorite tourist trap in San Francisco.

There are great views of Alcatraz, the Bay Bridge, and Golden Gate Bridge.  There are plenty of shops, restaurants, and you can see the sea lions at the end of the pier.

Parking can be kind of tough.  A place across the street validates for a certain amount of time.  There is street metered parking a few blocks away if you don't mind the walk.

There's a carousel and shows for the kids from time to time.  They sell a lot of souvenirs, post cards, apparel, and random knick knacks, such as left hand equipment and Christmas decorations. 

It's a nice place to walk around and enjoy the view.  You could spend the whole day there depending on how many stores you walk into.  

It is wheelchair accessible and has ramps.
author: Esther L.

description:
A tourist area through and through, but it was fun to take the walk. Great spots to find for people watching.  It would have been a great spot to grab a cup of joe, but the prices on food and drinks were elevated. 

As far as people, we walked it on Labor day, so not a lot of people.  It was also 9/10AM and that seems to be a good time to wander around the tourist areas with a lot of people sandwiching against you.
author: Jac H.

description: If you're visiting San Francisco, you must visit this place. I think it's a rite of passage of some sort.  There are sea lions.  They are smelly.  There is overpriced crap in a myriad of overcrowded shops.  If you just HAVE to get your I heart SF t-shirt and mug, this is where you need to go.
author: Lisa K.

description:
OK I wandered this way (to Pier 39) because I wanted to go to the aquarium and mebbe buy Alcatraz tickets. Turned out tickets were sold out (something you will never experience going to Statue of Liberty here in New York) and the aquarium was ridiculously expensive, like many attractions in San Francisco. No thanks, we got one  in Brooklyn, I am sure this one is not much different,  These prices really made me appreciate New York, I must say.

Anyway, I'll be honest, I wanted to see the sea lions. I mistakenly thought they were a part of the aquarium. And the fact that Alcatraz was a no go, and my ok with not going to aquarium, I figured I'll "stroll" through the pier. Wow, I thought pier 17 (south street seaport) was bad. At least South Street Seaport has some things to appreciate, an indoor mall, cleaner bathrooms, food court, and some decent places to drink, party, and eat. 

Pier 39, on the other hand,  is a complete tourist trap - Times Square has more to offer!  I can;t believe I spent as much time as I did there (I was half hoping that there MUST be something there worth seeing).  The only highlights were seeing the Alcatraz (to which i could not get to) and finally stumbling across the smelly, loud sea lions (though i did enjoy watching them for a bit). I guess as a tourist, you will eventually end up at a place like this, but I that dirty feeling of being completely gypped is not pleasant.
author: Natasha B.

description:
Great tourist place, family-friendly and sea lions to watch.

We enjoy the food choices here, and the many small shops to visit.
author: Nikki W.

description: Nice place ... Had lots of fun, shopping malls are awesome...its been only 2 months i am here in san ramon, went to pier 39 already 4 times...lol
author: Tareque M.

description: Three stars because while the Pier itself had great little spots and shops, the sea lions were MIA (darn mating season) and that's why we came.  Silly sea lions!  Will definitely re-review if we return when they're here.
author: Courtney L.

description: Overall, this is a great San Francisco classic attraction to check out if you're around the waterfront. Lots of shops to see along with the infamous sea lions. Some people might say this is a tourist trap, but it's really not for me. I prefer to just walk around and enjoy the cooler temperatures and ocean breeze.
author: Paul N.

description:
Seems like people have so many bad things to say about this place...and yes the bunch of you are right. Pier 39 is full of tourists, stinky sea lions, its really windy at the end of the pier, the restaurants are not that great, and seagulls/pigeons everywhere. 

But for me this is a bit different, I remember coming down here as a kid with my parents or relatives when they visited. Its always been the place to go visit. Just walking around looking at the different stores and what used to be. Its nice to reminisce.

And strangely enough to some, each time Ive been to the Pier I've always had a good time.

The Pier is a part of the Wharf and its all part of my home and memories.
author: phillip w.

description:
Pier 39 is a great place to take your East Coast family out for a day to see the city.  Oddly specific, but believe you, me; your parents will totally think more highly of your decision to move out to the West Coast for college.  I wouldn't listen to anyone who rates Fisherman's Wharf negatively...(What?  You think you're too cool for sea lions?  Cause you ain't).

     But in all seriousness, Fisherman's Wharf is great, it IS a tourist trap but that's part of the fun.  If every city had an attraction this unique, there would certainly be a lot more world travelers out there.
author: Sean D.

description: Pier 39 is awesome!! It was a little rainy and foggy when we went, but it was still so fun. So many cute shops, a clear view of Alcatraz and cool sea lions! Pier 39 is a must do when in San Francisco.
author: Camille P.

description: Well what can I say, if you're visiting San Francisco you have to come to Pier 39. It has all the good shops, great food and not to mention the best attraction.  sea lions, where can you go and see sea lions laying out in the sun. Not locked up, or forced to stay here. They're free, free to come and go as they please. what a treat, natures beauty at your back door.
author: Kenneth T.

description:
The first time I visited SF, I stayed at the Sheraton Fisherman's Wharf a few blocks away. We stopped by Pier 39 once for about 20mins.

It wasn't until I hung out with a friend of mine (a local) that I ended up actually walking through here and seeing more than tourist-geared facades on our hunt for great crab. I'll admit I enjoyed watching the sea lions and the view of the bridge + Alcatraz..

Pier 39 and the Crab House are routine stops whenever we have first-time visitors or kids to entertain.

Parking can be difficult, but if you intend to eat while you're there, there's always that one lot with validated parking.
author: Asha S.

description: fun place to visit, not a shortage of shops/restaurants, but parking rates were ridiculous (as expected)! easy to access walking tours, and entertainment @ every corner.
author: Marvin B.

description: Relaxed, had a beer and listened to that guy with a guitar, lots of restaurants for everyone. We had a soup in a bread bowl at Boudain and a beer at Beer 39. Nice place to spend up a half a day, close to other attractions.
author: Gabe P.

description:
Do left-handed people travel more often than right-handers, or are they just more susceptible to buying crap while on vacation? For whatever reason, left-handed stores are the sign of a tourist trap. 

And this is precisely the problem with Pier 39. It's a generic tourist trap. If you ignore the bay, it could be anywhere. I've seen the exact same shops at Quincy Market, the same faux-old timey architecture in Santana Row and Epcott Center . . . there is nothing about San Francisco here. Really, does a magnet shop give you anything essentially San Francisco? Or a knife store? (Although, I will admit, my boyfriend kind of liked that place). And wouldn't it make more sense to go to Ireland for ye olde Ireland treasures? (Yeah, the Irish community is important to San Francisco's history, but that's clearly the Thomas Kincaid version of Ireland). Apparently, even two decades ago or so, there was still something of the working pier about it and you could get a sense of the Port of San Francisco and its history. 

We recently decided to play tourist and walk around here. After some weak, overpriced lattes, and a walk past the various generic souvenir shops, I decided that I will probably keep this off the itinerary when I have visitors in the future. Except for maybe a quick stop at the AAA on the second level, where Steve L. says you can get a coupon for two hours free parking. Damnit, I wish I had read that review before I went. But now that I know it, it's enough to raise my review by a star.
author: Susan S.

description:
As someone said this is a tourist trap. It is interesting to walk around, but traffic is "HELL".

Go on weekdays if possible and bring some cash as this can be a $$$ vacuum- sucking your hard earned cash for the simple things.
author: J T.

description:
This place has EVERYTHING you could possibly imagine on a single pier - from Ice Cream to Antiques (and a carousel to boot!) - but be ready for the throngs of people that accompany this smorgasbord.  It is a carnival-style atmosphere, so bring your energy; but it also offers great views of Alcatraz, the Bay Bridge and the marinas. 

TIP: Take the lower level near the marina for a quiet walk around the pier. The center walkway is a zoo!
author: Arpana W.

description:
Label me as a tourist, I don't care.  The pier is awesome.  Those freaking sea lions are mesmerizing. 

Yes,yes yes... the pier is touristy, so what?  Be a tourist for once in your life. Enjoy what other people travel thousands of miles to go see.  Enjoy it for what it is, touristy shops, touristy food and touristy people.   This place is fun. 

Every time I am in San Fran I take a run down to the pier early in the morning before any people are there and stop by to watch the sea lions.  The antics !  So FUNNY. 

Two things you have to eat:
* The mimi donuts - make sure you get them right out of the little donut machine.
* The crepes - nutella and strawberrys... need i say more
author: Denise S.

description: Pier 39 is a complete tourist trap but since we were visiting Fisherman's Wharf and my friend wanted clam chowder, we made a stop here to grub at Fog Harbor Fish House. Although locals never go to the pier, it's really not too bad and more fun that Santa Monica Pier in LA. Worth a visit if you've never been before. Probably wouldn't go back unless it's to eat at Fog Harbor again.
author: Ivy W.

description: A fun place to go when you're in San Fran! They have everything here. Seafood, taffy, shopping places, and you can even see the Sea Lions. We always go there when in town!
author: Erica Y.

description: LOVED THE PLACE! Was in SF for a long weekend and found the time to go twice there!! You can just walk around the shops, take a delicious cheese sandwich, shop local products, get an exotic ice cream, pick up some chocolate samples and sit outside to enjoy the bay view on Alcatras. Loved the atmosphere of the place, between european markets and an old industrial peer. The place is quite crowded but omg you will come back just for the amazing smell of the food!
author: Delphine R.

description:
In short, Pier 39 is insanity. 

Too many people, too many street performers (which are fun, but block the flow of traffic), too many shops charging too much for their stuff - just too much of everything. 

The most fun is the free stuff: sea lions, people watching, views. 

The rest is OK, but honestly it takes it out of you after a couple hours. Stores are overcrowded and overpriced. The place is dirty due to the volume of foot traffic and it makes you want a place to go and sit in quiet for awhile afterward. 

A must for any tourist's first trip to SF, but prepare for the crush of crowds and the sting of high prices.
author: Jessica J.

description: I love Pier 39! Cute little shops and restaurants. Love the fact that thereafter an aquarium on the pier. Can't wait to come back!
author: Zochi F.

description: You go to see the sea lions and that's about it.  AVOID the fresh produce market... it's a tourist trap and priced accordingly.... $10 per lb of cherries, seriously??? On my way to the Pier we passed a street vendor who had them for $1 per lb.  Again, go see the Sea Lions and once you get tired of the smell, head back towards Pier 1 and the Market.
author: Chirag P.

description:
Pier 39 is kind of the quientessential San Francisco tourist trap.  It's akin to Granville Island in my home town or Pike Place Market in Seattle, but even MORE.  Either way, it's a fun place to meander through when you're an out-of-townie, like myself.  I'm pretty sure I've been here on every trip I've ever taken to Frisco.

I love taking some time taking in the view of the Golden Gate Bridge & Alcatraz from behind the pier, watching the sea lions sun on their very own wharves and wandering the shops like The Left Hand Store and The Candy Baron.  The best thing that Pier 30 has though, is the Zoltar at the Antiquities store - this may be due to my love of a certain Tom Hanks film, but it still makes me happy every time I see one.

(5/30)
author: Monique B.

description: Lots of great shops and local street entertainment!
author: Janel B.

description: Had fun on a cool windy day. A must for tourist and kids. -1 star, it gets really fishy stanky smell at certain times of the day
author: Mo H.

description:
This place is such a nice place for a date. So many places to eat (yummy clam chowder!), things to do, street artists to check out (they're incredible!) and nice to just walk and check out.  

It's a must-see if you're in San Francisco!
author: Jennie P.

description:
I have tons of memories here as a kid 'til now. No matter if you're a tourist from Peru or a local from Palo Alto, you'll love the little shops. It's definitely something to put on your bucket list. 

+ My favorite part: ICE CREAM! There is no lack of creamy goodness here. No matter where you go it's gonna be delicious. 

+ There are also tons of street performers. It just adds to the fun. Look for the comedians that ask for crowd volunteers. Double fun.

+ Sea lions. Don't miss out on them. A whole army of seals are lounging about around the docks sun bathing and shouting sweet nothings to the crowd. Don't be a grump if they stink. You should be more worried if they don't stink right? 

+ Bay cruises. If you're local, look for groupons, etc. for deals on these. You'll find fishing trips, hour long boat rides beneath the golden gate, and round trip tix to and from Angel Island. And if you're feelin' lucky, take a ride to the Alcatraz. 

'Nough said, go to the Pier! At least once in your life...
author: Steph C.

description:
On my weekend stay in Frisco, my boyf thought I'd appreciate this place, so off we go. As the day went on, he keeps hyping me up on this place. ''You'll love it! There's hundreds of them.'' Here I am, all pumped up and what not. First of all, the pier gets packed. Looks like they're giving away free money and people and trying to get their share. Ugh, I hate being crowded. I don't want to feel your musty elbows -_-

We finally get here and cooooooooooooooooooooool, there was only like 7 of them. 

I look back at my boyf and give him a stupid look. Really? I saw more sea lions chilling by the parked yachts on the way here. Really nothing exciting about this. Unless you're 8 and under, then I can understand why your panties would get all wet. Otherwise, you can see this shit on the Discovery Chanel right at your home, guys!

I wouldn't revisit this place again, that's for sure.


-Thanks for taking me though, lover :)
author: Diana V.

description:
3.5 Stars
It's a TRAP!

This is the Waikiki of San Francisco but like all good tourist traps you have to go at least once.  Here's the thing I've been to SF at least 3 times and have gone there every time hahaha! 

It's super crowded but there is lots to do around this area..
Rocket boat
Wax Museum
Sea Lions
Eat
Ride a double decker carousel 
and so much more...

If it's a clear day you can see Alcatraz island and the GG bridge I think it is.  

Must try: Trish's donuts.  So mini and cute yet so delish!
author: Jasmine N.

description:
There are some good touristy shops to look at through here but the part not to miss is the sea lions. I could sit here all day and watch the sea lion and I have the video to prove it. I wasn't so much into the chain restaurant that market on the ocean and up sell it to the tourist. I can pay $9 dollars for a lions cream some where else. On the upside to the tourist parade is that there are cheaper souvenir store around the area. It is quite long so be prepared to walk. 

What I didn't know is there are some older navy type boats that you can pay (of course) to go on and have a look around. This is the place you bring your family when they come in from out of town. 

So I say go see the sea lions and then vamoose out of there and go see real San Francisco. Oh yeah and don't even think about using a bathroom here with out a 2 hour wait minimum.
author: Cris F.

description: As a native to the Bay Area, this is my least favorite touristy area to bring my friends from out-of-town to. Always crowded and the only special thing about it is the docks with the sea lions and seals. Went there in early March and the sea lions and seals were scarce. There are much better tourist things to see and do in SF.
author: Emma W.

description:
How can you not love Pier 39!!  Tip of the Day: go to www.pier39.com and down at the bottom right you can click and print a coupon for a free fun pack. There are TONS of coupons!! One of them is for 2 hours of free validated parking!!  

One of my favorite stores is the Sock Market. Every pair of socks I get from there lasts for years.  

Try the fudge, Krispy bars, and cashew clusters from The Fudge House. 

The only gift shop that carries sweatpants that have 'San Francisco' on them is the Alcatraz Gift Shop.

If your looking for a blast of fun ride the Rocket Boat.  There is a coupon for that too in the fun pack.

Restaurants are overpriced, but if this is your big vacation then go for it!!  On your way out stock up on Boudin Sourdough bread.  I think I just drooled on my keyboard....
author: Holly F.

description:
I was so confused that I was in California, but I had to buy a jumper here because I was so cold. Ah well, I suppose the seals make up for it. Not really.

I suppose this place is just a huge big tourist destination, with shops and restaurants and attractions. I enjoyed it; it's definitely a must-see place when you're in San Francisco, but there's a lot more exciting places to go and things to do. Such as go looking for the house Charmed was filmed in, only to find out that it's actually in downtown Los Angeles. Not like I did this...
author: Martyn M.

description: Nice place to visit while in SF to sight see or grab a drink and a bite to eat, even to people watch ezpecially on a warm  clear day...
author: Carlos O.

description: If you love to eat seafood and just want to enjoy a day near the water with your children than this is a great place to be. OUr children loved watching the seagulls and sea lions as well as to pass by all the boats. Bring your jacket when you come here as it is windy and cold. Some patient as it can get crowded on the weekend and a great appetite to eat some great clam chowder or fish and chips!
author: Eri H.

description:
Pier 39 was the best place I visited while I was in California.

The location is perfect.  Pier 39 is nestled against the hills of NorthEastern San Francisco. You have views of home covered hills rising above the shoreline and water crashing over Alcatraz Island. It's a very cool place to be. 

The main attraction to this particular Pier is the food, they have everything you could ever want (and being this is where Sourdough was invented you would be a fool not to try it).  Mini donuts, seafood so fresh it actually begs you not to eat it, old fashioned saloon style candy stores, sports bars, smoothies, sushi...I'm serious, you can have anything you want.  I wasn't there often enough to figure out the schedule, but there is a farmers market just down the boardwalk. You walk about half a mile South of the pier and there is the most diverse selection of fresh food you could possibly hope to choose from. It's like walking into a Whole Foods in Heaven.  

Pier 39 caters on a professional level to the tourists that need gifts to bring back home. There's an entire gift shop dedicated to Alcatraz memorabilia, several crystal shops, antiques stores, jewelry, art, shells, knives, cigars...once again, just about everything you could ever want. 

You could go to Pier 39 for everything from grocery shopping at the farmers market to a romantic dinner with your sweetheart (they have a restaurant at the end of the pier that is perched over the water on braces..and is only accessible by boat, how awesome is that). 

Bring a jacket, the breeze off the ocean can get a little uncomfortable. 

Thanks for reading.
author: Zach O.

description:
It is true Yelp fans, Pier 39 boasts a spectacular view of San Franciso and is complete with sea lions, ocean views, and sumptuous seafood delights. However, I have to be honest in saying the shops along the Pier are over-priced and often contain faulty products. For example, I lost my phone charger in the airport on my most recent visit and found a technology shop offering chargers. I asked the man at the desk to point toward a charger that would fit my Galaxy 5S, which he did, and proceeded to pay...$22 dollars for it! Yikes. This wasn't the worst part. When I returned home for the evening and attempted to plug my new charger in, it simply did not work! I returned the following day with the device and was told that all sales are final. Not a happy camper. 
However, were this the only incident I could easily over-look it as one bad egg among other vendors. Yet my friend in our group experienced a similar issue. Due to her Irish heritage, her attention was drawn by a cute shop advocating Irish goods. She found a ring that particularly caught her eye and proceeded to pay a whopping $70 for it. Now this price would not have been unreasonable had the stone been real, but later on our trip we came to find that what we thought was a stone was in fact paint over a piece of cheap metal. 
Now Yelpers I must admit, the food was tasty. Our group stopped in at the famous Boddins bakery and partook of the classic clam chowder sour-dough bread bowls, which were heaven. I would however STRONGLY urge you to use caution when making your purchases at the other gift shops.
author: Sam M.

description: I'm a local, 'live in walking distance to this attraction, and I enjoy it very much. Goes without saying, that I take visitors and houseguests here- a no- brainer for offering food and entertainment to kids and adults alike. I actually stroll over here two or three times a month myself to check on "my sea lions". The views of Alcatraz and Angel Island and on out to the Golden Gate Bridge (on clear days) are stupendous. There are dozens of shops and cafes but do avoid the hokey tourist traps like Bubba Gumps, Hard Rock Cafe and those stupid "Find a pearl in the oyster" joints. ( I think there are 3 of those here on the pier!) Actually, the other tourist-oriented shops here which do sell the tee-shirts, posters and coffee mugs seem to have better quality merchandise than the vendors on the the rest of Fisherman's Wharf or Chinatown. I've reviewed my favorite eateries independently but among them are Fog Harbor, The Wipe Out and The Eagle Cafe.
author: Paula H.

description: Tourist trap?  Maybe...I didn't buy anything, but the place is lively with lots of people and cool things going on like random mime performances, etc.  Tourists should give it a whirl.  If I lived in San Francisco, I likely wouldn't itch to return very often though.
author: Myia B.

description:
OK... there are TWO things worth coming to the ol' Pier 39 to see: the sea lions marina and Magowan's Infinite Mirror Maze (http://www.yelp.com/biz/magowans-infinite-mirror-maze-san-francisco). 

Like a few people have mentioned, the place has really changed. Well.. more that it's just clogged with people. I remembered the occasional theater group performing short plays, even ultra-condensed Shakespeare, in various nooks around this glorified shopping center. These days it's breakdancers and metallic-painted human statues asking the multitudes of tourists for money alongside the homeless.
author: Christine A.

description: Over the years P39 has improved. It's fun to watch the sea lions and walk to the end past Ghirardelli out onto the boardwalk type areas. And who can forget SF's only In-N-Out location.
author: Josie C.

description: Not very interesting. Just a lot of shops and restaurants selling overpriced goods to attract vulnerable tourists. I would recommend only spending an hour here to eat at Chowder's and see the sea lions. The sea lions were adorable, so if for nothing else, stop here just to see the little guys.
author: Zak C.

description: It was over hyped for us. Kind of disappointing actually, I have an 8 year old a 5 year old and a 3 year old and besides the arcade and little aquarium. Not a whole heck of a lot to do. But hey if you want to buy a some take homes there are plenty of shops!  The one thing I will suggest is the smoothie shop we bought a couple pineapple mango smoothie they are awesome!!
author: Alexerica A.

description:
What happened to our beloved Pier 39? It is now a touristy nightmare. No more broken down arcade, karaoke singing music booth, run down stanky fish smelling wonderland?! So sad.

Came down here on a whim the other day to find it's really just a tourist trap for shopping with high priced t-shirt shops and sports apparel, overpriced pretzels and the underwater aquarium walk through. I'd rather plan a trip to Monterrey! 

It's a must take for when you have friends/family visiting....otherwise, steer clear.
author: Jocelyn J.

description:
I agree with the Daniel S.' review: This place is the biggest tourist trap with two chain restaurants (Hard Rock Cafe and Bubba Gump) as well as tacky souvenir stores and other over-priced stores.  Yet, it has one of the best panoramic views from the Golden Gate Bridge to the Bay Bridge.

If this is your first time in SF, then you just need to visit Pier 39, especially if you have kids.  It's very family friendly.

And rumor has it that the sea lions are leaving as their food source in the area has become scarce.

If you're not a fan of the crowds, go in the morning.  From brunch till closing, it can get pretty packed.
author: Vira P.

description: Great place for tourists. Everything you could wish for in a blocks distance of a walk. Be sure to check out the free shows and sea lions also!
author: Adrian P.

description:
Where else in the good 'ol US of A can you explore a city and stop for a viewing of sea lions? Yes they smell, suck it up and enjoy watching them sleep away the day. O the joy!! 

November is the best time to see the maximum amount of sea lions one can take! 

Walking down the center part of the Pier is not for the anti-crowd person! Walk on the upper level for a less crowded walk.
author: Bryce A.

description:
A-OK,as Yelp puts it.

The 3 stars is for the view of the city from the top level.

The shops here are way overpriced and every restaurant that we have tried here has also been overpriced and not really that great.

The best clam chowder on the pier is at Sea Lion Cafe.Service sucks regularly.
The coolest restaurant is Players,only because there is an outside patio in the front with a fireplace,but the food sucks.

Bottom line,its cool to visit,but I wouldn't buy anything or eat here.
author: Mike M.

description:
The only reason I don't love Pier 39 is the parking.  Sometimes you get lucky, but sometimes trying to find a spot can be like finding one at college.  Impossible.  You have to pay for parking no matter what, but some of the restaurants on the Pier will validate.  There are a ton of shops and restaurants on the Pier, but my favorite part has always been the Sea Lions.  

Also, there are lots of street performers which are pretty entertaining.  

Definitely a cool tourist attraction you should check out if it's your first time in the city.
author: Katie B.

description:
My sister took me here when I visited her. It was okay except for the rain, but there is so much things to do (bike riding, buying souvenirs, and eating). It's a big tourist attraction so everything is pretty much expensive, come with a lot of cash to spend.

We spent a little over $35 for parking at we only stayed for 4 hours. This place is very crowded so I would hold your wallet and bags close. We went to fisherman's wharf later and one of those silver statue guys actually STALKED me cause I didn't put money in his cup when I was trying to take a picture. 

Highlight: Clam chowder in the sourdough bread bowl. Your visit isn't complete without getting one.
author: Reid E.

description:
TOURISTS - yeah, that's what it's for.  This is how we get our money, people.  Why do you think the cable car ends here?  

Yeah, the lure of overpriced bad seafood is enough to knock all my stars off (I've succumbed both as a tourist and as a pseudo-native), but those greazylicious Mini Donuts give em AL:L back.  I believe they squish those baby pieces of heaven right in front of you.

The postcard water view, sea lions and various magic shows near the fudge stand & brokedown arcade are decent, too.
author: Randy Y.

description: recommend get a table with a view.  I really loved their clam chowder, the difference is they have crab meats on top of it.  Such a creative touch and you have to ask them for it, because you won't find it on menu. This place is always crowded so be ready for it.  It's not a bad thing though.  Love it love it!!
author: Melody J.

description: Fun experience. Good place to take out of town folks. The sea lions are so much fun, even if you don't have a kid in your group, still go.
author: Catherine Q.

description: Soooo San Francisco touristy, but that's what makes it fun.  Love going and viewing the noisy sea lions basking at the pier, and love walking to the end of Pier 39 and looking at Alcatraz.  Kitschy, but fun! :)
author: Devo S.

description: Came for 4th of July to watch the fireworks show ! Amazing show, beautiful fireworks show the city put on. The pier itself was packed with tons of people but definitely worthwhile . Parking prices were crazy high! The highest we saw was $60 flat rate. Recommend taking Bart or MUNI when traveling for a holiday event to the pier !
author: Melissa M.

description: Great tourist and local place! A lot of sea food! It's really cold, so layer up! The 7D experience was really fun, you'll feel dizzy at first but you'll get use to it. There's a lot of shops there, pricey though. They have a parking garage the first two hours I believe is free.
author: Selina F.

description:
This is another childhood favorite of mine- I made many trips here with my family, growing up here (proof that locals like doing touristy things too). There were always: seafood restaurants, a carousel, a Midway game place, and a pizza-by-the-slice place. Through the years, some of the shops have changed. I remember the Sanrio store that was in the front where a souvenir shop now stands. The Hard Rock Cafe wasn't always there. On the backside, the sea lions- there was a new story that they left and when we visited (april/may 2010), they were back! It's fun watching them. This is a unique fun tourist attraction that I still enjoy coming to, whenever I'm in town. 

We (my husband and I) always stop in the following: Bubba Gump (I introduced this restaurant to him- been going to this one for years, whenever I'd visit- the first time for me was in the mid-late 1990's- if you're early enough you might get a seat overlooking the water) , the candy shop at the back (neat place), the two-level sports store in the middle (I'm always on the lookout for Niners stuff), the various souvenir shops (so many specialty shops!), and recently discovered the San Francisco Music Box Company  (love love love their music boxes and globes- I've got a little collection) store upstairs on the second level- hope that this store sticks around. This was my husband's third time here (3rd trip together) and he still enjoys coming here. Plus, San Diego's Seaport Village doesn't have anything on Pier 39. 

If you're lucky it's sunny, but since it's on the water, still windy, sorry. Don't get my wrong, it's still a nice site to see, even in it's foggy glory. What I am saying is, dress accordingly in layers, so as it gets warmer, you can shed the layers. Since it is popular, expect a large crowd of people. It's huge too, so allow some time to linger at some stores that interest you. It's a family-friendly place with lots of shops and lots of restaurants. And remember, locals and tourists alike partake. BTW, the parking garage right across the way is primo expensive, so we park in another parking garage, buy something at one of the stores, and the ticket is validated. It's a short walk away from Pier 39.
author: Margret C.

description:
Sure, this place is a tourist trap, but I love the pier! Every time I go to SF, I have to visit the pier. It is crowded, it does have lots of touristy type of places to attract you, but it is all fun and everyone knows this coming in!

All in all, come and enjoy the street vendors, some food, go shopping, take in the great scenery and smile at (or ignore) the bums asking for money.

I love this place and always will.
author: Michelle M.

description:
If you're a tourist, then sure, go check it out, but otherwise, it's too touristy and crowded. They have a whole bunch of seafood restaurants but how many can you really go there? I personally think the best ones are not IN the Pier 39 plaza area. I like the ones a little off the side where they sell crab and calamari at the stands. Can't think of the name right now, sorry... But if you're in the mood for clam chowder and such, you're in the right place so enjoy! 

The shops are all the same. All the touristy shirts, magnets and mugs you can get. The arcade is boring but maybe it's just cause I'm not a kid anymore, but I do like the carousel in the middle. 

I guess when I do come to Fisherman's Wharf, what I enjoy most are the seals, the clam chower at the stands only, the sweets (they have some decent candy/ice cream shops there) and some of the cool shows and fireworks. I also like Alcatraz as touristy as it may be, it's a part of history that everyone should learn; it's interesting! 

All of my out of town guests, I tell them to try Pier 39, but for specific things for a couple of hours, but after that, leave, there's no need to spend an entire day there. Walk down the Embarcadero all the way to AT&T Park to see what else is on beautiful Embarcadero! I did it (in heels!), it's fun! 

Beware of the Bush Man!
author: Lucky N.

description: I've never, never had a kind of Terrence Malick day here. But I've always had a Michael Bay day whenever there's a festival or during Fleet Week.
author: Sean C.

description:
Look Ma, I caught a tourist,

I'm not saying it's a tourist trap, per-say, but there are a ton of tourists here.  All the time.  It is definitely a must see if you're visiting for the first time.  Of course I've been here I don't know how many times throughout my life.  There are some pretty cool shops here, and you'll usually find at least one sea lion in the marina.
author: Eric L.

description:
We really only come here for the sea lions and it's proximity to the Rainforest Cafe, both of which my toddler loves. Besides that I don't have much use for Pier 39 as it is crowded, overpriced and tacky. The bathrooms weren't half bad though, it was actually the first time I had seen a longer line for the men's room than the ladies.  

We tried to go to the Marine Mammal store to buy my son a sea lion stuffed animal and benefit them at the same time, but the store was locked with a sign saying they would return in 10 minutes. We waited almost 30 minutes and we could see the employee inside ignoring all the people waiting outside and even some people who knocked. I think they lost quite a few sales with that move.
author: Lisa H.

description:
How can people not like Pier 39? Yes, it's a tourist trap. Yes, the shops and restaurants are not really anything to write home about. But it's Pier 39 with the friggin sea lions!

It's got a lovely view of the bay and of course, those cute cute cute sea lions. 

I don't usually dine at Pier 39, I'd rather walk a little farther and go somewhere better, but if I'm in the neighborhood walking around, I will definitely come over to say hello to the sea lions. "Arf arf arf!!"
author: Barbara S.

description: Super touristy (as to be expected by it's location) but a good place if you're looking to have some good ol' fashioned fun....and that goes for locals, too. There are lots of food options - full service restaurants as well as food stalls and more casual places - and all kinds of stores to enjoy. Also good for people watching and being out and about in the fresh air. Was a plus to see the Christmas tree by the entrance (lots of people like to take pictures there).
author: Judi B.

description:
So many tourists!
This is a must-see once, but I think there are so many better things to do in SF. 

Good food and local attractions (silverman, musicians, bush man, etc), cheap t-shirts, and great place to people-watch.
author: Lucas R.

description:
A famous landmark of San Francisco, Pier 39 offers a great variety of shops and restaurants, and of course a view of the sea lions "tanning" on the docks.

If you're looking for a quiet walk on the shore, this is not the place to go as it's swarming with tourists all year long.
author: Stef L.

description: Definitely one of the best days that we had in San Francisco. Lots of things to do here. We got to see the sea lions, walk the shops on the pier. We visited the Aquarium of the bay, where we got to pet a shark (SO COOL). We took the scenic boat tour out to the golden gate bridge, and around Alcatraz. Definitely invest in the Citypass if you are planning on visiting. Worth the investment. Filled with lots of great deals, and ideas. Includes public transportation. We also rode the trolley (Can't visit San Fran without doing that).
author: Ryan B.

description: Nice and touristy just the way I like it.
author: Jay C.

description: Great place to walk around & check out the shops. Be sure to get a clam chowder bowl at Chowders and check out the sea lions that like to sleep on the docks :)
author: Tracy C.

description: Tourist Trap at it's finest. Good for kids, but if you're looking for a true San Fran experience this is not the place...gift shops, cheesy restaurants, and a magician? Pier 39's one shining quality is that at the very end of it is an incredible view of Alcatraz and the Golden Gate Bridge - but you have to walk through the madness to get there...up to you! I've experienced it once and once is enough!
author: Sammy S.

description:
Looking around for a place to eat is not hard to find here.
There's usually a musical performance near the giant crab.  I do not know what they feed those sea lions but they stink.  After about 10mins of watching them do absolutely nothing, it's time to move on.  I can't imagine how smelly it gets during the summer months.

There's not much to do here unless your coming for a boat tour or going to the tiny Aquarium.
author: Sandy C.

description:
HEADACHE EVERY TIME,

In the last few years San Fransico's Infrastructure has become a maze to no where, allowing your to get in to the city but a huge pain to get back out. The parking is up to 50$ and not as easy as it seems to validate. 
 
My suggestion, head over the Golden Gate to Sausalito its very nice and the parking is less. The town is cleaner and not so many distractions from the view.
author: Shane S.

description:
Come on so-called "locals" (aka yuppie/hipster transplants from cornland, midwest), Admit it, when you first came out to San Francisco, you squealed like a school girl at seeing fisherman's wharf, and thought it was the coolest place ever...Just because it's hip to hate on fisherman's wharf doesn't mean you should have to as well in order to build your "local" credibility. I loved Fisherman's wharf as a child and if you didn't, you're lying.

With that said, aside from Nostalgia purposes, this place really has nothing to offer someone who lives here; Still doesn't justify acting like a hipster douchebag about the place.
author: Stevie D.

description:
I LOVE this tourist trap we call Pier 39.  I've been here a handful of times and I love it especially on a beautiful day in SF.  From upstairs you turn one side and see Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, and then the Bay bridge. 

There is so much fun random stuff to do here.  Of course you will find the option to get Clam Chowder in a Sourdough bread bowl for about 9 bucks at any restaurant or booth.  You can also get yourself an I love SF shirt/sweater or Alcatraz shot glass. 

There is an arcade and merry go round for the kiddies.  There is a pretty scent sea salt area where you can put these beautiful scents in a bottle and remember your trip to SF with. 

There is also the Aquarium of the Bay that I have yet to go to.  The one thing I SUPER miss that was the best FREE entertainment was the seals in the back being all obnoxious and loud.  Wherever you are I hope you are safe but come back soon!  SF misses you!

There is plenty of Ghiradelli's chocolate to buy, Dreyer's ice cream to be eaten, and alcohol to sip!  

Pier 39 could be a kid friendly place, a fun group outing, or romantic date.  

I always have so much fun here!  I'll try to check out the aquarium or boat ride or something. 

After strolling around the Pier 39 plaza go out to Embarcadero and see break dancers performing, Bush Man scaring people, and those silver/gold people holding so dang still you have no idea they are real until they kiss your cheek and it is stained with metallic.
author: Anya R.

description:
I'm gonna give it a five because I'm a local and I LOVE SAN FRANCISCO but I mean it is a tourist spot.

I hate taking my out of townies here during the summer. Its UBER crowded, its hot, and hard to get to into restroom. All the food is marked up and mega expensive. Produce from their fruit stand is way over priced and crappy! Only the expensive restaurants get parking validation and that's if you can even get a spot in that crazy garage.

BUT.... in the winter....

HUGE beautiful Christmas tree, Christmas music, small local crowd, nearby BOUDIN for some bread and chowda, or a bucket of boat trash from Bubba Gumps, biscoff biscuits and coffee, lighted up carousel, Trish's Mini Donuts, cute sealions, and a stroll by the Bay all snuggled up in my warm winter coat and boots. PURE LOVE. (Especially when I park in the parking lot by Boudins and get free, validated parking).
author: Trishia P.

description: Walking along the Pier on a brilliant fall day in the city is one of life's simple pleasures. It IS a tourist trap and priced accordingly but it's also full of full things to do and experience as benefiting a world class tourist destination.
author: David C.

description:
This would have been a 4 or even a 5 star review if there'd been anywhere to breathe while we were at the Pier.

Tons of shops and places to walk around and see and do. Go down to the end and see some seals while you're there. Wander the shops and spend all your money on touristy crap :)

Tons of street performers, which was pretty cool. Also a few hobo's, which really wasn't. 

I'm not a crowd person and neither is the wife so after about an hour of trying to wade through the tidal wave of humanity we beat a hasty retreat and went a couple blocks over and found a hole in the wall bar to have some drinks.
author: Jason J.

description:
LOVE IT!

It's touristy, yes. I was once a "tourist" too the first time I set foot in SF. Don't hate them, they keep our economy going.  

I always get the mini-donuts dusted with cinnamon sugar served at one of food stalls here -- piping hot!

And don't forget about Fleet Week!  I know it's months away but good-looking men in uniform, oh yes!

Leave your boyfriend at home.
author: Janice C.

description:
Love the pier!  Tons of little shops and great restaurants and food stands.  Always get the clam chowder/chili bowl here...they are SO good!  My son really loved the carousel and I had fun in the candy shop picking out my salt water taffy.  The sea lions who are laying out are pretty cute too!  

Supposedly there's this famous homeless guy who hides behind bushes that like to scare ppl.  YouTube him!  I don't understand why he would do this, but it's always good to know about cuz I get startled easily =P
author: Esther Y.

description: Pier 39 is a top tourist trap that's main appeal is its few restaurants, bars, souvenir shops, and wharf views.  Though it is one of those lame musts for visitors, there is really nothing that unusual to see here.
author: Alison C.

description: Had Dante written Inferno in contemporary America, this place would easily work for one his circles of Hell.  Crowded, expensive, and loaded with national franchise businesses.  Possibly the least San Franciscan spot in all of San Francisco.
author: Joshua W.

description: Fun place to jump off the trolley at. Walk hand in hand and just wander around to see the shops, look at the bay.
author: Christina V.

description:
I have mixed feelings about this. Yes, it's touristy, but I am a tourist, so hey - show me the way!

The food we ate at whatever little place that was was, OK.  The atmosphere was nice with the live music from the street performer, I wish the restaurant had turned down their radio - the two were competing against one another.

We went to the Aquarium - you can see the separate review, but we liked it.

We enjoyed meandering through the shops, too.  It was a nice afternoon.

The children were quite entertained by the magician - Jack SpareRibs - that they had there in the evening in the center stage.  The entertainment is free, if you're that kind of person.  We pitched in a few bucks for all the entertainers we saw that we liked (which was pretty much all of them). 

Yes, everything is overpriced...food, parking, Tshirts... But, aren't all tourist traps?  And have you seen what real estate costs here?  

The HIGHLIGHT:  If you can find your way to the water, there are sea lions that beach themselves on piers here.  SO COOL.  I gather the locals are less than thrilled, you know, trying to get their boats in and out without killing them.  But, I have never seen sea lions other than in an aquarium or show before and I thought it was magical.  We watched them for hours.

The down side - it you didn't know there was water on the other end of the pier you'd never figure it out.  All that beautiful bay and it's like the place was designed to hide it rather than show it off.  That's why it got 3 stars.  They should take some notes from the Inner Harbor in Baltimore or Annapolis - we celebrate our beaches, bays and water views on the east coast.  Maybe you Californians just don't realize what you have.

(Oh, and we parked at a lot at Pier 33/35 - just a few blocks.  It was expensive, and more annoyingly, the "self pay" machine that takes credit cards does not take credit cards, nor does it give change so you have to have exact change or over pay for parking which is already $35 a day - ouch.  We were there a few days and never had a problem finding parking.)
author: Vicky C.

description:
Absolute tourist hell.  Chain store after chain restaurant and millions of freezing tourist wearing short pants and fanny packs and why in the name of God are you people visiting chain stores when you can visit the same stupid stores back home?  Thus, unlimited negative stars for having no redeemable value whatsoever aside from one thing:  

The sea lions.  

5 stars for the lions, negative 683 stars for everything else.  I'm giving Pier 39 a generous 2 stars for the loveable lions.

These wonderful creatures are a local SF landmark and they are a delight to observe.  Unfortunately, they are close to the far end of the pier so you have to walk through hell to get there, and then jostle with the tourists once you find the lions, but if you are in the area, they are worth a look-see.  Their antics are truly hilarious.
author: Craig W.

description:
It always busy - day or night, and it feels like a holiday there, even if it's not a holiday. If you would like to buy souvenirs there, stop by in a few shops since they all mostly have the same items, but price might be different (of course it you care to save a couple of bucks).
We bough two sourdough bowls (one with clam chowder and another with chili) for lunch right on the street and enjoyed them seating on the bench and admiring fun ambiance of the Pier 39.
Despite so many people, promenade is clean and beautifully maintained with flowers.
Also  I would definitely recommend Fog Harbor Fish House restaurant there.
author: Yelena Z.

description: Beautiful area to stroll in. Lots of tourists of course.  You can get your garage parking validated if you eat around pier 39.  It gets super busy and hard to find parking.  The lots are about $10 but you have to walk a few blocks.  Nice views & tons of food that's catered to tourists.
author: Trynh K.

description: It's a pretty typical tourist area. I would say a tourist trap area? It's still fun to walk around and enjoy the water and scenery but it does get pretty crowded with tourists. It's really just walking around and seeing street performers and typical gift shops. I can't recommend any food there except Boudin's, but for experience, the outdoor food stand near musee de mecanique is fun.
author: Yuki A.

description: I love the pier. Even though it is a bit crowded, I still adore this place. Everything about this place gives me comfort as well as adventure. All the stores and many options of food choices are wonderful. I especially love hearing the silly calls the sea lions do. =)
author: Anji W.

description: i love pier 39 the shops are fun and its always great people watching . the weather can be a bit cold as its on the bay . the marina is nice and its allways fun to walk along the outside of the pier and look at all the boats . i love going here with friends intown
author: Bety S.

description:
Loveeee the aquarium! 
crowded but of course it is san fran!
author: Claudia G.

description: Lots of places to eat and drink and very loooooong lines to use the bathrooms.
author: Cash M.

description:
This place is SUPER touristy

Since I have been living here for about 3 years i rarely make my way to Pier 39, but every time I do... I honestly love it. Sure it's touristy, it's crowded, there's seagulls and bird shit everywhere, but its fun. 

My favorite part is definitely those sea lions doing their thang. If you come here later on in the evening or even during the week, you definitely won't catch too much of a crowd and can enjoy the view and the arrrr of the sea lions that much more. 

Pier 39, you're A Ok by me
author: Julia L.

description: Very fun and definitely touristy.  Lot's of variety for shopping, dining and site seeing.  Street performers, fun times for kids, and the seals top of the walk down the pier.  A must see/do during your visit in San Fran.
author: J M.

description:
Fun fun fun! Older games, but still fun!

They ran out of candy in the prize section. However, there were other random prizes to be bought with my tickets.

-1 because they need to fix the bee and honey pot game
author: Margaret R.

description: The seals are kind of cool, but it seems that even they can sense the lame tourist-y vibe emanating from the dock. Avoid this Pier at all costs - it is a terrible tourist nightmare.
author: Sam R.

description: Lots of fun for the family. Tons of little shops that delight all ages. The food is good and they have live entertainment like little magic shows and stuff. There's a carousel as well as an arcade in the back of the pier. And who doesn't love sea lion watching?!
author: Kimmy N.

description:
What can I say? I'm corny.  I loved this place as a kid and love it going back as an adult.  The only difference was, when I was kid, my parents would ruin the whole trip pissing and moaning about how expensive and overpriced and touristy the whole thing was, and as an adult there's no one to shame me out of enjoying the dumb things I enjoy - fudge, a round trip by carousel, the sea lions, a walk by the water, a visit to the aquarium, fighting a Japanese oyster to give up its pearl, a nutella latte at the bakery.  Oh yes, and a heaping dinner of crab at the Crab House to end the night, along with a glass of wine while watching the sun set over Alcatraz and all of that weird history.

I mean I know we're supposed to be ashamed of places like this, or detest them, or hate what they stand for - or at least to have a healthy hatred of tourists and children.  I must be missing the intellectual rigor to feel most of those things.  It revives my excitement to have grown up in such a special place.  I'm happy I grew up in the Bay Area.  I'm sad I moved away.  I'm happy when I go back to watch visitors and locals alike taking in one of the only things that still exist here from when I was a kid.  The rich tech people have pushed all the rest of us idiots out of San Francisco proper.  This corny shit doesn't sit well with them, I know.  I even married a rich tech dude and might very well end up back in the city someday.  But I won't ever be too good to watch a sea lion inhale a fish directly out of the bay, or pet some starfish in a kiddy pool. It'll just get more expensive and I'll regret not having gone more as a kid.
author: Olivia O.

description: As always, this place is very touristy. But really, it is always a fun time just to go, even if you want to deal with crowds of people from out of state. There are some cool (and extremely overpriced) shops here and there, but it is still fun just to walk around and enjoy the area with someone special.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Pier 39 is the place that tourists go to see the sea lions. Just realize they are sometimes here and sometimes not.  If you see a crowd of people snapping pictures frequently, they are there.

Pier 39 is a place where tourists flock to, wander in and out of small shops; look at the bay; perhaps have a meal.  It has an aquarium (which I would say avoid - there are far better in the area, especially in Monterey).

While Locals in San Francisco will not go here regularly (they go often enough when visitors come to town), its a place tourists to San Francisco go to when on vacation.  As such, the busy times for Pier 39 goes hand in hand with peak vacation times such as summer vacations, holiday week-ends, or week-ends in general.

In this area there are various street artists, etc. to watch - and amuse about.  Its fun - as its one of those things you do not find in your usual community shopping mall.
author: Samantha K.

description: Spent most of my vacation here.  It's nice,  looking forward to it not being so full of tourists though
author: Rena A.

description: Yes this is the go to place for tourists, and they have attractions and food, but for the most part, SF is sooo much more than Pier 39. Explore people, explore!
author: Olia M.

description:
I love Pier 39 San Francisco & everything around it! Not only a tourist spot, but a great place to hang out w/ friend(s), family, lover, or solo. Too much to enjoy here!

Went to Pier 39 for Father's Day (Sunday) 6/21/09 evening like after 6pm for dinner @ Crab House & followed by dessert @ Dreyer's Ice Cream, which is just down the stairs from Crab House http://www.pier39.com/Dining/casualeateries.htm I honestly felt like a crepe, but Crêpe Cafe's desssert crepe doesn't include ice cream the way I like (see my crepe from Richmond's Honk Kong Snack House http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/VbVC4omAR1FVhWS7oVHiPQ?select=7XF17PgsP7ZXdD_78IObcQ ) so Dreyer's met the challenge. I didn't take a pic, but I was sooo pleased w/ my Green Tea Waffle Ice Cream Cone...that was scrum-didly-umptous!!!

We walked around a bit, & didn't seem as crowded compared to when we arrived just after 6pm, no complaints, I mean by this time it's creepin' up to 8pm http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/B5e069dbuKZG9IJypIhkyg?select=jycOTLLyCMuQC-SLQoDT1w Isn't it nice to see such a sky 8pm in the Bay Area http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/B5e069dbuKZG9IJypIhkyg?select=Ywjw0gWhYqRWQ2LxejLYeQ Love it! Back to our car @ Pier 39 Garage Parking http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/B5e069dbuKZG9IJypIhkyg?select=Ow1diEEPFIzeiHHYyd2xUw to go home but honestly, we'll likely be back here a few more times this year just for the hell of it...why not!
author: Mary J.

description: Had a great time here,always something going on. Shops are great,shows are fun to watch,and weather is always nice. Can't wait to go back!
author: Isaac F.

description:
Tourist trap?  Of course it is.  That doesn't mean it's not an awesome place to visit.  Then again, I AM a tourist; what do I know?  ;)

We visited on a cold January day.  When I say "cold", I mean it was somewhere around 50 degrees.  The cool air kept the crowds away, and it was wonderful to wander around peacefully.  I'm not a fan of crowds.  Come summer time, I'd probably hate to be in this area.  But winter?  50 degrees and slightly windy?  Perfect.

My friend and I are great at amusing ourselves with little to nothing.  Just walking around was good enough for us.  We had fun window shopping, getting some food, visiting the mirror maze, watching the sea lions for a bit... it was a lot of fun, and I feel our time spent here was worth it.  I only spent $20 or so while here, and where else can you spend $20 for a good four hours of entertainment?
author: Jenna A.

description:
This place is a nice little touristy place. There's not a whole lot to see if you're just browsing though. Maybe 3 hrs max to eat and look through the stores and see some sea lions/seals idk what they are.

You can walk over to Boudin's bakery and watch the bakers make bread in the window. It's just a block or two further up the pier. You might be adventurous enough to walk to Ghirardelli square too. There's plenty of bread bowls of clam chowder shops on the way there. 

Find some of those brochures that have free 2 hr parking validation. Or have a AAA card. Either or. You have to go to the 2nd level to the visitor's center to get your parking validated if you park in the pier 39 lot. They'll also give you a coupon book which you might or might not find useful.
author: Karen Y.

description:
My fiance and I really enjoyed Pier 39.  It was Thanksgiving night - and we had already walked through Fisherman's Wharf and had our crab and clam chowder bread bowl.  We had already walked through Ghiradelli Square and taken photos of Alcatraz Island.  We were about ready to move on when we spotted a Christmas tree!  I am a huge Christmas fanatic so the sight almost brought a tear to my eye - and suddenly my tired legs felt as though I could endure maybe one more walking excursion.

Walking toward Pier 39 was  a gorgeous site.  It is a must see around the holidays.  So romantic - it felt like Disneyland without the rides.  Thanksgiving night was perfect because it was pretty empty.  Hardly any tourists.  Just a few couples enjoying the lights.  The carousel, tree, and garland made everything so cozy.

We did all the touristy things.  We took pictures in a photo booth.  We took pictures of the tree.  We took self portraits in front of the carousel.  And never once did I feel bored.  All of the shops and restaurants were open, even on the holiday.  

The only negative was that being night - it was freezing cold.  Definitely colder than in the city because you're literally right by the water.  I haven't been that cold in awhile - my Arizona blood was not prepared!  But all in all - a magical night.  I would recommend the Pier to families, couples, or anyone who just wants to people watch.  And find a time when it's not crazy packed!  That definitely made the experience more intimate!
author: Kristy K.

description: Nice stores. Disappointed with the Crystal Geyser show. The two guy show had sexual comments . Very disappointed. Not completely family friendly. Hard Rock nice place finest with family.
author: Alice B.

description:
Its the City...so its kinda sorta ok just cuz of that...but seriously, I see all the ghetto SJ Valley peeps here hanging out. We always play "Spot The Stocktonian" game here.  
Over priced, tourist-y, crowded, frontal buttocks ghetto mama's spending their welfare checks...yeah no thank you.
author: Monica H.

description:
If you're fine with being amongst a plethora of tourists, by all means come to Pier 39. As you can well imagine, parking costs are insane. Take public transportation if you can. 

There are some nice restaurants, specialty shops, and ample opportunity to take care of all your souvenir shopping. It's nice that there aren't that many "chain" stores/eateries, other than some bigger names such as Hard Rock and Bubba Gump. 

Of course the main attraction are the sea lions. It's a hit or miss nowadays with the changing seasons and ocean temperatures, so some days there will be many, and some just a few. The pier is dual-level, but there is elevator access for the handicap and families with strollers.
author: Andy P.

description:
This place was the first place that made me love San Francisco. My mother always brings far away family to pier 39 and for her it never gets old. I'm a bit jaded for always coming here. I'm more of a downtown person. I mean the area is nice and expensive bit I've jsut been here too many times.
As far as beverages they're like 3 or 4 dollars a bottle. Also I recommend the wipe out by the begging of the pier. Ice cream here good i'll tell you that as well as those donuts in the buckets.
author: Nadav M.

description:
fun for everyone.  lots of cool shops and good places to eat.  yes, it's touristy and expensive, but that doesn't make it less fun.  We always find something interesting here and keep going back.

my pier favorite stops:  donuts, phone gadets, the produce stand, the candy store at the end.  and for the kids:  do the trampoline jump in the middle.  my daughter will wait in line for this thing forever... and she hates to wait for anything.  so much fun!
author: Linnea E.

description: I love walking up and down Pier 39! They always have cool little shops to look at and great food. The food can be pricey sometimes but it's so worth the adventure. ALSO go to Alcatraz. It's pretty cool.
author: Justine C.

description: My gawd, horrible tourist trap.  The only reason we EVER went here (we are locals) was to see the Sea Lions and their population has virtually disappeared so there is NO reason to go.  It's t-shirt shops and touristy junk.  We had recent visitors here from Australia who wanted to visit on their own.  I suggested they skip it (based on the above) but they decided to go just to check it off their bucket list. Why not? They were very disappointed.  Skip it, you'll be glad you did.  If you do go, look for the "Bush Man" and watch him scare the c&$p out of unsuspecting tourists.
author: Ottis M.

description: Good place to walk after a good meal, not many attractions, but the boat ride did look like fun next time I will ride the speed boat.
author: Carlos M.

description: This is a really nice attraction for people who are new to San Francisco.  If you're in the mood for the best seafood in the area, then you should definitely dine here.  In addition to seafood, you can try the best clam chowders too.  You can always find a great view, and it's a very chill place to hang out.  It's really chilly at Pier 39, so dress warm.  The area is a great place to go running.
author: Buortau L.

description: I really enjoyed going there. The sights were great. Seeing the ocean and golden gate was one of the best highlights of my life. Also san fransico was by far the most beautiful cities ive ever seen.
author: David H.

description:
Love Love this store!!!


We dedicated a whole day just doing some shopping at union square and fisherman's wharf and I told my girlfriends that no matter what we NEED to go inside Pier 39. 

This store never disappoints but this past trip there it disappointed me with their customer service! I was looking for one of those "I HEART SF" jackets for me and a friend and while looking I found a black one with the pink color heart but all the sizes were Large and of course I'm not a Large so I asked the cashier if he could go to the back and check if any other sizes were available and of course he steps in the back for only a second and comes back saying he didn't have any other sizes...Are you kidding me?? Can you be more obvious that you didn't even check! After that happened I saw one that a maican was wearing so I asked if he could check what size was on the manikin and his reply was "we can't switched items on the manikins" omg I was going to loose it if it wasn't for my friend who was with me to tell me to just buy the red color heart jacket. I was so annoyed that I almost never wanted to come back here again on future trips!


BAD BAD customer service especially for being located in Fisherman's wharf!
author: Raych D.

description: I love Pier 39. It is my favorite stop whenever going to San Francisco, having everything needed for tourists and locals alike. We went for the Christmas tree lighting ceremony & it was nothing short of magical! The tree was huge and decorated in an incredibly sparkly, gorgeous way. Disneyland characters were present, Christmas music was playing, and everyone was in the spirit. I'd definitely recommend this event for anyone who celebrates Christmas!
author: Alyssa L.

description: Like peanut butter and jelly, San Francisco and Pier 39, just go together! If you're a tourist, or just feeling nostalgic about this beautiful city, then Pier 39 is a must. The area caters to tourists with dozens of shops and restaurants that will fill your fancy for whatever your heart desires. There's something for everyone here, even an awesome organic ice cream shop and plenty of places serving up house-made crab chowder, for anyone who isn't a clam fan. The walk to the SF Giants stadium isn't too far either, and there are a bunch of great bars and lounges along the waterfront. The ambience in SF is unique everywhere you go, but nowhere will disappoint you. SF folks are friendly and eclectic. So if you're not feeling one spot, just keep moving, you're sure to find a place you love.
author: T P.

description: I always enjoy going to Pier 39 to see the seals.  Unfortunately over the years it has become very commercial.  When I checked in with Yelp I was told that I got a "fun pack" and when I went to go get it I found it was coupons.  I was disappointed.  I will continue to come to see the seals but avoid the traps.
author: Denise B.

description:
They got SO MUCH good stuff here !!  Grew up outside San Fran mostly and was one of the tourists people talk about but I liked it..  Last time I saw they got a arcade with alot of games and Air Hockey !! Bubba gump shrimp is close to..  Hate there outifts in that spot but its fun to switch the signs all the time at random.  They hate me lol but I tip okay so they could take a long walk off there short pier haha !! 

Anyhow you got to try coming here even once cause its unique and different and it could stay in your memories a long time like mine did..  Very happy ones to. Those robot guys are cool and they never go for the Two For Flinching game. I tried.  Some weirdos to but thats just like any where in San Fran.  

Seals are cute so you could bring a date here I guess..
author: Xavior G.

description: Pier 39 is the largest tourist attraction in the city. That said, the pier sees a lot of traffic, and for good reason. The views of the SF Bay are gorgeous, and there are so many activities to do in the wharf area in general. There are a bunch of bay cruises you can take from Pier 39, on a ferry or a sailboat. An array of tour buses stop in front of the pier. The aquarium of the bay is unique because it has creatures that are found in the SF Bay. The mirror maze is fun and inexpensive. There's a carousel, magic show, and sometimes they have live music. Of course there are many restaurants to try, and some good happy hours. Definitely spend a couple of hours if you're in town. You can visit the California Welcome Center on the upper level to get some free maps and coupons.
author: Michelle W.

description:
We opted to check out Pier 39 for old time sake.  But, it's TOTALLY touristy, (like Disneyland on Labor Day weekend)

That said, the view from the end of the pier was wonderful.  And, the noisy seals were fun to watch.

We also stopped off and bought Bamboo sheets, which we had never seen before.  The salesgirls were helpful and they offered to ship us the sheets for free.
author: Tony S.

description:
Lived here all my life and I thought after driving by Pier 39 last week that it was about time I review this place. Ya it's a tourist trap but so what. We've all been tourist at one point in time unless you're a home body and don't do much. The stores on the pier are pretty cool to check out. The food in the area is good. Anything from Burgers to clam chowder in bread bowls can be found anywhere and on a cold summer night, a mouthful of hot clam chowder with the scent of bay water makes for a memorable night. 

If you're in the area on a Friday night, don't be lazy and walk through Aquatic Park over the hill and you'll end up at Off the Grid. This is our local food truck gathering and you can find local food here and a way cheaper price. 

Parking sucks in Pier 39. I'd love to tell you where I park at for FREE but then I'd expose that to all viewers and then my parking won't be available next time! Sorry!!
author: Philip O.

description:
Pier 39 is touristy without being a tourist trap - - and that's an important distinction. An attraction of long-standing reputation, it's a fabled San Francisco landmark with good reason.   Sea Lions & Street Performers Aquarium of the Bay - - fun!!   

PIER 39's location provides the picture perfect backdrop for postcard views of the Golden Gate and Bay Bridges, Alcatraz, Angel Island and the City skyline. PIER 39 is located two blocks east of Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco, at Beach Street and The Embarcadero.
author: Adrienne A.

description: This is the "go-to" pier.   I wouldn't eat here on a regular basis, but some of the restaurants aren't bad.  Trish's Donuts are TOO DELISH!  It's a fun place to hangout for awhile & people watch & it's a gorgeous view across the bay.  It's definitely more tourist-heavy, but there are plenty of residents around too! I love the aquarium nearby and it's just a fun way to spend a couple of hours.
author: Melanie E.

description:
I'm here often because i have a class over here. It really isn't a bad area, infact i would love this area if it hadn't sold itself to tourism. I suppose every city must have some tourist attraction though, and sadly in Frisco they all flock to the pier. I will still enjoy coming around here on occasion when i am with someone because it can be quite enjoyable. However coming here on my own to enjoy the view is incredibly unlikely unless its far away from the main area where there are no shops, or later in the evening when the shops start closing. Hard to enjoy this area and feel calmed on a nice day with the constant strollers, crying children, and ignorant people you have to constantly dodge. Unfortunate, but i could still enjoy this area on awkward times or days when there are alittle less of them around. 

Living in Union Square has made me get tired of tourists quite quickly. If you are looking for a nice ocean view with actual good and modestly priced food that is not cluttered with women popping babies or hundreds of Frisco T-Shirt stands *seriously how many of them do you need possibly need* then explore the rest of Frisco. You won't be dissapointed
author: Brittainie B.

description:
We went here twice on a short, 3 day trip.  Plenty to see and do for all the family, lots of restaurants, dessert shops (donuts, crepes, ice cream), lots of trinket/souvenir shops and great views where you can get great pictures :)

I loved it, but then again I've always been a sucker for tourism!
author: Lasairiona M.

description:
Typical tourist trap. It is like a cute little town with all these shops. Restaurants here tend to be overpriced - Walk few blocks towards Fisherman's Wharf or even a little past that for better value - in terms of quality, quantity, and/or view

I really do love shopping at all the cute shops here though. I have to be really watchful with how I spend my money here because it can get pretty expensive (again, typical tourist trap)

Lots of photo ops, and super crowded every day of the week - lots of kids and strollers so be careful not to step onto anyone
author: Christina P.

description:
Crowded overpriced touristy bullshit.  Im surprised they dont charge $20 to get in hhahah! 

There is literally NO reason to go here. Theres NOTHING unique, cool, or interesting, ok! Better cheaper food is almost anywhere, and literally the same damn views of the bay and Alcatraz  can be seen from ANY pier hah hah hah!

The most important thing I can say is that any souvenir stuff you NEED to buy, please please please walk to Chinatown and buy literally the exact same stuff for 1/2 the price as pier 39 or even less (ie: FIVE tshirts for $10 in Chinatown, at pier 39 $20+ each).

If you MUST go to see the Sea Lions, thats legit, but please plan on eating somewhere else and getting your souvenirs from Chinatown :)
author: Cory R.

description:
Sure it's a tourist stop, but there is lots of fun things to see and do around here.
