I would skip the eating/drinking as so many other great options in other areas (nob hill, tenderloin district, haight/ashbury) but if you want to walk around and see the city, this is a great part of it.
author: Alysha J.

description: I know this place is an SF tourist trap, but I still love it.  This place is fantastic on one of SF's rare, warmer days, and there is so much to do.  The sea lions on the decks outside, checking out the different eateries, and taking in all of the Greater Bay Area's scenery.  It's a magical place.
author: Mel G.

description:
Okay, this place is cool the first time you're here and IF you're under the age of 12. Otherwise, it's a really, really touristy spot. And, let's not bother with the crabs. Not that good! 

I do enjoy watching the sea lions. But, that's about it. Not really much to do around here.
author: Will C.

description: Yea, it's basically the same as Fisherman's Wharf but it's crowded and I'm not a big fan of the so called fresh seafood (the ones that are the open air kind with the boiling pots and the baskets piled up).
author: Jason G.

description: Gotta have Trish's Donuts...It's so yummy...and I love just walking around checking out the stores.
author: michelle b.

description:
OK, so I'm a little behind on wrapping up my Month Long Yelp for June 2009... it's been a lot of work keeping up with all the places I've visited!

Our Road Trip 2009 is over, but I still want to share a few of the places I haven't gotten to review yet with you all.

Pier 39... if you've ever been to San Francisco, you know it. It's the shopping pier near Fisherman's Wharf... and generally, you won't find a local anywhere near here unless they're hosting visitors from out of town!

It's a fun place to go... great, but not the best, views of the bay, lots of touristy shops and street entertainers hanging around. When we went, there was a comic all the way towards the end of the pier and a sax player at the entrance. Both were good.

The seals on the west side of the pier are always a smelly treat to visit. Lots of great picture opps there and plenty noisy!

The entertainers seem to be more vocal on what they want to be paid these days... on all my previous visits to San Francisco, I never remember any street performer saying how much of a tip would be appropriate. On this trip, half the street entertainers we saw mentioned a suggested tip for their shows and what their type of entertainment would garner in a paid establishment.

Anyways, Pier 39 is a fun place to visit when you're in San Fran. Go for it and have fun!
author: Rick D.

description: This is probably to most popular tourist spot in San Francisco because it's beautiful there and there are tons of things to do. The photo opportunity alone will keep you there for hours. There are tons of places to eat. It's almost over-whelming. At the end of the pier are the famous sea lions and now there is a museum dedicated to them right there. The is the Aquarium by the Bay and rides and an arcade and a wine tasting place and of course tons of gift shops. You can take tours of Alchatraz and the bay. The Pier, as I said offers a great view of the bridge, and Alchatraz and Angel Island. There is a merry go round and performers put on live shows all over the place. You could spend the whole day in that area easily. Take a jacket. It gets windy especially at night. Good luck in finding parking though. You may have to either pay a lot if you want to park close or walk a ways if you want to find a cheaper spot to park. I recommend taking public transportation. There are several that go right to it like the cable cars.
author: Liz C.

description:
Certainly a tourist trap.

A lot of nice stores that of course are very high priced.

A few spots to buy food that of course are also nigh priced. 

And of course this is where you will find Bubba Gump Shrimp Co.

...on a clear day you can see forever, or at the very least the Oakland/San Francisco Bay Bridge, the East Bay and Alcatraz.
author: Patricia V.

description:
Ew. Avoid. 

I know it's a prerequisite for a San Francisco trip but I would question that. For the traveler on a time budget, time is better spent elsewhere. 

Views of Alcatraz, OK fine, it's pretty close. Sea Lions? Fine, there's a bunch of them sunbathing. (though you can totally find them doing this elsewhere) 

Every thing you do or see is a trade off on a trip. Limited amount of time, and you can't see or do everything. What would I recommend instead? Go to the Redwood forest across the bridge, go to Sutro Park, go to San Francisco Park. Twin Peaks. ANYthing that is famous for something other than being famous. 

Looking back on my trip, I wish I did something else instead of seeing Pier 39. I was afraid of missing something, and I did. 

Not advice for every traveller. I totally understand the appeal, but for those who seek a more "real" experience, look elsewhere
author: Alex M.

description:
Do you LOVE to walk around or visit an overrated, overly promoted, overly stupid, and overly mind-numbingly commercialized tourist traps with absolutely zero soul to it that will leave you absolutely disenchanted after hearing about it so much?

Then Pier 39 is all yours. 

Seriosuly, I cannot believe that thousands of tourists get suckered in this horrific mass of mediocre-at-best quality eateries, laughable shopping options (except for one store that sells all kinds of sport jerseys), and hug amounts of filthy facilities.

In my opinion, Pier 39 is not worth it at all. There are far nicer and more authentic places along the coast.
author: Gerardo F.

description: One of the biggest tourist spots in SF. Parking here is expensive! $8 an hour at the garage closest to the pier. However, if you get your parking validated & leave before 5pm, you will get 1 free hour of parking. If you leave after 5 or 6pm (with validation) you'll get 2 hours free parking.
author: Alexis A.

description: There is so much to do here! It is crowded and expensive like everyone says, but it's worth it. Can't go to Pier 39 without having clam chowder in a bread bowl either.
author: T S.

description:
Tourist trap! Beware! Beware!

So if you are a tourist and you want to see what SF has to offer, Pier 39 is probably a good choice. You have a good concoction of street performers, homeless, shopping, and gimmicks to keep you entertained. You can bring the kids here, or you can have an evening for the adults. 

I enjoy the food this place has to offer and it's unique vibe of tourism. I got my head stuck once in between the hole that the sea lions make in the brass sculpture, so beware :( 

Also watch out for the ATM they have here. You swipe your card and when you're done withdrawing money, you need to stay and cancel out of the next screen. I've walked up to the ATM where people got their cash and ran and didn't finish closing out the transactions. That's kind of dangerous. Good thing I'm not a corrupt, gold digging Asian.
author: Grace Y.

description: This is a really fun place to go! There are so many things to do and the view is good. I love the variety of restaurants and shops so you really can't get bored. The sea lions are adorable and hilarious. I really recommend going here.
author: Danny A.

description: It's always a beautiful day at the Pier ! I still love to come here take a stroll once in a while in SF it always relaxes me even though it can get pretty packed but Hey ! It's a tourist attraction. Everything about the pier I love ! From scenic to restaurant to shops ! Parking is pricy but if you redeem the fun pack you validated for 2 hrs of parking free save $16 at least since it's $8 per hr. Also you get buy one get one free coupons and some discounts. I love the shops ! Always different random cool stuff to buy.  Till next time pier 39 :)
author: R F.

description:
Ehhh... I guess its cool if you have never been to a tourist place like this in a coastal city. I have.....many,many times. People really need crowd walking 101 It seems like its a basic skill but damn I guess for some it is not. I tried to avoid all places touristy and cheesy but we sort of just fell into her trap. First time traveler to SF problems lol!
sealion....ewwwww
author: Carolyn T.

description:
I will give Pier 39 1 star only because I am not sure if I can give 0. I work in a hotel 2 blocks away and have only been to pier 39 twice in the 5 years I have lived in SF. The first time was When I got this job 3 years ago just so I could guide tourists to the right direction. The 2nd was when I had to meet someone outside of the Hard Rock Cafe which thankfully is on the outside of the pier. 

Not only is it over priced and disgusting. Guess what people. Its not historical. Not in the least. The only historical thing about the wharf it that the entire area of town isn't even land. Its a freaking Ship Graveyard covered in Tar. Even the Sea Lions have left because they hate it so much.

So you've got shopping that is going to cost you an arm and a leg. You've got food that is going to make you take a dump in a hour and is just plain Gross.

Hey Tourists...ask someone who has been here for a while where the real attractions are because 39 is not one of them. Oh and those of you that come to SF to visit and all you do is hang around the Pier and you know who you are. Please. Please...I beg of you..Catch a taxi and go to the Mission, West Portal, the Loin, and Polk Street. Anywhere but here!
author: Damien K.

description: My kids love this place and I'd just assume miss it. Lots of tourist shops and junk food to eat, and always crowded.
author: Michael S.

description: Was a fantastic day down at the pier. We walked along it, ate some Minnie donuts and walked in and out of some nice shops. The view of the end is amazing overlooking the Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz. Also worth while is the stage which had a very awesome circus show on. If you want a cheap cruise under the bridge and around Alcatraz if you walk left down the wharfs some of the fishing charter boats offer $15 one hour cruises which are well worth doing. Take your own food and beer on board and relax as you travel around the bay. All in all a very relaxing friendly place.
author: Markus S.

description:
It's a tourist trap like many have stated before. Although the vaginal smell has vastly improved since the sea lions are no longer near the pier. However, it doesn't mean that this is not bad place to visit. Lots of shops and gift items to take home for friends and family. Plenty of places to eat. A few rides for the kids and an arcade to boot.

The donut-holes are dangerous and delicious, watch out.

As a local, I tend to avoid coming here. Yet I find myself coming here whenever a friend or family comes to visit--it's a love/hate relationship.
author: Terry C.

description: What a great place to watch the SF fireworks on the 4th of July. The best spot is right were you can see Alcatraz. it was breath taking. Aside from that this whole place is such a cool place to walk around, go shopping, eat and watch magic shows. They even have a carousel. Many of the stores are touristy but many other just have cool stuff.
author: Sarmad N.

description: You have to see the sea lions! Parking was difficult, but you can get your ticket validated for an hour or two off. Glad I entered the tourist trap.
author: Michelle T.

description:
HOT SPOT OF SAN FRANCISCO!

When you are in San Francisco, you have to stop by Pier 39.  It's great!  A pier near the water filled with restaurants, shops, rides, views of the city and entertainment, it's a great place to spend the day at!  

My favorite parts of Pier 39 is the view of Coit Tower, the Sea Lions, Alcatraz and the entertainment near the carousel!  

Although it's very touristy, Pier 39 is a must see!  Just be sure to cab it there cause parking is $20 near the Pier!
author: Hula R.

description:
Let me just say that I am more or less a local. This place is nice, if people are visiting and you don't want them to see the "real" SF. By "real" I mean men kissing, homeless people, tepid hipsters, and hippies. The part of SF that is composed of back east carpet baggers and trust fund hipsters. Most Americans don't want to anger up the blood on what should be a nice vacation.

PIER 39 is the Disneyland of SF. Here you find cheap wares, nice restaurants, waffle cones, and bread bowls. They have every kind of shop you could imagine, sans porno or decent quality clothing. Cheap amusement thrills and a view of the bay that simply can't be beat.

I took two stars off for being a local. This place doesn't excite me because I am from the east bay. But if you're looking for a good time, come here...Its probably better seeing the City for what it is.
author: Lana P.

description:
I've been to Pier 39/Fisherman's Wharf many times, but it never fails to entertain every time, and it's one of my favorite places to take my visiting friends to. From all the street performers to the Bushman, I feel like Pier 39 never gets old for me. 

Today I happened to be here during Fleet Week and got to catch part of the Blue Angels airshow. Pier 39 definitely had a great view of all that...it was pretty crowded but it's great if you like to feel the excitement in the air. :)
author: Esther Y.

description:
Crowds of people and great eats around the area.
Fun to walk around and browse shops.
Wish there we more to do here, but there's always plenty to do 
in the city anyway :)
Bush Man is a must see!
author: Holly M.

description:
Great place to go out and enjoy the city. Plenty of restaurants to choose from, love enjoying a clam chower on those cold nights. The only bad thing I could say is the parking, but thats something to expect from a place with plenty of tourist. 

Great place and wanted to write a review because as little girl it was one of my favorite places to be taken to, there's so much to do, and your really can't be bored in a place like is. Love it.

And be careful with the guy hiding behind the bush, the funny is thing to watch is people be scared by him!!
author: Isabel F.

description:
If you've been to San Francisco before and never once gone to Pier 39 than you're wrong!

There are plenty of things to do at Pier 39, you can watch local street attractions, eat at great restaurants, or even get yourself a personalized caricatures of you and the friends.

There are plenty of tourists here so parking is a hassle unless you don't mind paying a little more at the parking structures. Aside from that, Pier 39 is a wonderful tourist location that must be visited once in your lifetime.
author: Daniel N.

description: A very lively and happening spot in the city. Great for taking a stroll and sightseeing the bay, golden gate, Alcatraz and the sea lions. The pier also has carousel rides to the excitement of little kids.
author: Gopi V.

description:
If it wasn't touristy....what would be the point of it? 
Would you like to have a "NO tourists allowed" sign there and maybe check IDs to make it OK for the locals?  I never quite understood the hatred of touristy areas. 

Maybe SFricans take it for granted, but people WANT to see YOUR city. They come from all over the world to see it. Don't be such a snob as to look so far down on the touristy areas. There are reasons why THEY ARE TOURISTY....historical, beautiful, & diverse. 

I agree that too many people=sucky. So the best time to come here is early in the morning, on a rainy, foggy day right when the shops & restaurants open. You can get your breakfast, walk the dog and get home to take a nap before you pass 50 people. 

My favorite odd part is hearing the sea lions 3 blocks away from the pier at 3 am. That is pretty cool. With all the chatter during the day, you can't decifer if it's them making the noise or some 10 year old kid that's running around imitating them. But in the middle of the night, you can really hear them yelp. I wonder what they would have to say about all the anorexic, gangly freaks on land. 

Another favorite of mine is to venture out  on the pier JUST for the chocolate flavored waffle cone ice cream, while people watching or staring off into the scenic bay.
  
And the winner of my favorite thing to do is.....ding ding ding.... walking around trying to pin-point the different accents of the tourists. 
Today's flavor of the day was: French.
author: Barbara D.

description: Loved watching the sea lions rest on the pier.  The rest of the pier was souvenir shops and restaurants... nothing particularly special.
author: Lori P.

description: My husband and I are on our honeymoon from Australia. We took a tour on a ferry then walked across to pier 39 because of all the flags and so glad we did! The vibe on the pier is fun, we had a great time looking through touristy shops, eating clam chowder followed by some Ben and Jerrys and watching the sea lions on the decks. Lots of fun for an hour or two, especially if you're in the market for touristy knick knacks and gifts.
author: Erin P.

description: Pier 39 is great.  Went there on our vacation 2 weeks ago and had a great time.  Be prepared to spend $45 just to park your car...that was a shock!  The shops are great and my kids loved the 7D Experience as well as the aquarium and two story carousel.
author: Jessi S.

description:
Lots of things to do here. Food is great !! Great for tourist !! My favorite local attaction here is the " Bush Man " & " The One Man Band " that does their acts along the sidewalk. You'll know what i'm talking about once you walk pass them lol usually there's a huge crowd around them. It's a long strip so you'll see alot of interesting things along the side and tons and tons of resturants that you can just walk-in and grab lunch or dinner.

p.s. parking sucks. lol
author: Trina M.

description:
Im going to rate this place 5 stars, simply because i am a bay area native, born and raised.  Without doubt, if i want to spend a day in SF, Pier 39 is always on my agenda.  Yes it is a bit messy, but just walking along side all the mini shops and tourists is the best part... Places like these (SF landmarks) makes me a proud local of SF. I would not live anywhere else!! 

i will always come back to this spot.
author: Becky U.

description:
A tourist trap to end all tourist traps, but it has three things I love: churros, corn dogs, and sea lions.  I could live on churros and corn dogs.  I'd live for about a week, but what a glorious week that would be.  

There is a whole lot of stupid crap here that can keep kids entertained for hours, so I can understand why families of tourists like the area so much.  There are also some great views of Alcatraz and the Bay.  There are worse places to spend an afternoon.  

And hey, churros, corn dogs, and sea lions.  America.
author: John H.

description:
Tourist trap... but always cool to people watch out of towners.. 

The bushman was scaring people-- to the bf's amusement.. I just watched the boats and the sunset.... 

got some clam chowder.... called it a night
author: Vicky T.

description:
Seeing as I was being the quintessential San Francisco tourist while there I did stop and roam around Pier 39 while, a short while that is.  I wanted to see the sea lions and let me tell you I smelled long before I saw them.  Those things stink so bad I dry heaved in my mouth which made GBF#1 laugh at me stupid stinky sea lions.  OK they aren't stupid I still liked them just not their stench.

The place is a total tourist trap with gift shops galore; something for everyone even old great Aunt Betty in Podunk, IA.  I didn't buy anything but I did check out some of the shops, and even took a picture of GBF#1 posing outside Fairyland, so cute.  I will admit I found it kind of funny that they even had a Bare Escentuals store right at Pier 39 in case you're looking for some cosmetics.

The street performers were kind of cool but the bush man scared the living day lights out of me, he's lucky my bladder was empty or else there might have been a mess to clean up.  If you visit San Francisco you have to check out Pier 39 just watch out for scary bush man, the key to finding him is to look for a group of people across the street laughing and watching a bush, hopefully you'll find him before its too late.
author: Me H.

description: Ya know what I love about Pier 39? It's one of those rare outdoor places you can visit whether it's raining or sunny out.  There's a ton of touristy things to see and stores to stop by at.  For the rest of things about Pier 39 - well, everything said by other Yelpers pretty much fits the bill.  I realized that everytime relatives visit, each one has wanted to go to Pier 39 and I've not once dreaded going.  Parking is a bit troublesome and expensive though.  Some restaurants except iHop (only one I know for sure) charge a premium.   Not because the food is that awesome but because of locality.
author: Hanna Y.

description: Lots of stuff to do, just not my scene.  It's all about making the sale over quality of products and experience.  That being said the magic shows, the maze, and sea lion watching are pretty awesome.
author: Jason H.

description: Pier 39 is the perfect place for sight-seeing, first dates, and/or a good kick-it spot with friends and family. Theres a lot of places to go and a lot of things to see, so I highly suggest wearing a good pair of comfortable shoes and bringing a jacket since the Bay area tends to get pretty cold at night. Since this is a prime tourist area, be prepared for large crowds, long lines, live music & entertainment, and over-priced stores & restaurants. Despite all of that, you and your company should be able to enjoy your visit here.
author: Paulamertha A.

description: Reminds me of a hot mess place back home we call Bayside. Very touristy, loud, crowded. Perfect place for the locals to bring tourists to eat the famous clam chowder, look @ the seals, etc. I didn't care much for it since it reminds me of Bayside and to a Miamian, Bayside straight up sucks. Lots of street performers, bums, and homeless kids outside asking for $ for "blow and hookers." Classy.
author: Faby P.

description: i raise my right hand and swear everytime im in san fran i will visit the pier. theres just so much to do here...how do i do it all? i love the street performers and the shit tons of stores here. and the farmers market with the giant strawberries...def a great place for tourist and locals.
author: Somchai I.

description:
Pier 39 is always a fun place to visit and spend time with family. I have grown up in NorCal so I have been here a ton of times. I see tons of comments that say "too many tourists". That's What you get when you live in NorCal or SF, deal with it!

There are tons of places to eat, especially my favorite: Bubba Gumps! There's a huge Ferris Wheel in the middle that's $3 per ride, or $5 for two riders. The only draw back is in order for parents to ride with their kids, you must pay also... No free rides!

The sea lions are always a fun attraction (when they're present). Many don't know that they all left without reason almost a year ago an still have yet to return. I went today and saw about 5. Definitely not the usual 100+ I've been used to seeing all my life.

Also be prepared to get ripped off for parking! This is SF so I'm used to it, but the Pier 39 garage gives you 1 hour free only if you eat at a sit down restaurant. Then $8 per hour, with a $36 daily max, so tourist plan ahead!

Pier 39 is always a fun family friendly place! Enjoy your time here.
author: Blake C.

description: This is a great place to visit for a day trip or vacation. The sea lions are a popular attraction here and a unique scene you won't find anywhere else. There are restaurants and eateries of almost any kind you seek and overall the food is good and more reasonable than anywhere else in San Francisco. I especially love the clam chowder in the sour dough bowls that you can get at many locations there, but there are shops for chocolate lovers, ice creams buffs, and other snack offerings that will whet the appetite of most anyone plus full scale restaurants with varied menus to suit your most varied taste. There are tours available all around, street performers which are very good, and novelty and gift shops of all kinds. It's a great place for a family to enjoy, you and your significant other, or even alone, but I'd suggest you have someone with you. A must see if you are anywhere near it while in San Francisco.
author: Bella B.

description:
San Fransisco. So this is the place where an unimaginable amount of people left their hearts? ... I TOTALLY see why! I loved being in SF and had an epic worthy amount of fun here! Pier 39 seemed endless and honestly, I don't know if we visited other piers or only this one seeing as we walked up and down the whole thing (I think!.)

Fantastic little seafood "stands" to try although we are at a restaurant, Scoma's, that was recommended to us. There was so much to see, so many little shops to try.  I love salt water taffy and so you know how people refer to the whole "kid in a candy store" thing? Well, that was totally true here. I had gotten excited as if I'd never seen or tasted taffy in my life! 

There was also a dog store that I loved, because my doggie has my heart!  

Next time I go, I'd like to see more of Alcatraz. I'd like to visit, not just ride the boat passing it.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
BFFs were in town for our "special-year" event & having never been to SF, of course they wanted to hit all the touristy highlights & this included Fisherman's Wharf & Pier 39.........

Just the mention & I completely cringe so when they asked, I was like hmmmmmmm, welllllllll, okay; if you *really* want tooooooooo

People all over, bumping into us, cutting us off, hard to walk around - absolute hell

Lots of cheesy SF jackets, t-shirts, cable car memorabilia & ** like, Uh Meh Gawd **  Soup in Bread Bowls are among the many kitsch temptations that await unsuspecting tourists.....they loved it  ( & secretly, so did I )

We got to see the Bush Man in all his glory & scaring the beegeebees out of this lady ( always funny ); saw the Seals; rode the Cable Car

It was all totally worth it & we had a great time & a true SF tourist experience
author: Adrienne G.

description:
If nothing else - go be a tourist for a day (or 3) and hear the sea lions barking.  It's a great sight to see.  Lots of gift shops and kitschy-swag to procure - but that's not what it's all about, man.  It's about the vibe.  The people watching.  The sea lions.  The view of Alcatraz.  The sunset (or sunrise - or both.)

I miss my City by the Bay.

Whoooooooa -oh-oh-oh.
author: Karen F.

description: Pier 39 should be on your top 5 list of things to do in San Francisco. There's tons of things to do there like shopping, eating, go to Alcatraz, go to the movies, watching street performers, riding your bike, running, grabbing coffee, go to the aquarium!! There's a bunch of stuff here on this wharf! It's a fun place to go and the weather is always great. but don't forget a jacket, if you'll be there at night (:
author: Ry D.

description: It's a cute touristy place. Lots of gift shops and restaurants to choose from. My favorite part was looking through the gift shops. I got a couple gifts. I really liked the shell store. I didn't get to see any seals laying out though. We ran out of time so we had to head out. Maybe next time?
author: Nari L.

description: Fascinating place to walk n relax n it's very alive with million things to do n see... Great restaurants to choose from!.. Dreamy scenes but will be with a judgement day quality of crowdedness !! Hhhhh... Looking for an active a hell of an afternoon after being in all the important san fran places ... Go for this baby
author: Yasir K.

description:
I always enjoy visiting Pier 39 even for someone who avoids crowded places whenever possible.  I guess the crowds don't agitate me as much since there's so many things that take my mind off of it.  I don't spend money on buying souvenirs and other useless trinkets, but I do spend it on the aquarium!  I'm willing to support anything that increases shark/marine life tourism and awareness in hopes that it will decrease the demand on shark products (esp. shark fin soup).

Other than that, it's a great place to take photos of sea lions or with Alcatraz in the background.  It's a must-see if you're visiting!
author: Jina R.

description:
T O U R I S T Y

But quaint.  And a must for anyone who has never set foot on this magical pier numbered 3 9 in the magical city of SF.

Lot's of touristy shops selling 6 t-shirts for $10 and other knick-knacks known for attracting dust and later presence in a cardboard box stored in the dungeons of a basement or the attic of close relatives.  Food shops jostling for capitalistic intentions by charging an arm and a leg for a bowl of clam chowder just to be eaten near a window with a view.....Or a viewing of our fun loving seals camped out on the pier entertaining the masses with their antics and loud verbal responses.

However, I do enjoy paying exorbitant prices for some of the precious fruit out at the produce vendor there........excellent grapes and cherries.  In addition, I am sucker for anything chocolate and fried, so you will find me poking around in the chocolate shop for treasures for my friends in Sac and on once occasion, fell victim the smell of fresh donut holes being fished out of the fryer, so bought some.

When my friends roll through town, they always request that I take them here, so I acquiesce.  Hey, when in Rome....

I confess, however, that one of my girlfriends did drag me out here for Fleet Week in order to catch a glimpse of some of our boys in blue.  Sigh, what we do for men in uniform.

Although I rarely go here, I'd have to list it as a must for anyone passing through the city.  A definite.
author: Miika M.

description:
If there is one thing in San Francisco that screams tourist, it is Pier 39 and Fisherman's Wharf. Yet, it has to be one of my favorite things to do in this fishy city. Fisherman's Wharf is perfect for the seafood lover, with fresh seafood in the numerous street vender's carts that surround you. Crab is the specialty, but there is also an abundance of fresh clam chowder (in the infamous sourdough bread bowl). If you don't eat seafood, make sure to at least stop at Boudin's for some sourdough bread. 

There is also an abundance of street performers around this area, who are lively and entertaining for the entire family to watch. Going down to Pier 39, you can catch the Sea Lions barking away. Stinky but I still enjoy watching them lay around.
author: Carol Y.

description:
Everything has been said already, but I love beating a dead horse.

If you can stand the hordes of tourists and the over-commercialized aesthetic, make your way to the sea lions and stand there for a while.  Maybe even get something to eat while you enjoy watching their antics against the backdrop of some great bay views.  

So yes, it is worth it just for the sea lions.  Anybody who cannot find pleasure in watching those little devils has no soul.
author: David R.

description: Yes its San Francisco and parking is ridiculously hard to find and expensive.   A quarter will get u 2 mins at the meters.
author: B W.

description:
My first visit...The sea lions, though very smelly, and dryers ice cream (awesome) seemed to be the only reasons to go. It seemed like a tourist trap with cheesy souvenir shops and over priced tourist trap restaurants (based on our trip to the crab house). There were a billion tourist families walking through the place.

My second visit a few days later... We went back so the kids could ride the carousel and they had fun. There was a magic show going on that looked entertaining. My 5 & 8 yr old kids loved the bunji/trampoline ride. It was totally worth the $10 ticket given the amount of fun they had and the amount of time they were given on it. The guy working it was great with the kids. I really wanted some of the fair-like mini donuts on the way out. Overall, this place is worth a visit, especially for families with kids under 12.
author: Curtis H.

description:
It seems Pier 39 has seen better days. I rember from previous visits to San Francisco that this place seemed to be more bustling and upbeat, but this past weekend it seemed pretty lonely. Don't know if it was the weather or if the area around Boudin (up the street) has been pulling the crowds away.

At Pier 39 you will find the Hard Rock Cafe along with several restaurants and shops, a ferris wheel and of course the world famous Pier 39 seals which are located toward the end of the pier. 


Overall a good place to visit. It felt like I was at the Santa Monica Pier with its wooded decks, shops and ferris wheel. 

PS: There is a Boudin location here as well which is less crowded than the location up the street if your looking to get away from the crowds.
author: Saul A.

description:
One hundred person lines waiting for overpriced, crummy clam chowder.  Tourists in shorts and tank tops shivering as they try to remember who told them California was warm.  Sea lions barking a dirge for the death of hard earned dollars in souvenir shops.  

Skip the main pier and head to the Musee Mecanique.  Dump quarters into vintage arcade games for a hour, and you'll still come out for less than you would if you bought that special collectors edition set of Guinness pint glasses at the Pier 39 Irish Emporium.  (Am in the only one confused as to why Pier 39 needs an Irish store?)  Get an ice cream cone (to cool off in the hot 60 degree weather, and watch the sea lions put on a show.

Until we meet at the arcade...
author: Roland F.

description:
Fun place to hang out, but there are WAY too many people and inconsiderate tourists during the day. I'd recommend going here after sunset when there's not as many people. 

If you go here during the day on a weekend, be prepared to get very angry. It becomes extremely crowded with tourists and annoying kids who refuse to move out of the way making it impossible to get where you wanna go unless you physically remove them from your path.
author: Brian E.

description:
I love visiting here! Totally tourist spot...But I still love it.
 We make a trip here every year if possible. Everyone has pretty much explained everything there needs to be said about this place in the previous reviews sooooo.....I will just reflect on what I loved about this place. The odds shops, the aquarium, sea lions, food everywhere, sports store, poster store, the carousel...the list could go on, but I will stop there. Just go and enjoy yourself!
author: Trisha H.

description: Pier 39, a decent place, but nothing special at all. I accidentally wandered over here, while looking for Pier 33 for the main event Alcatraz Tour. It was very crowded and some of the people that worked there was not very friendly at all when asking for help. Overall a decent place, but I wouldn't come here if I didn't have too.
author: Simon W.

description:
Aahhhh the infamous tourist trap Pier 39. I really like this spot for their Bubba Gump restaurant, Crepes, and puppet store for my son. Not to mention the stinky seals that bark like ducks. There are plenty of stores here and maybe they are overpriced but they do provide plenty of window shopping for houuurrrssss. 

Just beware of the hawaiian pearl ladies. They will try to hustle you. A friend of mine was smart and went to their site online before heading to the store in person. Some lady there tried to sell her a necklace chain for a couple thousand even though my friend had already asked for the $79 one. And then an hour later, she finally revealed the cheap one. 

Oh well. Lucky for me, I don't wear pearls.
author: Julie A.

description:
The last visit to Pier 39 was over 15 years ago. I should know by now that nostalgia does wonders on memories. 

I enjoyed strolling around the Pier on a beautiful sunny winter day and being able to look at all the trinket shops and eat a semi-decent meal. 

It didn't seem to have the appeal or bustle though that I remember it from years ago. 

So many places trying to get you to come in and eat and pitching their "chowder" was the best. We ended up browsing for a few hours in all the shops and getting a souvenir or two for our nephews but wasn't as fun as I remember it.
author: Julia W.

description: This is where I celebrated my anniversary with my boyfriend. There are so many restaurants in the area so its really worth going. We also rode the boat and we enjoyed it.
author: Serena M.

description:
Sure, Pier 39 isn't perfect and it lacks culture and substance, but what do you expect from a tourist destination? You want art and culture, get yourself a tour guide and head to Chinatown, North Beach, Mission, etc.  However, if you're showing friends or family around San Francisco, Pier 39 is one of your best bets.

The Pier has all kinds of activities, restaurants, shops, and attractions.  Some of the more popular attractions being the Sea Lions, which recently returned and the Aquarium.  Additionally, the Pier has several eateries and specialty shops ranging from Hollywood memorabilia to a chocolatier.

My most recent discovery was the Blue and Gold fleet which does boat rides around the San Francisco Bay, under the Golden Gate Bridge and around Alcatraz Island.  The boat ride gives unparalleled views of the Bay Area and for $23 is a bargain.  Pier 39 can be considered a tourist trap, but it's the second most visited attraction in California for a reason!
author: Alexander E.

description:
Mini-Disneyland feeling.  Video games, fatty foods, mimes, jugglers, some silver person and sometimes a gold person.  

I love the guy who does the paintings of the universe with spraypaint.  As a graffiti writer that's my favorite part of the whole place.

You got yer seals, you got yer Alcatraz ferry boats, you got yer tourists all over the place in groves.  Cool place.  Watch out for losers creepin' on a comeup.  lol

Blow your money on some crap!  Woohoo.  Cookies, random posters, figureines, San Francisco shirts and magnets.  Yes!
author: Cynthia B.

description: They have done a nice job updating the pier. Its a lot nicer than several years ago. This is a tourist spot. Only went cause it way in our walking path. Too many people to maneuver!! Great to stop and see the seals though!!!! Great to visit once and never go back again. Too expensive.....
author: Michael C.

description:
I love-hate this area.

I love the area for all of the seafood, the cheap deals on certain stuff, the bushman, etc.

I hate the traffic, the lack of parking, and the strange tourists.  No, I'm not rude to people, but I do get annoyed...

It's always worth a trip for a first-time visitor, but you've been warned...some of these places in this area are truly a rip-off.  Good luck.
author: Fannie S.

description:
It had been a long time since I last visited Pier 39 and it was a lot of fun sightseeing and spending like a tourist on a beautiful autumn day in San Francisco.  It was great and exciting to stroll through the different shops, restaurants, and the many attractions in this area as well as hearing the multitude of foreign languages being spoken.

Visiting Pier 39 after a long time is like rediscovering why tourists come to the San Francisco - for the spectacular views of the Golden Gate and Bay Bridges, Alcatraz Island, Treasure Island, the Bay, and the San Francisco skyline! 

Yes, Pier 39 is a great place for a staycation or just for playing tourist for a few hours.
author: Lupe M.

description:
yeah its such a fun place here, random shops, random people, good, food, quick food, knick knacks, sea lions barking, people barking lol
Great place to people watch
author: Mary Jane P.

description:
How is it possible that this unbelievable destination has gotten trashed by so many of it's own people? You San Franer's sure are a tough crowd. Maybe when you live in a place where you wake up to views like this you begin take a single view that includes ocean, mountains, sea lions, and amazing architecture, all in one for granted. 

I say it's a tourist trap for a reason. 

Breathtaking. 

PS; I agree that if you cant love a sea lion you have no heart!
author: Christina B.

description: Definitely a place where you should bring your family and friends who are not familiar with the area. the place can get quite boring if you come often because the stores are mostly the same unless you are there fore the foods. A lot of the stores sell souvenirs items ! There are a variety of food joints surrounding the area and live performances. Be aware that parking can cost a lot so make sure to validated your ticket if you are dining in! Beautiful view and attractions nearby such as tour bus, cruises, and even bike tour. You will have a blast if you are from out of town!
author: Diane N.

description:
A cheesy tourist trap.  Good for seeing a) sea lions and b) Alcatraz but other than that it's just kitschy shops that aren't worth going into.

There is so much to see in SF!  I would definitely make a point to stop here, but I wouldn't waste more than 45 minutes.
author: Shaina S.

description: I'm really confused why this only has a 3 and 1/2 star rating average. Pier 39 is the ultimate tourist spot. I love coming here. It has amazing restaurants, shops & attractions.
author: Emma S.

description: Pier 39 was perfect to burn some free time before an Alcatraz tour.  In that time I got to see some great tourist kitsch like the shell, everything Irish  and Alcatraz stores.  In addition to these shops, we were able to do lunch in an empty Chowders restaurant and read about Pier 39's history upstairs.
author: Darren S.

description:
When I come here, at first glance a lot of  people, the most touristy place in San Francisco. After that there are plenty of shops and Great smelling & tasty restaurants; Bubba Gump Shrimp.
    Pier 39 is sea food heaven. I believe all great place have vendors. Indeed, this place is filled. 
      Bring your camera, plenty of photo spots,  shopping, 3D fun, and also a bunch of smelly sea lions for your viewing pleasures.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Pier 39 gets 2 stars. 1 star for the unbeatable view out into the bay. One more for the sea lions. Other than that, there is no other reason to go here.

Really, don't go here, THE PIER IS A LIE.

Okay, maybe not, but this place is packed to the brim with terrible stores and restaurants that appeals to the kitschy side that tourists love so much. This also makes it expensive as fffffuuuuuu.

Personally, the only great time I've had here was during NYE where they shoot fireworks right off the pier, and everyone stops dead in the middle of the road anticipating the new year.

Other than that, there are much better places to see and do in SF that makes you wonder why people go here in the first place.
author: Kevin P.

description:
Ok I usually stay away from the tourist traps like Fisherman's Wharf & Pier 39 but I gotta hand it to Pier 39 for sponsoring family friendly events!  We went to Pumpkin Pandemonium where each little kiddie gets to pick out a pumpkin from their make shift patch.

The stores in Pier 39 also participated in Trick or Treat.  So you don't have to worry about where your kid's candy is coming from.

Gotta love the carousel.  You don't see too many of those anymore!

Views are wonderful.  From the 4th floor of the Pier 39 garage, you get an unobstructed view of Alcatraz.  BTW, if you are a AAA member, you can grab a family fun pack which contains a coupon for free 2-hour parking!

What sucks?  The parking structure of Pier 39.  You spend forever trying to move your way up so you can get a space.  People ahead of us, stop being lazy.  You are not gonna find a space on level 1 or 2 in the middle of the day.  Move your fat ass cars up.  You are wasting our time!
author: Wendy H.

description: hi its a great Place to be dawdle away an afternoon or evenin´g so much to do Everything restaurants food Music Entertainment lots of people safe....love this johnnyb.
author: John B.

description:
My Ratings: 
Quantity: 4 - Lots to do and see
Quality: 4 - Fun place
Price: 3 - Tourist trap prices
Location: 4 - Interesting
Parking: 1 - expensive at parking lots
Service: 3 - ok
Speed: 3 - ok

Overall: Fun place to hang out on a really good day. If you're a tourist or bring a tourist with you, take them here.

My Opinion/Story: 
Pier 39 is a nice place to show the lifestyle of SanFranciscans.  There are lots of entertainment plus more of what you don't expect.  Just be aware of your surroundings and prices of the items.  Parking is expensive but if you know where to go, be prepared to walk alot.
author: Cherryl D.

description:
How can you give less than 4 stars to a place that has live shows 24-7. As in the Sea Lions arf arf arf-ing all the time. I know their numbers are down, but I fully expect a comeback. There are also magicians, musicial acts, and puppet theaters on the Pier when the weather is cooperative. Those are not 24-7, but during the day time, especially on weekends. There also is the famous Forest Gump restaurant (I know, a chain restaurant) that serves up some good fried seafood. 

All of the shops are tourist minded, and have great mementos to take back home. And plenty of sweatshirts for those unexpected cold days of summer.
author: Betsy W.

description: Tourist trap it is. There's really not much to see here yet everyone seems to flock here. There's a few nice views but not much. You're really just looking at a dirty dock with people's boats. I guess if you're lucky you might see some wildlife which would be cool. The restaurants here aren't really that impressive. You're better off grabbing food at the Ferry Building (Pier 1) or the many other restaurants in the surrounding area. Even the aquarium was under par. I checked it out anyways since I made the trek all the way to Pier 39, but we didn't spend very much time there.
author: Jackie T.

description:
For the attraction that it is, Pier 39 is great. Even though it has the scent of a pretty big tourist trap, my guy and I did have fun strolling the pier and window shopping in the stores. 

There are all sorts of stores for any variety of tastes. We strolled through the wine shop and through the Ghiradelli outpost. We stopped for coffee (don't recall the name) and it was just what I needed. 

It can get a little cool at night, so take a jacket if you get cold easily; we were there in January. It had been a beautiful day but cooled off quickly as night fell. You can lose yourself in the crowds if you need to get out of the house for a bit.
author: Daisy D.

description: This is SF's version of Cannery Row (Monterey)... speciality tourist shops, great food, a produce outlet, when you come here be sure to take public transit, I got socked with $32.00 parking bill for 3 hours for a super tiny space on the 2nd floor. The concessioners are great, it was great weather to get out in the bay... from Salt water taffy, to fish fries, sourdour chowder bowls and touristy type souveniers, it's all here with great scenic views of the bay.  We come here with family from time to time.... again watch out for the OVERPRICED parking, suggestion if u have to park, park at another garage that is cheaper and take MUNI in
author: Wil G.

description:
I absolutely hate pier 39. The smell of whatever sweets are there makes me nauseous. The amount of people and children running around makes me nauseous. The prices of everything makes me nauseous. 

The last time I went there against my will, my friend went to park in the parking lot across the street. The sign said it was $10. 

So, he reluctantly puts a $20 bill into the machine because none of us really want to be there. Then we look at another sign next to the machine: "Machine does not give change." 

WHAT? He just put $20 to park at a horrible, hellish tourist trap of a place, that will only further drain money if we choose to eat a bunch of donut holes and submit to the $3.50 for bottled water. HATE IT.

Why do people go here? All there is is a bunch of chain stores and chain restaurants selling you crap you don't need. You can go anywhere in the city and you go there? Argh. 

I don't know man. I just hate it.  

Although I will give it one star because I did have a good time here, once. We went to that horrible Mexican restaurant, La Salsa. We ordered beer and margaritas, and sat out on the balcony where there was a fantastic view of the bay. The best part: The restaurant was practically empty. The service there was horrible though. 

Everything about Pier 39 is horrible, except for the view.
author: Kat M.

description: Miserable tourist trap. largely abominable and entirely overpriced food - sally's/salty's fishwich being a rare exception. one star for the sea lions, who stink but are fun to watch. and one star for musee mechanique, which is by far the coolest thing there.
author: Erica W.

description: No need to explain what Pier 39 is about as even the tourists know exactly what is offered there.  This place offers nice pictures of SF in guide books and helps bring tourist money into the city - therefore we should all treasure it.  We all know that best seafood has to be served next to the water...right?  Why?  Because chefs catch them from the balcony during the day and serves them at night.
author: トモ T.

description:
It's a tourist trap, sure. But it's one of those tourist traps that can also serve even the most local of locals well, if you're looking for what they've got! Here are FIVE THINGS YOU SHOULD KNOW before visiting Pier 39: 

1) Maybe I'm jaded. Maybe I'm just cheap. Whatever... $7 per hour is WAY too much to charge for parking. Shame on you, Pier 39. That's just greedy. 

2) Sea lions? They smell. No... really. They SMELL.

3) Come hungry and get yourself some clam chowdah in a Boudin Sourdough bread bowl. Don't even consider passing this up. It's edible San Francisco. 

4) Don't miss Pery Kids, a very cool store with handmade Peruvian clothes for the little ones. Reasonable prices. Yes, I realize that handmade Peruvian clothes really don't have a lot to do with being a tourist in San Francisco... but don't let that steer you away. I saw one hand-knit sweater with a cable car on it that'd be WAY cooler than the same ol' cheesy "I Escaped from Alcatraz" stuff.

5) It's deceptively clean, but don't let that fool you. If given the chance, any seagull will be more than happy to poop on your head. Don't say I didn't warn you.
author: Kym G.

description: Soooo much things to do you can definatly spend a whole day here. From the animals to the live shows to all of the cool stores it is a must to come by and see the pier!!!
author: DJ F.

description: By far my favorite pier.  Great for families who need a quick stop especially for a meal or any souvenirs.  They have restaurants, crepe place, mini donuts, Aquarium of the Bay and Chocolate Heaven. The merry-go-round is all the way in the end. Past that you can get a view of the Alcatraz and the Golden Gate Bridge on a clear day.   They also have the piano stairs that the kids would love to experience. Check it out and it's at least a couple of hours to do your touristy thing.
author: Barbara H.

description: Very diverse place to be at. Enjoyable and a lot to see. Dress extra warm during the cold season though.....it gets really cold.
author: Julie Y.

description: So many thing to do and see but it very hard to find parking without paying up the ass. lol
author: Chris A.

description:
If I'm entertaining guests from out of town, this is most likely going to be a stop on their tour.  It's a good place to kill time before going to Alcatraz, and it's always fun to watch the sea lions.

That said, it's not somewhere you want to go more than a few times.  It's just too tourist-y, too expensive, and too...predictable.  If you've been to Navy Pier in Chicago or Fisherman's Wharf in Monterey (or any of many other tourist-y waterfront places around the country), you know what to expect here.  Overpriced restaurants.  Candy stores with lots of "ooh look at this" novelties and a halfway decent fudge counter.  A few hot dog stands.  T-shirt stores.  And so on...

On a warm spring weekday with few tourists around, Pier 39 can make for a lovely afternoon.  On a typical cold and crowded San Francisco summer weekend day, it's sheer misery. 

Pro tip: If you have to park and you have to eat, use the garage immediately across from Pier 39 and don't forget to get your parking validated at the restaurant.  Most of the "sit-down" places will credit you with 1 hour for lunch and 2 hours for dinner.
author: Stefanie H.

description: It is always fun to be outdoor, specially when the sun is out and not foggy. I love just walking and sight seeing. Nothing extra ordinary since I come here often these days. Love the chocolate factory, love the candy shop, love boudin bakery.
author: Fenny K.

description:
- Great shops. 
- Cute sea lions.
- Fun.
- Touristy. 
- Great place to hang out with family.
author: Jocelyn C.

description: Lot of fun and tons of dining choices, stuff to do from the Aquarium to just watching the sea lions to America's Cup this week!
author: R J.

description: Tourist Central! And despite living in the SF Bay Area for 29.6 years, I still love being a tourist. I like Pier 39, it embodies a lot of SF, from the endless amounts of crab and delicious, fresh seafood (Bubba Gump and the various clam chowders are my fav), to the hippyish souvenirs shops, Pier 39 is a great way to spend 3-4 hours for a tourist. You can walk to anywhere else along the Pier, so it's a good starting point as well. The seals often come out to bark and lie out all day as well. Great photo ops galore of Alcatraz, the ocean, tons of cool art and statues, etc.
author: Chuck N.

description:
Nearly two years after my initial review...I still agree with my original review, that Pier 39 is quite a tourist trap, but since it's been some time since I moved away from this part of town, I feel nostalgic when I re-visit Pier 39.

If you avoid the tourist attractions here and focus on the bay and the sea lions...well, Pier 39 isn't too bad. And hey, if you get bored at night, you can always go to the arcade in the back of the pier and play old-school ice-ball and air hockey.
author: Helene K.

description: Very touristy, and expensive! I enjoyed my time here, candy apples are a must!
author: Samantha S.

description: The place is kind of a kitschy arcade/mall with a myriad of small shops where you can get the usual San Francisco tourist-y-type stuff like shirts or license plates. For a mall like this, its food options were rather limited unless you were willing to depart from Pier 39 and search more of the Embarcadero or the better places on Fisherman's Wharf. Searching the Embarcadero means you need more money because the restaurants and cafes are much more pricey than I expected. But it's a nice place to take a leisurely walk (despite the tons of people that crowd the main street outside Pier 39) or bike.
author: Henry T.

description: Love the BAY expecially here in San Francisco pier. Good food & good people. Beautiful view of the golden gate bridge & bay bridge. Tours & entertainers on the streets of the 415. #yee
author: Johnny E.

description: Definitely a tourist trap, but what a fun one!  The kiddos love coming here to see the seals and shopping for souvenirs to take home.  We try to make this our last thing to do for the weekend when we come to the City just so we can get in and out quickly.  Not somewhere you get a real feel for SF.  Just a place to waste a couple of hours as a tourist and entertain yourself with some people watching and mindless entertainment.
author: Michele P.

description:
It is a tourist spot, but out of all the waterfronts on the west coast I enjoy this one the best. Lots of great food spots and bars, as well as family friendly and adult activities. Always an awesome view and on a nice day makes the experience more enjoyable.

This place is crowded and transportation to and from is a pain but take a walk down there and get some exercise. If you are from out of town then try SF's famous sourdough as a bread bowl of chowder or chili. It's legit and a must do.
author: Kate D.

description: f you are in the San Francisco area, you must visit Pier 39 / 45.  There are numerous activities, shops, and the beautiful view of the bay.  If you are so inclined, you can select from the numerous boat tours, including Alcatraz Island.  Its a great place to spend a sunny afternoon with family, friends, ect.
author: René B.

description: I loved it!  The Seals were so cute at the end of the pier, the cheap clam chowder in a bread bowl, and the hot fresh cheap shrimp with ciltano cole slaw, YUM.  The smells of doughnuts, waffle cones, men walking on glass, what's not to love about this place.
author: Monica A.

description: I would have to say that Fisherman's Wharf, more specifically Pier 39, has the largest concentration of tourists that I have even seen.  I wasn't too sure what to expect here but let me just start off by saying that if my time wasn't limited, I would have wanted to stay here longer.  There's something here for everyone.  They have a magic shop, sports souvenirs/memorabilia stores, lots of places for getting food, rides, gift shops, and more. One of the places that I went to was the Sea Lion Center which is located on the second floor towards the end of the pier.  It's like a little museum and information center about the sea lions that you can hear from just outside on the docks, and best of all, it's free!  Speaking of the sea lions, I was there in mid-July which we found out was when most of the sea lions that would typically be found on the docks were down south in the Santa Barbara area.  Luckily, we were greeted by a four sea lions who had shown back up and happened to lay on the docks closest to the pier (well, people probably feed them even though you're not supposed to...). Plus, there was one harbor seal, which isn't as common also sun bathing on the docks.  Besides checking out the sea lions and the little museum, we went to Trish's Mini Donuts and the Only in San Francisco gift shop. Just as a tip, it can get very windy on the pier, even though there are buildings on either side of you, and it is so crowded if you're with a group, wear bright clothing in case you get separated. Even though this place is extremely touristy, that's no excuse for you to not go here and experience for yourself, especially if you yourself are a tourist, which was my case.
author: Michael G.

description: As a tourist, I thoroughly enjoyed myself!  We wandered around, had some food, did a little shopping, and watched a most excellent street performer behind the carousel.  The sea lions are ridiculously adorable, and there's always something to see or do around.
author: Cat C.

description:
I like Pier 39. Yes, it's a super touristy, but it's a lot of fun and the views are incredible.

The stinky sea lions are always fun to watch. You can't help but smile when you watch them sleep, play or fight.

It's been years since I've bought anything on the pier besides food, but I think it's worth the walk through the swarms of people.

Basically, it's more fun than it's annoying.
author: Madeline R.

description:
Pier 39 was recommended to me by a fellow Yelper- Andrew L from Newport Beach (thank you SO much, by the way!) =]

There are many parking lots available within walking distance ($20 for the entire day, or $10 if you arrive before 10 AM. Or in our case, free if the guys in front of you pay for the ticket and forget to take the ticket after it prints).

It was the first place I dragged my brother to when we arrived in SF for the first time. Not very many shops were open yet (it was 9:30 AM), but everything was so cute and reminiscent of a carnival. I was so in love with the pink jewelry store!! My brother wouldn't stop groaning because it was so girly =P There is even a Houdini's magic shop (which didn't turn out to be all that exciting). 

The scenery is absolutely gorgeous- you can see the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, and the Bay Bridge.

Like my fellow Yelper wrote in his review, there is truly something here for everyone- chocolate/fudge stores, bakeries (they even have crepes!), hot dogs, seafood, clam chowder bowls, jewelry, fun souvenir stores... they even have a guy who does all sorts of tricks (he's wonderful entertainment, especially for the kids). Definitely couldn't have picked a better place to start out my first SF trip!
author: Angela H.

description:
You can see the Sea Lions which is neat but you can only look at them for so long before you are like 'okay... time to move on"

Lots of fun, cute and catchy shops but very touristy (and I was a tourist and thought that). Typical places "Hard Rock Cafe", "Wax Museum" "Arcades" etc... it's like you can do all the stuff in they closest big city back wherever you already live why travel all the way to SF to do it? Just not our thing. I heart SF shirts everywhere.... Yeah not our thing.

Glad we did it as everyone will ask us "did you go to FW?" and we can say yes.  We LOVED visting SF but if we ever visit again this probably won't be on our list of things to do.
author: Jenny D.

description:
LOVED coming here! Yeah Yeah its touristy, yeah yeah its busy. but its awesome! My son and husband went on the blue and gold fleet cruise, and I stayed on land with our 1 year old and took her to the shops. She got a little restless because there is such a large amount of shopes, but loved running around back and seeing birds and boats and water. It was a beautiful day and we found some great deals! I grabbed some souvenirs (cool stuff, not the annoying kind) and some other things. If you want  I heart S.F. stuff, your best bet will definitely be Chinatown for the price, but Pier 39 offers other goods at decent prices! I picked up a new purse for 15 bucks, some beverages from their *ahem* beverage store for pretty cheap. I also found some fun toys for my girl to play with to get her through the monotony of shopping with mom! I'd come back! I recommend off season if you have a chance, otherwise its busybusy!

Also there are more than a couple places to eat, so youre set for an afternoon!
author: Rachel L.

description: Pier 39 is a perfect place to walk at night. There is almost everything, restaurants, shops, restrooms. It just that all my friends and I were very cold, it is extremely cold and windy at night. Make sure you bring a jacket if you come to pier 39 in the evening!
author: Andrea B.

description: Sea Lions!   Lots of Sea Lions.  The kids sometimes get a bit bored on a weekend and who wants to go to the zoo and see animals behind cages when you can go to this place and see the Sea Lions in all their natural splendor.  They are a bit like old men fighting over that parking space in front of their house!   One Sea Lion will always have the prime piece of floating pier and another one will come up and try to claim his spot.  Oh, and the smell, well I can't say it is delightful but since when did anything natural every smell pretty?   When I get tired of watching the Sea Lions, I watch the tourists and there are plenty of them to gawk at. They are almost as entertaining as the Sea Lions.  After watching the Sea Lions and bumping into a few tourists, there is a stage where someone is performing some amusing act and a Merry-Go-Round for the little ones.  There is no shortage of food or pigeons to clean up after you either.  Take Bart to get here and you can save on parking and view a whole other slice of humanity while riding Bart!
author: Mike R.

description: Its a TRAP! A tourist trap. You have to come here in the right mind set and be willing to spend money and deal with tourists. I loved coming here back in the day, but now that it is my hard earned money I am spending, it isn't as exciting. The best part of Pier 39 and my only reason for coming is because of Chowder. Its a little off to the side, but they have the best bread bowls and I go there every time. The performers at the end of the pier are also really great, but you have to know the schedule of events to find great performers.
author: Michael M.

description:
Pier 39 is great at being what it's supposed to be: a gimmicky tourist trap. The shops are all hum-drum hokey run-of-the-mill crap purveyors that people love to frequent when they visit other cities not their own. There is very little that is actually 'San Francisco' on the pier, other than the fact that it is located in this city.

Please do not think you will get good sea food because you are on this pier. You will not. Your food will not be from the bay, more than likely, and you will be paying too much money for this under par cuisine.

The somewhat saving grace of this place is 1) the nice view it provides north to Alcatraz & Tiburon and 2) the omnipresent sea lions. Those guys are awesome, and always barking up a storm.
author: Wes T.

description: I love the energy at this pier!  I definitely recommend the Boudin's sourdough shop since the bakery down the road is always crowded!  I love going to Lefty's because it definitely entertains us left handers!
author: Josh D.

description:
This was a great first stop for me in San Fransisco.  There are a lot of really interesting stores to shop in.  I really enjoyed walking through them and getting a feel for the local flavor.  There's a great coffee stand on the pier.  


You also have to walk down and see the sea lions.  I have seen pictures, but this was my first experience with them in person (If you can stand everyone trying imitate them). 

Found some great souvenirs, but everything was pretty expensive.  Some of the stores has deals on shirts, like 3 for $15, but mostly inflated prices.
author: Ashley C.

description:
We have been here twice and I have had a great time both times. 

Parking isn't my favorite... either too far away for walking or close and really pricey. 

Overall I really enjoy the sights, the seals, and the food! Will definitely be coming back the next time we are visiting family!
author: Karma M.

description:
The environment of the restaurant is really nice. If you sit in a certain area in the restaurant you are able to view the pier and the water outside which makes for a really lovely environment to be in. The service is quick and friendly. I like the idea of placing specific signs on the table for them if you need service or not. This minimizes being bothered when you're eating and also lets them know when you need something. The trivia game the waiters and waitresses play with your are fun. 

The food is very good! I have eaten here on several occasions and every thing I have tried has been satisfying. 

I give this place 4 stars because the food is not nutritionally sound. They use a lot of butter so be ready to pack on a few pounds!

this review is for bubba gumps..
author: Amy T.

description: Pier 39 is packed with tourists and it's just a hassle to drive a car there.  People are walking without pay attention to the lights.  They will cross the intersection even though the walking light is RED.  So, it's almost impossible to move around near Pier 39 with the car.
author: Tony T.

description: They got a really beautiful place. Nice restaurants and hang out spots. A really pretty ocean view and wonderful cruise rides. There's also really nice people and great customer service. And their food taste good.
author: Mandeep S.

description: Not a big fan of crowded places because I'm afraid I'll be lost and bumped a lot, but overall I liked this place. The gift shops and restaurants are runner mostly by Asians(idk why). The gift shops are pretty expensive for a T-shirt, so I'd recommend going to Chinatown because they'll give you the same t-shirts for better price...I got 3 shirts for $11 in Chinatown. Anyways, I had calimari and chips from a stand that was actually part of a fine dining place, and that calimari n chips filled me up pretty good... I quite like it. I saw sea lions which was cool so I took lots of pictures. Bring a jacket because its still cold during the summer and the sun rarely comes out since its always cloudy. I'd recommend coming to this area although its crowded. Enjoy the experience of the atmosphere and all that good food(unless you consider it bad food)
author: Trac N.

description: Love the view from Alcatraz, but I hate the tourist traps around here. Made the mistake of coming for the 4th of July, worst decision ever! Took 3 hours to get out of the parking lot!
author: Tim L.

description:
Lots to see! Quintessential place to visit when in SF.

This is definitly a major tourist attraction. I like to take family and friends who visit us from out of town to this pier. There are a lot of shops that are basically "touristy" type shops. If you walk past the Pier, you'll find other shops along the strip and eating places as well that are better on your wallet. Parking is kinda ridiculous when exploring this part of SF. Be sure to be ready to pay some major cash flow at the different parking areas. 

I like taking my little ones to the aquarium and seeing the sea lions. 

If you walk down past the pier, there is a Penny Arcade Warehouse where you can play old time video games from the turn of the century for just pennies..Check this place out for sure.
author: Charissa G.

description: If you don't mind getting pooped on by the millions of seagulls, I guess it's ok.
author: Cryo L.

description: it's a major tourist space and parking prices are ridiculous.  no.
author: tiana w.

description: One of the most memorable places I visited in San Fran. Even in bad weather, nice little shopping center w/ restaurants. Great chowder in bread bowls from the small little chowder stands! Oh, and the best part, the sea lions!
author: Jocelyn F.

description:
It seems like a nice place to bring out of town guests.  Sea lions relaxing on the docks.  Quirky tourist gift shops.  Variety of food choices.  Very crowded.

I really wanted to try the mini cinnamon donuts I saw people carrying in buckets.  Maybe another time.

I would go back, but if I had a limited amount of places to see when I'm up in the area, it wouldn't necessarily make the top of my need to go back list.
author: Jennifer A.

description: nothing but gimmicky retail chains and eateries (Bubba Gump Shrimp Co. I SEE YOU). such a tourist trap and not even an awesome one with shit you want to buy. it gets super crowded and there isn't really anything to look at. it's just people walking around aimlessly thinking, erroneously, that they're getting the San Francisco experience.
author: Melissa N.

description:
I was genuinely surprised at how much I enjoyed Pier 39. It's probably the single biggest tourist trap in the city, but it has a lot going for it. The seals are truly entertaining, and it has some interesting shops and restaurants. Everything is way overpriced, but that should come as no surprise. There was a wide variety of street entertainment, and the people watching is top-notch. 

I wouldn't consider it a must see, but I'll likely be back for a visit the next time I'm in town.
author: Joseph B.

description:
There's many little boutiques and restaurants/eatery places here.  It's a cute place for couples, tourists, and families to take a stroll on the pier and enjoy the SF environment and culture.  you also get to see all the seals on the water.  

Bubba gump is a good place to eat here, there's a lot of variety here, but mainly fried food so not a place for a person who wants to diet or eat healthy.  the best thing to eat at the pier is clam chowder, the best clam chowder can be found here. I love the clam chowder here.  for those who likes sourdough, they have great clam chowder in sourdough bread bowls.  I'm not a big fan of sourdough.
author: Phuong Q.

description:
I've visit Pier 39 from time to time and it never gets old to me. We were out there for the 4th of July fireworks show and thought that I should write a review. 

This was my first time celebrating Independence Day at the Pier and I had a good experience. We may even come back next year. 

A few things you should know that I learned today. 

1.) Parking lots/garages cost a lot more than they usually do. The closer you are to the pier the more expensive. I always park in the same area and the lot I always go to is usually cheap (under $10 for a whole day). So we drove there today and they were charging $40. There were others for $18, $30 and $60. There is also metered parking around the Pier but its hard to actually find one that's open since people get out there early. You just have to be lucky. There is also metered parking on Embarcadero (along all the gift shops, restaurants....) BUT during the 4th of July they post up "NO PARKING", this is because they block off the street. 

2.) Not sure if they do this every year but they block off Embarcadero st. at a certain time. At the beginning of Pier 39 to about a block down from where the old Hooters used to be. 

3.) Boudin Bakery throws freshly baked bread into the crowds randomly throughout the day. While all the regular street vendors set-up their stuff in the middle of the street. There's a clown lady that has entertainment and animal balloons for the kids, spray paint art, guys that draw cartoon pictures of you, break dancers that think they're buff, acrobatic performers, old guy doing some cool magic tricks, guy playin' his saxophone, live scheduled performances by various artists in front of the Hard Rock, and of course the legendary Bush Man----(if you have no idea who this is, I don't want to spoil it for anyone so you'll just have to head out there and hopefully be one of the lucky people that get to surprisingly get the chance to met him.)

5.) Fireworks are lit from 2 different locations at each end of the Pier. So no matter where you are on the Pier or just on Embarcadero street where all the shops are, you will see the fireworks show. Obviously, if you want front row seats/spot...plan to come about 2 hours before the show to secure a spot closest to the water. This is the best seat in the house!

6.) The Pier's shops close a bit later (11pm) so you have the chance to shop around once the fireworks are done. Keep in mind the streets are flooded with cars and pedestrians so getting out of this particular area will take longer than usual. 

7.) I've read complaints here on how it smells and how there are bums around but really....That's not something worth writing about. Common sense...YOU'RE AT THE PIER, surrounded by a large body of water and there are many outdoor food stands that sell cooked seafood....does it really surprise you that it sometimes has an unpleasant smell? As far as the bums go, they don't bother anybody so why should it bother you? You are in San Francisco and the bum rate is pretty high. 

8.) Just had to mention that Ghiradelli Square is a few blocks up so that's worth checking out if you've never been. They serve ice-cream and a large assortment of their chocolates for all you chocolate lovers. 

Overall I had an good experience being here on the 4th of July. The key here is to plan ahead so good luck and just have fun out there and STAY WARM!

So last thing you need to know...if you're from SF you know but for those that aren't it's FREEZING out here at night because you're by the water so bring your winter coats. (I'm serious.) You can wear whatever you want during the day, bask in that sun and enjoy the breeze...but once it starts getting later and darker that breeze gets cooler and cooler and then it's just plain cold. 

My essentials: thick Northface jacket, gloves and scarf. For the kids: Thick coats, gloves, beanies AND if they are in the stroller, please please PLEASE bundle those babies up and add a blanket for extra warmth, if they're in a baby car seat cover up the top with a blanket. If you have toddlers that sit in a stroller, just bring an extra blanket so that they can keep warm. I've seen young babies out here at night with no socks on, shorts even and their faces look ICE cold and I pray that they won't get sick. My kids are in fleece lined jeans (found at Old Navy) and my older daughter still says she's cold. 

So keep the weather in mind and come prepared.
author: Just Meeh B.

description:
Pier 39 is a very fun spot to spend a weekend with the family, or take a date in San Francisco. Pier has a verity and very diverse group of people from all walks of life. 

The variety of shopping centers and restaurants will keep you busy for hours. Pier 39 is not very assessable through car, and will require you to walk a few blocks both down and up-hill through San Francisco. 
Also traffic flow in the area is very small and crowded with both cars and people. 

Overall, a great place with a large variety of activities.
author: Roger I.

description: Your fun time at Pier 39 will be dashed when you exit the Pier 39 parking lot.  At $9 per hour, that's right, $9 per hour for each hour (not capped at any figure other than $9 x 24), you'll feel like a stupid, easy mark.  Solution:  park anywhere else.
author: jim r.

description:
Pier 39 on a sunny day is my nightmare.  There is nothing "San Francisco" about it besides the view. It's a tourist trap full of tourists, fortunately I haven't had to be there for years but yesterday my luck had run out.

First let me explain that part of the reason I hate this place is because I get claustrophobic in large groups, so to some extent it is me and not the pier. Besides the big crowds though there's still plenty to not like about the place.

One extra star for having sea lions and one more for little donuts straight out of the oven.
author: Manny F.

description:
To my lovely friend Erica H. for whom is the only person I would dare venture into all of the tourist traps within this beautiful city I call home. 

Double Decker Busses 
*Smiles and shrugs

Chinatown 
*Grabs a big purse ready for knock off jewlery and some dim sum! 

Twin Peaks 
*Smiles wide, tells her to pack the camera & wear a dress....*evil snicker*

Lombard Street
 *Laughs while dropping her off at the bottom for photo ops and drives around a couple of streets only to see her frantically waiving her hands to pick her up

Alcatraz
*Laughs hysterically when wrapping legs around the bars of an isolation cell

Pier 39
*Dies of laughter while watching the youngling sea lions bicker and fight each other off of the docks.
*Hears a new joke about getting crabs and no I do not mean a really nasty thing that itches.
*Gets scared by some homeless man dressed up like a bush
*Watches Aussie performers tell two different groups that "they're the best group they've ever performed in front of and they don't accept credit cards" at different times
*Walks by the Lefty's Store and automatically thinks of Ned Flanders
*Learned how to use a 'Bump it' in a public restroom, thanks to the Snookie look-a-like

Well that was a lot of fun, and I've got my fix of tourism for an entire lifetime!
author: Morgan M.

description: Don't miss the seals floating on the docks!
author: Weston N.

description:
I am a native Californian who was born in San Francisco and grew up around the bay area.  I enjoy playing the tourist from time to time and visiting pier 39.
