The atmosphere around Pier 39 is just fun and electrifying.  You have people visiting from all over the world, shops and restaurants.  In addition to this, you have a great views of Alcatraz, Golden Gate Bridge, San Fancisco Bay, sea lions, and etc.

The only downside is that everything is very expensive, but that is the price that you have to pay if you want to go to a touristy area.  I would recommend this place to anyone who has a few hours to kill around the S.F. Bay Area.
author: Alan A.

description: Fun place to hang out BUT the BUMS have got to go . C'mon SF get these people outta here!
author: Hellbilly M.

description: I went back to Pier 39 and had a much better time. Perfect weather, and a great ride on the bay! They are back on my good side.....
author: A N.

description:
Yes, it's a HUGE tourist trap.  The Aquarium is OK, but not as fun and fascinating as when I was a kid.  Restaurants are decent, but as with many of the stuff in the stores there, it's overpriced.  Still, I take my family and friends who visit to Pier 39 so they can experience it once.  Fun to watch the sea lions barking away and sunbathing, though it can be smelly.  One of the places I tend to visit while there is the candy shop that has all sorts of varieties of candy to choose from.  And as with many SF restaurants, because they're known for their seafood they seem to think it's good enough reason to jack up the prices, and when you order things like a crab or seafood salad you get a small scoop of crabmeat (1-2 tablespoons) and mostly shrimp.  A good place to take a stroll up and down and around.  There's also one of those bouncy trampoline things there.  They strap you in a harness and you can bounce around and do flips and such.

Be sure and stop by the Visitor's Center on the top floor about halfway into the Pier.  If you're a AAA member you can get a free book of coupons good for the businesses at Pier 39.  Have your AAA card or number handy.
author: Wyman L.

description: This is a must hit destination if you are in San Francisco if for nothing else then the Sea Lions!
author: Kyle S.

description: You can get a nice view of the water here. You can also see Alcatraz in the distance, but my main highlight were the sea lions! They've completely took the liberty of making the pier their home. Awesome!
author: Ron B.

description: Never a dull moment on the pier. I always recommend my friends visiting if it is their first time to the city. Always seems to be a little too over crowded.
author: Mike P.

description:
Ack... tourism central... or should I say, tourist hell. If you have kids they'll probably like Fisherman's Wharf, and you might too if you're a crazy tourist. Don't get me wrong, you should come here when you visit to say you've visited, but it's not an experience I'd be big on repeating.

On pretty much any vaguely nice day, coming here involves tripping over tourists everywhere you walk, tripping over street performers trying to make money from tourists, and trying to avoid the gaudy overpriced shops with ridiculous knick-knacks. And, when I say tourists, the tourists who tend to come here aren't the cool kind. They're the ones who fit every stereotype in the book, have a screaming broad of kids they can't control, and don't realize what they've coming to see isn't really "San Francisco."

There are nice views, although you can head to the  beach and get those just as well. Also a lot of good seafood restaurants, but they tend to be more expensive than other comparable restaurants because they want to get money from the tourists.
author: Denise B.

description:
"Can you take a picture of me?" 
"No" 
"Can you take a picture with me?" 
"No" 
"Can I take a picture with your dogs?" 
"No" 
Welcome to Pier 39 the biggest tourist attraction of the bay. Where the locals keep the conversations to a one word minimum.
author: Alex H.

description:
I'm a tourist...

Walk down to the merri-go-round and turn left...

Arrr arrr arrr arrr arr arrr arr arr
author: Lizzie S.

description:
SUch a tourist trap. But I keep finding myself coming back... when I want to feel like a tourist. 

Especially during the holidays, this place can get suuuuuuper packed. I particularly like how they sometimes have street performers in the back deep in the pier. I feel like a kid watching those guys... however it's been a while so I don't know if they still perform by the merry go round. 

Occasionally you'll view the sea lions if they didn't migrate far. Parking in the lot across can be a pain and hassle getting out.. but check for validation.
author: Deanna G.

description: Pier 39 is a great place to just have fun.  If your a local, I promise you that you'll find some great deals here.  They offer 50% off for locals at most places.....Now if thats not a reason to go to the pier...nothing is.
author: Kenneth G.

description: I really like Pier 39. Yes it is another tourist trap, but it's just the area is really nice. If i was a local, I would love to come down here with a book and just read by the water. This place has great places to shop, eat and watch street performers, which reminds me a lot of South Street Seaport back in NYC. However, there is something that South Street doesn't have that Pier 39 has. Sea lions! I mean it's not an every day thing you get to see sea lions, well not in NYC. Although I did stay for a good 15 minutes observing them, they did get boring after awhile. All they do is bask them lazy selves in the sun and make sea lion noises. But overall pretty neat place to check out.
author: Sandy C.

description: So touristy! But fun. It kind of reminds me of a clean Jersey Shore boardwalk. There are plenty of places to get your souvenirs and lots to eat. Take time to see the sea lions. So freakn' cute! I could of watched them for hours.
author: Angela G.

description: Although this place is as touristy as it gets and everything you see has the authenticity of Disney World, I absolutely love it. Any excuse will do to take another walk on Pier 39. Get some grub, buy some stuff you don't need or watch the sea lions.
author: Yoni D.

description:
One of my yelp friends sent me these links, so that you can enjoy savings while dining at and visiting Pier 39.  Enjoy and thanks Bob aayyyy!.

http://www.pier39.com/funpack.html

http://www.pier39.com/UserFiles/File/P39Sampmenuguide08.pdf
author: DJ M.

description: Even though this place is very touristy. I enjoy coming here to just walk around and relax. They have very interesting shops and it is a very nice atmosphere at night near the bay.
author: Dr. Trent G.

description: Basically, if you've never been, you should go.  Then, you can check it off your bucket list and never go back.  For me, it was too crowded to really be enjoyable, but the sea lions are always a treat... if you can elbow another tourist out of your way to see them.  Be aggressive if you have to because no one is going to politely step aside for you.
author: Shannan W.

description: This was my wife's first time here. It is always fun to walk through and people watch and also Sea-lion watch. Coming here for the Sea-lions was the main reason I brought her here. There is a large variety of shopping here, but you pay a much higher price for many things you can find elsewhere. But I guess it is the tourist thing to do.
author: Steve A.

description: Pretty nice place to visit, but very expensive.
author: David X.

description: I have been to pier 39 for the last few years but yesterday I was told that I had to leave by two cops.  Because I was not wearing a shirt even thou I saw many men walking round shirtless but because I am a woman I am not allow to be.  This is not only sexist but unfair because in San Francisco it legal to be topless for women but it seem not down at pier 39.
author: Ambrosia N.

description:
Ludicrously touristy, but a fun place to walk around when waiting for a ferry to Angel Island or Alcatraz. Just beware of several perils.

Pickpocketers: Rumors abound, but no first hand experience.
High Prices: Yeah, its SF. But it can be even worse here.
Idiots: Seriously, it seems that your average tourist here doesn't know how to WALK. "Move forward... No... wait... hey.... which way are you going... no you go left... ok I'll go left... ok STOP!" Ugh.
author: Paul S.

description:
Ahh Pier 39 the biggest tourist trap in San Francisco. I live in San Francisco and I still love Pier 39 on a sunny day! They got lots of fun shops to shop at (if your into that stuff), they got that big carousel, turbo ride, museums, food, and more food, and of course the sea lions. They got lots of tours going on around their (Blue and Gold Fleet, Cable Car tours, ect)

Nice place to hang out with friends or even to watch the fun street performers. Fun place but pricey. Not a bad place at all!
author: Daniel S.

description: Great shops and great deals. Great place for tourist to check out. Very popular spot and very busy. Great places to eat and check out and a great view of the pacific ocean.
author: Lindsey B.

description:
I have gone here so many times and would go back again. I love being by the water, heading to watch chocolate being made, enjoy fine dining and shopping, wearing a cliche san fran hoody, and touring any of islands around....and sometimes watching the sunrise in a classic romantic fashion.

Typically this is where we take out of towners, but this is also a place to enjoy as a tourist or a local. The water has so many seals and offers up great views of san fran. People are either having a good time, locals are jogging and sea gulls always around.

There is a chocolate shop where you can watch chocolate being made, do some tasting and buy some to go. There is a magnitude of places to go eat here and an aqarium for the kids and adults alike.

The weather is always unpredictable and might get cold but not to worry there are shops with hoodys on sale for san fran tourists. I own a few myself hehe. There are also boat tours avaliable to alcatraz, tours of the bay area, angel island and you can drive to treasure island.

There is a lot to be done, and when finished one can drive down the longest most complicated street in the world or head to chinatown. Either way, pier 39...whats not to like?
author: Kamni G.

description:
Tourist Trap.

Bunch of chain restaurants, crowded, over priced. Stay away.
author: David N.

description: Overcrowded with tourist, over priced like most tourist traps. The foods not even that great.
author: Patricia S.

description:
Quality: 3
Value: 5
Service: -

I've been here twice over the last year. The first time was with my gf for July 4th, and the second time was for a company dinner at the Crab House (http://www.yelp.com/biz/crab-house-at-pier-39-san-francisco#hrid:dSqlZ5B6-SlDGw3h58K1TA).

For July 4th, we arrived around 3-4pm and ended up circling for over 15 minutes trying to find a parking spot, since garage parking was charging $30-40 (ridiculous!) Finally, we got really lucky and found one just outside of a parking garage just a block and a half away from Pier 39. It must have been a miracle, considering how many people there were.

We walked around and visited most of the shops in Pier 39. Nothing was particularly interesting, and we browsed some of the restaurant menus to decide on a place for dinner. We did, however, watch a magician's performance, which was quite amusing, and we gave him a few dollars since he claimed that it was his only source of income for the show. 

We ended up walking over to Ghirardelli square, and came back about an hour before fireworks started. The place was already getting really packed, but we got lucky and found some box-like benches on the left-side of the pier. Within an hour, the firework show had started, and they were absolutely gorgeous. The fireworks were set off extremely close to the pier, and we had a terrific view. Definitely the best July 4th I've had.

Afterwards, we walked back to our car, which was when the problems began. There were people all over, walking across the streets, the sidewalks, pretty much everywhere. To make matters worse, they had blocked off parts of our street, so it took us nearly 20 minutes just to drive a single block. From there, traffic got a little bit better, but it still took us nearly 40-50 minutes just to get out of the city and onto the freeway.
author: David L.

description: For nostalgia's sake, I can't give this place less than three stars, but my goodness a lot has changed. I can't help but not really like this place anymore...it feel a lot like the Universal City Walk and has gotten...too clean, too nice. At least Crab House is still there. Definitely too touristy.
author: Frances L.

description: This is what people mean when they say "tourist trap". I know I felt trapped! It was crowded and swarming with other out-of-towners like myself, trying to get a good view of SF bay, see some sea lions, and spend too much money on asinine things. Places like this just generally make me uncomfortable and cranky, and I didn't stick around for too long. It was nice to take in the view, I loved watching the sea lions, and there is a good concentration of shops to pick up souveniers as well as restaurants to eat at, and an aquarium you can visit. Those things make it great for people who are traveling with family in particular, but I would rather venture out into the city somewhere and experience something that wasn't hand-crafted for a tourist.
author: Winona R.

description:
So, I wrote a long fxing review about the Pier, then my internet decided to disconnect. ;_;
Here's the Readers Digest version...
TOURIST TRAAAAAAAAAP. It's hard to find locals here, and I always hope tourists don't imagine that this is what SF is really like.
I usually grimace when I come here, because it's so gimmicky, but then I enjoy myself.
The shops are crowded but cute. There's always interesting characters lurking around, asking for money in the most creative ways. (Watch out for the guy who volunteers to take your picture, future visitors.)
Just come here & see for yourself.
author: Jessica G.

description:
Wow, it's been a very long time since I've been here. My parents wanted to come here yesterday, so who am I to say no? The place was MOBBED - I think everyone wanted to be out in the sunshine after several weeks of rain. 

Weather was gorgeous, the smell of salt air and sea lion breath, gulls dive bombing small children and elderly people to get their crusts, the sounds of the carousel and crying babies, and above it all - the odor of hot grease - Pier 39 has it all. 

All as in crappy souvenir shops, funnel cake purveyors, lots and lots of sit-down restaurants (didn't remember all those), a music box store, an Irish store, a store for left-handers, waffle cones, beer, wine tasting - you name it. I had a hot dog from a place called Aunt Fanny's that was possibly the worst I've ever had, but it was served with a smile and some nice sauerkraut. 

The views are amazing and I never get tired of gazing out across the bay. And my parents bought some new San Francisco-logoed sweatshirts - just what they wanted!
author: .Hon H.

description:
Yeah, this is a tourist-friendly spot (AKA tourist trap), but you know even for a native San Franciscan like myself, it's OK to be a tourist in your own backyard. A Stay-cation. Looking at the different people walking, the lively activity, and even the souvenirs that they've come out with.  The sea lions are always a favorite.  Watch out for the diving (and bombing, if you know what I mean) seagulls.

Nice to look, but don't expect to see any bargains. As far as food is concerned, if you're expecting to find culinary nirvana, this place ain't it.  But food is OK, and good enough to fill the tummy.

It's a good launching point to visit the rest of the Wharf, Aquatic Park, Cannery, and Ghirardelli Square. Kids were focused on the candy shops and funnel cakes. Managed to convince them there's more places for candy and ice cream along the Wharf (yes, daddy knows best, daddy knows where's the "good" stuff). 

If you're a AAA member, go up to the California Welcome Center on the 2nd level, flash your card, and get a bunch of coupons to use at Pier 39. Among them, 2 hours free parking, 20% on select restaurants, and numerous other coupons.
author: Steve L.

description: Good place to spend the day! Many shops to shop in or peruse, and good places to eat (my favorite is Hard Rock Cafe). Pier 39 is great, the parking garage is a little ridiculously priced.
author: Melissa B.

description:
Typical tourist spot. Lots of overpriced food and souvenirs. 

Im from the bay so I come to the City almost every weekend. 

This is a nice hang out place if you want to be a tourist for a day. 

I get a kick out of the real tourists....taking pictures of everything..even the bathroom signs...I mean really? bathroom signs? 

Anyways...we put up with tourists....they are spending all their money here...so might as well even though they are ANNOYING AS HELL. ...I guess we are spoiled  since we have frisco in our backyard. 

Come here enjoy the sea lions and the views...if your not from around the bay..make sure you bring a sweater..since you will be very cold at night if your not used to the weather. 

Yes even in the summer it gets chilly. 

If you want good food stroll further west of the embarcadero and you will find good food and a hooters..oh yeah and the souvenirs are cheaper also..
author: Jessica M.

description: This place is just a tourist attraction. There are better and cheaper food but if you want to show a foreigner the busyness and "upbeatness" that is San Francisco, I guess you can go here.  Just go here once just to say that you did.  I don't have any reason to come back.
author: Cali N.

description:
No need for a lengthy essay on why this place is foul. I will simply list my grievances.

1. Too Crowded - If you enjoy walking shoulder to shoulder with an army of fanny pack yielding tourists who have no clue what they're doing or where they're going, this is the place for you. 

2. Horrible Shopping - If you are in the market for magnets in the shape of the Golden Gate Bridge, a trolley car, or for no logical reason, Elvis or Michael Jackson's silhouette, Pier 39 is your heaven. If you are looking for a store that sells useful and or high quality merchandise, you need not roll through. Besides junk souvenir/ magic shops, there is really nothing here.

3. Mediocre Restaurants - The food here is either extremely expensive because you're paying for a view or overpriced, greasy fair food. Steer clear if you're looking for quality at a decent price; or even just a place that includes a drink with you meal and doesn't charge extra for a packet of ketchup. 

4. The Smell, the smell, and ummm, THE SMELL!!! - So, seals used to hang out on floating pieces of anchored foam near the pier and tourists would watch them. Apparently they are no longer around for whatever reason but if they are, here's fair warning: If you have absolutely no sense of smell or enjoy the acute odor of a combination of rotting meat and dirty ass, you'll love this attraction. If not, don't go to Pier 39 because this smell permeates the entire place.

I've said my peace, now don't go here unless you are fulfilling a bet.
author: Sarah S.

description: This is a tourist destination but alas, I was a tourist and so I enjoyed it.  I bought a little sea lion stuffed animal to commemorate the hour we spent watching the sea lions hang out.  Boy did they stink.  Pier 39 is huge with lots to do and eat and watch.  If you are thinking of spending the day by the water then definitely check out this area...especially the sea lions.
author: Jess K.

description: Took my friend her and she loved it! I've been here before and I love going here everytime! Great stores and good places to eat and great views of the bay!!!
author: Scott G.

description:
Sea Lions, tourists, Alcatraz Island, North Beach, F line (tram), The Embarcadero, cable car terminal, Ghirardelli Square, Fisherman's Wharf, and Coit Tower. 

Oh! Let's not forget the awesome view of the world famous Golden Gate Bridge! 

All that is within a short ride bus or walking distance! 

I'm sure there's many more stuff to check out that's nearby, so Pier 39 is a good central location for man attractions in San Francisco! 

I think there's a hostel right there... 

Next time I'm staying within the Fisherman Wharf area!
author: Matt M.

description: Yes, it's a tourist trap, but it's an obligatory stop for tourists to see the sea lions basking in the sun (they're so popular they even have a webcam for them - http://www.pier39.com/webcam.cfm). They have a bunch of restaurants, knick-knack shops, the aquarium, carousel and free shows.  During the winter time, they used to haul in snow to go sledding and have festivals during the warmer months.  For locals, there are often discounts on the pier39 website and a fun pack that I always forget to pick up - http://www.pier39.com/funpack.html  They used to offer discounts on parking, so it might be worth the extra minute to get the coupon book if you're in the area.
author: Nicole D.

description: I love it here. I almost always come here whenever I come to San Francisco. I don't usually buy anything here because it can get expensive, but the food is pretty amazing. Fresh seafood is always the best. And the clam chowder in a sourdough bread bowl from pretty much anywhere here is to die for. Watching the fireworks on the 4th of July is amazing here. Sure the tourist crowds can get a bit out of hand at times, but you can't really expect anything less. There are lots of street performers here, live music, shops, and other tourist type entertainment. Definitely a must do in San Francisco.
author: Justin M.

description:
Tourist frenzy 24/7? .. Yes.

Lots of free fun & entertainment?... Yes.

Good food & speciality shopping??.... Yes!

SEALS?!?!?!... YES!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Pier 39 is a fun way to cut loose when you wanna have some innocent/care-free fun.
That's my story & I'm sticking to it.
author: Kai S.

description:
Tourist Trap -- hell yes.

But what a great place to take out of town guest and children. 

Ice cream, fish restaurants, over priced fresh fruit, bike rental, carousel, chocolate, fake sky diving, magic acts, and my personal favorite

THE SEA LIONS

They are worth pushing past the families in shorts and newly bought SF sweatshirts. Lean against the rail and just watch and watch and drift off into the world of the sea lions.
author: Shelly V.

description: come for the sea lions.. the rest of it is really touristy which you should skip.. if must stay around here.. at least grab some sourdough at boudin
author: Stan L.

description: The sea lions are great and the Gold & Blue Ferry around the Bay was nice, but the shops should be avoided if possible.  If you're a tourist, just don't go.  It's super-crowded and not really that much fun.
author: Fred M.

description:
What the sea lions at Pier 39 REALLY say:

Wharfwharfwharfwharf [Welcome to Pier 39 where you overpay for EVERYTHING! Suckas.]

Whhharf-warf-WARF-Wharf! [Oh yay, another fucking tourist family that, apparently, has never seen one of us before. Here's a hint -- LEAVE KANSAS MORE OFTEN!]

Wharf-wharf-WHARF! [Look at ME! Look at ME! Look at ME!]

whhhaaAARF! [Let my family go! Also, free Willy!]

WHARFwharfwharf-WHARF! [Nice "San Francisco" sweatshirt, you douchebag]

Wharfwharf-wharfwharf-WHAAAARF! [You have no idea how much it sucks to be the only vegetarian member of a carnivorous species. And no I don't want more fish, fuck you.]

wharfWHARF-wharf-wharf-WHARF-wharfwharfWHAAAAAAAAAARF! [The rain in Spain stays mainly in the plain.]

Whwhahahwhaaaarf! [I hate humans. I WILL MURDER YOU ALL.]

wharf-wharf-wharf-wharrrrfffffffff! [You know what? Let's burn this fucking eyesore to the ground and start over! RAISE YOUR FINS IF YOU'RE WITH ME!]

Whaaaaaaarrrffffff! [Vote Obama!]

Wharf-warf...warf [Buy me a funnel cake, bitch.]

WHARF! [I saw that you fauxhawked pocket gaysian! Stop taking pictures of us! Go eat a dick!]

...

One star for the chaos cultivated by the egregious display of tourism and overpriced everything. But two more stars for the sea lions. They're badass.
author: d s.

description: We accidentally stumbled upon Pier 39 and it was a nice little treat.  We were just exploring a new city and taking in our surroundings.  I liked this area because of the shops, restaurants and the overall family ambiance.  We stopped into a few of the shops, and I loved Enlightenment.  I bought a nice, reasonably priced necklace.  We also noticed a few crowds by the water and noticed people taking pictures of the sea lions..that was a pretty cool sight... We also liked that  this was in close proximity to Alcatraz tours... we were able to get a quick bite at Eagle Cafe before our evening tour.
author: Liz O.

description:
Yes, that's a four-star rating up there for the most touristy of tourist areas in San Francisco.  It's because I have discovered the secret.

I recently visited Fisherman's Wharf on a Sunday morning at 8:00am.  It was a beautiful sunny but crisp fall day --- one of those days that reminds you how glorious the weather can be here.  I was waiting to get on a ferry and as I waited, coffee cup in hand, I wandered the largely deserted wharf area.  Eventually I found myself all the way out on the end of the long wooden pier at Pier 41 that parallels Pier 39.  As I wandered out, I could hear the occasional barking of the sea lions lolling on the floating docks, the lap of waves on the pilings and distant ring of the channel marker buoy bells.  It was a gorgeous day --- the marine layer was retreating back through the Golden Gate and Angel Island and Alcatraz lay in full sunlight while the bridge was still swathed in clouds.  I stood on the end of the dock, alone except for a couple of fishermen, and then I turned around to go back.  

WOWZA!  The city on all her glory!  This is quite probably one of the best views in the city, and I never knew because I don't come down here.  From the pier the hills spread out in front of me --- Telegraph, Nob, Russian --- and the edges of the Financial District and Ft Mason peeked over the tops of the wharf buildings.  

Every once in a while the pressure builds and I wonder why I still live here.  The cost of living is outrageous.  The press of so many people can become unbearable.  The hordes of tourists try my crowd-hating soul.  Every time I think 'enough, I'm moving!' I find something or someplace that reminds me of just why I stay.  On one Sunday morning at 8:00am that something was Pier 39 at Fisherman's Wharf.  So --- four stars.
author: Suzanne B.

description: Another tourist attraction, but hey! It's fun! Lots of things to see, and places to walk around. Food, shops, picture ops, souvenirs.. ain't bad at all. I am a sucker though since I like to come back every single time I'm in town.
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
I give Pier 39 a 3.7 rating. 

This is definitely a place where you should visit at least ONCE if you're in the SF area. It's a good place for you and your friends/family to explore and enjoy. There are many shops that line the pier and a lot of restaurants worth checking out. This place is even a good spot for a romantic date. They have a sea lion exhibit on the side of the pier (beware of the smell because its stinky!). And they also have an aquarium next to the pier. Although, it may not be the most exciting place to visit, it is definitely worth the experience to see yourself. 

PS: DO NOT MISS OUT ON THE BEST CLAIM CHOWDER IN NORTHERN CALI! I forgot what the restaurant is called but if you want to get really delicious chowder... you can find it at the pier ;)
author: Cindy H.

description: After finishing our Ciao Bella gelato we decided to continue to utilize our pre-paid parking and mozy on over to Pier 39. We recalled not enjoying Pier 39 on our initial SF visit but we decided to give it another shot. It was not any better the second time around; is the worst parts of a busy shopping mall mixed with a tourist trap. It's not even worth the people watching. AVOID AT ALL COSTS!
author: Jessie S.

description:
Everything you could ever want! 
Except the massive crowds of tourists....blah.
Clam chowder bowls are bomb!!
author: Stephanie R.

description: Great place for food and drinks! If you go during an event (i.e. July 4th) it gets really crowded! So plan accordingly.  While I was there I had their clam chowder.
author: Gary A.

description: Massive tourist trap.  Super inflated prices.  Low quality food and goods.  Very large crowds of annoying dummies visiting from Middle America.  Mean seagulls that steal your food right out of your hands.
author: Mark B.

description:
If you ever need a reminder of how little you enjoy mass amounts of people, come here and try to make your way through the crowds during Fleet Week! I have never seen so many God dang people looking up. But besides that, what do I think of Pier 39?

Honestly, I don't mind it. I know it is all about the tourists, but sometimes your local comedy club doesn't have a good comedian in town. Sometimes your DVR recorded repeats of Comedy Central Presents. Sometimes your funny friends are out of town and on those occasions when you need a laugh or eight, tourists will do the trick!

Not a hater, just a fan of humans in their unnatural settings and this definitely makes for many a snicker. Oh and they have a Bubba Gump Shrimp place! Sold!
author: Stephy S.

description: I had been craving fish and chips.  I had fish and chips there, they were cold and soggy.hey were disgusting.  I let the head cook, manager and owner know with no response from any body.  I let them know over a month ago without a response.  I will never eat there again.
author: Doreen L.

description:
Everybody from locals to tourist come here to enjoy a day at the Pier. Plenty of things to do and plenty of entertainers on the streets for a free show (not including tips). Parking can be tough but if you're not lazy, you can find street parking couple blocks from the wharf and just walk. 

There are so many restaurants/stores every where you turn, you wouldn't know where to go and where to eat. It's always crowded but hey, it's where all the tourist goes, what do you expect? 

If you're craving clam chowder? Boudin's is the place to go. I seriously think there's like 4 of them at the Pier.
author: Juliane N.

description:
Another tourist trap I went to, but I enjoyed it.

A lot of stores selling stuff you don't need and even more chain restaurants.

There was even a live show towards the middle.

I enjoyed taking a break from the walking and watching the seals.

Even as a tourist, I was getting annoyed at all the tourists, too many people here.

More for kids than adults.
author: Eric H.

description: This was within walking distance from where our Disney Cruise ship anchored.   This place is touristy but still fun.   It's nice to walk around and there are a few fun things to do there like the mini aquarium, places to eat and little shops to poke around.
author: Toshi I.

description:
Sea lions!  I love them in all their sun-basking, smelly glory.  One time a sea lion threw up off the side of the bobbing dock thing and a seagull swooped down and ate it!  

SF is genius for corralling all the tourists here.
author: Mokirobinson M.

description:
From the times I was a small child visiting my Grandparents to the present where I'm a grown man looking for a nice vacation, Pier 39 has been a favorite spot.  There's just something special about walking along the San Francisco boardwalk in the beautiful mediterranean weather and taking in the sights.  Call me a tourist, but there's just so much to do that it's pretty hard to leave unsatisfied.

You've got your oinking sea lions, your magic show, your hundred-some stores, your thrill-ride theater, and your great eats.  You're also right near lots of other great San Francisco attractions, and the combination of all these elements puts you into a euphoric mood.  Sure, Pier 39 can get a little carnivalistic at times, but in no way does it ever feel like I'm at a Carnival (ugggh. . . Carnies. . . .).  

So if your visiting or simply live there, stop on by for a nice time and don't forget to play some games and bumper cars on your way out.  My favorite is to take a Ferry down to Pier 1 and then walk to Pier 39, that's a great way to get into the mood and enjoy some nice views.
author: John G.

description:
Can you say "touristy".  But, hey, that's what this place is all about.  When I have out of town visitors, I do park in the area, and do the Fisherman's Wharf walk-through.  Almost mandatory for some. Pier 39 is a large bunch of shops for every item you never thought you needed, until you saw it.  

Shops selling every tourist item you ever thought of and more.  However, the one bright spot is that you need to make your way to the left side near the end, and see all the sea lions basking on the docks they took over.  Get ready for pungent smells on some day, but hey, for  your guests this will be their only chance for an up close look at California sea lions.  Worth the trek. 

Hint:  recommend you DO NOT park in the parking garage. Even with validation, it still can run up to $30 for a half day.  Recommend you park one or two streets up. There are several parking garages, that on the weekend, have a $10 all day policy. 

So, get going for that salt water taffy, crazy crowds, chocolates, pictures, personalized mugs, sweatshirts, etc., etc., etc. It's a trip. 

And, by the way, the view at the end of the Pier is pretty nice overlooking SF Bay.
author: John G.

description:
Okay yes there are always tons of people here, but so what!!  Everytime I come to visit the city, which is about once a month, I always end up coming here and I don't know why!!

Many different choices of restaurants, shops, sweet shops, and fun stores...you will see all types of different people down here and there are some great views of alcatraz from here along with views of the city from the parking garage bridge that leads you in to pier 39

No matter how many times I will come to the city in the future, I will always make time for this place!
author: Alicia C.

description:
I will stab someone if I have to take another out of town family member to pier 39.

"Where do you want to go?" I ask, dreading the answer.

"Lets go to Pier 39 and Fisherman's Wharf," they respond.

"What about Golden Gate Park?" I ask. "Or Coit Tower, or the Bridge, or Dolores Park, or shopping, or Chinatown, or Northbeach, or lots of other places I may still hate but hate far less..."

"But we want to see sea lions."

*stabs self in brain*

On the plus side, they have good clam chowder bread bowls. On the negative side, everything is overpriced, there's too many people, and everyone wants you to take their damn picture. See once if from out of town or when one is a local but between ages 5 and 8. Avoid at all costs otherwise. I have to give it 2 stars for that "good for kids and amusing for about 10 minutes" factor... but parking is a bitch and most out of towners not used to the lack of cars think bart to pier 39 is a long walk...
author: Stephanie H.

description:
I'll admit, Ive become a snob since moving to the city.  I stay away from all (most) things tourist, and when tourists actually ask me where they should go, I send them to not so touristy places like the Mission.   It is however, hard for me to hate on the Pier.

This is where i came and met up with my first boyfriend when he started college in Berkeley.  I came up to visit from San Diego, and we spent our one day in SF on the pier.  Oh to be 18 again, and find the pier romantic....watching the seals, trying on goofy hats, and riding the carousel.  Now its all a little cliche', but i could see it being kind of cute with the right guy.

Flash forward a few years, and I move to the city, without a job, so the first thing i think to do is try applying to the restaurants on the pier.  I mean, they get a lot of business right?  After getting denied a job at Bubba Gumps (thank god),   Hard Rock Cafe starts my life off in the city as the first job i had.  I didn't know any better!  I didn't realize how much amazing food this city had to offer!  I was still kind of a tourist myself.  I remember my interview, sitting on a bench outside, admiring the spirit everyone had on the pier, and stumbling over my words, because i though that my interviewer was hot. Soon after i started dating management (the interviewer), and he turned into the first boyfriend i had in the city, and first live in as well.  It obviously didn't last, but the memories from him and the HRC are still up there in some of  my favorite memories.  

Yes, I still bring tourists that are visiting me here....i mean, its sort of a staple, isn't it?  Its like visiting Paris and not going to the Eiffel Tower, or visiting Rome and not going to the Colosseum.  The wharf, and the Pier exist for tourists, and as long as I realize this....i can hang there on occasion.

Locals know better.  Locals now know how to scare tourists on the Pier.  A prime example is the Bushman.  He is a street performer who jumps out from behind a plant, holding a bush, and scares the bejezzus out of unsuspecting tourists.  These now newly scared tourists will stand around and wait for him to do it to someone else.  It takes on a life of its own.  Locals, including myself, last Christmas time, participated in Santacon, and hundreds of people were dressed like Santa, scaring tourists.  The look on the pier-goers faces, seeing all these Santa's, some in fishnets, chaps, or nothing but a hat was priceless.  That is when the pier is fun for me now.  When i realize I'm a local, and that its not much fun hanging out with a bunch of gawkers....its only fun if you are the one being gawked at.

Yes I used to be a tourist.  I don't want to say I'm too cool for the pier....but, yeah...I'm too cool for the pier.  It will still get 4 stars from me though.  Its done me right so far.
author: Lauren F.

description: A tourist trap forrr real which was good since it was my first time in SF.  Great views such as Hyde Street Pier and a dude playing Sublime on the sidewalk.  I saw a Hooters there too which was a plus.  Lol.  First-timers should  go to the traps first to get a good feel of this city but I would not eat here often cuz it's REDONKULOUSLY expensive for the their seafood.  Actually I would come back for some delicious sourbread bowl new england clam chowdaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa but that's about it.  A good spot for family time though.  There was a merry go-round for my niece to circle around on and a view of Alcatraz from afar.  Oh yeah I remember seeing sea lions oinking around on the docks and the small sea lions pushing over the other sea lions off the dock for a spot to nap.  That was funny.  And if you want SF souvenirs...  yeah this is the place to go fo' sho.
author: Steve W.

description:
Here is a link to my Pier 39 photoset containing 34 photos on Flickr:
http://www.flickr.com/photos/jimg944/sets/72157594184991519/
author: Jim G.

description:
As a local i dont go here often, but its always fun to head over if your in the mood to see people and walk around and look at nic nacs in touristy stores.  
Its definitely a stop on the list for when out of towners are visiting, and fun to visit during the holidays when everyone is out.

I would suggest staying away from the restaurants, you will not be getting any type of quality food here. With that it mind, it might be worth sitting in one of the restaurants and grabbing an apetizer or a drink for the awesome views of the bay.
author: Shadi N.

description:
Stop 2 on our tourist-tastic day in San Francisco.

This place seems to be on every tourist's short list of place they are told they must go while visiting San Francisco.  So we went.  

We arrived fairly early to avoid any crowds and spent our time window shopping, people watching, and of course went to see the sea lions.  There are tons of shops, many catering to tourists, and our guest seemed to be entertained.  Shops ranged from jewelry stores, a hat store, a Lefty store and stores carrying  handcrafted gifts, mementos, and stained glass.  There were several restaurants (Bubba Gump, Crab House, Hard Rock Cafe, Sea Lion Cafe), but also quite a few small eateries/snack shops to get a quick treat.  I was tempted to get a pretzel, mini donuts, and a crepe, but lunch was our next stop (and I had just eaten a bagel) so I refrained.  

The sea lions, right beside Pier 39, seemed to be a big draw for tourists.  We had to wait a while to get a clear view, and also to get out of the way of people taking pictures.  Our guest, a current resident of Phoenix, but from Wisconsin, hadn't seen sea lions in their natural habitat before, so one would think she might be the most excited.  But no, it was me.  They were my favorite part.  It helped get me into my Hawaii mode.  Soon I will be on the beach, scantily clad, chubby but happily lazing around in the sun, before dragging myself into the water with a splash.  I'll try to refrain from barking though.  Growls are more my style.
author: Heather F.

description: Same crap different year... It is what it is, a tourist trap. Like another helper said, it's just a bunch of over priced trinkets and touristy food. The only thing I do enjoy are all the street performers.
author: John C.

description:
Pier 39 aka Fisherman's Wharf. They say it is a tourist trap. If I were a tourist and I have to be trapped, I would rather be trapped at our very own Fisherman's Wharf. 

Yeah you have your chain restaurants:  Hard Rock Cafe, Dreyers, Mrs. Fields, etc.  You also have your kitchy souvenir shops of seashells which were farmed from the Philippines. (No wonder the ecosystem in the Philippines are currently in danger.)  And the waterglobes where if you shake the globe,  you can make it snow in San Francisco (which you know will never happen although historically it actually snowed in SF in the past.)

Despite the banality and kitchiness of it all, I love Fisherman's Wharf.  As a tourist, you will be trapped almost whever you go but to have a million dollar view of the San Francisco Bay, Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, and the City skyline, while being serenated by the seals as stinky as they are, I love it and don't mind being trapped as long as it is in SF!!!!

I go to Fisherman's Wharf at least once a year for a total uniquely San Francisco experience but I will go more than once a year if I could.  

Don't forget those yummy ice cream sundaes at Ghirardelli Square.  Not all touristy stuff are bad. Some are actually delicious!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Leah E.

description: AKA - Fisherman's Wharf. Yuck! San Francisco's #1 toursit attraction. It is an equivelant of Times Square in New York City, Navy Pier in Chicago - you get the picture. Nothing unique to San Francisco here. The only reason we went was for a tour we purchased. We walked about 30 ft down the pier and turned around because it was trashy, loud, and worthless. If you want to experience SAN FRANCISCO, go to North Beach, The Mission - anywhere but here. There is no culture. . . just a bunch of venues to waste your money at, and average to less than average restaurants that are some sort of chain. No thanks.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Fourth of July on Pier 39, 2007.  

Living 2 blocks away from Pier 39, it always fascinates me that 50,000 crowds will come here and spent the ENTIRE day waiting for the 9:30 pm firework show.  The last 3 years has been pretty disappointing due to fog.  

However, an hour ago, I witnessed one of the best firework I've ever seen on the roof top of my condo with my closest friends and neighbors.  

Now I understand why 50,000 visitors continues to come annually.

PS.  Lots of traffic outside as people trying to go home.
author: Gin H.

description:
One good thing about living in San Francisco is you can be a tourist every weekend.  Pier 39, you say, a tourist trap.  Well ... how about a two-story carousel?  An aquarium you can walk through? The historic F line passing right by?  Lots of decent restaurants.  Lots of gift shops, sure, and boutique clothing.  The Eagle Cafe.  Seals taking over the harbor.  See, it's actually pretty good!  

P.S. the free public bathrooms, on the 2nd level, were clean today.
author: David D.

description:
Yes, a big touristy place to go, but always have to make a stop here.

Last Friday was a beautiful day.  Sunshine, little wind and no need for a sweater.  

Tulips in full bloom and a nice clear day!

So much fun to wander around the shops and then sit for awhile and people watch.  

Where else can you see a purple poodle!
author: Monica M.

description: Another tourist attraction in SF.  It's fun and definitely family oriented.  There's a lot to see from a random carousel, sea lions in the water, an aquarium, and a bunch of restaurants and stores.  It's nice to roam around and then settle in one of the restaurants there for some clam chowder. There's also a small mini donut stop and ice cream shops.
author: Tanya N.

description: Pretty good.  I don't eat chowder often, but I do pretty much every time I am here.
author: Luke K.

description:
visited 11/18 and 11/20/09 
pier 39 in just a place of souvenir shops and games for kids and what not. I loved the sea lions. I stood there for about an hour watching them! First I went to the upstairs area, then later to the downstairs area. I read all the info along the pier about the sea lions. found them so fascinating!
author: Liza M.

description: whats one of the first things you think of when you say sf? pier 39 of course.  celebrating 35 years this month.  every saturday in october theres fireworks at 8:30pm.  a pretty good 15 minute show.  it overlooks the bay bridge.  the new bay bridge with the fancy light show.  theres plenty lil shops to see and restaurants to eat at.  starts with hard rock in the very front, a grill, bubba gump in the back, a fancy place upstairs.  boudin.  junk food.  you name it.  plenty of options.  lil tourist stores to get alcatraz gear, pier 39 stuff, i heart sf shirts.  this is also where you get your alcatraz tickets, blue and gold fleet boat tickets, rocketboat tickets.  you can see the bridge on a non foggy day.  sea lions in the back.  7d ride experience to kill zombies.  a carousel for kids.  and adults i guess.  even club tattoo to get tattoos!  a day trip will suffice.  but everyone who visits sf has to do pier 39.  just bring money cause it expensive! parking is expensive too.  $8 per hour.  max $40.  you can validate 2 hours if you eat at a restaurant.
author: Matthew G.

description:
Read that as 2.5 Stars

God, I love to hate Pier 39! But we love it, too. I say "we" because my whole department works right directly across the street. So we live the ugliness and the glory that is Pier 39 on a daily basis. Hence 2.5 stars -- it's an average of the high and low points.

High Points:

#1. Definitely the Sea Lions ~ an open air animal behavioural study 24-7. Worth a few laughs every time the big seal belligerently claims the raft for his very own.

I love that the Sea Lions are now the number 1 attraction at the Pier for everyone and that it's free. And that the Pier tried desperately and cruelly to remove them until they realized how good it was for business. Says everything.

#2 high point? Gosh I have to think about this. The $1 Coffee, my coworkers would say (Starbuck's, so I wouldn't) at the Crepe place. The $1 deal is just for people who work nearby, so forget it if you work downtown ; )

#3 The Landscaping. No kidding. I was a landscaper for 11 years and I appreciate (deeply, I should write them a note) the good diversity of beautiful and often native plants that they take such good care of. And in that area on the South side of the pier are really nice benches near lovely plantboxes where a tired worker can take a nap in the sun.

#4 I'm putting this one in for my friend who celebrated her lunchtime bday there - Turbo Ride!! (truthfully I didn't like it...but this is written with my entire dept. in mind). 

Low Points:

Everything else ~ the crowds, the bad and expensive foods, the horrible shops....the terrible crooners broadcasting their sounds to the crowd at large. The Blue Angels (Ai!); the perfume wars;  the totally annoying way that the tourists ride Muni ~ Stay away from the F car at this end of SF when it's tourist time (before 8am is generally safe)

Oh and I've been dying to say this. I hate the silver painted people. It's so pathetic, it's so boring. There are too many of you. I shudder evey time I pass you by. Go away and do something else...please.
author: Liza B.

description:
You will have to claw your way through a fog of hairspray, tanning lotion fumes, overripe tourist smells, and cigarette smoke to get to the only thing with any charm in this tragic cancer on our waterfront: the seals.  Take your visiting dignitaries here, bring extra goons to help ease them through the throngs buying tee shirts and stale salt-water taffy, go directly to the seal viewing area, get your photos, and then run back to the car, quickly.  Your IQ and your taste are going to corrode every second you are here.  

And by IQ, I mean your intelligence quotient, not your My Boyfriend, who you shouldn't be squiring off to see the sea lions without me.
author: Kevin S.

description:
this place is definitely the center for tourists coming to San Francisco.. you'll always see people taking pictures, pointing with an amazed look on their face (not gonna lie, that was also how i was my first time coming here, like any other tourist!) After the first time, this place really isn't all that special, except for its ridiculously cute 24/7 sea lions & great view of the ocean! the stores here are tacky tourist stores, the 'attractions' they have are overpriced usually.. I do however recommend everyone who comes to visit here go on the Blue & Gold Fleet tour. its cheap for a boat ride, which is always a place on a nice day, & you can also pay a few bucks more for a tour of the infamous Alcatraz Island! 

all-in-all, if youre a first timer to San Francisco, go.. if not, its not worth it to come back here, unless you're gonna eat the fresh seafood they serve here (which to me is also overpriced, but hey, its not tourist centeral for no reason!)
author: Alice L.

description: Interestingly little touristy outdoor mall. Good for a walk in and out, and maybe some souvenirs for the folks at home.
author: Celeste T.

description: So many things to do yet so little time.  Tourist trap it is, but hell, I don't care.  From the shops to sights to salt water taffy and what have you... The pier has so many great things to see and do.  Truly one of a kind and makes me happy to know that even though you can take the girl outta Cali, you can't take the Cali out the girl!  ;)
author: Jai J.

description:
I loved Pier 39 when I was a tourist, I still love Pier 39 after 6 years living in the Bay Area. You SF natives can look down on me all you want. If I was a native I'd be proud of Pier 39 instead of calling it overpriced and touristy. Although I almost never buy anything there because it IS overpriced :-\

There are plenty of things to do without spending a lot. Get a bowl of fried seafood, enjoy it by the sea, feed some crumbs to the seagulls, watch the seagulls say "mine mine mine", watch sea lions having an orgy, walk under the sun (with SPF of course), watch bushman scare some tourists, etc etc.
author: Ari C.

description:
Pier 39 is a fun place to walk around, eat, make new friends with the sea lions, and so much more. It's a pretty big place to walk around - ideal for tourists as there are many gift shops, restaurants, and places to sit and watch the boats go by. You can even see Alcatraz in the sea! Parking can be a pain but once you find some, everything else is smooth sailing (literally). It's a very busy area, with lots of tourists and kids running around - it really makes you feel like you're all apart of a collective activity. 

The sea lions are awesome to watch and there's plenty of eateries on the pier that overlook the sea. It can be fun and romantic at the same time! I definitely recommend coming here if you're in the San Francisco area, even if it's just to stop by and take a quick stroll.
author: Kristina K.

description: The Sea lions were adorable and free to check out. I went during morning so wasn't crowded and the sock shop has awesome unique socks.
author: Autumn S.

description: A nicely designed, clean place to visit, shop and eat. Easy parking across the street, decent shops and very nice restaurants. We will be going back for sure!!
author: Cassondra S.

description:
Okay, so I set off with a friend today to find the Union Street Festival, didn't think it would be that hard, I mean, wouldn't it be ON Union Street? Wouldn't there be tons of people and preppy folk walking around NB to go to this thing? Well, it turns out I should have looked up the cross streets before heading out, because apparently it isn't as noticeable as we thought. 

So, instead of going to the Union Street Fair to try and mend my friends broken heart, we ended up doing a walking tour of San Francisco on accident. Now on to the point of my review: 

Pier 39 is one of the first places we ended up, I haven't been there in a LONG time (as I usually try to avoid all over crowded touristy places), but I loved it! I totally felt like an excited little kid all over again! We got ice cream from Dryers (I don't care that it was freezing today!) we sat by the boats and chatted and my favorite part, we went and watched the sea lions playing! So much fun! 

Ya, it is touristy and probably over priced. Ya, it is crowded. But it is just so darling! It is great to just wander around and see why people like coming here so much! A great way to spend an hour or two!
author: Jessica R.

description:
If you do not Like crowded places with lots of action do not visit on weekends..
I love it..Being from San Jose And never seeing much happening only on cinco de mayo!
Pier 39 is awsome..I love All the diffrent ethnicitys..So Many Tourist you see here.Theres always entertainment.free magic show or  Break dancers.Lovely shops.It seems like theres never enough time to spend here.
author: Jehzabella V.

description:
Boudin sourdough bread bowls.  The chowder in this city isn't like Monterey Bay, but you can't beat the aesthetic.  A friend's family owns the grotto so I get hooked up down that way.  The singingest singing sea lions crooners ever... it smells awful but a joy to watch people ogle them.  The magic store was a childhood favourite... Museum Mechanique is stunning, the video game parlour is one of the last, I think.... 

and the cheese covered soft pretzels are divine!

Hell... I know it is a tourist trap.  But five stars for being one of the best tourist traps ever.  Maybe it is just 5 stars for the city.  I love this town.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
No visit to the Bay Area would be complete without a trip here. Not for the overpriced souvenirs or shopping, but for the people-watching, the boat-watching, the atmosphere, and of course, the sea lions. 

Wherever you are on the pier, head West and fight your way to a good spot. They're harder to see in the dark, but daytime and sunset are excellent for photo opportunities. The evening creates an area ripe for late-nate smooching to the tune of barking sea lions... Yeah. It doesn't do it for me, but apparently it floats some peoples boats, so there you go. 

If you're touristing or dragging your favorite tourist around-- the sea lion visit isn't complete without a bread bowl of hot stuff from Boudin's. Skip the one on Pier 39 and hit up the one on Jefferson St. It's bigger, provides bakery tours, sells more trinkets, and feels a little more open. Afterwards, you can hit up that arcade place and/or just walk off all those calories you just consumed, you big sea lion, you.
author: Loli L.

description:
whenever tourists come into my work with their maps and ask me how to get to the wharf i want to scream... really its overloaded with tourists especially the ones who walk around trying to take pictures in the process and get in the way of people like me who are on the way to work... and have no idea what is going on.  also it smells like shit down there and its as if people have never seen sea lions before. COME ON. find somewhere where everyone doesn't go and be different.  there are millions of things to do in san francisco, don't do what everyone else does!
Although the sea lions do smell not so great, they are adorable and THAT is the only thing good about it.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Pretty good to wind out the boredom.
All touristy, but sure can be fun for everyone, just like overal Fisherman Warf area.
author: Cat of a Donut J.

description:
Got to  \see Alcatraz Island from a distance..but we still had a great time on this pier.  We also got to go on this Russian sub that was definetly worth the money..   Got to see first hand, how cramped the quarters are down there..
   Think about being under water for months on end during war time...it was interesting.
   When we left there...and just a few feet away was a fish restaurant and we enjoyed the rainbow trout..
   Had a great enjoyable time..
author: Ron L.

description: This place was a childhood staple for me and my parents/friends to go to. The sea lions are the coolest part I think. It is more of a tourist trap place as the food and stores are expensive but it's fun to come out and enjoy a rare sunny and warm day here near the ocean and marine life. My recommendation is to go here on a weekday if you're local to avoid the crowds of tourists and high traffic.
author: Petra S.

description: Nice to stroll, people watch, or window shop, but too pricey to buy much more than lunch.
author: Dirty D.

description:
My hotel was right down the street from this spot.

Nice place to hang out, if not overly touristy.

There are the sea lions (which I have already reviewed) and there are many, many shops and restaurants. All of them are......pretty overpriced. The gift stores charge like $6 for blasted keychains. No thanks, I'll grab a 99 cent one at some random gift shop on the wharf. 

It's a cool place to hang out, that's for sure. There's also quite a bit of street life going on in this area, always something to see going on. Just make sure to eat and shop elsewhere.
author: Philippe C.

description:
I have a really bad habit of dressing up like a tourist (y'know, shorts and an Alcatraz sweatshirt and one of those little backpack things that holds like half a waterbottle and a tube of Mentos) and spying on actual tourists. I can't help it, they're just SO FUNNY. I love hearing old people who were expecting some sort of tropical vacation complaining about the weather. I love how everyone has their tube socks pulled all the way up. And most of all, I love going into random SF merchandise shops and telling the clerk that there are eels in my hovercraft.

That said, Pier 39 is way overpriced and extremely crowded most of the time. The crepe place earns it most of its stars. Whomever came up with the idea of smothering a crepe in chocolate syrup and nutella and then folding it up and drowning it in whipped cream is my hero and deserves to be president.
author: Liz A.

description:
I love the occasional afternoon here with my family. There's a huge selection of restaurants, shops, fun for children, and the scenery is very appreciated. The last time we were there we enjoyed the street dancing, Jamaican live band and silver man entertainment.

It's a great place to go for family fun time or a romantic stroll with your honey.
author: Lily M.

description:
The one good thing about this place and Fisherman's Wharf, is that it keeps the tourists out of my 'hood. ;D
The bad thing is that they won't really see what it's about. i.e. the 'Loin.
author: J A.

description:
I visited here on a trip before I moved to the city.

Tourist trap.  For sure.  But still fun.  

There is nothing wrong with enjoying the sea lions.  Or seeing all the street musicians or enjoying shopping.  Its a great place to just lose yourself, become a kid, ride the carousel and eat some food.  So take the trolley over and really make a day of just enjoying what it has to offer.  And be sure to check out the great view of Alcatraz.
author: Jen K.

description:
Eek.  Pier 39 and all of Fisherman's Wharf is tourist hell.  What's funny is the moment you enter the the vicinity of any tourist-hell place like this, anywhere in the country, you are greeted with the same olifactory "HELLO!" of funnel cakes.  The minute that hits your nostrils you know EXACTLY what you're in for: themed shops with overpriced chotchkies; souvenir shops with overpriced trinkets that are sure to end up in a box in the back of a closet somewhere; "family-friendly" restaurants with menus laden with fried foods; street entertainers...many of questionable talent; fat, fat Americans.  The kind of Americans that make me deeply understand why the rest of the world hates us so much.

But here's the thing: there's a time and place for everything and kitschy Americana is no exception.  Sometimes it's just fun to get an ice cream and wander around, killing time looking at pointless "stuff".  And at least Pier 39 has those awesome sea lions that like to hang out there.  Maybe they like the smell of funnel cakes too.
author: Christmas D.

description:
pier 39 is a nice day in s.f. and a starting point to a pretty cool day. i like to bart it in then just walk around or find a nice place on the street to park. definitely avoid the parking garage at all cost, save your money for other things. at the pier i love to browse many of the shops like the hollywood shop, the huge nfl store and sure even the disney store. great boardwalk treats await and down to the end to check out the sea lions and stare aimlessly into the water for hours. 

you then have to head on into fisherman's wharf and i like to get a quick and simple crab sandwich and from here head up into ghirardelli square. the people watching in s.f. is always a blast and you can always find some pretty cool stories to tell your friends when you get home.
author: Scotty D.

description:
Ahhhaha~!

I like it here! 

I'm a native San Franciscan, but I like to go to the Pier once a year and act like a tourist...looking at the shops, eating the tourist food and taking pictures with friends.  We like to do poses and yell, "Ooh, look...I'm a tourist!"

When I lived in the City, I used to like running from ATT/SBC Park to Pier 39.  The Pier was my little break of browsing, before running back.  Try it.  It's an easy run...it's all flat.  

Hey, why not.... LoL
author: Ladi Da A.

description: Just a series of trinket shops that all have the same trinkets. The only reason to come down here is if you are boarding a day cruise. Otherwise, it is not worth finding parking then wading through the crowds. There is a reason that the locals stay away from this place.
author: William P.

description: A great place to spend some time.  There are tons of unique shops and a billion excellent places to eat.  You can find real fresh seafood at all of the restaurants and unique things to buy that scream San Francisco.  Also gotta love how ridiculous people sound trying to mock the sealions.  A fun time for any person of any age.
author: Chai S.

description: If you are visiting San Francisco, or if you live in the area and haven't been here, it is worth the visit.  I have been here probably more times that necessary but I like to bring my guests here!  This place is full of SF history.  It is full of tourists and shopping and gross food, BUT the history and it's fun and cheesy, and you can see the Sea Lions, and there is even a carousel.  Just do it at least once.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
My family and I used to come here all the time just to get away from the South Bay area and do something different for once.  I love the bay and I love the mist from the ocean, yes like others have said below the tourists running around like chickens with no heads can be annoying, but you have to almost be around that to realize what you've missed.

I love the shops here because they always seem to have interesting and fun shops.  Like the cultured pearls and oceanic jewelry that you can find, the over priced strawberries and fresh fruit that they sell on the streets, as well as that crazy hat store and the Harley Davidson store that you always just walk in and never buy anything from.  ITS JUST FUN!!!

I shared a lot of memories with the arcade located in Pier 39 as well.  And you've gotta love the street acts that you know the punch lines and you know the jokes, but when you haven't seen in it years...It cracks me up....

I also love the seals that bark and the steels drums that play during the summer and that damn trampoline set up that I've done a few times in my teens....

Wow I do miss that place...
author: Joanne E.

description: Its fun. Lots to see. Shops galore. The outside coffee stand is awful and priced to high. I've been many times. I will deffinently go back.
author: Chef PrettyKelly P.

description: This is the place to go for tourists. It's like a year round carnival with everything from funnel cakes to crepes, donuts, Mrs. Fields Cookies, chowder Houses, bubba Gump shrimp, celtic Gifts, canine Gifts, San fran Souvenirs, clothing Boutiques, arcades, carousels, live Entertainment, The hard Rock, And The seals. Hundreds of them snuggling And snoozing together on The Pier is a sight to see, especially if you are sitting on the pier with a cup of hot chocolate in your hand.
author: Jacqueline M.

description:
I cannot believe that people come here to a "Disney-fied" pier when there are so many other legit attractions in SF. Pier 39 would be great in a boring/bland city, but it just seems misplaced in SF. 

The saddest part is seeing how many international tourists are there, probably thinking "this is America." I guess maybe they're right. I hope they get away from the touristy areas and see some of the actual city. I was saddened to see how densely packed this place was...more than any other area I visited.
author: Timothy P.

description: Just the best memories by being in San Francisco! The Place is like no other in the world and I can stay there the whole day until 1AM and is just great food and fun!!
author: Antonio A.

description: What is not to love?! The pier can be a romantic evening, a day in the sun, a great casual or fancy dinner spot and family fun. A must see/visit if you are visiting and a great day out for locals.
author: Jessica F.

description: I go to the piers just about every weekend, not too much to do but it does have spots to chill with friends and family. Players is a great restaurant to watch any type of sports and to eat good & decently priced food. During the weekends they usually have a magician near (players) and or a band playing near (hard rock cafe). Not too many places to shop, but great gift shops for tourist.
author: Mario M.

description: Living in San Francisco can be expensive. If you need a second-job, Pier-39 is great place to work just for extra spending money. Also instead of payin tourist's price,working here in Pier 39, you get 10%-20% discounts on anything. Coffee,memorabilias and food at Pier 39 can be pricey. I miss working @ pier 39!!!
author: Matt G.

description: I love Pier 39! I've come here on every trip I've ever taken to San Francisco and probably will come on every subsequent trip. Cute shops, like the left hand store and the store that had mermaid/merman xmas ornaments. Tons of great picture opportunities and I love seeing the sea lions. We didn't eat here, as you can go to any of these chain restaurants anywhere.
author: Juleigh J.

description:
Meh.

This is a great place to run by on your morning jog and get a nice view of the city.  Other than that... not much to do unless you like fried food and 3 for $10 t-shirts.  In Chicago, I would compare it to Navy Pier, which I'm also not too fond of.  There are so many more enjoyable touristy things to do in San Fran... take the boat tour to Alcatraz or a bike ride to Sausalito.
author: Laura H.

description: I miss the old arcade with bumper cars here.  Tourists come here day in and day out, but it's way overpriced.  SF's gotta maintain somehow so I'm glad it's here!!  Haha.  It's nice to take a walk around the outside of Pier39 to see the seals, and take in the view of the Bay Area.
author: Dee H.

description:
whats with all the good reviews. This place sucks.  All there is here are restaurants for deep fried fatness and stores to sell crap to the fat asses that just ate at the restaurants.

2 stars for the sea lions.  Lets hope they never migrate to someplace with more personality.
author: Tamar N.

description:
As someone else said, this is one of my most favorite landmarks in the whole world.  I grew up in the city so I'm a bit biased, but really, other than Madison Square Garden I can not think of any place I've ever been to that's just as electric.  This place is full to the brim with life: the events, the tourists, the natives, and just flat out people enjoying themselves on the streets.  

Pier 39 isn't just about restaurants.  Everyone will always have their opinions on food, but there's so much more than just the eats.  You can take ferries from the area going to various places such as Larkspur, Vallejo, and even those outstanding night time trips to Alcatraz (which I highly recommend because the views of the city's ports are like no other).  The place also attracts musicians representing various genres.  

If there is one time I recommend going here in on July 4th.  The fireworks show is the bomb, but just rocking to the live band is like no other.  Have fun, take pictures, enjoy the food, and live to the fullest when you're there.
author: Joe V.

description:
Didn't really know what we were doing. My sister brought me here as I was the "tourist" and it was frankly the tourist thing to do. Pretty standard pier, some interesting shops and LOTS of souvenir shops, but on a lovely sunny day, the view is pretty wonderful. Great picture opportunities all around. 

AND the seals! I've totally seen seals before but for the first couple minutes, you have to admit it's kinda cool to see so many of them chillin,  sunbathing and whatnot. 

This time around, we didn't eat here (my "tour guide" took me to Fog City Diner otw) but I am looking forward to come back and eat. 

PS, the fancy schmnacy bath and body shop on the pier give free demos of their exfoliating scrubs and creams. Even if you don't buy, those will be the nicest, post seafood grub your hands will ever be!
author: Stephie D.

description:
If you're a tourist, and you're staying outside the city, take the ferry into the city and plan to spend the day at Pier 39. 

Enjoy the sea lions, buy your souvenirs, buy the kiddies some salt water taffy, munch on some authentic sourdough bread, maybe have an early dinner, and snap photos to your heart's desire. There's a lot of activity and something for everyone in your group.
author: K P.

description: Even for tourists, this place sucks!  I think when they were designing this place, they weren't sure if it should be a mall or a boardwalk.  The stores are average.  There are a few good restaurants upstairs or on the outskirts, but that's about it.  Parking is terrible and expensive.
author: Jamie J.

description: I love pier 39. theres so much yummy stuff to eat! I can never get tired of this place.
author: Serena L.

description:
This is a great place to come and take in some San Francisco flare. Yes, it is for the tourist, and things are expensive here. But when you go on vacation, don't you like the convince of having a spot that encompasses many things?
The sea lions are super cool to see, although they do stink. There is a great view of Alcatraz. The aquarium  is pretty neat.  Some pretty good restaurants, with a ton of seafood. I mean if you are here from the mid-west, imagine how cool it is to see this place.
Since I now live here, it is not a place I hang out in, but when I came to SF as a tourist ,I went here and had a lovely time.
author: Lisa A.

description: We have overnighted in the west side Marina Berths several times. Be aware that there is a lot of surge, Ferry Boats going in and out, the launch for Forbes Island running customers out to the restaurant (which is really fun, and good food). The Sea Lions do sing at night and they can smell pretty bad if the breeze clocks around. That said, We love the sea lions and the general ambiance of Pier 39. If you can stand a little 'character' a visitors berth here puts you in the heart of what is happening on the shore of San Francisco Bay. Bring some good dock lines and a couple of bungees for your power cord. Pretend you are sailors. You will be in walking distance of The best hot fudge Sunday on the Planet ( Ghirardelli Square),  An world class cracked crab lunch (Fishermans Warf), the Balclutha tour (historic boat museum on the Hyde Street Pier), and the cable car turn about. Walking the other direction you can explore the newly renovated Pier sections. Among the many, and varied, restaurants available right at the Pier, we always visit the Crepe Café early morning before the crowd starts to build. The Marina staff has always been friendly and professional. The Marina shower and lounge facilities are above average. It can be challenging to secure a berth for Fleet Week, New Years, and other big City events, but Pier 39 is one of our favorite overnight destinations on the Bay.
author: Mark W.

description: I love Pier 39. I could watch the seals for hours. And speaking as a tourist, all the reviewers below who complained about us can all kiss my arse! Give me your address so I can hang around on your street.
author: Ed R.

description:
Pier 39 and Beach St around it is like Universal City Walk and Hollywood and Vine and Venice Beach all combined. 

Nasty bathrooms. A hell no.

Clothes around there are pretty cheap. I feel like those merchants just moved here from the Fashion district in Downtown LA. I've always been fond of Korean owned clothing stores. (Forever 21 anyone?) 

You don't have to spend a dime here if you just want to walk around, and that's the best thing to do here I think.
author: Kokoro I.

description:
People told me to stay away from Pier 39 ever since I moved to the Bay Area a few years ago.  But the more people told me to stay away, the more intriguing Pier 39 became.  

So I ventured over to Pier 39 a few months ago.  And by that I mean hopped on the F, checked out the sea lions for twenty minutes, and promptly returned to muni.  

The sea lions are amazing - they basically reclaimed the dock area, just showed up one day (at least that's the story the Pier 39 folks tell you).  The rest of Pier 39 wasn't nearly as cool.  It seems like a good place to take my visitors from the midwest.
author: Lauren G.

description: Even though I am local and in SF a lot one can never get enough of Pier 39 and always drop by when along water.  Views great and plenty of places to eat.
author: John F.

description:
Anyone who visits me is going to end up at the Wharf during their trip. It's just a given and there's no way to argue out of it. Even if they really don't want to go, well, they're going. I happen to love Pier 39 in all its tourist glory and out of town guests serve as the number one excuse to head over. 

Yeah, everything's totally overpriced but who really wants to buy a wacky jester hat or a giant lamp shade fashioned out of sea shells, anyway? The arcade rules. The aquarium rules. Alcatraz rules.  The sea lions rule. Hell, I even have a copy of the zany "magic carpet ride through SF!" DVD that we made with some friends a couple years ago at that one DVD making place. Does it rule? Fuck yes.

And c'mon, who doesn't love a concentrated dose of the worst people from around the world every once in a while? The tourists that flock here are absolutely golden and largely contribute to the hours of fun that the pier already guarantees. 

Plus, what could be better than talking really loudly about the "size of the balls on that sea lion over there" or asking your friends with a raised voice, "hey, did you catch a glimpse of that sea lion's vagina?", all while standing very closely next to some German dude's video camera? 

Golden! 5 stars!!!
author: Chloe S.

description:
This is definitely a stop to make if you're heading to San Francisco on vacation.  Although there is a parking structure right across the street, I would highly recommend taking the Muni here (I took the F line which are the really cute historic streetcars).  You get an amazing view of Alcatraz Island, can walk down to Fisherman's Wharf, the Boudin bakery and cafe, and even to Ghirardelli Square.  

There are a lot of restaurants here serving up seafood or other beachside snacks.  You can get a glimpse of the sea lions hanging out and view all the sightseeing boats in the harbor.  There are lots of kitschy stores on the pier as well selling overpriced candy or souveniers.  

It is definitely a crowded spot with all the tourists coming in, especially on the weekends. I was there on a Sunday and it surprisingly wasn't too bad.
author: Janet P.

description: It's pretty obvious right?  Touristy.  Buuuuuut, it's a lot of fun to people watch and just wander around the area and plus you can't beat doing all of this in the wonderful SF weather.
author: S H L.

description: Very relaxing, clean despite all the folks there.  Great spot to watch fleet week
author: Daniel R.

description: Trish's bucket of donuts!! $9.50 for a bucket of THIRTY SIX little pillows of heavenly goodness. Ah, they literally melt in your mouth when you bite into them. Once you eat one, it's so hard not to eat another one... and another one... until you eat the whole bucket. It's best to eat it while it's still warm, too! I share of course, but I'm pretty sure one person can kill the whole thing. It's THAT addicting.
author: Annie S.

description:
Yes it is very touristy.

But I had a nice day here when I visited SF in 2005.

I loved the shops, the energy of all the people having a fun spring day. Plenty of places to eat and we went with the very touristy (and tacky) Bubba Gump Shrimp Company. I had a delicious bacon cheeseburger and crab cakes here so I cant complain about it.

I only spent the day in SF, so we kind of rushed around looking at all the tourist traps. I cant wait to get back to the bay area and be a full fledged tourist snapping my digital camera as you look at me in disgust.
author: Andy K.

description:
My best friend TC and I went here and had an awesome time.
He picks me up after work and we trek out to Fisherman's wharf for an evening of fun. He's the type of buddy where I always find myself laughing, having fun, and always wondering how the time flew by so damn fast.

We parked in the parking garage, and I surprised him by purchasing tickets for the Blue and Gold Fleet and then riding the boat around the Bay, then we hit the arcade and played air hockey (he won), shot hoops (I won..hahaha) and then walked around and did some shopping, and then had 2 seafood Louise Salads for Dinner.
