We also like the little stupid free comedy show outside of Bubba gumps on the first level. Bring alot of cash if you intend to eat at the wharf and want to have a good time. There are alot of little shops that sell, hawaiian jewelry, shades, hats, crepes, candy, ice cream, and hot coffee. Thanks Bro for showing me a good time and for keeping me on my toes. That's what a good buddy is for. :)
author: Charlene C.

description:
There is so much cooler stuff to do in SF.

I do like Boudin though, and it's a great place, on a sunny day, to catch a nice afternoon stroll, but really? All the chain restaurants in the area make me nervous, as do the tourists in their SF sweatshirts...it's just overcrowded, over-priced, and I feel like it doesn't reflect what the city's all about. I don't know, I guess if that's all I ever saw/knew about San Francisco, I'd be a little disappointed.
author: Danielle D.

description:
I loved Pier 39 when I was a kid. I loved to go on rides, go to the arcade, visit the seals that beach themselves on little wooden islands by the pier, and check out all of the random shops. 

When I got older, I'd pay the Bush Man to scare my relatives. There's nothing like watching your aunt's face when a man jumps out of the bushes at her. Cruel, but hilarious.

Pier 39 is a tourist place. This we know. But if you have reason to go, say, to entertain some out-of-towners, you can find yourself having a pretty swell time.
author: Sophie D.

description:
The famous Pier 39. I didn't get a chance to check out a lot of the shops on the pier, but I did see the numerous sea lions, napping and sunbathing. Also, I caught a glimpse of Alcatraz which was pretty cool.

Now, to rave about the food here.... I don't even know where to begin.

While I'm a big fan of seafood, I'm not for oysters most of the time. But since I was munching on all different types of stuff, I decided to give it a try. And I'm SO glad I did, because it was the freshest, best-tasting oyster I've ever had in my life.. and let me tell you, I've gone through a lot of them in the past.

The seafood here is absolutely the best. Crab cakes, shrimps, and all that, but DO try the raw stuff, because it is as fresh as it can get. Right off the boat... no joke.

I give it minus one star despite how good it was, because the parking here sucks really bad. I went beginning of March, which isn't even a usual vacation period, but goodness it was so crowded. Not to forget they charge you a looooooot, too. Really hard to find spots to park! Boo.
author: Rina K.

description: Yes Pier 39 is super touristy but rightfully so. Where else are you going to go and see piles of wild sea lions less than a hundred feet away for free at a moments notice? Lately the docks that were once filled have mostly been empty and only 3 of them have been occupied by sleeping and barking sea lions squirming around but it's still fun to check out if you haven't been. Luckily the pier that goes along the water is long enough that there's plenty of room to check them out without having to push your way through anyone. In addition to the sea lions Pier 39 is probably the best place to see Alcatraz (unless you're actually going there). If animal watching isn't really your thing or you've seen it enough then Pier 39 has a large dual layered courtyard with lots of snacks, restaurants, and shops to check out. Even if you don't want to eat or buy anything it's still fun to walk through on a nice day and window shop or people watch. Pier 39 and the neighboring Fisherman's Wharf may be geared toward tourists with lots of mediocre food and gift shops but it's still cool to check out, especially if you've never done it before.
author: Matt E.

description: Worth a visit, don't forget to grab a lunch at Pier 39 before you get out of San Francisco. Usually a little chaotic, the place has a potential of becoming a nightmare to any fan of silence. That being said, it's tourist attraction and should be treated as such. Visit with relatives, make a day of getting lunch. If you are in a rush, you are going to panic. It's also an expensive treat. With parking at about $8/hour and overpriced restaurants, it can be a bit overwhelming. However, that being said, it's important to the city of San Francisco and it's right on the bay. What more do you really need? The restaurants on the Pier are usually terrific, with fantastic choices of food in the market place as well. It also has antique shops, ice cream dispensaries, and more. Everything you would ever hope to find on a Pier! Being right on the bay, you'll need to bring a jacket. One that gets the job done. (Yes, even if it's June).
author: Maxwell R.

description: This is a must-see for tourists.  We stop in to one of the restaurants for Bloody Mary's when we are on our way to board a ship at the cruise ship terminal.  We take the train to Emeryville and the Amtrak bus drops you off at Pier 39.  Fun way to travel to SF and beat the traffic and parking.
author: P S.

description:
One of my very favorite landmarks in the whole world. The shopping and restaurants are excellent, and the lively crowds and entertainers make it an event. The local sealife sunning themselves make it fun for kids and kids at heart as well.

A must do whenever in San Fran. I've been going here whenever in San Fran, since I was about 8 years old.
author: Jessica D.

description: This is a review of the public restrooms at Pier 39. Had a great time at the aquarium (perfect for toddler aged 2), but suffered miserably at the public restroom. Seriously, can you guys install a diaper changing station in all of the larger stalls (re: handicapped stalls). I hate having to use 50 toilet seat covers on the floor as a diaper changing station. GROSS!
author: caryl r.

description:
I don't come here often, but as a San Francisco resident for a little over 12 years now, I still love Pier 39 and refuse to think that it is only for tourists. =) It's great for kids because they have those 3D shows, and yes, I've seen them, even the one with Spongebob! haha. Sometimes they put on small magic shows and anything else that kids may enjoy. Also, there is a large carousel, which is great for kids AND adults! Yes, adults too. My friends and I sit in a tea cup and spin that thing SO hard that we can't even tell if the ride is over or not. One time we actually got a crowd of young adults going for it..haha. Childish? Maybe, but hey, you can loosen up and act like a kid once in a while. :) 

I think Pier 39 is a very family oriented place, so bring your kids, spend some quality time together, and don't forget to check out the robot man! Have fun. =)
author: Narina A.

description:
Pier 39 is a mess of obnoxious, smelly, loud tourists sporting 'I Love SF' t-shirts eating overpriced seafood. I suggest you only visit that area for one reason: the sea lions. They fight, they lounge, they swim, and they emit loud "oort oort oort" sounds. They are fantastic and amusing, and I love them.

Here's a video clip on YouTube of the Pier 39 sea lions from my friend and myself. Enjoy!

http://www.youtube.com/user/jakirwin#play/favorites/37/bJ82FxT3Jtg
author: Jordan K.

description: Cool stores and restaurants.  Must try Trish's Mini Donuts!  The restrooms are a bit filthy in this shopping center and I'm sure it is becaues of the huge amount of tourists that have to go...  My favorit part about this place is the location for taking pictures of Alcatraz and the San Francisco Bay.
author: Camilo G.

description: I rate Pier 39 a 3 star because it gets boring after a while. Tourists may think that this is a 4-5 star, but for all the real city people, do crepes really cost 8 dollars? I've been here countless times and nothing has really changed... same arcade.... same shops.
author: Jeffy Y.

description:
Great views of the alcatraz! Lot of shops and restaurants to choose from so its a good time...nice place to bring visiting friends and family along to. It's important to my husband because it was the first touristy type place he visited in America after he arrived from Seoul. So its sentimental to us. He loves all the sun bathing seals. My pup loves to mingle with the other dogs following their owners not to mention he seems to love all the attention and compliments too. (starting to wonder how many people took pics of him) ^^
Good variety of attractions and photo ops!
author: J A M.

description:
Obviously when you step foot onto Pier 39 AKA Fisherman's Wharf - you are entering tourist central.  I am from Seattle and as a tourist - I get it.

That being said - the Pier is charming.  Filled with delicious restaurants, cute stores, the carousal, and great performers - its a fun place.  

I like that it is enclosed enough that I can let my teens go around the area in groups of three or more and stay (pretty much) out of trouble.

There is lots to do and see and buy - something for everyone!
author: Amy B.

description:
If I were looking to have a discrete affair, Pier 39/Fisherman's Wharf is where I'd go. Somehow I doubt anyone I know would find me there.

While I wouldn't really choose to eat/shop here, I always bring visitors and 98% of the time, they love it so whatever... at least I made family and friends happy. Go check out the sealions and take the out of towners.
author: Anita B.

description: Great place to check out sea lions and very good restaurants and cute boutiques..
author: Wendy P.

description: I could have watched the sea lions all day. Cute looking shops and definitely crowded and touristy but, worth it if you like sea lions. Sounds silly but, we stopped in an arcade with our kids and saw a stunning view of the bay. Really worth checking out if you get a chance.
author: Ellie S.

description:
This place has changed so much through the years. Some of the shops I remember seeing are gone, but there are your standard restaurants (get clam chowder in a sourdoug bowl) and funky souvenir shops. Don't forget to make sea lion calls on the west end. Those silly things.

The view of the Golden Gate Bridge is good from here, and is especially neat when it's foggy (but when isn't it, really?) 

One of my favorite things to do as a kid was watch the tree lighting after Thanksgiving. That kicked off my holiday the right way.

This is a tourist "must" I suppose, but because I have been there so many times, it's just another shopping destination, place to hang out or bring out of towners. Don't forget your sweatshirt!
author: Kimberlee J.

description:
Felt like high school.  There was a parade of camaros and mustangs driving down the main drag revving their engines, annoying the hell out of everyone.  There was a day that I would've thought that was cool.  I guess I'm old now.

0 stars.  Plus three for awesome sea lions.
author: DH H.

description:
Fisherman's Wharf - the one place in San Francisco where people will call you faggot to your face.  

Despite the very annoying collection of tourists wearing things only tourists will wear - Fanny packs and poofy hair - I'm going to cut Pier 39 a break.  I personally hate the place, but my mom LOVED IT when she visited and since my mom rocks - I'm gonna give it 2 stars.

The aquarium is actually kinda cool and walking through the very bright and loud pier is an unfortunate necessity to get to the ferries which will take you to uber cool places like Angel Island and Alcatraz.

I'm also not sure what the fascination is with the smelly and very loud seals - I totally don't get that.  It's like standing around and watching cows sleep and fart.  But the kids seem to really love it.
author: Daniel H.

description: Really fun little place.  Of course I loved seeing the sea lions!  The only reason I didn't put 5 stars is that it's extremely touristy, with lots of people around with little kiosks and street performers. I prefer less touristy, but if you love kitsch, you'll love Pier 39!
author: Abby T.

description: Beautiful views of Alcatraz, the golden gate bridge, and the bay. Otherwise, it's super touristy, it's the equivalent of the South Street seaport in New York lots of chain stores an souvenir stands.
author: Nes L.

description:
Another famous tourist attraction in San Francisco. The coolest thing about this place is the sea lions at the end of the pier. I felt a close connection to those fat sea lions as they did nothing but lay about. It reminded me of myself, and I couldn't help but think that even if I were born a sea lion, my life wouldn't be much different than what it's like now. 

Unfortunately there isn't much else of interest in Pier 39. There are a couple interesting shops such as an oxygen bar and a store that sells only stuff made for lefties (as in handedness, not politically). Other than that the few shops here sell pretty much typical tourist items like t-shirts, mugs, caps, etc. There are a good number of restaurants in pier 39, but most of them are overpriced and mediocre. Considering the high concentration of restaurants in San Francisco, you can get much better stuff without having to go too far away. Pier 39 is worth a visit, but once should be good enough for anybody.
author: Byron C.

description: I guess depending on my mood, the number of stars could change from visit to vist, so I went with middle of the road. I hadn't been here in years and since the day was so nice, we walked up the Embarcadero from the Financial District. You ever one of those days where you're walking amongst hunderds of people and everything seems to move in slow motion? That's what it felt like even though there were oodles and oodles of tourists, but for some reason it didn't seem to bother me. Perusing the shops and watching the sea lions just like all the other tourists. I guess even though it's SF's ultimate trap, it's still fun to go when the conditions are right.
author: Kim N.

description:
Walking through Pier 39, a little voice kept screaming in my ear...TOURIST TRAP! Even the parking structure for Pier 39 is a great money pit ($7/hr). But I have to admit, the area is quite clean and is worth taking the kids and out-of-towners who only have a day or two to enjoy San Francisco. At least you get some of the local flavor here, whether it is the street performers, the noises of the sea lions, the views of Alcatraz, Bay Bridge, Golden Gate, etc., or simply just buying something to remind you that you went to the city.

If you plan to go here, though, make sure you get some type of coupons or discounts in those tourist flyers, especially for parking...it's most likely worth it.
author: Isaiah N.

description:
It's like a tourist fly-trap.

At least it keeps all the Texans away from the places I frequent.
author: Matthew R.

description:
What do you think of when you hear the phrases "Fisherman's Wharf" or "Pier 39"? Most likely you think of overweight Texan tourists and mediocre restaurants with over-priced menus. 

But, my fellow city-dwellers, as you do your best to avoid this tourist-trap-to-end-all-tourist-traps, spare but a smile for the the noble sea lions that grace the docks with their blubbery presence for several months out of the year. 

From afar - as distant as the top of Telegraph - you can hear their playful bark as they sun their enormous bellies and dive for fish off our fair city's waterfront. It is surely enough to soften even the most steely heart among us. 

And while some might think their smell repellent, I would call it "natural", with the pungent aroma of sea spray and composted fish. Magnificent.

So spite not the sea lion, good sirs and madames. Zalophus californianus means you no harm. He is simply biding his time and tending to his affairs in hopes that one day you, too, can share in his joy. Arf.
author: Andrew K.

description: I was very disappointed with Pier 39.  It makes the Santa Monica pier seem "homey".  It is a super tourist trap...literally -- as you can't escape easily.  The worst part???  The restrooms.  Signs leading you to phantom bathrooms...and when you finally find it -- there is only one stall.  Seriously.  This place was really sad and disappointing.  Overpriced shops...overpriced everything.  Ugh.  Very sad.  We did find a parking spot just across the street...pretty amazing!  But other than that, I will never be back.
author: Kyle R.

description:
Great place to take the relatives visiting from out of town. We drop them there first, first expose them to things that are used to, in my case Myrtle Beach, SC (also known as Myrtle and Gomorrah).

Now that they are all tranced out on the sea lions and the sailboats, etc, then we show them San Francisco. Once we are done, they don't remember Pier 39  - just the sea lions.

UPDATE: Also, if you plan on going to Pier 39 while using MUNI, be prepared to take a cab back. Return trips back from Pier 39 to anywhere in the city is impossible where Muni is concerned unless you ride all the way up to North beach and get a bus elsewhere.
author: Storm W.

description:
I am only going to waste vowels and consonants here so that I can add it to a very particular list. 

I'm sorry people. This place is immature. There are so many things that make San Francisco great and this really isn't it, regardless of how many people like it. 

Feel free to figure out what's great about cultural importance at any time and come join the party.

The only good part is the sea lions, which is why I give two stars instead of none. Yeah. I said none.
author: John S.

description:
Biggest touristy place around...DO NOT come if you don't like people!

Pier 39 is extremely crowded with people, especially during the summer, when it is tourist season. Most of the stores are really touristy places, which means that they sell random junk that is really expensive. The salt-water taffy store is amazing though, I always buy a large bag of it whenever I go.

The sea lions are GROSS and loud and I have yet to figure out why tourists love them so much! They might be cool if you have never seen a sea lion before. 

I guess I would never decline the opportunity to watch tourists struggling in their fanny packs and Capri pants, but I just don't see why tourists flock here. Personally, I go to watch the tourists, not the sea lions!
author: Elaine S.

description: Very busy spot. I definitely felt like I was at The Promenade in Santa Monica. A bit too touristy for me, but the view was pretty cool. I enjoyed watching the Sea Lions though. There are a bunch of awesome stores and candy. I did enjoy it, but not the crowd. It was a bit difficult to get through at times. It's a must do though, especially if it's your first time to this city. There's lots to see, eat, and do.
author: Scylis A.

description: Many restaurants and activities to do in the area. Of course, the seals are always fun to go watch although there are fewer of them than ever before. There are always tourists out in the area and its just a fun atmosphere.  You can book different activities like going to Alcatraz from this area too.
author: Melissa W.

description: It's nice to stroll down pier 39 when it's an off season. Going into the tourists can be fun, on a seldom occasion...
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Touristy stores...

But, a great variety of stores to visit.
Stores are very updated and clean.
Lots of deserts and restaurants to choose from.

Of course, the prices will all be on the higher end.
author: Realtor Karl B.

description:
Two Words: Tourist Trap!

The best thing down here are the sea lions.  If you're into shopping, this is your place.  Lot's of over priced tourist garbage.  Seriously, any of the trinkets sold here, can be purchased on just about any block at Walgreens for a fraction of the cost.

We got there around 9:30 a.m before the crowds... By the time we left around 11, the waves and flocks of people were pouring in.  

I've heard this compared to Pike Street Market in Seattle.  I have to say, that Pike Street is rich with culture, history, quality restaurants (i.e. not Bubba Gump Shrimp), local vendors, artists, etc.  Pike Street is alive, it has soul.  Pier 39, is commercialized, the soul has been sold out.
author: Noah B.

description: Though full of tourists (& I guess, because of them), this place will always hold a special place in my heart.  Maybe it's because I always go on double dates here with one of my closest friends...and although we always try to check out a different seafood restaurant, we continually find good food in this crowded atmosphere.  But if you're looking for great clam chowder, always head towards the stands on the streets.  You know, the ones near the Fisherman's Wharf sign.  Hey, that's why there are tons of birds around the area.
author: Rinne R.

description:
Obviously, this is probably one of the most touristy places in the city. However, its perfect for out of town guests and superb location for people watching. 
The Sea Lions are the fun little surprise that I told my visiting friend about and he didnt believe me. 

All in all, a great area for those beautiful days when you just want to get out and walk around and remember what it was like to be a tourist.
author: Erin F.

description:
The last time I've been here was almost ...ugh... its been that long... let's say its been a while - more than 5, but less than 10... Fair enough?!??!

Although its been a while, most recent visit brought back memories of the times I've came here with my family. I imagine for the locals, this place would be considered a tourist trap, and it is. However, it was a pleasure coming back here. Any location with the ocean at a jumping distance, is usually going to get great scenic views. If walking towards the end of the pier, great photographs can be taken of the Golden Gate Bridge, the Bay, Alcatraz, boats and ferrys, and myself swimming across the ocean - yeah right.

There are your basic chains of Hard Rock Cafe, Dryers Ice Cream, Boudins, etc. Also some live entertainment as well as a poor man version of a farmer's market (although its appropriate due to its set-up).

It's a must see.
author: Robert Jr E.

description: This is a fun place to hang out with tons of restaurants, shops, aquarium, etc, or you can chill (yup, it does get windy and quite chilly) sitting on the chairs next to a giant crab under the California sun while listening to the street musicians. For street performers suggestion, check out a guy named John Clarke who plays acoustic guitar with a Spanish flavor. His CD is great, but his live performance, especially the song The Most Evolved, is so truly breathe-taking and so passionate that I feel the recording doesn't do him justice =).
author: Michelle N.

description: great place for shopping and entertainment, often go there and spend the whole day walking, watching the show, go to Alcatraz is another story,  but I regret to 3 very important things that bother me and they are: it's too crowded, too strong wind, and a bad taste and expensive food ........
author: Mary H.

description: The biggest tourist trap San Francisco has to offer, and the most UnSan Francisco thing the city has to offer. And yet, I still enjoy coming here on a sunny day. I have to admit that its kind of fun- sea lions, the arcade, little rip off restaurants that no native would be caught dead in. But how can you hate Pier 39? If you grew up in San Francisco, odds are you have fun memories of this place as a child- I know I do.
author: David D.

description: Omg, has San Fran lost the will to provide a family friendly environment?  We had been planning a trip through San Fran for years.  We got a overpriced hotel close to fishermans ward so we could walk around the tourist spots easily.  On the first day we were headed to pier 39 and the first thing we see is a guy with a ponytail on rollerblades with no clothes on.  My kids saw his private parts.  I think they are still in shock.  Not too much further into our day a couple more naked guys were just hanging out.  We saw a policeman and told them about it and they said welcome to San Fran.  They said it was against the law to be naked in public but they didn't enforce it.  We decided to be more vigilant and try and shield our young daughter from being exposed to older naked men.  As we proceeded to down the street we were approached over and over and over avian by homeless people, who were pretty aggressive seeking money.  During this adventure we smelled marijuana smoke the entire day, all over.  Needless to say, we didn't stay 4 days I. San Fran.  We didn't even stay the night.  We decided not to expose our kids to public displays of nudity, public use of drugs, aggressive panhandling and in general lawlessness..  This is the last time we ever go to San francisco.  no wonder the city is broke.
author: Master B.

description:
Oh but is there anything more lively than a slightly enhanced jaunt down the twists and turns of this waterfront Pier?  I suspect that most of the other sheeples around me are at a perfectly ecstatic level without any assists other than from the cotton candy they consumed at the entrance or any of the various food whatsits dangled out like fishing lures from the purveyors of the way... but yet part of me thinks adding a dime toss wouldn't be an entirely bad move.

And happy fun chaos aside the view of Alcatraz and the Bay of My Fair City cannot be beat, nor can I help but pay homage to our resident sea lions on my way out.  

(And as a small bonus, is a great dumpoff point for the visiting friends & family that would otherwise sit in my home space for slightly uncomfortable periods of time).
author: Jim W.

description: Great place to visit while we were there. Also, it is very close to Alcatraz Cruise dock so it was convenient to spend some time there while we waited. It was clean and family friendly.
author: Roman K.

description:
my familia spend lots of time here but rarely spent any monies here. we came to look at the seals, the vaudeville acts, the tourists, and window shopping. we may occassionally buy an ice cream or clam chowder.

the seagulls keep this piece clean by snatching up every piece of food that's dropped on the decks.
author: Victor G.

description:
This is my over all review of Pier 39 and not the stores. First off, the Aquarium is tight, if you got the money. Kinda expensive because of the millions and millions of tourist that come here each year. If you don't have the money, see the Crystal Geyser Show right near the Carousel Horses. Free show for public viewers. In the Show, they might do Magic or dangerous stunt, it just matters what day and hour, you go. The Carousel horses are a great treat for the kid. It kinda has a long line and a bit expensive. Talking about treats for kids, there are two stores worth noting. One is Crazy Hat Store, where you can check out weird strange hats and the magnet store.  If you get hungry, there are a number of cafe like Bubba Gump Shrimp (expensive as hell). MOMMY ALWAYS SAY LIFE IS A BOX OF CHOCOLATE, YOU NEVER KNOW WHAT YOU GOING TO GET!!! YES THAT BOX IS EXPENSIVE!!!  Then there is the sea lions which looking at them at period of time could make you as lazy and as sleepy as those sea lions. LOL. Are we watching them or are they watching us??? They honestly don't do anything and is kinda boring. It's like watching fat ppl on the beach! They sit around. Go see the Aquarium of the Bay. Why see that!  Over all, it's fun for the kids and at nights, Romantic. ;)

Overall:
author: Ivy V.

description: Pier 39 is pretty much your local San Francisco tourist trap. It has all the shopping and restaurants you expect. They even have a merry-go-round and an arcade for the kids. One of the great things about it is that when you get to the end of your stroll, there is a great view of the bay! Off to the left you will probably hear all the seals barking away also. It's a great place to take the first time visitor or just people watch.
author: Brian A.

description: TOO TOO MANY PEOPLE  at one time  OMG!!!  i love  this area  bout the tourist shop need to stop  on their prices,  they know people  will  buy it so they have high prices. Bubba Gumps had a 2 hr wait for a party of 10, as big as that place is- no i did not wait. i love watching them make the crepe in the window, and it was a zipper purse i wanted that was nice but to high $40.00. this is more  for kids then adults in the heat.
author: Mishelle N.

description:
Every time I go back to visit or bring along a new friend to the city I always wind up here and every single time I wonder "why the fuck am I here?".

There's a Wyland gallery here, but I hate dolphins.

There is one restaurant that is good where you can see Alcatraz while eating lobster but expect bad service and to pay at least 75$

Unless you like tourist trap shops (magnets, sweaters, "film your adventure", puppets, etc), there's really no point to go.
author: Ashley B.

description: Very touristy, but I still liked everything here. Especially the fresh fruit. It looked so good. I wouldve liked to check out more of the food here, but theres only so many meals you can fit in (and afford) in so little time.
author: Katie P.

description: Really crowded and touristy. My wife and I did not spend very long here. It's worth seeing the sea lions, but that's about it. You can do much better dining throughout the city. I would recommend spending maybe 45 minutes here and then getting away and experiencing the culture the rest of the city has to offer.
author: Steve B.

description:
Tourist trap...need I say more?

Well I will. I hadnt really been here in a while and I ended up going here a lot during the summer. I mean, it's great to walk along, but really, the people who actually go there are just tourists. Lots of camera flashes and such. Nothing tremendously special
author: Dustin H.

description: i love it here i grew up in the valley but i go to the bay all the time and everytime i go this is a place i visit i just enjoy it to much not to go.
author: Anthony V.

description: Is it too much to expect an eating establishment in tourist area to have clean utensils, a clean table top, clean windows, freshly made french fries instead of dirty, dirty and rewarmed leftovers?
author: Corinne d.

description: I come by every time I'm in town. Love all the street performers and all the nick knack shops. A must see any time.
author: Nancy B.

description:
Yes this area is full of tourists,but regardless this place is interesting and continues to pull people down here.

Visit Ripleys Believe Or Not,The Wax Museum or many of the wonderful seafood restaurants.I have had tasty meals at  Alioto's,Crab House and Grotto
author: Dani D.

description:
This place is super tourist-y, but still really fun. 

It's fun to poke around in the shops and eat clam chowder and see the seals. 

It's not a "must do" for my list, but it is somewhere you should check out at least once.
author: danelle g.

description:
Yeah, it's crowded all the time
Yeah, it's so many tourists each time I visit
Yeah, it is over commercialized
Yeah, there are sea lions
Yeah, the parking is expensive

But, I still love to come here and enjoy the sunny days at this place! 
Oh! The view of Alcatraz and the city from the roof of Pier 39 parking structure is a steal!
author: Daisy S.

description: Touristy fun! Nice selection of food and snacks combined with lots of souvenir shops. Beautiful view! The only downside: parking is $7/ hour.
author: Angie D.

description: As everyone else states, this is definitely a tourist stop. It is super crowded with foreigners who don't understand the meaning of personal space and who aren't very polite. The public restrooms are absolutely disgusting and are not well kept at all. While we were there yesterday they had a magic show on. There is a lot to do with the tours to Alcatraz and the aquarium as well as shopping. (Check out the Lefty's shop) It is definitely not a location I would frequent regularly because the masses of people are quite a turn off but it's a great place to bring friends/family who have never been to SF.
author: Alie C.

description:
Pier 39 is an excellent destination for those visiting San Francisco. 

Street performers, restaurants, and souvenir stores are amass. Further, Pier 39 is home to the Aquarium of the Bay, and sightseeing tours -- including the most noteworthy: Alcatraz.

Yes, you are probably going to encounter a "bum" who will ask to spare some change. However, you will also see some of the most interesting characters that the city has to offer -- some of which include "The Bushman," jugglers, magicians, and silver painted mimes.

Alcatraz is within viewing distance from Pier 39. And most certainly, the scenery around Pier 39 is great.
author: A B.

description: It's a place that everyone needs to visit at least once.  No need to visit any of the shops, just say hello to the sea lions and maybe take a ride on the carousel.  Definitely don't park in the Pier 39 lot, just across the street is much cheaper.
author: Chris K.

description: It's really fun to walk around here and people-watch. Beware the expensive prices for food and everything else, it seems. Very touristy, but it's still a good time. Don't forget to check out the sea lions at the end of the Pier. They OWN that pier and are so awesome to observe.
author: Mari R.

description: #439 This place really isn't all it's hyped up to be. As it was going to be my second trip here, I was braced for the splash of consumerism that was going to hit me, but I was still surprised at how capitalistic this place is. Tons of chain restaurants (+ way too many football fans this past weekend) and all sorts of tourist shops. Not a fan. The prices here are also going to be more than you would feel comfortable paying, but I'm sure most tourists are fine with the premium. We walked by the carousel, where they also had a magician's show going on for the kids. Most of the people in the audience were there only because they wanted to sit in the empty seats. Poor magician. Anyways, I say come by for a look if you've never been. But, don't make it the main point of your time and don't expect anything awe-inspiring. What happened to the true fisherman's wharf that so many musicians have sang about?
author: Stephanie P.

description: Even though I had to run with my clam chowder bowl in hand on the way to Alcatraz Cruises, I was so glad to have enjoyed authentic new england clam chowder - on the West coast!  The kiosk that serves it is close to the street near the shopping on pier 39.  Enjoy!!
author: Sandra F.

description: On my first visit to Pier 39, I thought it was over-crowded open air mall. There's tons of amazing stores & restaurants. Plus you can always stare at the manatee's.
author: Jamie H.

description:
Five stars for the sea lions!
Minus one star for all of the tourists.
author: Francis K.

description: This is always a fun place to visit. It was beautiful when the Christmas tree was lite.
author: Darlene Q.

description:
TOURIST TRAP.

whenever we think about going here, i roll my eyes and say no. but everytime we actually get here, i actually realize that at the end of the day, im still having a good time. maybe its the seals that bark like ducks or smell like shit. maybe its the clam chowder that is about $5 for a small cup or maybe the crepes that arent even that good but theyre good enough to spend on anyway or the candy shops that has those weird dinasour chocolates. if you dont know what im talking about, well, thats okay.

bottom line; i still enjoy this place.

just not every month, please.
author: Jillian R.

description:
nice day today so I decided to come down with friends to visit... 

as a resident of San Francisco, I don't think I've been down here more than a dozen times in the past 18 yrs that i've been here. because of that, I feel like i'm a tourist and should enjoy the place every bit just like any tourist that were visting. I pretended I didn't know anything and just looked @ the stores in amazement.
author: Eric Y.

description:
I LOVE coming here!
Especially on hot summer days at night, ii come out here with a couple of friends to walk around and get a little breeze. 
You can do a lot here! from shopping to eating to watching shows.  You can even go crabbing, i went out last night to go crabbing at Pier 39, crazy i know, it wasn't as cold as i thought it was, pretty dead late at night, make sure you bring a jacket even if its during the summer! its more of a tourist place but i live around the bay area and i come here all the time!
author: lisa m.

description:
I came on my first trip to SF and really enjoyed it. We found ourselves coming out here every couple months or so. Our last trip was for a timeshare presentation. No, we didn't buy.
 I took my mother here and she really enjoyed it. She's not a fan of crowds, and it was crowded this July day, but it was a beautiful day and Lou Feregno (Incredible Hulk) was there. We spent several hours walking around the area, going into most shops. 
 We took a ferry ride around the bay, had a nice lunch and ice cream there. Most any tourist trap you go to is going to be pricey,  that's the way it goes. My wife loves seeing the seals.
author: Matthew P.

description:
I know that Pier 39 is a tourist trap--but this is probably my favorite tourist trap in the whole world.

Unlike other tourist traps which are designed primarily to milk the poor tourist sap of his or her money without having much intrinsic value, Pier 39 actually has much to offer the casual visitor and locals as well.  Sweeping views of the Golden Gate, Alcatraz, Sausalito, and the Victorian house-covered hills of San Francisco.  Kitschy shops and stands.  Live entertainers and buskers.  And my personal favorite: the incessantly barking sea lions who hardly seem to care that thousands of tourists gawk and snap pictures of them every day.

Every time I visit the City by the Bay, I always make the stop here to visit my sea lion friends doing their thing.  They alone deserve 5 stars for their performance, not to mention the other charms of Pier 39 that are so quintessentially SF.
author: Jen O.

description: Even though we live in the Bay Area, we had never brought the kids to Pier 39. We thought it would be fun to be a tourist for the day. Pier 39 is most definitely a tourist trap. The stores are all overpriced and the place is insanely crowded. But it was fun. We went on a gray, overcast day during your typical SF summer. This is why I moved out of SF and to a warmer place. Here, you can buy tickets to take the ferry to Alcatraz, which is something we still have yet to do and I've never been to Alcatraz even though we've been living here all my life. I would like to come back in the Fall when it's a sunny day.
author: B W.

description: I came here for 4th and it was great. Lots of things to see. Parked at pier 1 and walked down. Got to see bay aquarium and ride the blue gold tour. It was over all a fun time. It could be pricey if you spent your dollars poorly. Bubba Gump was a great lunch too. And that is all I have to say about that.
author: Don M.

description: Enjoyed myself everytime I visit.  Plenty of stuff to see and eat.  Enjoyed the chowder loafs. There are times I notice trash on the ground or dirty curbs but I guess that is expected from so many visitors.  Remember to bring a light coat even during the summer as it can be a bit cool even during the day.
author: Big W.

description: Went there last weekend, its been about a year since my last visit.  What a zoo..  all the main parking lots were full, had to loop around twice (which took about an hour because of some construction) to find a parking spot in a garage that charged $9 hr.  Other than the pain of getting in and out of there, and everything being ridiculously overpriced, the food can be good if you know where to go and its a good place for people watching!
author: Sam J.

description: This place is probably the most touristy spot in all of San Francisco. I only come here when I have tourist friends to take there. The shops are all geared towards tourists and nothing really practical. There are some good restaurants at the Pier but again, geared towards tourists. Parking is outrageously expensive here so I suggest parking a few blocks away and pay less for parking there and then just walk over to Pier 39.
author: Rylan C.

description: Tourist central...but, if you do it right (and in less than 2 hours), you can avoid getting trapped. Do NOT miss the Mirror Maze!!! The sea lions are cute - yet stinky. Go into to only the best stores...this should take only minutes as there aren't many. Take some cool pics, then, walk up the street to eat at Buena Vista and revel in an award-winning Irish Coffee (or YELP to avoid overpaying for crap). Then, for God's sake, get the hell out...
author: Janet D.

description: I had so much fun there!  Lots of fun tourist shops and entertainment!  Go see the sea lions.  We saw some that wouldn't let one up and they started biting at each other which was sad...I never knew they make such strange noises!  I would also recommend the Ghirardelli (sp?) store!  Make sure to bring your jackets!
author: Avalon D.

description:
death trap or tourist trap? 
just something about that wood construction doesn't sit well with me. and all those Alcatraz or sf sweaters....bleh

I generally only go here because of tourists that I have to show around town or for the donuts. they got trish's mini donuts...hmmmmm 
http://www.yelp.com/biz/trishs-mini-donuts-san-francisco-3#hrid:UXTR_4qsglnRww_XTLttLw/query:trish%20donuts

I would say go to Boudins but hey...you're here...get some of the local stuff. you can get boudins anywhere. 

what else is pretty cool there?

you love those noisy hot dog looking things right? they got those seals over there in the corner and  can't forget that romantic view of Alcatraz. 
Hawtness!

other than that minus 2 stars because they turned me away when I was walking there.
.
.
.
in the middle of the night...
bastards
;P
author: John-Michael C.

description: very touristy, locals dont go here.  Its always those old people with the over sized visors taking poloroid pictures.  Food is good though.  would recommend House of Crabs or Crab House I think it is.  3-D rides are from like 1990.  They definately need to step their game up.  Those things are lame.  Good place for a date though for sure, especially if shes from out of town.
author: Brandon H.

description: You would expect me to give this place a bad review, right? Well, you're all wrong. I contain multitudes, baby, and an evening at Pier 39 is fine by me because not only do I enjoy the F Market, sea lions and fucking fantastic bay views, I also enjoy outdoor shopping adventures and SKEE BALL. Yes, somewhere in Pier 39 is one of those rip off arcade places where you play for tickets to win some prizes (usually a pencil or a neon colored rubber band). I don't care about winning or prizes, all I care about is skee ball and I have spent many hours here playing a game that's basically bowling for dummies. Love. It.
author: Maria D.

description: I no see why people come down here. Many stores sell garbage. I see arcade with many young people. I see carousel but so cold no can ride. I see nothing but sea dogs making lot of noise and smells.
author: Elizaveta C.

description: I love Pier 39!  I love seeing the seals/sea lions and the shops that surround this area!  The day was just beautiful, crisp and I was with family just enjoying the moment!
author: Grace C.

description: A true San Francisco landmark!!. It's a must to come here when you visit the city. It's a great place to shop and eat at, they got a arcade too which is really great also. Great place to see seals too since it's right next to the bay. Since driving in the city is a bad idea, take the Muni F streetcar here since it's the convenient way to get here and back!. Pier 39 rocks!
author: Ryan D.

description: Yeah... a tourist area.  But always fun.  Granted we only go to Pier 39 every couple of years or so.  It's especially a fun place to people watch.  There are all types of characters here.
author: Emily S.

description: This is definitely a cool place to hang out whenever visiting San Francisco! With tons of cool shops, live shows, and plenty of places to eat, Pier 39 is the one-stop place for everyone! Be sure to spend some time watching the sea lions - there are plenty of them!
author: Joshua W.

description: This is a Tourist trap, everything is pricey here.  There is free entertainment here, when the weather is nice a great place to check out the animals and people.  Nice view of the water, and nice place to hang. Alot of thieves and bums that don't know how to make a real living.
author: John F.

description: Places here are pretty overpriced and more of a tourist spot then for the locals. It's nice to bring people from out of town but other than that I usually don't come here too often.
author: Steven C.

description: While I wouldn't go here on a regular basis, this is a MUST for out-of-towners, just because it's something to check off that "i've been to San Francisco" list. Tried going here to get some lunch one day at work and got so annoyed, so many people and so hard to get around. But once in awhile, it works.
author: Hanan H.

description: I like Pier39  . There's sea lions , an arcade ( which is not that great btw ) , a 3D theater thing like those at Universal Studios , stands that sell churros , a place that sells caramel apples , stores that only sell chocolate , cheesy magic shows that try to hustle you for your money ( jk ! haha . ) , people painted in silver , a bushman that scares people on the street , and street performers . I love Trish's mini donuts .. their mini donuts are so good - and fattening !! So addicting !! There's some restaurants here too but I've only been to a few of them . They're either a hit or miss . Most of them are overpriced and aren't good . Sometimes I hate how Pier39 is filled with stupid tacky tourist gift shops .
author: Eileen L.

description: You've got to be thankful to something that keeps all those god-awful tourists away from the rest of the city... now what do we do to keep the marina folk out of the mission????
author: Bone D.

description:
meh...I live in the city so it's only once in a while I ahave to do Pier 39.  as in last week.  
first visit in prolly 10 years, same same.  
but I do like that bar with like, 80 beers on tap.  
stinky sea lions bore me and I can get tourista shit anywhere.
author: david s.

description: We spent alot of our time on this pier. I didnt realize how big it was. Its got alot of great stores and alot of stores selling the same crap. You cant go wrong going here. dont forget to check out the sealions
author: Mike L.

description: Yes, I am a tourist and yes, I LOVE Pier 39.  It is so fun and there is so much to do...we got coffee and ice cream and listened to some street musicians and then spent about an hour watching the sea lions.  They were hilarious.....it was a fun family outing and we will remember it for a long time.  Sure, it is crowded but people watching is great......not as fun as sea lion watching but hey.....it makes the day go by....we loved it and I can't wait to go back.  I love those crazy sea lions!
author: Z Z.

description: So this is obviously a major tourist spot right I dont come here that often to be honest and all in all i like to only come here to stare at the sea lions lol. There really is not that much to do here but because it is a tourist spot there are a lot of people. Definitely venture elsewhere if you really want to enjoy San Francisco!!
author: Sheila C.

description: 3 Stars for the sea lions.  If only there were a way to magically teleport to where they were and by-pass the rest of Fisherman's Wharf (except perhaps for the Boudin bread window with the animals made of sourdough, which are awesome).
author: Tullia F.

description: Pier 39 is the highlight of Fisherman's Wharf for me. It is highly recommended to go there. They have a good selection of food & shopping there. Also, they have some unique shops there.
author: S. K.

description: I lived in San Francisco for several years but never really understood what the whole fuss about Pier 39 is all about. It's really just an overcroweded touristy place with a few seals lying in the sun. Granted, the seals are kind of cute, but that's about the only thing that's worth your time at Pier 39. If you want to experience a cool SF place, head to the Girardelly Square, which is only a few blocks away from Pier 39. It's cute, authentic, and will give you a great view of the Bay (and if you're lucky, you'll score a free square of Ghirardelli chocolate, too :)
author: Paula L.

description:
in the morning sun, or fog... & your carousel.

dreamy.
author: vincent m.

description: Thank you Pier 39 for keeping the douche bags corralled in one place away from my neighborhood.
author: Dru P.

description: My girlfriend brought me here when I came to visit her while she was living in Berkeley for an internship before we moved out here. It is really pretty here and the sea lions were nice to look at. The crepe place here was really yummy along with the chocolate store. The only downside I wasn't expecting was how cold it was going to be! It's a great place to bring friends or family when they come to visit you from out of state.
author: Kevin W.

description: I understand all the locals' reviews discrediting this attraction but doesn't Pier 39 do exactly what it was designed to do?  It wasn't built as a community hangout.  I worked there for a while and it was a great place to meet tons of people every day.  Tourists spend tons of money to see the most popular sights in the city and from Pier 39 they get their money's worth.  Yes the restaurants are overpriced but the food is generally good and the views are second to none.  The shows are a great place to take kids and let the parents rest for a while.  The arcade is a little cheesy but for little kids its a fun place to play after spending the day with mom and dad sightseeing in a not so kid friendly city.  Locals relax.  You don't have to go here.  You can always go to Time Square or South Beach and read about the locals there complaining about how crazy you are for visiting.
author: Kevin G.

description: Yup - 4 stars.  I actually like Pier 39.  I come out here maybe twice a year, max.  It's very touristy, parking sucks, food isn't that good and is pricey, but I still like it.  The Pumpkin Pandemonium event they sponsor is awesome!  They have a pumpkin patch and kids under 12 get to pick a free pumpkin.  They're pretty good-sized pumpkins too.  And most of the stores participate in trick-or-treating, so the kids get lots of stuff and it's safe.  Go early though because if you go toward the end, almost all the stores have no candy left.  I hate the parking garage though.  It's so slow.  I swear I spent 30 minutes in there just trying to get to the top to get a spot!  And it's $6 an hour.  We were there about 2.5 hours, so it cost us $18.  I DID go and get the Family Fun Pack from the CA Welcome Center, but it didn't have a 2 hour free parking coupon in it!  What a jip!
author: Kris L.

description: I recently walked by Pier 39 to see if I hated it as much as I remembered. The answer was yes.
author: Kathleen B.

description: I love this place, been coming here since I was 3. The smell of the fresh ocean, the big crowd, stores, in and out burger, hooters, candy, arcade.
author: Keit K.

description: One of the best things about San Francisco is Fishermans Wharf/Pier 39.  The many restaurants to dine in, things to do, and my ultimate guilty pleasure: the warm mini cinnamon sugar donuts!  I bring all my friends here when they come to visit California.
author: Jay L.

description: This is the place you go to park people that you don't like when they're visiting San Francisco.  I mean, really, what's so great about this place?  It's San Francisco's biggest tourist trap.  The food is nasty, the stores are a joke, and the performances you can find in any other major tourist trap around the world.  But I guess since you're stopping by Ghirardelli Square and Fisherman's Wharf, you might as well stop by, even if altogether it's a waste of a day.
author: Tony L.

description: Love the sealions.  Hate the tourists.  But then again, love the tourists pumping money into the city. Great for the San Fran first timer.  Come once, dont come again.  My favorite tip? Check out the F Line Muni...theyve imported all these foreign cable cars from around the world for you to ride around on and theyre so cute.  Plus theyre $1.50, not 5 bucks like the Cable Cars are now, and It will get you to the hotspots like Ghiradelli Square, Pier 39 and the Ferry Building!
author: Cathleya G.

description: I have to agree with David D. on this one.  I love an excuse to come to the Fisherman's Wharf!!  My favorite part about it is roaming through the chocolate store there and picking out stocking stuffers for everyone I know.  They have a treat in the shape of every hobby you can think of!  They have chocolate meat cleavers!  Anyway, the carousel is nice, the seals are awesome, the stroll is great exercise before you hit up Ghiridelli Square, and the sea breeze is very refreshing no matter what the weather is like.  I like to get an ice cream cone at Ben and Jerry's and window shop all the way down the dock, then take my time stopping in at places on the way back.  You can also take the ferry to Alcatraz from here!  Lots of tourists, but if you go expecting that, you can let loose and have a good time pretending that your a stranger in your own city.  Great day trip.
author: Amy M.

description: This will be a great place as long as the sea lions stay. Bring a sweater, because even in August, it got pretty cold come 8 o'clock.
author: Constancia W.

description: The Sea Lions are some of the best free entertainment this city has to offer
author: Kelly S.

description: I rarely come here because it's just one of those "tourist places" that doesn't interest locals much. I hate it when its windy and gloomy (as I would anywhere else). But it gives off a pretty good vibe when the weather is nice and the water on the wharf sways left and right slowly (with a good sparkle). I don't know if the magic carpet taping thing is still there, but I thought that it was totally cool. Theres a bunch of souvenir shops, which I won't be walking into and plenty restaurants (which I do plan on trying the majority of). Its definitely a go-see if you're a tourist, and can be a pretty nice hang out spot too for non-tourist. Afterall, theres plenty ice cream, treats and a couple of more subtle places off to the sides where you can just watch the ocean.
author: Elaine H.

description:
This place is great. It's the perfect place for tourists, or even locals that just don't have anything to do. 

I love the hustle and bustle of the area, and how for the most part, you can never run out of anything to do. 

The pier is full of cute little stores, and yummy food. The fisherman's Grotto is right next to it, and you can pick whatever you want to eat, for decent prices. 

Across the street from the pier, you have all those touristy type shops to get something for all the people back home that are jealous that you're there in the first place, LOL. 

All in all, I love it here.. Even sitting, and looking out into the water doesn't get old. =)

Just park next to the Grotto though. Parking's decent over there.. don't park in the Pier's garage.. It adds up after all the face stuffing you do in the area.
author: Heidi L.

description:
busy and expensive.

some good food and attractions.  
check the seals messing with each other.

definitely a tourist spot.
author: Roger A.

description: Hey, if you live here you HAVE to go here, I mean atleast once. I have been here for fleet week, 4th of July etc..it's a good time.
author: John S.

description: Cool place!  I was being a tourist last weekend when I was in S.F. with some friends.  We walked around a bit at Pier 39 after we had lunch at Butterfly down the street.  It was a nice day and we decided to take a stroll down here. We walked to the end of the pier and took some pictures with alcatraz in the background. There are a lot of shops and several places to eat at. We didn't stay long but it's a place that I recommend if it's your first time to S.F.  One of the tourist things to do while your there.
author: James Y.

description: i heard a lot about this place but it  dident quite meet my standers i went to the shell store and got some shells boring hahah thats perrty much all there is to do hear food wasent so great eather had more fun at the beach the was like 10 min away it would be better if they had a spa to kill time get a massage while there hahaha but o well
author: Pauly F.

description: You gotta love the Pier. The water, the view of Alcatrez, sea lions, tons of shops, places to eat. They even have an aquarium and arcade. You can spend all day here. Im in love with the Wyland art gallery...if I could afford it , I would have several of his masterpieces. Also, a good idea when visiting the pier is to munch on food from all the local vendors, the restuarants, arent all that great. But , they do have great clam chowder. Also, one of my favorite things to do, when it isnt so cold out, is to go on the bay cruise.
author: Lori T.

description: Dirty pigeons on a mission to snatch hot dogs out of unsuspecting children's hands.  Overpriced mementos that will most likely fall apart in a couple of weeks.  Greasy carnival food.  Tourists that believe that this must be the best San Francisco has to offer.  Why else would they spend hours of their precious vacation time wandering around here?  Locals love to hate Pier 39, and I am no exception.  Although, I admit that there is one thing that makes it worthwhile to stop by the pier...the sea lions.  Their daily pier activities pretty much consist of sleeping and fighting amongst themselves, but hey, it's a glimpse of wildlife without the zoo fee.
author: Kelli C.

description: I really like this place. But it was so hard to get there by bus, especially when you have to pass through the China town to get there, and China town bus are like crazy, so crowded. So get a car to get there, not by china town buses lol. Anyways, I loved Pier 39. So many things to do!! There's seal shows, there's these nice restaurants. I love their clam chowder!! I love their souvenir shops and their cute chocolate store, I bought like a lot of them there. I remember I bought lots of key chains cause it was so pretty, and I bought a mood ring at this one souvenir store. It's a pretty mood ring I tell you that, I still have it, it's been almost 10 months that I had this mood ring with me! It has the designs of the most popular places in San Francisco. I wonder if they still have it there, because my sister regret for not buying one for herself lol!
author: Susan R.

description: we and my parents had a great time visiting pier 39, there's a lot to see and to eat inexpensive palatable foods.  Sorry.....lt's fun and fun...
author: Henry P.

description:
it was my first time touring SF so where do i go? duh, the biggest tourist trap EVER! 

got to see the very uneventful sea lions. they stink.
walked around window shopping because everything was expensive.
ate some overpriced seafood.
totally ignored the street performances. very silly.
took a picture of my bf holding alcatraz in his hand.
bought a bob marley poster at the hollywood store. (which was very stupid because i live, like, 10 mins from hollywood anyway! but it was a cool poster)
watched the crepe-makers 

i really wanted a crepe but the line was hella long and all i could say was "haha, that mexican guy is makin crepes like its a quesa-dilla."

i left after that.
author: Tasha H.

description: Yes, it's super touristy, but you've got In N' Out, the Bushman, and the sea lions.  One can watch the sea lions for a long long time on a beautiful day like today.  People watching can be fun too.  The comedian guy on the Crystal Springs stage?  Less good.
author: Leo C.

description: Fun shops, good food, amazing scenery. It's fun to listen to the seals barking and watch them sun-bathing. Parking can be hard to find (and very pricey!).
author: Nancy L.

description: Pier 39 is a must if you are visiting SF.  I took my family here to see the sea lions, the aquarium of the bay, and to wander around some of the shops.  If you stay in Fisherman's Wharf, it's a quick walk!  Also, this is where you can buy tickets for those City Sightseeing tours.  I recommend the motorized cable car tour :0)
author: Diana N.

description: I actually used to work on Pier 39 when i was in college. The only thing great about pier 39 is the sea lions, the view of alcatraz, and the carousell out in the back. Also the tulip festival in the spring. Most stores and restaurants here are over-priced. They claim they are the second biggest tourist attraction next to Disney - i seriously doubt you can count foot traffic or any traffic passing by pier 39 as someone visiting the pier.  Can get busy as cruise ships anchor in the nearby pier.
author: Edwyn A.

description: Well I hate this place. What local doesn't. BUT people who have never been to the city and want the full tourist experience - these people love it. So this is where the tour should start - its to me the worst attraction so just get it over with. At least its near the water which makes for a nice walk. There are tons of cheesy shops here, and street performers - the guy I saw ate fire, which was pretty disgusting.
author: Stacy H.

description: Ah the smell of sea lion fart...nothing like it to get the apetite piqued for an overpriced dinner of defrosted "seafood" served by dirty nailed, european youth hostel escapees at generic restaur-tainment center. Why does my family insist on "visiting" me in San Francisco here?! Thank god for the tiny donut store. Binge the pain away Binge the pain away
author: Krismet C.

description: Yea, it's touristy, but I'm a tourist!  I liked all the cheesy SF-trinket shops and the smell of the waffle cones as you walk around.  Complete surprise to me to see Alcatraz, the Golden Gate and the sea lions at the end of the pier.  But that's my bad for coming into SF totally blind of where everything was.  Take this place for all it's worth...a trip into touristville for a little bit to see some cool SF sights.
author: Bryanne R.

description: Sure, it's not for locals, but the tourists enjoy it and if it's good for San Francisco businesses, then it's good for me. If you aren't too cool, then it's at least worth the trip to see the seals and sea lions.
author: Philip M.

description:
i always spot really good looking foreign guys around here, so i am giving it 3 stars.  

p.s. they have a place around here that rents Segways, so you can ride around on one and pretend that you're GOB from arrested development.  but, it's like $75 an hour.
author: Claudia B.

description:
if someone's visiting san francisco, they're always going to visit this area of the city.  
it's decent but just too packed with people everywhere.  and after having been there numerous times with all these visitors i've had, it's not very exciting seeing the same shops with the same silly t-shirts or the same street performers etc.
there are a few decent eats around.  you can get a pretty good sourdough bowl of clam chowder.  some seafood sandwiches, but those are all foods you could also get elsewhere in the city...
oh and you better not need to go to the bathroom, because there aren't any around...
author: charlotte s.

description: good place walk around, eat, shop and watch sea lions!
author: Mike C.

description: This is the best place in town to get San Francisco branded apparel, magnets, greeting cards and little statuettes of angels holding flowers...
author: Quartknee K.

description: I take my family and visiting friends here frequently.  Good for eats, scenery, and souvenirs.
author: B H.

description: I come here every time someone visits from out of town because it is one of San Francisco's most famous places. But I've noticed something about it. Maybe it's just cause I've been so many times, but it seems like no one really cares about most of the shops on it, other than some of the restaurants. There's a sock shop, a hat shop, a jeweler shop, a magic shop... kind of a weird mix. Even the candy shops don't seem to get much attention. Last time I was here with someone who'd never been to sf, we walked on the outside of the pier, watched the sea lions and pretty much left... that was it. It's a bit hyped up, and really crowded. Ok, but after all that, it is a cool area and better than some other touristy areas (china town...). It's a huge pier with great views of the bay. Some of the restaurants are pretty good, like Bubba Gumps and a few other seafood places. The sea lions are also really fun to watch. I would say everyone should come check it out once.
author: Jessica C.

description: Standard tourist site to see. Lots of fun shops and eateries. Beautiful view of San Fransisco, both of the sunset and the city lights. Be sure to check out the sea lions on the left side of the pier before leaving. If you venture all the way to the back, you will get an awesome view of Alcatraz, and the Golden Gate bridge on a clear day.
author: Rachel S.

description: This place used to be really fun back in the day. I guess it hasn't changed much over the years. It's still packed with tourists and locals alike. The shops are pretty touristy and the food is so-so. But it's definitely one of those places you kind of have to go to in SF if you are a tourist or a local wanting to rediscover your city. Be sure to say hi to the sea lions if they're in town : ). If you go, be sure to walk all the way to the end so you can get that great view of Alcatraz and the Bay. This is also in the immediate vicinity of the tours that leave for Alcatraz and the other Bay tours. There is a parking lot across the street. You may be able to find street parking nearby, but I would not recommend it. If you're feeling adventurous and are willing to make the trek, you can walk up toward the Ferry Building and the Embarcadero area for more sights and shops.
author: Al B.

description: Have out of town visitors?  Bring them here.  They eat it up.  Go poke your head in the little overpriced stores, watch the sea lions, take in the outdoor entertainment, but you have to get the mini donuts when you are there.  The ones that come in a little paper sack covered in cinnamon sugar.  I am salivating at the thought of those little sugar dumplings.
author: jen n.

description:
I don't know why I'm drawn to this place any time I head to SF or why it's the kind  of place we all take our out-of-town guests, but we do it time and again, so there must be something to it. It's just a pier with a bunch of touristy shops and restaurants, but for those coming for the first time, hopefully this will provide a glimpse of what to expect:

-Walk along the Embarcadero to get to the pier and you'll get caught up in at least one or two street performer acts. No where else will you see free "talent" like this on display. You can also see acts on the stage at the end of the pier.
-Enjoy the Aquarium of the Bay. It's small, but unique in that it lets you walk through a glass tube with the fish all around you, so you get to see sharks and stingrays literally swim over your head.
-Buy a fruit and grande marniere crepe with whipped cream at the Crepe Cafe (midway on your left) and take it to the right side of the pier. Sit on a bench and enjoy the view of the yachts and your dreams of owning one some day...
-Walk to the far left of the pier and enjoy the sea lions. It's nice to watch animals in nature rather than in a tiny exhibit at a zoo.
-Try some Ghiradelli chocolate.
-Dine. Focus on your friends and the views and ignore the fact that the food may not be so great.
-Treat your child to a ride on the carousel near the rear of the pier ($3 a ride--I wish I owned this baby!)

What the heck. It's on the water. That's why we come back!
author: Erin O.

description: I have been living here almost a decade, and I STILL go here once in a while. It's a fun little walk. Plus, my son loves the merry-go-round. Lots of fun shops, some crappy restaurants, and a bunch of tourists.....eye candy for the voyeur in all of us! Plus, my favorite part is that....(well, last time we did this, you could still do it, but it's been a couple of years)...you can buy beer in plastic cups at the seafood restaurant that has the to-go counter...hint hint.....and walk around the pier all day. hint hint... Spend the day drinking beer, watching tourists....(oh, my son doesn't go on these outings....obviously) It's a blast. And the Hard Rock usually has some music out in front of the restaurant....
author: Mike B.

description: I can people watch somewhere else.  I'm not on vacation to see the homeless.  I don't care for street performers and there are better places to watch the sunset.  I don't go here anymore because it's a tourist trap.  The shopping is also better elsewhere in the city.
author: Ai M.

description: Growing up in SF, I loved making visits to Pier 39. The sounds of the sea lions barking (I think, is the best way to describe their call) and the horn of the ferries.. It's a tourist trap, I guess it's kind of hard pushing past people in fresh Alcatraz shirts and whatnot.. but that's fine. A stop by Trish's Mini Donuts is a must.
author: Vickie B.

description: One of those places you take your out of town relatives or friends to let them see it.  Otherwise it's boring and bland with generic chain stores and restaurants.  I will say though it's worth going to check out the Sea Lions on the dock and on a nice day you do have some good views from some parts of the Pier.  The best part of the experience for me is getting here.  I hop on the F Line which runs refurbished street cars from various eras from all over the country and runs along the Embarcadero, down Market to Castro.  That to me is the best part of Pier 39.
author: Rob M.

description: For what it is, Pier 39 can be fun.  It's this 'Fresh Choice' little-of-everything-that-San-Francisco-has-to-offer-with-high-cheese-factor sort of evil buffet.  The kids love it in a pure way 'cuz they're not payin'.  Definitely very expensive here, and definitely tourist-laden.  Probably the best thing, which happens also to be free, is watching those smart little sea lions play with each other off the dock.  Hours of entertainment.  If you want to spend your day there without emptying your pocketbook, pack a lunch and sit in the bleachers overlooking these fascinating creatures.
author: Wayne Q.

description: So gorgeous and clean. However, I'd skip grabbing lunch or dinner here when you can go down away from the piers and get food for cheaper. The sea lions are always laying out basking in the sun, which is worth it to see. The aquarium is yucky and Alcatraz is iiight.
author: Joann P.

description: I always forget this place is here.  I never go except when I want to take visitors around or want to check out the aquarium.  It's fine, but don't waste too much time in this area when SF has so much to offer.
author: Surf R.

description: Very touristy, but everyone should see it once I think. I went on my first trip to San Francisco just recently and decided to make a stop down at the pier. It's fun to walk around and check out all the street performers...although the silver robot men freaked me out. The seals are cool to look at and there are quite a few good little shops. We also had some clam chowder bread bowls at some restaurant near the end of the pier.
author: Ericka S.

description:
oh how i LOVE the pier! sure the sea lions or whatever they are can be annoying, and sure, it does smell, and sure there can be a lot of people, but there were, are and will be fun times spent here..

there is so many to do.  I cam here for the first time 12 years ago for my last happy family vacation (oh well, things change).  we stayed at the local Howard Johnson.  i dunno what i twas about that day, but we it was fun.  We did the carriage thing, took picture, and the day in general was nice - sunny with a breeze.   Also so many places were giving out samples.  We had at least 3 different types of clam chowder (ill never see Claim Jumper the same), and the BEST garlic bread/bruschetta i have ever had.  this was like at first taste for garlic as i never was into it before.  it was from this little place that sells whole heads of roasted garlic (forgot the name).

came here two years later for a high school competition of sorts and no more samples 8o( ....but i did do some damage on a local movie poster store which, i shouldve thought about more, but have no regrets as i still have those poster  9 years later...

then came here 4 years ago and experienced one of the BEST 4th O July's ever.  It was like a 30 minute fireworks bonanza...sitting down, facing the water, watching fireworks with a Ghiradelli sundae in our hands...AMAZING!

anyways, there are other things to do there too - give money to bums, buy some handmade jewelry, get your name written in that weird Asian way (you know, where the A can looks like a flamingo, the O into a waterfall). oh and always, the historic Alcatraz prison...
author: Jen N.

description: Yes...its considered a tourist trap...but I don't care. In the few years that I've lived here, I've been here at least a dozen times. I love every minute of it....
author: Hilary G.

description: if you have family from out of town/country and plan on coming here, go during the week.  the weekends will be chaos.  there are plenty of deals around so take your time and enjoy the SF bay
author: Dennis d.

description: Really touristy is expected... and Pier 39 is a means to round them up and keep them in one location... its a great place to eat (of course) until some music shows up... and scare people. I don't mean in that startled kinda way either.... the bush-man's got that on lock!
author: Eugene G.

description: A very popular tourist attraction, that has a lot of potential for one and all.  It's a great place just to people watch, shop, or just cruise around to take in all the sights.  I love it here.  And on really NICE and SUNNY days, you can see all the way to Alcatraz.  If you're ever in the area, Pier 39 is A MUST DO tourist attraction.  In fact, I'm gonna have to try to go again, very soon.
author: Cheryl N.

description: I used to drive up here alone just to enjoy the air, and I live in Los Angeles, CA! Seriously, this place is really cool, and I wish LA had more places or at least ONE place just as nice as this place. So many stores, so much to see. I have to go back!
author: Matthew S.

description: Love going to San Fran to visit Pier 39! Great place to walk around and it has a great view of the Golden Gate Bridge and Alcatraz.  Really nice restaurants and places to shop.  Parking is a bit hectic but what place in San Fran isn't.
author: D P.

description: lots of nice shops and fine dining/attractions breezy relaxing very nice scenery
author: Kevin L.

description: This place is overcrowded. Took my daughter to the carousel and was treated so poorly. The two Asian young men were more interested in speaking with each other and working their cell phones than answering customer questions.  Nothing like being treated like crap for a $9 2 min ride.  NOT WORTH IT.
author: Reardon M.

description: 2 words...tourist trap. Nothing but t-shirt shops everywhere that sell the same ole I heart San Francisco T-shirts and trinkets. 1 star because it's a nice place to take a person who isn't from here on a date (I guess) another star for all the street performers who breathe life into what would otherwise be your average generic tourist trap/spot. And I guess another star should be rewarded for all the good views you can get here...especially during fourth of July which is probably the only time I'll ever come down here. Coulda given it another star but all the sea lions are gone....whatever they smelled like shit anyways.
author: Mike A.

description:
I still like Pier 39. It's  a fun atmosphere with a little bit of something for everyone. Shopping, farmer's market, arcade, sweat shops, restaurants, free shows, street performers, seal watching, etc.

Very touristy, but I still go there when I get a chance or am entertaining out of town guests.
author: Michael S.

description: good place to chill for day and it's very good place they have alot of sea food if you want to eat i persnoly like it
author: Jason S.

description:
Some locals really hate on Pier 39.  The complaint sounds something like "Nobody goes there anymore. It's too crowded".

This place is pure San Francisco tourism from concentrate and that's why it works as a localized MiniMe version of DisneyLand Main St. USA.  It's especially useful when you need to entertain/ dump your out of town visitors for a while.  Sea Lions? check.  Iconic views and photo ops? check.  Fisherman's Wharf? check.  Bay Cruise? check.  Alcatraz? check.   It's also just walking distance to other things on the standard tourist bucket list, such as cable cars, the rest of the Wharf, the Ferry Building, etc.

If you like crowds and people watching, go between May-September.  If you don't, go between October-April.
author: vox m.

description: Pier 39 never fails you and those sea lions are very cool. We came up here late at night so the sea lions were asleep , or out somewhere else because I don't remember only 2 floating panel full of sea lions. There are usually 5-6 panel full, I thought ? Bubba Gump food is still the bomb, but parking structure is pretty dirty and smells like urine!
author: T Is For Tom N.

description: Pier 39 is a must for any first-time visitor to San Francisco but once is really enough. Check out the shops and candy stores and Bubba Gumps restaurant at the end of the pier. Hard Rock Cafe moved here a couple years ago and it's hard to imagine it anywhere else now.
author: Darrin A.

description:
First I will give you reasons why I am going to give more than one star. It's not something I would say people should stay away from It has a nice view of the bay, there are sea lions that are there for most of the year, The restaurants work for me, but if your looking for cheap you won't find them here. 

The unfortunate thing about Pier 39 is that there are good reason why locals don't like it. It gets very crowded, The gifts here are overprice and tacky, parking is outrageous, and even if you go far enough, it is still expensive. The tourist that it attracts often get amused by the cheesiest things, which is alright to me because they are looking for things that they don't find at home, but still, it affects its quality quite a  bit since it seems that it's for people who don't aspire to have a lot of imagination come here.
author: Tedster H.

description:
I was going to give it two stars but if you're a tourist, you just might like cruising the area just once.

We actually went twice during our August trip.  The first time it was around 7 a.m. so there were NO crowds and it was great!  We watched the cute sea lions basking in the sun, playing and barking out to each other.  Totally worth it to see them!  

The second time we went to eat there because we got a discount for North Beach Pizza, which was pretty good.  Pier 39 was JAMMED with people at that time!
