So if you like sea lions (they ARE very cute) it might be worth a go-see but beware that it's packed with people vying for space to watch them.  By the way, there are cameras right near the roof top of the building near the sea lions that your friends can watch if you coordinate times or if you just want to see them yourself one boring afternoon!  Google Pier 39 sea lions and it should show up.
author: Sunny D.

description: Typical tourist trap, complete with tons of stores and places to grab high-fat, no-good-for-you sweets. Also a launching point for many boat tours.
author: David W.

description: good place for chowder but it is always so crowded and parking is a pain... I usually try to avoid this place unless im entertaining out of towners.
author: Shawn A.

description: I know that locals tend to always shoot down any high traffic areas of interest as touristy and bunk (i'm quick to do the same) and of course Pier 39 is touristy and bunk ,but it's great fun!  I had a friend in town and it was her last day so we decided to come here as opposed to GG park and it was perfect!  We had a delicious lunch at Fog Harbor Fish House, great food, great server, great view and NOT overpriced at all, seafood is expensive!  We watched the sea lions for a little while and fell in love (how is it in a year and half not one person mentioned these little angels to me?!  Neglectful friends!)  We did a boat ride with I want to say, Captain John??  All I remember is that we were told he was the "opposite Captain Eric", whatever that means.  The boat was called the Lola, which was a good sign since that's one of my favorite Kinks songs.   The captain could have been a little more informative about the area but he was nice and friendly and told us *before* we fell out of the boat to not fall out of the boat!  We finished up with an ice cream cone from Dreyers and walked down to the Ferry Building, this was probably the most (un-boozed fueled) fun I've had in SF so far so that's saying a lot.  Definitely "Yay, I'm a fan!".
author: sasha y.

description: This place REALLY makes me miss San Francisco! I really never wanted to leave, and I can't wait to come back! I've been there both times I've visited San Fran, and aside from the crowds, it's an amazing place! The sea lions are so cute, the views off the pier are spectacular (you can see Alcatraz and the Golden Gate!), and the restaurants and shops are really cool! But back to the crowds...it's utter chaos. People are right and left, and you can barely see the pier you're walking on! If you're a crowd person, I guess you're fine with that. But other than that, it's a great place! There are all sorts of interesting things to do, but I warn you, it does get touristy! It is known as the #1 tourist destination in San Francisco. Personally I think more people should focus less on this and appreciate the natural, historic side of San Fran, such as the hills, Lombard Street, the Golden Gate Bridge, Pacific Heights, etc. Pier 39 feels a bit more set up and artificial, sort of like Williamsburg, Virginia. But at the end of the day, it's an awesome shopping paradise!
author: S. F.

description: Sure, Pier 39 is not a place I would want to visit everyday, but when you're only in the city once or twice per year, it's nice to check out.  The shops have some fun stuff to look at and there are, of course, the sea lions.  One question- what is the deal with that "band" always setup at the entrance to Pier 39?  The two people in it kind of sketch me out.  Anyway, I would definitely recommend this place to to someone visiting SF for the first time.
author: Rick G.

description: this place is totlly fun! u can stay there the whole entire day with a smile on ur face ^_^
author: sARaH s.

description: If you ever feel like coming to SF you have got to go to the Fishermans Wharf and walk along the Pier.  The food at Pier 41 is ok.. the clam chowder is 5.50 while at Pier 39 it is 6.50.. but the clam chowder is nothing to write home about.. I think the can version from Progresso is better, how sad is that? The fried Calamari is decently good.. we had both at a place right next to the Crab House..I think it's called Saulito Brothers..The wharf is a tourist trap with water running at 4.00 bucks a bottle- and restaurants Galore! It's definitely fun to walk around and site see.. but if you are into quality eats- this is not a stop. Everything like Hanson Q. said is expensive.  Funny there is a Gap right across the street from Pier 39, and a HUGE Boudin Sour Dough Restaurant, both products of SF.  It was a beautiful day when I went today, and even though it was Friday, there were plenty of folks all tourist from all over the world, what a wonderful sight!
author: Tulie L.

description: Touristy as touristy gets, but still worth it. Lots to do and see, even if you don't spend a dime. If you need some cheap souvenirs to bring home, this (and the surrounding area) is the place for t-shirts, key chains, etc. The sea-lions are a must-see, and the views are incredible.
author: Stormy J.

description: This place is so much fun to go to when you're with a group of friends and the perfect place to go on a date..there's an arcade, a carousel, neat shops, and sea lions!!  Everyone on the PIER is nice and the food is amazing!!  Yes it's touristy and crowded at times, but that should be a good thing for San Francisco.  It's not too expensive either, because you can get these local advantage coupons, I guess just call the PIER and ask where you can get them since I got mine from a friend.  Go here!!!
author: Trisha H.

description: We went to the wax museum today and decided to take my preschoolers to see the sealions.  They thought the sealions were cool and wanted to wander around the area a bit.  There's a  sign stating 2 rides for $5 on the carousel.  I inquired with the three employees  manning the carousel if I could pay $5 for both of the kids to take one ride each.  They told me sure however, because they were too young to ride on their own....we would have to pay for one more ride for the adult.  WHATTT......I don't understand the logic here.  I was told that one parent can ride free and the other one has to pay since there is two of them.  They acknowledged that both of them were too young to ride on their own and that they would need someone standing by their side holding them on the horse. I took the kids to buy a treat instead of riding the carousel.  It's not about the extra $2.50 but the principal that a parent should not have to pay to assist their child on the ride.  I've taken the kids on plenty of carousel rides elsewhere and no one has EVER asked for us to pay an extra fee.
author: c v.

description: yeah i know it's a tourist trap, but i'm not a city native, so eff you!
author: Pickle R.

description: shopping, gifts, pearls, dinner! its an experience you have to do when you're in SF!
author: GABBS P.
